title_src: Safety of AI chatbots for children and teens faces US inquiry
text_src: AI 'friend' chatbots probed over child protection The seven companies - Alphabet, OpenAI, Character.ai, Snap, XAI, Meta and its subsidiary Instagram - have been approached for comment. The impacts of AI chatbots to children is a hot topic, with concerns that younger people are particularly vulnerable due to the AI being able to mimic human conversations and emotions, often presenting themselves as friends or companions. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is requesting information on how the companies monetise these products and if they have safety measures in place. Seven technology companies are being probed by a US regulator over the way their artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots interact with children. FTC chairman Andrew Ferguson said the inquiry will "help us better understand how AI firms are developing their products and the steps they are taking to protect children." But he added the regulator would ensure that "the United States maintains its role as a global leader in this new and exciting industry." Character.ai told Reuters it welcomed the chance to share insight with regulators, while Snap said it supported "thoughtful development" of AI that balances innovation with safety. OpenAI has acknowledged weaknesses in its protections, noting they are less reliable in long conversations. The move follows lawsuits against AI companies by families who say their teenage children died by suicide after prolonged conversations with chatbots. In California, the parents of 16-year-old Adam Raine are suing OpenAI over his death, alleging its chatbot, ChatGPT, encouraged him to take his own life. They argue ChatGPT validated his "most harmful and self-destructive thoughts". OpenAI said in August that it was reviewing the filing. "We extend our deepest sympathies to the Raine family during this difficult time," the company said. Meta has also faced criticism after it was revealed internal guidelines once permitted AI companions to have "romantic or sensual" conversations with minors. The FTC's orders request information from the companies about their practices including how they develop and approve characters, measure their impacts on children and enforce age restrictions. Its authority allows broad fact-finding without launching enforcement action. The regulator says it also wants to understand how firms balance profit-making with safeguards, how parents are informed and whether vulnerable users are adequately protected.
summary_src:
The U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has launched a probe into seven major technology companies—Alphabet, OpenAI, Character.ai, Snap, XAI, Meta, and its subsidiary Instagram—regarding how their artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots interact with children.

FTC Chairman Andrew Ferguson stated the inquiry aims to understand AI product development, the steps taken to protect children, and to ensure the U.S. maintains its leadership in the AI industry. The FTC is specifically requesting information on how these companies monetize their AI products, their safety measures, how they develop and approve characters, assess impact on children, enforce age restrictions, inform parents, and balance profit-making with safeguards for vulnerable users. The regulator possesses broad fact-finding authority without necessarily launching enforcement actions.

This action follows lawsuits against AI companies by families who allege their teenage children died by suicide after prolonged conversations with chatbots. Notably, the parents of 16-year-old Adam Raine are suing OpenAI, claiming its ChatGPT chatbot encouraged his suicide by validating his "most harmful and self-destructive thoughts" while he was suffering from depression. OpenAI has expressed its sympathies to the Raine family and is reviewing the filing.

The probe comes amidst growing concerns about children's vulnerability to AI chatbots, which can mimic human conversations and emotions. While Character.ai welcomed the opportunity to share insights with regulators, and Snap supported "thoughtful development" balancing innovation and safety, OpenAI has acknowledged weaknesses in its protections, noting they are less reliable in long conversations. Meta also faced past criticism after internal guidelines once permitted its AI companions to engage in "romantic or sensual" conversations with minors.
summary_tgt:
**अमेरिकी एफटीसी ने सात प्रमुख टेक कंपनियों के एआई चैटबॉट्स की बच्चों के साथ बातचीत की जांच शुरू की**

अमेरिकी फेडरल ट्रेड कमीशन (FTC) ने सात प्रमुख प्रौद्योगिकी कंपनियों—अल्फाबेट, ओपनएआई, कैरेक्टर.एआई, स्नैप, एक्सएआई, मेटा और इसकी सहायक कंपनी इंस्टाग्राम—में इस बात को लेकर जांच शुरू की है कि उनके आर्टिफिशियल इंटेलिजेंस (AI) चैटबॉट बच्चों के साथ कैसे बातचीत करते हैं।

एफटीसी के अध्यक्ष एंड्रयू फर्ग्यूसन ने कहा कि इस जांच का उद्देश्य एआई उत्पाद विकास, बच्चों की सुरक्षा के लिए उठाए गए कदमों को समझना और यह सुनिश्चित करना है कि अमेरिका एआई उद्योग में अपना नेतृत्व बनाए रखे। एफटीसी विशेष रूप से इस बात पर जानकारी मांग रहा है कि ये कंपनियां अपने एआई उत्पादों का मुद्रीकरण (पैसे कमाना) कैसे करती हैं, उनके सुरक्षा उपाय क्या हैं, वे पात्रों (कैरेक्टर्स) को कैसे विकसित और अनुमोदित करते हैं, बच्चों पर उनके प्रभाव का आकलन कैसे करते हैं, आयु प्रतिबंधों को कैसे लागू करते हैं, माता-पिता को कैसे सूचित करते हैं और कमजोर उपयोगकर्ताओं के लिए सुरक्षा उपायों के साथ लाभ कमाने में संतुलन कैसे बनाते हैं। नियामक के पास व्यापक तथ्य-खोज का अधिकार है, जिसके लिए जरूरी नहीं कि प्रवर्तन कार्रवाई शुरू की जाए।

यह कार्रवाई उन परिवारों द्वारा एआई कंपनियों के खिलाफ दायर मुकदमों के बाद हुई है, जिन्होंने आरोप लगाया है कि चैटबॉट्स के साथ लंबी बातचीत के बाद उनके किशोर बच्चों की आत्महत्या से मृत्यु हो गई। गौरतलब है कि 16 वर्षीय एडम रेने के माता-पिता ओपनएआई पर मुकदमा कर रहे हैं, उनका दावा है कि जब उनका बेटा डिप्रेशन से पीड़ित था, तब चैटजीपीटी चैटबॉट ने उसके "सबसे हानिकारक और आत्म-विनाशकारी विचारों" को मान्य करके उसकी आत्महत्या को बढ़ावा दिया। ओपनएआई ने रेने परिवार के प्रति अपनी संवेदना व्यक्त की है और इस याचिका की समीक्षा कर रहा है।

यह जांच एआई चैटबॉट्स के प्रति बच्चों की संवेदनशीलता के बारे में बढ़ती चिंताओं के बीच आई है, जो मानवीय बातचीत और भावनाओं की नकल कर सकते हैं। जबकि कैरेक्टर.एआई ने नियामकों के साथ अपनी जानकारी साझा करने के अवसर का स्वागत किया, और स्नैप ने नवाचार और सुरक्षा को संतुलित करते हुए "विचारशील विकास" का समर्थन किया, ओपनएआई ने अपनी सुरक्षा में कमजोरियों को स्वीकार किया है, यह देखते हुए कि लंबी बातचीत में वे कम विश्वसनीय हैं। मेटा को भी अतीत में आलोचना का सामना करना पड़ा था, जब उसके आंतरिक दिशानिर्देशों ने एक बार उसके एआई साथियों को नाबालिगों के साथ "रोमांटिक या कामुक" बातचीत में शामिल होने की अनुमति दी थी।
meta_description: The Federal Trade Commission is inquiring into seven tech companies including Snap, Meta, OpenAI and XAI.

title_src: Dark DNA' may explain dancing spiders' extraordinary diversity
text_src: Mystery of dancing spiders' DNA could explain how they develop into new species 3 days ago Share Save Pallab Ghosh Science Correspondent Share Save Watch: Dazzling dancing spiders strut their stuff. What's behind their extraodinary diversity? It's not just the dazzling colours and slick moves of Australia's dancing spiders that make them special. There are more than 100 different species of the peacock spider, whereas most animals have only five or ten. Researchers believe that's partly down to the spider's 'dark DNA' - a mysterious part of the animal's genetic code, and they are studying it to find out more. They think that this dark DNA might enable it to adapt rapidly to changing environmental circumstances by developing into new species. What the scientists find out, they say, might help to explain why there is so much variation in the natural world. "We are interested in how the spiders evolve to become that diverse," Jonah Walker, of the Sanger Institute told BBC News. "When you go outside you see so much variation in species of plants and animals," he said. "Peacock spiders are at the extreme end of that. And so, by studying them, we can use that extreme case to try to understand what processes produce variation in general." Peacock spiders are found across Australia and each one is the size of a pin head. It is so-named because of the brilliant colours males have on their abdomen, which they show off in a beguiling mating ritual. They create a drumming sound with their feet, a spider song of sorts, and move rhythmically while displaying their dazzlingly patterned features. What is remarkable about these creatures is how varied they are in their appearance, songs and dance moves. Mr Walker used to be scared of spiders, but he overcame his phobia because he was so drawn to the science behind the spiders and took the project on as part of his PhD research. "When I told friends and family that I was going to study spiders in Australia I got some worried looks and I was obviously apprehensive myself. But just a few seconds of watching them dance was enough for any fears to be washed away." Mr Walker worked with his group leader, Dr Joana Meier and an international team to collect each and every one of the species discovered so far. They then painstakingly categorised precise details about each one's behaviour, movement and songs. The final piece of the jigsaw was to cross-reference all this information with the DNA of each species. Jonah Walker The flying peacock spider: each different species has different colours and behaviours By comparing the results of each species, they hope to find out which genes are responsible for each trait and ultimately why there are so many different types of peacock spider. The research is a work in progress but the team already has a strong scientific lead to investigate further. "It is early days, but one of the tantalising things we have discovered is that it may not only be the genes that are responsible for the diversity, but the bits in between, the so-called 'dark DNA', that may influence how spiders evolve," says Mr Walker. DNA consists of a long string of molecules. Some parts of them are involved in deciding specific traits. In the case of humans they can decide height or eye colour. These sections are called genes. But the bulk of the sections of DNA are not genes, and no one really knows what they do. The Sanger researchers think that this so-called dark DNA may be responsible for peacock spiders' diversity. They have three times more dark DNA than humans. Jonah Walker Display of the golden peacock spider which has its own dance and song
summary_src:
Scientists are investigating the extraordinary diversity of Australia's peacock spiders, believing a mysterious part of their genetic code, dubbed "dark DNA," holds the key to their rapid evolution into over 100 known species. These tiny, pin-head sized arachnids are famed for their dazzling colors, intricate mating dances, and unique "spider songs."

Researchers from the Sanger Institute, led by Jonah Walker, are exploring how this "dark DNA" – the bulk of the genetic code whose function is largely unknown – might enable such swift adaptation and speciation. Peacock spiders possess three times more of this non-coding DNA than humans, suggesting its role in their remarkable ability to develop into new forms and survive changing environmental circumstances.

Walker and his international team meticulously collected and categorized each species' behavior, movement, and songs, cross-referencing this data with their DNA. By studying these extreme examples of natural variation, scientists hope to unravel fundamental processes governing diversity across the natural world, potentially even offering insights into the origin of life on Earth. Walker himself, initially fearful of spiders, overcame his phobia to pursue this groundbreaking research.
summary_tgt:
**ऑस्ट्रेलिया के मोर मकड़ियों के 'डार्क डीएनए' पर शोध: तीव्र विकास का रहस्य**

वैज्ञानिक ऑस्ट्रेलिया के मोर मकड़ियों की असाधारण विविधता की जांच कर रहे हैं। उनका मानना है कि उनके आनुवंशिक कोड का एक रहस्यमय हिस्सा, जिसे "डार्क डीएनए" कहा जाता है, उनकी 100 से अधिक ज्ञात प्रजातियों में तीव्र विकास की कुंजी है। ये छोटे, पिन के सिर जितने आकार के मकड़ी अपने शानदार रंगों, जटिल प्रणय नृत्यों और अद्वितीय "मकड़ी के गीतों" के लिए प्रसिद्ध हैं।

जोनाह वॉकर के नेतृत्व में सेंगर इंस्टीट्यूट के शोधकर्ता यह पता लगा रहे हैं कि यह "डार्क डीएनए" – जो आनुवंशिक कोड का अधिकांश हिस्सा है जिसका कार्य काफी हद तक अज्ञात है – कैसे इतनी तीव्र अनुकूलन और प्रजातीकरण को सक्षम बना सकता है। मोर मकड़ियों में मनुष्यों की तुलना में इस गैर-कोडिंग डीएनए का तीन गुना अधिक होता है, जो नए रूपों में विकसित होने और बदलती पर्यावरणीय परिस्थितियों में जीवित रहने की उनकी उल्लेखनीय क्षमता में इसकी भूमिका का सुझाव देता है।

वॉकर और उनकी अंतर्राष्ट्रीय टीम ने प्रत्येक प्रजाति के व्यवहार, गति और गीतों को सावधानीपूर्वक एकत्र और वर्गीकृत किया, और इस डेटा का उनके डीएनए के साथ मिलान किया। प्राकृतिक भिन्नता के इन चरम उदाहरणों का अध्ययन करके, वैज्ञानिक पूरे प्राकृतिक जगत में विविधता को नियंत्रित करने वाली मौलिक प्रक्रियाओं को सुलझाने की उम्मीद करते हैं, जिससे संभावित रूप से पृथ्वी पर जीवन की उत्पत्ति के बारे में भी अंतर्दृष्टि मिल सकती है। स्वयं वॉकर, जो शुरुआत में मकड़ियों से डरते थे, उन्होंने इस अभूतपूर्व शोध को आगे बढ़ाने के लिए अपने भय पर काबू पाया।
meta_description: There are many more species of peacock spider than other animals, scientists think they may know why.

title_src: Real chance' of whisky tariff deal with Donald Trump, says John Swinney
text_src: Real chance' of whisky tariff deal with Trump, says Swinney 3 days ago Share Save Angus Cochrane BBC Scotland News Share Save Swinney outlines visit to White House after talk with Trump First Minister John Swinney says there is a "real chance" that a special trade deal for Scotch whisky could be agreed with US President Donald Trump following talks in the White House. Swinney claimed the UK government had not sufficiently prioritised whisky in trade discussions with Trump, but that he had "sorted" that situation over the summer. The Scottish government is seeking a reduction or removal of 10% import taxes, known as tariffs, on Scotch entering the US - which the whisky industry says costs businesses £4m per week. The BBC understands the UK government is seeking whisky tariff reductions as part of wider trade negotiations with the US. In a statement, a UK government spokesperson said: "There is huge appetite for our whisky in the US and around the world, and our Trade Strategy will help Scottish firms sell even more products in new markets as part of the Plan for Change. "We continue to work with the US to get this landmark deal implemented as soon as possible." Swinney met Trump in the Oval Office during a two-day visit to Washington DC this week. After arriving back in Edinburgh, he said that whisky had not been on Trump's "radar" when he visited Scotland in July. "I sorted that out over the summer, and it's now got the attention that it needs," Swinney told reporters. He said: "A better deal for whisky was not previously on the agenda – and it now very much is. "But the ball is firmly in the UK government's court. They must press on with the detailed negotiations and try to get a deal over the line." He warned that Trump "believes in tariffs" and that it would not "be easy" to negotiate a deal. "But I think – and I hope – there is now a real chance of a better deal," the first minister told reporters. Swinney said that Trump had taken his arguments "very seriously" during a 50-minute meeting. The first minister argued that relaxing tariffs would be a "win-win" for whisky distillers and US bourbon producers, who sell hundreds of millions of pounds of used barrels to whisky producers each year. The White House Donald Trump and John Swinney had a 50-minute meeting in the Oval Office During his whistlestop visit to Washington DC, Swinney met representatives from whisky industries in Scotland and the US before meeting Trump. The Oval Office talks also covered the conflict in Gaza and Israel's air strikes in Qatar. The UK's ambassador to the US, Lord Peter Mandelson, accompanied the first minister to the White House. Swinney also stayed at the former Labour minister's residence in Washington DC. Mandelson has come under media scrutiny for his past friendship with convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. He told the BBC that he "very much regrets ever having been introduced to Epstein". Swinney said UK government had been "helpful" during his visit and that there had been "no issues" with the support given by the embassy. He added that it was up to the prime minister to choose his ambassadors. Tariff fears Trump announced a 10% tariff on most UK good earlier this year, as part of his efforts to boost US industries at the expense of international competitors. The 10% tariff is a base rate, and lower than the 15% tax on EU imports. However, the Scotch Whisky Association says it is costing the industry £4m a week. The US is the biggest Scotch export market, with about a fifth of all exports heading stateside, and was worth about £1bn in 2024 according to the SWA. The industry body has said that the tariffs also damage the US bourbon industry due to a £220m-a-year trade in used casks. The bourbon barrels are sent to Scottish distilleries, where they are used to store maturing whisky. The White House John Swinney and Sir Keir Starmer held talks with Donald Trump when he visited Scotland in July When Trump visited Scotland in the summer he said he did not realise whisky was an issue but agreed to discuss it. Swinney said he raised the issue during talks with the president at his Aberdeenshire golf course in July. Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, who also held talks with Trump in Scotland, is hoping to negotiate further concessions on the tariffs. The effectiveness of Swinney's and Starmer's efforts is expected to become clearer when Trump makes a state visit to the UK next week. There is also a looming threat of further trade tariffs on single malt whisky, which was subject to a 25% rate during Trump's first presidency. A deal struck to suspend that tax during Joe Biden's time in office is due to expire next summer. The SWA has called for the UK and US governments to agree a permanent settlement to ensure the higher rate is not reimposed, potentially on top of the current 10% tariff.
summary_src:
Scottish First Minister John Swinney has met with Donald Trump, expressing optimism for a "real chance" to resolve the 10% US import tariffs on Scotch whisky, which cost the industry £4 million per week. Swinney claims he successfully raised the issue's priority with Trump, who he stated took his arguments "very seriously" despite his general belief in tariffs.

While acknowledging the difficulty of negotiations, Swinney presented tariff reduction as a "win-win" for both Scottish distillers and US bourbon producers, but stressed that the "ball is firmly in the UK government's court" to secure a deal. The UK government, including Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer and Foreign Secretary William Hague, is also actively pursuing these reductions as part of wider trade discussions, aiming to boost Scottish exports.

The Scotch Whisky Association highlights that these tariffs also negatively impact the US bourbon industry due to the trade in used casks. Adding urgency, a temporary suspension of a 25% tariff on single malt whisky, agreed under the Biden administration, is set to expire next summer, prompting industry calls for a permanent settlement. The effectiveness of the diplomatic efforts is expected to become clearer during Trump's upcoming state visit to the UK.
summary_tgt:
स्कॉटलैंड के प्रथम मंत्री जॉन स्विनि ने डोनाल्ड ट्रंप से मुलाकात की है और स्कॉच व्हिस्की पर लगे 10% अमेरिकी आयात शुल्क को हल करने की "वास्तविक संभावना" पर आशावाद व्यक्त किया है, जिससे इस उद्योग को प्रति सप्ताह 40 लाख पाउंड का नुकसान होता है। स्विनि का दावा है कि उन्होंने ट्रंप के सामने इस मुद्दे को सफलतापूर्वक प्राथमिकता दी, जिन्होंने उनके टैरिफ में सामान्य विश्वास के बावजूद, उनके तर्कों को "बहुत गंभीरता से" लिया।

बातचीत की कठिनाई को स्वीकार करते हुए, स्विनि ने टैरिफ में कमी को स्कॉटिश डिस्टिलर्स और अमेरिकी बर्बन उत्पादकों दोनों के लिए "फायदे का सौदा" बताया, लेकिन इस बात पर जोर दिया कि समझौता सुरक्षित करने के लिए "गेंद पूरी तरह से ब्रिटेन सरकार के पाले में है"। ब्रिटेन सरकार, जिसमें प्रधान मंत्री सर कीर स्टारमर और विदेश सचिव विलियम हेग शामिल हैं, भी व्यापक व्यापार वार्ताओं के हिस्से के रूप में इन कटौतियों को सक्रिय रूप से आगे बढ़ा रही है, जिसका उद्देश्य स्कॉटिश निर्यात को बढ़ावा देना है।

स्कॉच व्हिस्की एसोसिएशन (एसडब्ल्यूए) ने इस बात पर प्रकाश डाला है कि पुराने पीपे के व्यापार के कारण ये टैरिफ अमेरिकी बर्बन उद्योग पर भी नकारात्मक प्रभाव डालते हैं। तात्कालिकता को बढ़ाते हुए, बाइडेन प्रशासन के तहत सहमत सिंगल माल्ट व्हिस्की पर 25% टैरिफ का एक अस्थायी स्थगन अगली गर्मियों में समाप्त होने वाला है, जिससे उद्योग स्थायी समाधान की मांग कर रहा है। राजनयिक प्रयासों की प्रभावशीलता ट्रंप की ब्रिटेन की आगामी राजकीय यात्रा के दौरान स्पष्ट होने की उम्मीद है।
meta_description: The first minister is hopeful of a tariffs exemption following talks with the president in Washington.

title_src: Trump lobbies EU for 100% tariffs on China and India to pressure Putin
text_src: Trump lobbies EU for 100% tariffs on China and India Separately, Trump told reporters on Tuesday that he plans to talk to Putin on a call this week or early next week. Trump, who previously pledged to end the conflict on "day one" of becoming president, is struggling to broker a peace deal between Moscow and Kyiv, and Russia's strikes on Ukraine have intensified . The US president made the demand during a meeting between US and EU officials on Tuesday discussing options to increase economic pressure on Russia, a source familiar with the discussions has told the BBC. Donald Trump has called on the European Union (EU) to hit China and India with tariffs of up to 100% to force Russian president Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine. China and India are major buyers of Russian oil, which helps to keep the country's economy and war machine afloat. Last month, the US imposed a 50% tariff on goods from India, which included a 25% penalty for its transactions with Russia. Although the EU has said it would end its dependency on Russian energy, around 19% of its natural gas imports still come from there. If the EU does impose the tariffs on China and India it would mark a change to its approach of attempting to isolate Russia with sanctions rather than levies. Trump's request to the EU, first reported by the Financial Times, follows remarks from US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, who said Washington was prepared to escalate economic pressure but needed stronger European backing Ukraine's main government building in Kyiv was struck by a Russian missile over the weekend - in an attack that was seen as both symbolic and a major increase of aggression by the Kremlin. The strikes across the country marked the heaviest aerial bombardment on Ukraine since the war began. Ukraine said Russian forces used at least 810 drones and 13 missiles. On Tuesday, more than 20 civilians were killed by a Russian glide bomb in the eastern Donbas region, as they queued to collect their pensions. Trump said he was "not happy with the whole situation" and threatened harsher sanctions on the Kremlin. The US president has previously pledged harsher measures against Russia, but not taken any action despite Putin ignoring his deadlines and threats of sanctions. A highly anticipated summit between the leaders in Alaska last month ended without a peace deal. Trump also said on Tuesday that the US and India were "continuing negotiations to address the trade barriers" between the two countries. He plans to speak to Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the coming weeks and expects a "successful conclusion" to their trade talks, he wrote on social media. In response, Modi echoed Trump's optimism that the talks would be successful and said the two countries were "close friends and natural partners." "Our teams are working to conclude these discussions at the earliest. I am also looking forward to speaking with President Trump," he added. Trump's comments have been seen by some as the latest sign of a reconciliation between Washington and Delhi, after a collapse in their trade negotiations. Last week, Trump emphasised the "special relationship" between India and the US, saying "there's nothing to worry about. We just have moments on occasion".
summary_src:
U.S. President Donald Trump has urged the European Union (EU) to impose a 100% tariff on goods from China and India. This demand, made during a meeting with US and EU officials, aims to pressure Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine, as both countries are major buyers of Russian oil, which sustains Moscow's economy and war effort.

Trump, who previously pledged to end the conflict on "day one," has struggled to broker a peace deal, and his request follows heavy Russian bombardments across Ukraine, including a deadly strike in Donbas. The US has already imposed a 50% tariff on goods from India, while the EU currently relies on sanctions against Russia, despite still importing 19% of its natural gas from the country. Trump has also expressed dissatisfaction with the ongoing conflict and threatened harsher sanctions on the Kremlin, despite past threats not leading to significant action. He plans to speak with Putin later this week or early next.

Separately, Trump announced ongoing negotiations with India to resolve trade barriers and a dispute over defense equipment, anticipating a "successful conclusion" to talks with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, whom he plans to speak with soon. Both leaders have expressed optimism, signaling a potential reconciliation in the "special relationship" between the two nations after previous trade negotiation setbacks.
summary_tgt:
**अमेरिकी राष्ट्रपति डोनाल्ड ट्रंप ने यूरोपीय संघ (ईयू) से चीन और भारत से आने वाले सामानों पर 100% शुल्क (टैरिफ) लगाने का आग्रह किया है। अमेरिकी और यूरोपीय संघ के अधिकारियों के साथ एक बैठक के दौरान की गई इस मांग का लक्ष्य रूसी राष्ट्रपति व्लादिमीर पुतिन पर यूक्रेन में युद्ध समाप्त करने का दबाव डालना है। ऐसा इसलिए है क्योंकि ये दोनों देश रूसी तेल के बड़े खरीदार हैं, जो मास्को की अर्थव्यवस्था और युद्ध प्रयासों को पोषित करता है।**

ट्रंप, जिन्होंने पहले "पहले ही दिन" संघर्ष समाप्त करने का वादा किया था, शांति समझौता कराने में संघर्ष कर रहे हैं। उनका यह अनुरोध यूक्रेन भर में भारी रूसी बमबारी के बाद आया है, जिसमें डोनबास में एक घातक हमला भी शामिल है। अमेरिका पहले ही भारत से आने वाले सामानों पर 50% शुल्क लगा चुका है, जबकि यूरोपीय संघ वर्तमान में रूस के खिलाफ प्रतिबंधों पर निर्भर है, इसके बावजूद कि वह अभी भी रूस से अपने प्राकृतिक गैस का 19% आयात करता है। ट्रंप ने चल रहे संघर्ष पर असंतोष भी व्यक्त किया है और क्रेमलिन पर कड़े प्रतिबंध लगाने की धमकी दी है, हालांकि पिछली धमकियों से कोई खास कार्रवाई नहीं हुई है। उनकी इस सप्ताह के अंत में या अगले सप्ताह की शुरुआत में पुतिन से बात करने की योजना है।

एक अलग घटनाक्रम में, ट्रंप ने भारत के साथ व्यापार बाधाओं और रक्षा उपकरणों से जुड़े विवाद को हल करने के लिए चल रही वार्ताओं की घोषणा की। उन्होंने प्रधान मंत्री नरेंद्र मोदी के साथ बातचीत के "सफल निष्कर्ष" की उम्मीद जताई, जिनसे वह जल्द ही बात करने की योजना बना रहे हैं। दोनों नेताओं ने आशावाद व्यक्त किया है, जो पिछली व्यापार वार्ता की असफलताओं के बाद दोनों देशों के बीच "विशेष संबंध" में एक संभावित सुलह का संकेत देता है।

title_src: Firms will hesitate to invest in US after raid
text_src: Firms will hesitate to invest in US after raid - S Korea president 2 days ago Share Save Kelly Ng Singapore and Hosu Lee Seoul Share Save How the massive immigration raid on a Georgia car plant unfolded South Korean companies will be "very hesitant" about investing in the US following a massive immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in the state of Georgia last week, President Lee Jae Myung has said. More than 300 South Koreans who were arrested in the raid have now been released from detention and are due to return home on Friday after having their release delayed by more than a day. Their departure was delayed because of an instruction from the White House, Lee added. President Donald Trump ordered the pause to check whether the workers were willing to remain in the US to continue working and training Americans, according to a South Korean foreign ministry official. Lee, who was speaking at a news conference to mark the first 100 days of his presidency, said "the situation is extremely bewildering," while noting it is common practice for Korean firms to send workers to help set up overseas factories. "If that's no longer allowed, establishing manufacturing facilities in the US will only become more difficult... making companies question whether it's worth doing at all," he added. Seoul is negotiating with Washington on visa options for South Korean workers "whether that means securing [higher] quotas or creating new visa categories", Lee said. "I think the US will address this if they see it as a practical necessity." The BBC has contacted the White House for comment. Reuters President Lee Jae Myung visited the US in August
summary_src:
A recent immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in Georgia led to the arrest of over 300 South Korean workers. While they have since been released, their return home was delayed by a White House instruction, reportedly from President Donald Trump, who wanted to assess their willingness to remain in the US for work and training.

South Korean President Lee Jae Myung expressed strong concern, stating that such actions would deter Korean firms from investing in the US. He emphasized that sending workers to help establish overseas factories is a common and necessary practice, and restricting it would make setting up manufacturing facilities in the US significantly more difficult and questionable for companies.

Seoul is now negotiating with Washington to secure better visa options, including higher quotas or new categories, for its workers. CNN's John Defterios suggested the US would likely address the issue if deemed a practical necessity. The White House has yet to comment on the incident or the reported diplomatic rift.
summary_tgt:
जॉर्जिया में हुंडई संयंत्र पर हालिया आव्रजन छापेमारी में 300 से अधिक दक्षिण कोरियाई श्रमिकों को गिरफ्तार किया गया। हालाँकि, उन्हें बाद में रिहा कर दिया गया, लेकिन उनकी घर वापसी में व्हाइट हाउस के एक निर्देश के कारण देरी हुई, जो कथित तौर पर राष्ट्रपति डोनाल्ड ट्रंप की ओर से था। ट्रंप यह आकलन करना चाहते थे कि क्या वे काम और प्रशिक्षण के लिए अमेरिका में रुकने को तैयार हैं।

दक्षिण कोरियाई राष्ट्रपति ली जे म्युंग ने कड़ी चिंता व्यक्त करते हुए कहा कि ऐसे कदम कोरियाई कंपनियों को अमेरिका में निवेश करने से रोकेंगे। उन्होंने इस बात पर जोर दिया कि विदेशों में कारखाने स्थापित करने में मदद के लिए श्रमिकों को भेजना एक सामान्य और आवश्यक प्रथा है, और इसे प्रतिबंधित करने से कंपनियों के लिए अमेरिका में विनिर्माण सुविधाएं स्थापित करना काफी अधिक कठिन और संदिग्ध हो जाएगा।

सियोल अब अपने श्रमिकों के लिए बेहतर वीजा विकल्प, जिसमें उच्च कोटा या नई श्रेणियां शामिल हैं, सुरक्षित करने के लिए वाशिंगटन के साथ बातचीत कर रहा है। सीएनएन के जॉन डेफटेरियोस ने सुझाव दिया कि यदि इसे एक व्यावहारिक आवश्यकता माना जाता है, तो अमेरिका इस मुद्दे का समाधान करेगा। व्हाइट हाउस ने अभी तक इस घटना या कथित राजनयिक दरार पर कोई टिप्पणी नहीं की है।

title_src: AstraZeneca pauses £200m Cambridge investment
text_src: AstraZeneca pauses £200m Cambridge investment 19 hours ago Share Save Mitchell Labiak Business reporter and Simon Jack Business editor Share Save Getty Images AstraZeneca has paused plans to invest £200m at a Cambridge research site in a fresh blow to the UK pharmaceutical industry. The project, which was set to create 1,000 jobs, was announced in March 2024 by the previous government alongside another project in Liverpool, which was shelved in January. Friday's announcement comes after US pharmaceutical giant Merck scrapped a £1bn UK expansion, blaming a lack of government investment, and as President Donald Trump pressures pharmaceutical firms to invest more in the US. An AstraZeneca spokesperson said: "We constantly reassess the investment needs of our company and can confirm our expansion in Cambridge is paused." Over the last 10 years, UK spending on medicines has fallen from 15% of the NHS budget to 9%, while the rest of the developed world spends between 14% and 20%. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical companies have been looking to invest in the US following Trump's threats of sky-high tariffs on drug imports. In July, AstraZeneca said it would invest $50bn (£36.9bn) in the US on "medicines manufacturing and R&D [research and development]". Earlier this week Merck, which had already begun construction on a site in London's King's Cross which was due to be completed by 2027, said it no longer planned to occupy it. The multi-national business, known as MSD in Europe, said it would move its life sciences research to the US and cut UK jobs, blaming successive governments for undervaluing innovative medicines. Getty Images AstraZeneca boss Pascal Soriot announced the firm's $50bn investment in the US in July
summary_src:
AstraZeneca has paused a £200 million investment at its Cambridge research site, which was set to create 1,000 jobs, following an earlier decision to shelve a Liverpool project. This move represents a significant setback for the UK pharmaceutical sector and mirrors US pharmaceutical giant Merck's recent abandonment of a £1 billion UK expansion, including a London King's Cross site, with Merck blaming a lack of government investment and the undervaluing of innovative medicines.

Both companies, along with others in the industry, are increasingly directing investments towards the United States, partly due to pressure from figures like former President Donald Trump and threats of import tariffs. AstraZeneca, for instance, committed $50 billion to US medicines manufacturing and R&D in July, while Merck plans to move its life sciences research there, leading to UK job cuts. This trend comes as UK spending on medicines has fallen from 15% to 9% of the NHS budget over the last decade, significantly below other developed nations.
summary_tgt:
एस्ट्राजेनेका (AstraZeneca) ने अपने कैम्ब्रिज रिसर्च साइट पर 200 मिलियन पाउंड (लगभग 2,000 करोड़ रुपये) के निवेश को रोक दिया है, जिससे 1,000 नौकरियां सृजित होने वाली थीं। यह फैसला लिवरपूल परियोजना को स्थगित करने के उसके पहले के निर्णय के बाद आया है।

यह कदम यूके के दवा क्षेत्र के लिए एक बड़ा झटका है और यह अमेरिकी दवा दिग्गज मर्क (Merck) द्वारा हाल ही में 1 बिलियन पाउंड (लगभग 10,000 करोड़ रुपये) के यूके विस्तार को छोड़ने के समान है, जिसमें लंदन के किंग्स क्रॉस में एक साइट भी शामिल थी। मर्क ने इसके लिए सरकारी निवेश की कमी और नवोन्मेषी दवाओं के कम मूल्यांकन को जिम्मेदार ठहराया था।

दोनों कंपनियां, उद्योग में अन्य के साथ, बढ़ते हुए अपने निवेश को संयुक्त राज्य अमेरिका की ओर निर्देशित कर रही हैं, जिसका एक कारण पूर्व राष्ट्रपति डोनाल्ड ट्रम्प जैसे शख्सियतों का दबाव और आयात शुल्क की धमकियां हैं। उदाहरण के लिए, एस्ट्राजेनेका ने जुलाई में अमेरिकी दवा निर्माण और अनुसंधान एवं विकास (R&D) में 50 बिलियन डॉलर (लगभग 4,16,000 करोड़ रुपये) का निवेश करने का वादा किया, जबकि मर्क अपनी जीवन विज्ञान अनुसंधान इकाई को वहीं स्थानांतरित करने की योजना बना रहा है, जिससे यूके में नौकरियों में कटौती होगी।

यह प्रवृत्ति ऐसे समय में सामने आई है जब पिछले एक दशक में दवाओं पर यूके का खर्च एनएचएस (NHS) के बजट के 15% से घटकर 9% हो गया है, जो अन्य विकसित देशों की तुलना में काफी कम है।
meta_description: Its decision comes as the industry says there is a lack of government investment and as the US pressures firms to invest there.

title_src: Will farming under solar panels take off?
text_src: Will farming under solar panels take off? 2 days ago Share Save Priti Gupta Technology Reporter Share Save Harpal Dagar Harpal Dagar has been farming under solar panels for five years "As a farmer, you're always at the mercy of weather," says Harpal Dagar who has a farm on the outskirts of Delhi. "So many times, we lost our produce due to unpredictable conditions," he says. But five years ago he was approached by Sun Master, a Delhi-based solar power firm, with a deal that would give him a much more predictable income. Sun Master proposed building solar panels above some of Mr Dagar's fields, with the panels high enough off the ground, that he could continue to farm underneath them. Under the 25-year deal, Mr Dagar would receive annual payments and Sun Master would keep the proceeds from the electricity generated. "When the solar company first approached us... many of us feared losing our land. It sounded too good to be true - maybe even a scam," says Mr Dagar. "But today, I believe it was the best decision I made. My income has tripled, and I sleep peacefully without the stress of climate or crop failure," he says. Sun Master pays him around $1,200 (£900) per acre, per year, plus $170 a month for work operating and maintaining the solar panels. "Even the turmeric I grow on the same land is mine to sell. How can I complain?" Siting solar panels above crops goes by the term agrivoltaics. India would seem particularly suited to such innovation. The fortunes of many of its farmers often hinge on an unpredictable monsoon, so a reliable income from a solar energy firm might provide some welcome financial security. But despite the benefits, take up has been slow, around 40 projects are operating in India at the moment, according to the National Solar Energy Federation of India (NSEFI), which represents India's solar power industry. There are several challenges. Not all crops will grow under solar panels. Depending on the layout, the panels reduce the light getting through by between 15% and 30%. Some denser layouts will block too much sun for staple crops including wheat, rice, soybeans or pulses. "What works well are high-value crops with moderate or low-light needs, like green leafy vegetables, spices such as turmeric and ginger, and some flowers," says Vivek Saraf, the founder and CEO of Delhi-based SunSeed, which specialises in agrivoltaics. There's also the issue of expense. To allow farming underneath, the solar panels need to be at least 11ft (3.5m) off the ground. That makes them between 20% and 30% more expensive to install than panels on a regular solar farm, where they are much closer to the ground. "Small farmers cannot own these systems. They don't have the risk appetite or capital," says Mr Saraf. SunSeed APV SunSeed promises to take the risk out of farming The solar power companies want the government to step in with subsidies to make agrivoltaics more attractive. "In India, where more than 55% of the population depends on agriculture and cultivable land is under mounting pressure, agrivoltaics offers a transformative model," says Subrahmanyam Pulipaka, CEO of NSEFI. "It reduces irrigation needs, shields crops from heat stress, and stabilizes incomes by diversifying revenue streams for farmers. For rain fed and climate-vulnerable regions, agrivoltaics can play a vital role in climate adaptation, making agriculture more resilient to unpredictable weather patterns," he says. SunSeed gives the farmer multiple options, including continuing to farm for a fixed salary, or handing over all the farming responsibility to SunSeed. "Our model ensures the farmer is not exposed to any risk. If the crop fails or there's a market issue, the loss is ours - not the farmers'," he says. Meanwhile, SunSeed has been finely tuning its system to work with different crops and conditions. "We have developed sophisticated agrivoltaics simulation software," he says. "It digitally replicates panel configurations and crop types to simulate how much light and heat each leaf receives, how photosynthesis is affected, and ultimately how much yield to expect." SunSeed Agrivoltaic projects are still relatively rare in India There's still caution in government circles over the combination of solar power and farming. "Agrivoltaics is promising, but we must protect both the farmer and the developer," says Manu Srivastava, who oversees solar and agrivoltaic projects in the state of Madhya Pradesh. "The biggest challenge is contracts. A 25-year lease needs clear obligations and protection for both sides. In India, long-term contract enforcement is still a hurdle," says Mr Srivastava. He also points out that agrivoltaics systems are more expensive than a traditional ground-mounted solar farm, so making a return on the investment is more challenging. "If the farmer starts charging too much for land and the developer has to bear high structural costs, then it becomes unviable," he says. At the moment India is falling behind China, where more than 500 projects are in operation, according to the World Resources Institute. "It's a small beginning. But if the farmer's economic interest is protected, if the right crops are chosen, and if contracts are clear and fair, there's no reason India can not lead in agrivoltaics," says Mr Srivastava. Anand Jain Anand Jain has been growing strawberries and tomatoes under solar panels
summary_src:
Agrivoltaics, the practice of farming beneath elevated solar panels, shows promise as a transformative model, particularly in India. Farmers like Harpal Dagar, who partnered with Sun Master five years ago, have seen their income triple and stress from unpredictable weather significantly reduced. Under a 25-year agreement, Dagar receives annual payments and additional income for panel maintenance, while retaining rights to cultivate and sell crops like turmeric on the same land. This innovative approach offers a stable income source, reducing reliance on India's often unpredictable monsoons and shielding crops from heat stress.

Despite the clear benefits, including reduced irrigation needs and diversified revenue streams, the adoption of agrivoltaics in India has been slow, with only around 40 projects currently operational, compared to over 500 in China. Several challenges hinder its widespread implementation. Not all crops are suitable, with high-value, moderate-to-low light needs crops like leafy green vegetables performing best, as panels reduce light by 15-30%. The elevated structure required for farming beneath makes installation 20-30% more expensive than traditional solar farms, making it difficult for small farmers who lack the capital and risk appetite.

Contractual issues are another significant hurdle, as 25-year leases require clear obligations and robust enforcement, which remains a challenge in India. If land charges become too high for farmers and structural costs for developers remain elevated, project viability is threatened.

Companies like SunSeed are working to mitigate these risks by offering models where they absorb crop failure and market risks, and by developing sophisticated simulation software to optimize panel configurations and crop types. They also advocate for government subsidies to make agrivoltaics more attractive. Experts believe that with proper protection for farmers' economic interests, selection of suitable crops, and clear, fair contracts, India has the potential to become a leader in agrivoltaics, enhancing climate adaptation and farmer resilience.

यहां अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

**एग्रीवोल्टेक्स: भारत के लिए एक परिवर्तनकारी कृषि मॉडल**

एग्रीवोल्टेक्स, जिसमें ऊंचे सौर पैनलों के नीचे खेती की जाती है, भारत में एक परिवर्तनकारी मॉडल के रूप में काफी संभावनाएं दिखा रहा है। हरपाल डागर जैसे किसान, जिन्होंने पाँच साल पहले सन मास्टर के साथ साझेदारी की थी, अपनी आय तिगुनी होते और अप्रत्याशित मौसम से होने वाला तनाव काफी कम होते देखा है। 25 साल के समझौते के तहत, डागर को वार्षिक भुगतान और पैनलों के रखरखाव के लिए अतिरिक्त आय मिलती है, जबकि वह उसी ज़मीन पर हल्दी जैसी फसलें उगाने और बेचने का अधिकार बरकरार रखते हैं। यह अभिनव तरीका आय का एक स्थिर स्रोत प्रदान करता है, जिससे भारत के अक्सर अप्रत्याशित मानसून पर निर्भरता कम होती है और फसलों को गर्मी के तनाव से बचाया जा सकता है।

सिंचाई की कम आवश्यकता और राजस्व के विविध स्रोतों सहित स्पष्ट लाभों के बावजूद, भारत में एग्रीवोल्टेक्स को अपनाने की गति धीमी रही है, वर्तमान में चीन में 500 से अधिक परियोजनाओं की तुलना में केवल लगभग 40 परियोजनाएं ही चालू हैं। इसके व्यापक कार्यान्वयन में कई चुनौतियां बाधा डाल रही हैं। सभी फसलें उपयुक्त नहीं हैं; पत्तेदार हरी सब्जियों जैसी उच्च-मूल्य वाली, मध्यम से कम प्रकाश की आवश्यकता वाली फसलें सबसे अच्छा प्रदर्शन करती हैं, क्योंकि पैनल 15-30% तक प्रकाश कम कर देते हैं। नीचे खेती के लिए आवश्यक ऊंची संरचना पारंपरिक सौर फार्मों की तुलना में स्थापना को 20-30% अधिक महंगा बनाती है, जिससे उन छोटे किसानों के लिए यह मुश्किल हो जाता है जिनके पास पूंजी और जोखिम लेने की क्षमता नहीं होती।

अनुबंध संबंधी मुद्दे एक और महत्वपूर्ण बाधा हैं, क्योंकि 25 साल के पट्टों के लिए स्पष्ट दायित्व और मजबूत प्रवर्तन की आवश्यकता होती है, जो भारत में एक चुनौती बनी हुई है। यदि किसानों के लिए भूमि शुल्क बहुत अधिक हो जाता है और डेवलपर्स के लिए संरचनात्मक लागतें अधिक बनी रहती हैं, तो परियोजना की व्यवहार्यता खतरे में पड़ जाती है।

सनसीड जैसी कंपनियां इन जोखिमों को कम करने के लिए काम कर रही हैं, वे ऐसे मॉडल पेश करती हैं जहां वे फसल खराब होने और बाजार के जोखिमों को खुद वहन करती हैं, साथ ही पैनल कॉन्फ़िगरेशन और फसल के प्रकारों को अनुकूलित करने के लिए परिष्कृत सिमुलेशन सॉफ्टवेयर भी विकसित कर रही हैं। वे एग्रीवोल्टेक्स को अधिक आकर्षक बनाने के लिए सरकारी सब्सिडी की भी वकालत करते हैं। विशेषज्ञों का मानना है कि किसानों के आर्थिक हितों की उचित सुरक्षा, उपयुक्त फसलों का चयन और स्पष्ट, निष्पक्ष अनुबंधों के साथ, भारत में एग्रीवोल्टेक्स में अग्रणी बनने की क्षमता है, जिससे जलवायु अनुकूलन और किसानों का लचीलापन बढ़ेगा।

title_src: South Korea workers detained in US may see return home delayed
text_src: S Korea workers detained in US may see return home delayed 3 days ago Share Save Peter Hoskins Business reporter Share Save How the massive immigration raid on a Georgia car plant unfolded South Korean workers who were detained in the US in a massive immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in the state of Georgia may see their departure delayed, according to the South Korean Foreign Ministry. Their return home "has been made difficult due to circumstances on the US side" and talks are being held to ensure that they are able to leave America as soon as possible, officials say. The workers were originally expected to leave the US on a chartered plane at about 14:30 local time (18:30 GMT) on Wednesday. The White House said earlier that US Secretary of State Marco Rubio would meet South Korea's foreign minister Cho Hyun in Washington on Wednesday morning. YONHAP/POOL/EPA/Shutterstock South Korean TV showed a charter plane taking off from Incheon International Airport on Wednesday
summary_src: South Korean workers who were recently detained in a massive immigration raid at a Hyundai plant in Georgia, US, are experiencing delays in their planned return home. Officials attribute the postponement to "circumstances on the US side," despite the workers originally being scheduled to depart on a chartered plane on Wednesday. Diplomatic efforts are underway, with talks being held to facilitate their prompt return, including a scheduled meeting between US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and South Korea's foreign minister Cho Hyun in Washington.
summary_tgt: जॉर्जिया, अमेरिका में हुंडई संयंत्र में एक बड़े आव्रजन छापे में हाल ही में हिरासत में लिए गए दक्षिण कोरियाई श्रमिकों को अपनी नियोजित घर वापसी में देरी का सामना करना पड़ रहा है। अधिकारियों ने स्थगन का कारण "अमेरिकी पक्ष की परिस्थितियाँ" बताया है, हालांकि श्रमिकों को मूल रूप से बुधवार को एक चार्टर्ड विमान से प्रस्थान करना निर्धारित था। उनकी शीघ्र वापसी सुनिश्चित करने के लिए राजनयिक प्रयास जारी हैं, जिसके तहत वार्ताएं आयोजित की जा रही हैं। इसमें अमेरिकी विदेश मंत्री मार्को रुबियो और दक्षिण कोरिया के विदेश मंत्री चो ह्यून के बीच वाशिंगटन में एक निर्धारित बैठक भी शामिल है।

title_src: Jaguar Land Rover plants shut until Wednesday after cyber attack
text_src: Jaguar Land Rover shutdown extended to next week Staff have been told not to come into work until Wednesday at the earliest, which means more than two full weeks of global output will have been lost. The company, which usually builds 1,000 cars a day, said some data had been affected but it is not yet clear who is affected - whether that's customers, suppliers, or JLR itself. Production halted at the plants in Solihull, Halewood and Wolverhampton with workers sent home following the hack, which came to light on 1 September. Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) has said its UK factories will remain closed until next week after the carmaker was hit by a cyber attack at the end of last month. Following the cyber attack, JLR shut down its IT networks in order to protect them from damage. However, because modern factories and parts supply networks are highly automated, this meant the manufacturer had to shut down its production lines. Dealerships were left unable to sell cars at what is usually one of the busiest periods of the year, and garages which service JLR vehicles initially struggled to obtain the parts they needed. Workarounds have since been introduced, which have improved the situation but disruption is continuing. JLR's suppliers have also been badly affected. On Wednesday, the company, which is owned by India's Tata Motors, admitted data might have been stolen or viewed by third parties in the hack. In a statement, the carmaker said: "As a result of our ongoing investigation, we now believe that some data has been affected, and we are informing the relevant regulators. "Our forensic investigation continues at pace, and we will contact anyone as appropriate if we find that their data has been impacted." A group calling itself Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters, which was behind cyber attacks on UK retailers including M&S earlier this year, has claimed responsibility for the JLR hack. M&S's operations were affected for a number of months, stopping customers from ordering online and costing the High Street retailer £300m. Last week, the Information Commissioner's Office told the BBC that JLR had reported an incident to the UK's data watchdog. Business minister Chris Bryant met JLR's chief executive Adrian Mardell on Thursday morning and the Department of Business and Trade has said it is speaking to the company on a daily basis. On Tuesday, Bryant told MPs that the National Cyber Security Centre, part of the intelligence agency GCHQ, had been working with JLR since the early stages of the incident. Local MPs are due to be briefed by the company during an online call on Friday.
summary_src:
Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) has extended the shutdown of its UK factories until next week following a cyber attack that came to light on September 1st. The prolonged closure, affecting plants in Solihull, Halewood, and Wolverhampton, will result in the loss of more than two full weeks of global output, equating to over 14,000 cars.

The carmaker initially shut down its IT networks to protect them, which subsequently forced the closure of highly automated production lines and sent thousands of workers home. The incident has severely disrupted dealerships, preventing car sales during a crucial period, and caused difficulties for service garages in obtaining parts, though some workarounds have since been introduced. JLR's suppliers have also been significantly impacted.

On Wednesday, JLR, owned by India's Tata Motors, admitted that some data might have been stolen or viewed by third parties during the hack. The company is conducting a forensic investigation, has informed relevant regulators, and pledges to contact individuals whose data is found to be impacted.

A group calling itself Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters, previously linked to cyber attacks on UK retailers like M&S (which reportedly cost £300m and disrupted operations for months), has claimed responsibility for the JLR hack. The UK government is actively involved, with Business Minister Chris Bryant meeting JLR's chief executive and the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) having worked with the company since the early stages. Local MPs are also due to be briefed on Friday regarding the ongoing situation.

**जैगुआर लैंड रोवर (जेएलआर) ने साइबर हमले के बाद यूके के कारखानों की बंदी बढ़ाई**

जैगुआर लैंड रोवर (जेएलआर) ने 1 सितंबर को सामने आए एक साइबर हमले के बाद यूके में अपने कारखानों की बंदी को अगले सप्ताह तक के लिए बढ़ा दिया है। सोलिहुल, हेल्वूड और वोल्वरहैम्प्टन स्थित संयंत्रों को प्रभावित करने वाली इस लंबी बंदी के कारण दो पूरे सप्ताह से अधिक के वैश्विक उत्पादन का नुकसान होगा, जो 14,000 से अधिक कारों के बराबर है।

कार निर्माता कंपनी ने शुरुआत में अपने आईटी नेटवर्क को सुरक्षित रखने के लिए बंद कर दिया था, जिसके बाद अत्यधिक स्वचालित उत्पादन लाइनों को बंद करने के लिए मजबूर होना पड़ा और हजारों श्रमिकों को घर भेजना पड़ा। इस घटना से डीलरशिप गंभीर रूप से बाधित हुए हैं, एक महत्वपूर्ण अवधि के दौरान कार बिक्री को रोका गया है, और सर्विस गैरेज के लिए पुर्जे प्राप्त करने में कठिनाइयाँ पैदा हुई हैं, हालांकि तब से कुछ वैकल्पिक समाधान पेश किए गए हैं। जेएलआर के आपूर्तिकर्ता भी काफी प्रभावित हुए हैं।

बुधवार को, भारत की टाटा मोटर्स के स्वामित्व वाली जेएलआर ने स्वीकार किया कि हैक के दौरान कुछ डेटा चोरी हो गया होगा या तीसरे पक्ष द्वारा देखा गया होगा। कंपनी एक फॉरेंसिक जांच कर रही है, संबंधित नियामकों को सूचित किया है, और उन व्यक्तियों से संपर्क करने का संकल्प लेती है जिनका डेटा प्रभावित पाया जाता है।

खुद को 'स्कैटर्ड लैप्सस$ हंटर्स' कहने वाले एक समूह ने जेएलआर हैक की जिम्मेदारी ली है, जो पहले एम एंड एस जैसे यूके के खुदरा विक्रेताओं पर हुए साइबर हमलों से जुड़ा रहा है (जिसमें कथित तौर पर £300 मिलियन का नुकसान हुआ था और महीनों तक संचालन बाधित रहा था)। यूके सरकार सक्रिय रूप से इसमें शामिल है, व्यापार मंत्री क्रिस ब्रायंट ने जेएलआर के मुख्य कार्यकारी से मुलाकात की है और राष्ट्रीय साइबर सुरक्षा केंद्र (एनसीएससी) शुरुआती चरणों से ही कंपनी के साथ काम कर रहा है। स्थानीय सांसदों को भी शुक्रवार को चल रही स्थिति के बारे में जानकारी दी जाएगी।

title_src: Nasa bans Chinese nationals from working on its space programmes
text_src: Nasa bans Chinese nationals from working on its space programmes The US currently bans Nasa from sharing its data with China China's accelerated space programme has alarmed the US and ramped up the race between the two biggest economies. Nasa then confirmed this, saying Chinese nationals would be restricted from using the agency's "facilities, materials and networks to ensure the security of our work". Chinese nationals, who could only work at Nasa as contractors or students contributing to research, found out on 5 September that they had lost all access to Nasa's systems and facilities, Bloomberg reported, citing sources. US space agency Nasa has blocked Chinese citizens with valid US visas from its facilities - a move that effectively bars them from working at one of the most respected space research centres. Chinese astronauts are already excluded from the International Space Station (ISS) because Washington has barred Nasa from sharing its data with China. The latest restriction from Nasa only adds to the decline in scientific collaboration between the two sides because of national security concerns. As they compete to gain a technological edge, Beijing and Washington have also grown increasingly wary of each other. The suspicion has made it harder for some Chinese students, especially those studying science and tech, to get visas or even enter the US once they have secured a visa. There have also been several cases in the US recently of alleged espionage by Chinese nationals, and scientists in particular have increasingly come under the microscope. It is unclear how much notice Nasa gave Chinese nationals who were working for the agency. Bloomberg reported that they had suddenly found they were denied access to the agency's data systems and were barred from participating in meetings relating to their work - both in-person and virtual. Nasa's press secretary Bethany Stevens told reporters that Nasa had indeed taken "internal action pertaining to Chinese nationals - including restricting physical and cybersecurity access to our facilities". China has made no secret of its space ambitions, with both Beijing and Washington competing to send their crews to the moon. "We're in a second space race right now," Nasa's acting administrator Sean Duffy told reporters in a news conference on Wednesday, where he spoke about US discoveries on Mars. "The Chinese want to get back to the moon before us. That's not going to happen." The director of the general technology bureau of China's Manned Space Agency last year said US concerns were "unnecessary", calling China's space exploration a "collective mission for humanity". At a US Senate hearing last week, lawmakers stressed the need for the US to put its boots on the moon before China. "China has made no secret of its goals," said Republican Senator Ted Cruz. "[If] our adversaries achieve dominant space capabilities, it would pose a profound risk to America... [The] stakes could not be higher." The race is not just about getting to the Moon, but also who can control its resources once they are there. The Moon contains minerals, including rare earths metals like iron and titanium - and helium too, which is used in everything from superconductors to medical equipment.
summary_src:
The US space agency Nasa has implemented significant new restrictions on Chinese nationals, effectively banning them from accessing its facilities, materials, and networks. This move, which resulted in a sudden denial of access for many Chinese contractors and students on September 5th, stems from mounting national security concerns and a perceived "second space race" with China.

Nasa confirmed these "internal actions," stating they were necessary "to ensure the security of our work." This decision exacerbates an existing decline in scientific collaboration between the two nations, which already excludes Chinese astronauts from the International Space Station (ISS) due to US prohibitions on data sharing.

The intensified rivalry is fueled by China's rapidly accelerating space program, its ambition to land crews on the Moon before the US, and a broader atmosphere of suspicion, including recent allegations of espionage by Chinese nationals. Nasa's acting administrator, Sean Duffy, emphasized the critical competition, asserting that the US will not allow China to reach the Moon first. US lawmakers, like Senator Ted Cruz, have echoed these concerns, stressing the need for the US to secure a dominant position in space to avoid "profound risk."

The competition extends beyond just reaching the Moon to controlling its valuable resources, such as rare earth metals and helium. While China's Manned Space Agency has dismissed US concerns as "unnecessary" and framed its space exploration as a "collective mission for humanity," the US remains resolute in its efforts to gain a technological and strategic edge. The heightened scrutiny has also made it more challenging for Chinese science and technology students to obtain US visas.
summary_tgt:
**नासा ने चीनी नागरिकों पर लगाए कड़े प्रतिबंध, राष्ट्रीय सुरक्षा और 'अंतरिक्ष दौड़' का हवाला**

अमेरिकी अंतरिक्ष एजेंसी नासा ने चीनी नागरिकों पर महत्वपूर्ण नए प्रतिबंध लागू किए हैं, जिससे उन्हें उसकी सुविधाओं, सामग्रियों और नेटवर्कों तक पहुँचने से प्रभावी रूप से प्रतिबंधित कर दिया गया है। 5 सितंबर को कई चीनी ठेकेदारों और छात्रों को अचानक पहुँच से वंचित करने वाला यह कदम, बढ़ती राष्ट्रीय सुरक्षा चिंताओं और चीन के साथ एक कथित 'दूसरी अंतरिक्ष दौड़' की धारणा से उपजा है।

नासा ने इन "आंतरिक कार्रवाइयों" की पुष्टि करते हुए कहा कि "हमारे काम की सुरक्षा सुनिश्चित करने के लिए" ये आवश्यक थीं। यह निर्णय दोनों देशों के बीच वैज्ञानिक सहयोग में मौजूदा गिरावट को और बढ़ा देता है, जिसमें डेटा साझाकरण पर अमेरिकी प्रतिबंधों के कारण चीनी अंतरिक्ष यात्री पहले से ही अंतर्राष्ट्रीय अंतरिक्ष स्टेशन (ISS) से बाहर हैं।

चीन के तेजी से बढ़ते अंतरिक्ष कार्यक्रम, अमेरिका से पहले चंद्रमा पर दल उतारने की उसकी महत्वाकांक्षा, और संदेह के एक व्यापक माहौल, जिसमें चीनी नागरिकों द्वारा जासूसी के हालिया आरोप भी शामिल हैं, ने इस तेज हुई प्रतिद्वंद्विता को और हवा दी है। नासा के कार्यवाहक प्रशासक सीन डफी ने इस महत्वपूर्ण प्रतिस्पर्धा पर जोर देते हुए दृढ़ता से कहा कि अमेरिका चीन को चंद्रमा पर पहले पहुँचने नहीं देगा। सीनेटर टेड क्रूज़ जैसे अमेरिकी सांसदों ने भी इन चिंताओं को दोहराया है, और "गहरे जोखिम" से बचने के लिए अमेरिका को अंतरिक्ष में एक प्रमुख स्थान सुरक्षित करने की आवश्यकता पर बल दिया है।

यह प्रतिस्पर्धा केवल चंद्रमा पर पहुँचने तक ही सीमित नहीं है, बल्कि उसके मूल्यवान संसाधनों, जैसे दुर्लभ पृथ्वी धातुओं और हीलियम को नियंत्रित करने तक भी फैली हुई है। जबकि चीन की मानवयुक्त अंतरिक्ष एजेंसी ने अमेरिकी चिंताओं को "अनावश्यक" बताकर खारिज कर दिया है और अपने अंतरिक्ष अन्वेषण को "मानवता के लिए एक सामूहिक मिशन" के रूप में प्रस्तुत किया है, अमेरिका एक तकनीकी और रणनीतिक बढ़त हासिल करने के अपने प्रयासों में दृढ़ बना हुआ है। इस बढ़ी हुई जाँच ने चीनी विज्ञान और प्रौद्योगिकी छात्रों के लिए अमेरिकी वीज़ा प्राप्त करना भी और अधिक चुनौतीपूर्ण बना दिया है।

title_src: John Lewis losses nearly triple to £88m
text_src: John Lewis losses nearly triple to £88m But the firm expects to deliver growth in its full-year profits, after the key Christmas season. John Lewis Partnership chair Jason Tarry, said there was "no doubt that consumer confidence is subdued" ahead of the Budget in November. The employee-owned company, whose shops include the John Lewis department stores and Waitrose, said losses before tax and exceptional costs increased to £88m from £30m a year earlier. John Lewis has said its losses nearly tripled in the first half of the year, fuelled by the new cost of dealing with waste packaging and increased National Insurance Contributions (NICs). John Lewis Partnership said it spent £29m on a combination of the new Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) policy - where waste packaging costs have shifted from local government to retailers and producers - as well as higher NICs. It also incurred costs on a long-running programme to turn the business around. The Bank of England has previously said that the EPR levy could add up to 0.5% to food prices if retailers pass the full cost onto customers. The £29m cost in the six months to 26 July was roughly equally split between the packaging levy and employer National Insurance payments. Last year, John Lewis was one of a number of British retailers that warned prices would rises and there would be "inevitable" job losses because of measures announced in last year's Budget which included the change to NICs. Commenting on the outlook for the economy and the upcoming Budget, Mr Tarry said: "There's no doubt consumer confidence is subdued. "We'll focus on what we can control." He is predicting that strong sales in the second half of the financial year, particularly in the run up to Christmas, will allow the company to post a profit in its full-year results. "We are a second half business, no doubt about that. All of our profit is in the second half." He added that the company expects strong sales for Christmas gifts such as wearable tech and Jellycat soft toys. Waitrose sales rose by 6% to £4.1bn, and Mr Tarry said he expected customers would want to treat themselves over the festive period. Total revenue across the partnership increased by 4% to £6.2bn. Mr Tarry said that John Lewis was committed to paying its staff bonus "as soon as we possibly can" but it was "far too early in the year" to say when that would happen. Staff at John Lewis have not received a bonus in three years. John Lewis has made efforts in the past few years to win back customers after the pandemic and increased competition from other retailers. It brought back its Never Knowingly Undersold price promise last year, two years after abandoning it. Commenting on the company's results, Zoe Mills, lead analyst at GlobalData, said this allowed the company to secure a "competitive edge". She added that John Lewis could continue to attract customers by offering staff with good knowledge of their products who can offer trustworthy advice and recommendations in areas like electronics and make-up.
summary_src:
The John Lewis Partnership saw its first-half losses nearly triple to £88m, up from £30m a year earlier, primarily due to new costs from the Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) policy for waste packaging and increased National Insurance Contributions (NICs), totaling £29m. Additional expenses were incurred from a long-running business turnaround program.

Despite this, the employee-owned company, which includes John Lewis department stores and Waitrose supermarkets, anticipates returning to profit for the full financial year, relying on strong sales during the crucial second-half Christmas trading period. Chairman Jason Tarry acknowledged "subdued" consumer confidence ahead of November's Budget but expressed optimism for festive sales, particularly for items like wearable tech and soft toys.

Waitrose sales rose by 6% to £4.1bn, contributing to an overall partnership revenue increase of 4% to £6.2bn. The company reaffirmed its commitment to paying staff bonuses, though it's "far too early in the year" to confirm details, noting that staff have not received a bonus in three years. John Lewis has also been working to regain customers, including reinstating its "Never Knowingly Undersold" price promise, which an analyst believes, alongside knowledgeable staff, provides a "competitive edge."

यहाँ अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

**जॉन लुईस पार्टनरशिप को हुए नुकसान में वृद्धि, त्योहारी बिक्री से वापसी की उम्मीद**

जॉन लुईस पार्टनरशिप को पहली छमाही में हुए नुकसान में लगभग तीन गुना वृद्धि देखने को मिली, जो पिछले साल के 3 करोड़ पाउंड से बढ़कर 8.8 करोड़ पाउंड हो गया। इसका मुख्य कारण कचरा पैकेजिंग के लिए विस्तारित उत्पादक उत्तरदायित्व (ईपीआर) नीति से जुड़ी नई लागतें और बढ़े हुए राष्ट्रीय बीमा योगदान (एनआईसी) रहे, जिनकी कुल राशि 2.9 करोड़ पाउंड थी। इसके अलावा, लंबे समय से चल रहे एक व्यवसाय सुधार कार्यक्रम से भी अतिरिक्त खर्च हुए।

इसके बावजूद, यह कर्मचारी-स्वामित्व वाली कंपनी, जिसमें जॉन लुईस डिपार्टमेंट स्टोर और वेट्रोज़ सुपरमार्केट शामिल हैं, पूरे वित्तीय वर्ष के लिए लाभ में लौटने की उम्मीद कर रही है, जो कि महत्वपूर्ण दूसरी छमाही के क्रिसमस व्यापार अवधि के दौरान मजबूत बिक्री पर निर्भर है। अध्यक्ष जेसन टैरी ने नवंबर के बजट से पहले 'मंद' उपभोक्ता विश्वास को स्वीकार किया, लेकिन त्योहारी बिक्री के लिए आशावाद व्यक्त किया, खासकर वियरेबल टेक और सॉफ्ट टॉयज़ जैसी वस्तुओं के लिए।

वेट्रोज़ की बिक्री 6% बढ़कर 4.1 अरब पाउंड हो गई, जिसने कुल पार्टनरशिप राजस्व में 4% की वृद्धि दर्ज करने में योगदान दिया, जो 6.2 अरब पाउंड तक पहुंच गया। कंपनी ने कर्मचारियों को बोनस देने की अपनी प्रतिबद्धता दोहराई, हालांकि उसने यह भी कहा कि विवरण की पुष्टि के लिए अभी 'साल की शुरुआत' है। उसने यह भी बताया कि कर्मचारियों को तीन साल से बोनस नहीं मिला है। जॉन लुईस ग्राहकों को फिर से हासिल करने के लिए भी काम कर रहा है, जिसमें अपनी 'नेवर नोइंगली अंडरसोल्ड' मूल्य प्रतिज्ञा को फिर से लागू करना शामिल है। एक विश्लेषक का मानना है कि यह प्रतिज्ञा, जानकार कर्मचारियों के साथ मिलकर, एक 'प्रतिस्पर्धात्मक बढ़त' प्रदान करती है।

title_src: The Caribbean islands battling the region's 'highest murder rate'
text_src: The Caribbean islands battling the region's 'highest murder rate' 6 days ago Share Save Gemma Handy Business reporter Share Save Wilkie Arthur, Eagle Legal News The Royal Turks and Caicos Islands Police Force is increasingly having to respond to fatal shootings Jacques Phanor used to sleep with his windows open. Until just a few years ago, the Turks and Caicos Islands were known predominantly as a luxury Caribbean tourist destination. The startling beauty of the archipelago has regularly earned it "world's best beach" titles, and thrust it onto the bucket lists of the globe's most affluent travellers. But alarming levels of violent crime have rocked the once sleepy British Overseas Territory, earning it accolades it welcomes far less. Last year it recorded 48 homicides, which, given its population is less than 50,000, gave it the worst murder rate per capita in Latin America and the Caribbean, according to one study. This year the territory had already recorded 24 killings up to mid-August, heightened by the first mass shooting in its history in July, which left four dead and nine injured. "People are very afraid," Jacques, a church pastor who lives on the main island of Providenciales, tells the BBC. "Some are even leaving. We all love the islands, the economy is good, but the crime environment is terrible." With record-breaking numbers of holidaymakers – almost two million – visiting Turks and Caicos in 2024, the crime does not yet appear to be affecting tourism. But there are fears that unless efforts to curtail it prove successful, crime could threaten its mainstay, estimated to account for at least two-thirds of the economy. Some, including the islands' Premier Washington Misick, have been quick to blame migrants from Haiti, which lies just 90 miles to the south. They flee to Turks and Caicos to escape gang-led turmoil and violence back home. "The crime situation is worse in the Haitian communities [on Turks and Caicos]," concedes Jacques, who was born in Haiti, and moved to Turks and Caicos where he gained citizenship 28 years ago. Most of those slain this year are of Haitian nationality, he says. Jacques and his young family were themselves victims of an armed robbery last December. "We were held at gunpoint by a guy who entered the country illegally on a boat. I am just one example," he adds. Premier Misick dubbed July's mass shooting in a local bar a "gangland-type slaying", and appealed to Haitian community leaders to help "keep these islands safe". "You know who these violent criminals are, you know how guns are getting into the country," he charged. A statement from the Haitian Heritage Association called for a "united front" in stemming the scourge - and lamented "hateful narratives" levelled at Haitian people by some members of the Turks and Caicos public. Some believe the territory's complex citizenship laws have inadvertently created a crucible of disenfranchised Haitian youngsters. Children born in Turks and Caicos struggle to acquire legal status if neither parent has such. As the government grapples to arrest a surging tide of Haitian migrants entering the country illegally by boat, deportation efforts have been stepped up. "They're picking [Haitian] people up on every corner, every street, on the road, at workplaces," Jacques says. "Most of the time the parents want the kids to remain here, rather than go to Haiti [with them], where it's chaos. So they stay with friends, family, church members." "A lot of kids fall through the cracks," adds Jacques. "They turn 18 and try to get a work permit as if they were a foreigner. Often they're turned down even for those." The country's proximity to Haiti is "both a blessing and a curse", he believes. "They need migrant workers to keep up with development, but Haiti's violence is spilling over to Turks and Caicos." Recently implemented anti-crime efforts include temporary curfews, tighter controls on establishments selling alcohol, and increased search powers for police. Meanwhile, a crackdown on informal settlements that police say harbour criminals saw more than 220 shanty homes bulldozed in August. Tourism provides the bulk of Turks and Caicos' revenues, bringing in $250m (£186m) during the first half of the 2024-2025 financial year. But while the country has seen rapid development over the past two decades, not everyone has reaped its benefits, says local reporter Wilkie Arthur. "Many people don't even want to be in gangs, they just can't find work. We need to empower them so they won't have to rob someone for a couple of dollars," he says. "A lot of gang members have legal status here, and there's also a number of local boys involved. Blaming it all on Haitians is not a good representation of the truth." Wilkie knows all too well the plight of young men existing on the margins of society. An ex-convict himself, he previously served 11 years behind bars for the armed robbery of a jewellery store. Since his release in 2023 he now tries to steer others away from crime. He agrees that too many young people of Haitian origin are finding themselves in legal limbo when they finish school. "They have no proper documents so the gangs recruit them, feed them so they become loyal to them, and then the gangs just get bigger. "Every graduating year, a lot of the kids don't have proper documents. Some are very bright and take their education seriously, but what do they do if they want to eat and survive?" Getty Images Turks and Caicos' visual appeal to holidaymakers is obvious Turks and Caicos is not alone in experiencing an upsurge in gang violence in recent years. A 2024 United Nations report spoke of an "intensification of organised crime and … lethal violence" across the Caribbean region. It said surging drug production in South America, which often passes through the Caribbean on its way to the US and Europe, and the high availability of firearms, had "contributed to soaring homicide rates". It named Jamaica, St Lucia and Trinidad as particular areas for concern. Yet the report added that "only a handful of the hundreds of gangs" in the Caribbean were active in trafficking drugs and guns to the US and elsewhere. Instead it said "most gangs in the Caribbean" were "typically parochial, and focused instead on protecting their territory". It added that the gangs were more often involved in local drug dealing, prostitution, scams, extortion, disrupting elections and securing government contracts. Wilkie Arthur Wilkie Arthur served 11 years in prison and now tries to steer others away from crime
summary_src:
The Turks and Caicos Islands, once a serene luxury tourist destination, are now grappling with an escalating violent crime crisis, recording the highest per capita murder rate in Latin America last year with 48 homicides. Residents, like Pastor Jacques Phanor, express profound fear, with some even leaving the territory following a surge in fatal shootings, including its first mass shooting in July.

While the islands' vital tourism industry remains robust, there are significant fears that unchecked crime could soon jeopardize this economic mainstay. Premier Washington Misick has largely attributed the rise in violence to migrants from Haiti, citing the high number of Haitian nationals among the victims and appealing to Haitian community leaders for assistance.

However, the situation is complex. Critics, including the Haitian Heritage Association and local reporter Wilkie Arthur (a former convict now working to deter youth from crime), highlight how the territory's intricate citizenship laws create a class of disenfranchised Haitian-born youth who, lacking legal status and opportunities, become vulnerable to gang recruitment. Aggressive deportation efforts, though aimed at illegal migration, inadvertently exacerbate this issue by separating families and leaving unsupported children. Arthur also points out that a significant number of local youth and those with legal status are involved in gangs, often driven by a lack of economic opportunity despite the islands' rapid development.

The crime surge in Turks and Caicos reflects a wider regional problem, with a 2024 UN report noting an "intensification of organised crime and lethal violence" across the Caribbean, partly fueled by increasing drug production in South America. In response, TCI authorities have implemented strict anti-crime measures, including temporary curfews, tighter alcohol controls, increased police powers, and the demolition of informal settlements. The core challenge for the islands remains balancing the need for migrant workers with controlling violence, and effectively integrating and empowering all youth to prevent them from falling into crime.
summary_tgt:
तुर्क एंड कैकोस द्वीप समूह, जो कभी एक शांत विलासिता वाला पर्यटन स्थल था, अब एक बढ़ते हिंसक अपराध संकट से जूझ रहा है। पिछले साल लैटिन अमेरिका में इसकी प्रति व्यक्ति हत्या दर सबसे अधिक रही, जहाँ 48 हत्याएँ हुईं। पादरी जैक्स फनोर जैसे निवासी गहरा डर व्यक्त करते हैं, कुछ लोग तो जुलाई में अपनी पहली सामूहिक गोलीबारी सहित घातक गोलीबारी में वृद्धि के बाद क्षेत्र छोड़ भी रहे हैं।

हालांकि द्वीप समूह का महत्वपूर्ण पर्यटन उद्योग मजबूत बना हुआ है, फिर भी गंभीर आशंकाएं हैं कि अनियंत्रित अपराध जल्द ही इस आर्थिक आधार को खतरे में डाल सकता है। प्रीमियर वाशिंगटन मिसिक ने हिंसा में वृद्धि का श्रेय बड़े पैमाने पर हैती के प्रवासियों को दिया है, पीड़ितों में हैती के नागरिकों की उच्च संख्या का हवाला देते हुए सहायता के लिए हैती समुदाय के नेताओं से अपील की है।

हालांकि, स्थिति जटिल है। हैती हेरिटेज एसोसिएशन और स्थानीय रिपोर्टर विल्की आर्थर (एक पूर्व अपराधी जो अब युवाओं को अपराध से दूर रखने का काम कर रहा है) सहित आलोचकों ने इस बात पर प्रकाश डाला है कि क्षेत्र के जटिल नागरिकता कानून हैती में जन्मे युवाओं का एक वंचित वर्ग कैसे बनाते हैं, जिनके पास कानूनी दर्जा और अवसर न होने के कारण वे गिरोहों में भर्ती होने के प्रति संवेदनशील हो जाते हैं। आक्रामक निर्वासन के प्रयास, हालांकि अवैध प्रवासन को लक्षित करते हैं, अनजाने में परिवारों को अलग करके और बच्चों को बिना सहारे के छोड़कर इस मुद्दे को और बढ़ा देते हैं। आर्थर यह भी बताते हैं कि बड़ी संख्या में स्थानीय युवा और कानूनी दर्जा वाले लोग भी गिरोहों में शामिल हैं, जो अक्सर द्वीप समूह के तेजी से विकास के बावजूद आर्थिक अवसरों की कमी से प्रेरित होते हैं।

तुर्क एंड कैकोस में अपराध में वृद्धि एक व्यापक क्षेत्रीय समस्या को दर्शाती है, जिसमें 2024 की संयुक्त राष्ट्र की एक रिपोर्ट में कैरिबियन में "संगठित अपराध और घातक हिंसा के बढ़ने" का उल्लेख किया गया है, जिसका आंशिक कारण दक्षिण अमेरिका में बढ़ती मादक पदार्थों का उत्पादन है। जवाब में, टीसीआई अधिकारियों ने कड़े अपराध-विरोधी उपाय लागू किए हैं, जिनमें अस्थायी कर्फ्यू, शराब पर सख्त नियंत्रण, पुलिस शक्तियों में वृद्धि और अनौपचारिक बस्तियों का विध्वंस शामिल है। द्वीप समूह के लिए मुख्य चुनौती प्रवासी श्रमिकों की आवश्यकता और हिंसा को नियंत्रित करने के बीच संतुलन बनाना, साथ ही सभी युवाओं को अपराध में पड़ने से रोकने के लिए उन्हें प्रभावी ढंग से एकीकृत और सशक्त बनाना है।
