title_src: Jay Wynne, former BBC weather presenter, dies aged 56
text_src: Jay Wynne, former BBC weather presenter, dies aged 56 2 days ago Share Save Annabel Rackham Culture reporter Share Save BBC Jay Wynne joined the corporation in 2000 Former BBC Weather presenter Jay Wynne died in June at the age of 56 after a long-term illness, his brother has confirmed to BBC News. Wynne joined BBC Weather in October 2000 and was a regular forecaster on BBC News at Ten. "Jay had a gift for gentle clarity, making his forecasts for sometimes complex weather systems feel accessible and engaging," his brother, Matthew, said in a tribute. "A keen skier, golfer and musician, Jay enjoyed travelling to pursue his sporting interests," Matthew Wynne added. "We will miss his wisdom, generosity and dry sense of humour." Liz Howell, former Head of BBC Weather sent condolences to his family and friends, and added: "I am deeply saddened to hear this news. "Jay blazed a trail to bring greater diversity to weather forecasting and was a pleasure to work with. He had his own distinctive style of presenting the weather story which was very popular with audiences." Some of Wynne's colleagues have also paid tribute, with BBC weather presenter Simon King posting on X: "Such a lovely bloke and brilliant broadcaster. Always a joy to be on shift with him and his wicked sense of humour. Good memories". Sarah Keith-Lucas also posted about the "sad news", writing: "Jay was a huge part of our weather team for so many years and will be hugely missed". These sentiments were echoed by another colleague, Matt Taylor, who said the news had "hit us all hard" on the weather team. "Jay was a great broadcaster, talented musician, enthusiastic golfer, and a good friend," he added. Checking for accuracy
summary_src:
Former BBC weather presenter Jay Wynne died in June after a long-term illness, his brother has confirmed.

Wynne joined BBC Weather in October 2000, becoming a regular forecaster on BBC News at Ten, where he was celebrated for his "gift for gentle clarity," making complex weather systems accessible and engaging. His brother, Matthew, also remembered him as a keen skier, golfer, and musician who enjoyed travelling.

The family's statement highlighted his "wisdom, generosity and dry sense of humour." Liz Howell, former Head of BBC Weather, sent condolences, while colleagues remembered him as someone who "blazed a trail to bring greater diversity" to weather forecasting and possessed a distinctive, popular presenting style.

Fellow presenters Simon King, Sarah Keith-Lucas, and Matt Taylor expressed deep sadness and shock, remembering Wynne as a "lovely bloke," a "brilliant broadcaster," a "good friend," and a vital part of the weather team, praising his "wicked sense of humour."
summary_tgt:
**जे वायने: बीबीसी के पूर्व मौसम प्रस्तुतकर्ता का लंबी बीमारी के बाद निधन**

बीबीसी के पूर्व मौसम प्रस्तुतकर्ता जे वायने का लंबी बीमारी के बाद जून में निधन हो गया, उनके भाई ने इसकी पुष्टि की है।

वायने अक्टूबर 2000 में बीबीसी वेदर से जुड़े और बीबीसी न्यूज़ एट टेन पर नियमित पूर्वानुमानकर्ता बन गए। उन्हें "अपनी सहज और स्पष्ट व्याख्या की ख़ासियत" के लिए सराहा गया, क्योंकि वह जटिल मौसम प्रणालियों को सुलभ और आकर्षक बनाते थे। उनके भाई, मैथ्यू ने उन्हें एक उत्साही स्कीयर, गोल्फर और संगीतकार के रूप में भी याद किया, जिन्हें यात्रा करना पसंद था।

परिवार के बयान में उनकी "बुद्धिमत्ता, उदारता और शुष्क हास्यबोध" की सराहना की गई। बीबीसी वेदर की पूर्व प्रमुख लिज़ हॉवेल ने संवेदना व्यक्त की, जबकि सहयोगियों ने उन्हें ऐसे व्यक्ति के रूप में याद किया जिन्होंने मौसम पूर्वानुमान में "अधिक विविधता लाने का मार्ग प्रशस्त किया" और जिनकी प्रस्तुति शैली विशिष्ट व लोकप्रिय थी।

साथी प्रस्तुतकर्ता साइमन किंग, सारा कीथ-लुकास और मैट टेलर ने गहरा दुख और सदमा व्यक्त किया। उन्होंने वायने को एक "प्यारा शख्स", "शानदार प्रसारक", "अच्छा दोस्त" और मौसम टीम का एक महत्वपूर्ण हिस्सा बताते हुए उनके "अद्भुत हास्यबोध" की प्रशंसा की।
meta_description: Jay Wynne joined BBC Weather in October 2000 and was a regular forecaster on BBC News at Ten.

title_src: Kolkata: The Indian city that sparkles like Paris at night
text_src: The Indian city that sparkles like Paris at night 6 hours ago Share Save Sandip Roy Kolkata, Writer Share Save Mudar Patherya The 157-year-old General Post Office (GPO) building remains one of the city's most recognisable landmarks As the air-conditioned bus weaves through the bustling traffic of the eastern Indian city of Kolkata, tour leader Sujoy Sen lists the many sights on the itinerary. It sounds like a snapshot of the city's cosmopolitan history - colonial buildings like the General Post Office and the former British viceroy's mansion, Hindu and Jain temples, Greek Orthodox and Portuguese churches, an Anglican cathedral, the homes of freedom fighters who fought the British Raj and Indian merchants who prospered under it. But unlike most heritage tours, this one happens after sundown. And its main focus is not just the history or architecture but the lights illuminating the buildings. Kolkata Illumination Project is the latest addition to the city's many heritage tours and walks. Mr Sen, who runs a tour company, chanced upon a newspaper article about city enthusiasts lighting up some of the city's grand but often neglected heritage buildings. He obtained a list of buildings and went to check them out. "I was stunned," he says. "I have seen Paris by night. I didn't realise Kolkata could be like that also. I wanted other people to see it as well." Himanjali Sankar, born and raised in Kolkata, now living in Delhi, joined the tour. She says the buildings themselves are familiar to her but the illumination changes them. "It is like they are coming alive, reclaiming their grandeur." The project is the brainchild of a citizens' group called Kolkata Restorers. "But it's not a real organisation. There is no committee, no president. It's just a label. A WhatsApp group," says Mudar Patherya, the force behind the endeavour. Mudar Patherya Built in the early 20th century by an Armenian builder, Queens Mansion is a heritage landmark Mudar Patherya Raj Bhavan, formerly the Governor's House, is one of Kolkata's grandest colonial-era buildings He says he didn't start out with plans to light up the city. He came upon an old market crowned with a grand dome and a broken clock that had numerals in Bengali, the language most commonly spoken in the city. An avowed Kolkata evangelist, he wanted to paint the dome and raised the money for it from friends and associates. "But then I realised while it looked good during the day, in the evening it could not be seen at all," he says. "So I again passed the hat around and raised money to illuminate it." He ended up with some funds left over. So he also lit up a temple tucked away in a storied north Kolkata neighbourhood. The temple's intricately carved stone facade came alive in the soft yellow glow of the LED lights in a way it could not in harsh sunlight. Mr Patherya was hooked. Within weeks he had lined up the imposing British neoclassical colonial building housing the Geological Survey of India. Soon he got permission to light up one of the city's most famous addresses - Raj Bhavan, the governor's mansion, once the residence of the British viceroy. "In about 21 months we are at about 92 buildings," he says. "The model is simple. It's your property, my lights. You only pay for the electricity and I work out that cost in advance." Getting the light intensity right required trial and error, says lighting designer Suyash Narsaria. Mudar Patherya Burhani Masjid, with its striking domes and minarets, is one of the city's prominent mosques for Bohra Muslims Mudar Patherya The brightly lit up Kalachand temple in north Kolkata "We reduced the wattage to make it more efficient, changed the positions, put lighting in layers to highlight columns, railings and murals." But as the project expanded, Mr Patherya realised there was one problem he had not foreseen, beyond squirrels chewing through the wires. The buildings were often in a state of disrepair and the illumination highlighted that. Before they could illuminate, they needed to be repaired and restored. For example, the 150-year-old Hogg Market, a huge Gothic market where one can find everything from parrots to hyperlocal Bandel cheese and Christmas cakes from a Jewish bakery. But the clock on its clock tower had stopped working. They found the roof had worn away and the floorboards had rotted in the rains. The tower had to be repaired first. But it's not easy to fix clocks that are over a century old. Luckily, Mr Patherya found the man who could help him. Swapan Dutta, a fourth-generation clock repairer, traces his lineage back to a great-grandfather who worked as a clock technician for the British-era firm Cooke and Kelvey. Mr Dutta, nicknamed 'Ghari-babu' or Clock-man, is excited to work on the Hogg Market clock, which he calls the star of Kolkata's tower clocks. It's a clock that chimes every fifteen minutes, a different tune for every quarter hour, a sound the city has not heard in years. Mudar Patherya The Dalhousie area, the seat of government and the site of many of the illuminated buildings Mudar Patherya The Angel of Victory atop Kolkata's Victoria Memorial - a 16-ft bronze figure designed to rotate with the wind. "These clocks had stopped working for years...We have to examine them, make calculations and reconstruct all the missing parts," says Mr Dutta sitting in his tiny workshop. But he is confident Kolkata's tower clocks will chime again. Mr Dutta has already repaired over half a dozen clocks for Mr Patherya, in churches, a synagogue and old markets. What Kolkata Restorers are really trying to restore are not buildings but a sense of pride in the city. Once the capital of British India, the city's fortunes have waned since independence. Its eclectic mix of neoclassical, Gothic and Art Deco architecture is fast disappearing, as old houses give way to apartments and malls - the land valued more than the heritage, with owners unable to maintain what remains. "Mostly we talk about how Kolkata is not keeping up with the times," says Himanjali Sankar. "It is wonderful to see people who are excited and passionate about the city and its buildings." But in a city anxious to woo business, heritage is often dismissed as an expensive luxury and a low priority. Mudar Patherya The clock tower of the Maghen David Synagogue - one of the city's most prominent Jewish landmarks Bishan Samaddar Returned Letter Office - a striking red-brick colonial building that once handled undeliverable mail in Kolkata
summary_src:
Kolkata is undergoing a nocturnal transformation, now sparkling "like Paris at night" thanks to the "Kolkata Illumination Project." This initiative, driven by an informal citizens' group called "Kolkata Restorers" and spearheaded by Mudar Patherya, aims to light up the city's grand, often neglected, colonial-era buildings, temples, and markets.

Patherya began by illuminating a market dome, quickly realizing the power of nighttime lighting. His project rapidly expanded, reaching 92 buildings in just 21 months, operating on a simple model: "your property, my lights," with property owners covering electricity costs. The project has amazed locals like tour operator Mr. Sen and resident Himanjali Sankar, who describe the illuminated structures as "coming alive" and "reclaiming their grandeur."

However, the illumination revealed a critical unforeseen challenge: many heritage buildings were in disrepair. This led the project to evolve beyond lighting, prompting restoration efforts. For instance, the iconic 150-year-old Hogg Market required extensive repairs, including its clock tower, which had stopped working. Swapan Dutta, a fourth-generation clock repairer, is now diligently restoring these century-old tower clocks, promising to bring back sounds the city hasn't heard in years.

Ultimately, "Kolkata Restorers" aims to do more than just light up buildings; they seek to restore a sense of pride in the city's rich heritage, which, since its days as the capital of British India, has often been dismissed as an "expensive luxury" amidst aspirations for modern development.
summary_tgt:
**कोलकाता इल्युमिनेशन प्रोजेक्ट: शहर का रात में कायापलट और विरासत का पुनरुद्धार**

कोलकाता में एक रात का कायापलट हो रहा है, जो अब 'कोलकाता इल्युमिनेशन प्रोजेक्ट' की बदौलत 'रात में पेरिस की तरह' जगमगा रहा है। यह पहल एक अनौपचारिक नागरिक समूह 'कोलकाता रेस्टोरर्स' द्वारा संचालित है और इसका नेतृत्व मुदार पाथेरिया कर रहे हैं। इसका उद्देश्य शहर की भव्य, अक्सर उपेक्षित, औपनिवेशिक काल की इमारतों, मंदिरों और बाज़ारों को रोशन करना है।

पाथेरिया ने एक बाज़ार के गुंबद को रोशन करके इसकी शुरुआत की और जल्द ही रात की रोशनी की शक्ति को महसूस किया। उनका यह प्रोजेक्ट तेज़ी से फैला और सिर्फ़ 21 महीनों में 92 इमारतों तक पहुँच गया। यह एक सरल मॉडल पर काम करता है: 'आपकी संपत्ति, मेरी रोशनी', जिसमें संपत्ति मालिक बिजली का खर्च उठाते हैं। इस प्रोजेक्ट ने टूर ऑपरेटर श्री सेन और निवासी हिमांजलि शंकर जैसे स्थानीय लोगों को चकित कर दिया है, जो रोशन की गई इमारतों को 'जीवित हो उठना' और 'अपनी भव्यता पुनः प्राप्त करना' बताते हैं।

हालांकि, रोशनी ने एक गंभीर अप्रत्याशित चुनौती को उजागर किया: कई विरासत इमारतें जर्जर हालत में थीं। इससे यह प्रोजेक्ट रोशनी से आगे बढ़कर, पुनर्स्थापन के प्रयासों को प्रेरित करने लगा। उदाहरण के लिए, प्रतिष्ठित 150 साल पुराने हॉग मार्केट को व्यापक मरम्मत की आवश्यकता थी, जिसमें उसका घड़ी का टावर भी शामिल था, जिसने काम करना बंद कर दिया था। स्वपन दत्ता, जो चौथी पीढ़ी के घड़ी मरम्मत करने वाले हैं, अब इन सदियों पुरानी टावर घड़ियों को लगन से बहाल कर रहे हैं। वे उन आवाज़ों को वापस लाने का वादा कर रहे हैं जो शहर ने सालों से नहीं सुनी हैं।

अंततः, 'कोलकाता रेस्टोरर्स' सिर्फ़ इमारतों को रोशन करने से कहीं ज़्यादा करना चाहते हैं; उनका लक्ष्य शहर की समृद्ध विरासत में गौरव की भावना को पुनः स्थापित करना है, जिसे ब्रिटिश भारत की राजधानी होने के बाद से, आधुनिक विकास की आकांक्षाओं के बीच अक्सर एक 'महंगी विलासिता' के रूप में खारिज कर दिया गया है।
meta_description: In 21 months, citizens have lit up 92 Kolkata landmarks with a simple model: your property, their lights.

title_src: Christy review: Sydney Sweeney's dramatic transformation can't fix 'clichéd' boxing biopic
text_src: Sydney Sweeney's remarkable transformation into champion boxer Christy Martin can't fix the film's flaws nor distract from the star's real-life persona. Sydney Sweeney trained for months, muscled up, and put on 30lb (13.6kg) to play Christy Martin, a real-life champion boxer with a dramatic personal story. She wears a dark wig and brown contact lenses. And yet it is impossible to forget that she is Sydney Sweeney in the cliché-ridden biopic Christy, as our hyperawareness of her off-screen image distracts us from what's going on in the film, which premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival this week. A contradiction at the heart of Christy is that Sweeney is the main reason anyone is paying attention to the project, but her own high-profile celebrity makes it difficult to believe her as the character. Can she ever escape the real-life chatter around her? The film pushes a lot of buttons, offering everything from an archetypal sports underdog to an actor's remarkable physical change The actress has been the centre of often unpleasant publicity, especially in recent months. There was a notable kerfuffle about her American Eagle ads, with the tag line "Sydney Sweeney has great jeans", which some took as a reference to Aryan genes. Then Donald Trump praised her for being a registered Republican. And The Hollywood Reporter wondered where her career would go "after being in the centre of the storm". That's not the kind of baggage any actor wants to be carrying on screen, but with Sweeney it's impossible to put aside right now. More like this: • Charli XCX shines in quirky film debut • The Gaza docudrama leaving audiences 'distraught' • A House of Dynamite is 'more terrifying than horror' It doesn't help that for almost all of its running time, David Michôd's film is just one more underdog sports story. It charts Christy Martin's rise to the top as a pioneer of women's boxing in the 1990s, prioritising the predictable sports story over her much more fascinating personal drama. Christy trains with and soon marries Jim Martin, a controlling bully 25 years her senior, with a laughable comb-over. He is played by Ben Foster, who successfully disappears into his role as a thoroughly despicable person. Martin is condescending, telling Christy, "Maybe there is something to this lady boxing business." He realises she is gay but forces her into the closet, saying, "Nobody wants to see a butch girl fight."
summary_src:
Sydney Sweeney's new film, "Christy," premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival, showcasing her remarkable physical transformation into real-life champion boxer Christy Martin, a role for which she gained 30lb (13.6kg) and trained for months.

Despite Sweeney's dedication, the biopic is criticized for its cliché-ridden narrative and inability to overcome the star's high-profile, often controversial, real-life persona. Her celebrity, amplified by recent publicity including an "Aryan genes" ad kerfuffle and a Donald Trump endorsement, creates an inescapable "baggage" that makes it difficult for audiences to see her purely as the character.

David Michôd's film chronicles Martin's rise as a pioneer of women's boxing in the 1990s, but prioritizes a predictable sports underdog story over her more compelling personal drama. Central to this is her relationship with controlling husband and trainer, Jim Martin, 25 years her senior, into whose despicable role Ben Foster successfully disappears. Jim is depicted as condescending and manipulative, forcing Christy into the closet upon discovering her sexuality, declaring, "Nobody wants to see a butch girl fight."

Ultimately, Sweeney's significant physical effort and performance are deemed insufficient to fix the film's flaws or fully distract from the ongoing public chatter surrounding her.
summary_tgt:
सिडनी स्वीनी की नई फिल्म, "क्रिस्टी", का प्रीमियर टोरंटो इंटरनेशनल फिल्म फेस्टिवल में हुआ, जिसमें उन्होंने वास्तविक जीवन की चैंपियन मुक्केबाज़ क्रिस्टी मार्टिन के रूप में अपना उल्लेखनीय शारीरिक परिवर्तन प्रदर्शित किया। इस भूमिका के लिए उन्होंने 30 पाउंड (13.6 किलोग्राम) वज़न बढ़ाया और महीनों तक प्रशिक्षण लिया।

स्वीनी के समर्पण के बावजूद, इस बायोपिक की आलोचना इसकी घिसी-पिटी कहानी और अभिनेत्री की हाई-प्रोफाइल, अक्सर विवादास्पद, वास्तविक जीवन की छवि पर हावी न हो पाने के लिए की गई है। उनकी प्रसिद्धि, जिसे हाल ही में "आर्यन जीन्स" विज्ञापन विवाद और डोनाल्ड ट्रम्प के समर्थन सहित प्रचार से और बल मिला है, एक ऐसा अपरिहार्य "बोझ" पैदा करती है जिससे दर्शकों के लिए उन्हें पूरी तरह से किरदार के रूप में देख पाना मुश्किल हो जाता है।

डेविड मिशोड की यह फिल्म 1990 के दशक में महिला मुक्केबाज़ी की एक अग्रणी के रूप में मार्टिन के उत्थान का वर्णन करती है, लेकिन यह उनकी अधिक दिलचस्प व्यक्तिगत कहानी के बजाय एक अनुमानित स्पोर्ट्स अंडरडॉग कहानी को प्राथमिकता देती है। इसके केंद्र में उनके नियंत्रणकारी पति और ट्रेनर, जिम मार्टिन के साथ उनका रिश्ता है, जो उनसे 25 साल बड़े हैं, और जिनकी घृणित भूमिका में बेन फोस्टर पूरी तरह से समा गए हैं। जिम को अहंकारी और जोड़-तोड़ करने वाले के रूप में चित्रित किया गया है, जो क्रिस्टी की लैंगिकता का पता चलने पर उन्हें अपनी पहचान छिपाने के लिए मजबूर करता है, यह कहते हुए कि, "कोई भी मर्दाना दिखने वाली लड़की को लड़ते हुए नहीं देखना चाहता।"

अंततः, स्वीनी का महत्वपूर्ण शारीरिक प्रयास और प्रदर्शन फिल्म की खामियों को ठीक करने या उनके इर्द-गिर्द चल रही सार्वजनिक चर्चा से पूरी तरह विचलित करने के लिए अपर्याप्त माने गए हैं।
meta_description: Sydney Sweeney's remarkable transformation into champion boxer Christy Martin can't fix the film's flaws nor distract from the star's real-life persona.

title_src: Severance season 2 review: The dystopian office drama 'works the same magic but is even more mind-bending'
text_src: When it premiered in 2022, Apple TV+'s surreal workplace show was a hit. Now it's finally back – and from the playful storytelling to the layered performances, there's a lot to savour. In the second season of Severance, one character spends hours practising how to put paper clips on properly (apparently there's a right and a wrong way). Other characters find a room full of goats in their office building, and out of the office someone finds a working phone booth on the street, as if that's an everyday thing. Yet viewers of season one of the series – among the most bracing and imaginative of recent years – know that its bizarro world is also relatable to anyone who has ever been bored at their job. With a perfect balance of the real and surreal, the show follows four employees who sort numbers floating on their computer screens at Lumon Industries, and who chose to have a chip put in their brains that cuts their memories in half. The person working inside the office, called the innie, has no knowledge of who they are beyond its walls – and their outside counterpart, or outie, has no memory of the working day. Identity crisis doesn't begin to describe it. The show's creator, Dan Erickson, was inspired by wishing that his tedious office temp job while he was a struggling screenwriter could zoom by as if it never happened, and his idea of being able to turn off your brain resonates especially well in our age of information overload. That twist on the familiar office-show premise is a great hook. But the series' true alchemy, and the secret of its success and acclaim, is how well it builds our emotional attachment to the characters in Lumon's Macrodata Refinement Department, who now realise they have made a terrible mistake. The cast makes them so credible that it's easy to empathize with the grief-stricken widower Mark (Adam Scott), fussy and lovelorn Irving (John Turturro), rebellious Helly (Britt Lower), and Dylan (Zach Cherry), an office drone who seemed hapless until he wasn't. Some series shake things up radically between seasons, but this is a seamless continuation that works the same magic with even more mind-bending turns. The plot picks up five months after the cliffhanging events we last saw, when Dylan stayed behind at Lumon Industries and laboriously held a switch that allowed the other three to briefly access their work memories while outside. Mark discovered that his wife, Gemma, might actually be alive, and is someone he encountered without recognising at work. Irv is an artist who for some reason has documents about Lumon employees hidden in his apartment. Most startling of all, Helly is Helena Eagan, heir to the Lumon fortune, who has undergone "severance", as the process is called, as a public display of confidence in it.
summary_src:
Apple TV+'s acclaimed surreal workplace drama, "Severance," which premiered in 2022, has returned for its highly anticipated second season, offering more playful storytelling and layered performances.

The series centers on employees at the mysterious Lumon Industries who volunteer for a surgical procedure called "severance," bifurcating their memories: a work-only "innie" has no knowledge of their outside life, and an outside-only "outie" has no memory of their workday. This bizarro yet relatable premise, inspired by creator Dan Erickson's wish for tedious jobs to "zoom by," explores profound identity crises and the universal experience of workplace boredom.

The show's critical success stems from its seamless blend of the real and surreal, and its remarkable ability to build deep emotional attachment to its credible characters, such as the grief-stricken widower Mark (Adam Scott) and the fussy, lovelorn Irving (John Turturro).

Season two picks up five months after the dramatic cliffhanger, seamlessly continuing with even more mind-bending turns. Viewers will see characters grappling with bizarre office occurrences like a room full of goats or intricate paper clip training, alongside major plot developments. Mark discovers his supposedly deceased wife, Gemma, may be alive and working at Lumon, while Irving is revealed to be an artist with hidden company documents. Lumon heir Helena Eagan's own public severance further highlights the procedure's impact.

यहाँ अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद दिया गया है:

Apple TV+ का बहुचर्चित अतियथार्थवादी कार्यस्थल ड्रामा, "सेवरेंस", जो 2022 में प्रीमियर हुआ था, अपने बहुप्रतीक्षित दूसरे सीज़न के लिए लौट आया है, जिसमें अधिक चंचल कहानी और गहन प्रदर्शन देखने को मिलेंगे।

यह सीरीज़ रहस्यमय ल्यूमन इंडस्ट्रीज़ के उन कर्मचारियों पर केंद्रित है जो "सेवरेंस" नामक एक शल्य चिकित्सा प्रक्रिया के लिए स्वेच्छा से आगे आते हैं। यह प्रक्रिया उनकी यादों को दो हिस्सों में बांट देती है: एक "इन्नी" (जो केवल काम के लिए है) को अपने बाहरी जीवन की कोई जानकारी नहीं होती, और एक "आउट्टी" (जो केवल बाहरी दुनिया के लिए है) को अपने कार्यदिवस की कोई याद नहीं रहती। निर्माता डैन एरिक्सन की नीरस नौकरियों के "तेज़ी से गुज़र जाने" की इच्छा से प्रेरित यह विचित्र फिर भी संबंधित लगने वाला आधार, गहन पहचान संकटों और कार्यस्थल पर ऊबने के सार्वभौमिक अनुभव की पड़ताल करता है।

इस शो की आलोचनात्मक सफलता का श्रेय यथार्थ और अतियथार्थ के इसके सहज मिश्रण को जाता है, साथ ही यह अपने विश्वसनीय पात्रों, जैसे शोकग्रस्त विधुर मार्क (एडम स्कॉट) और झक्की, प्रेम में पड़े इरविंग (जॉन टर्टुरो) के प्रति गहरी भावनात्मक लगाव पैदा करने की उल्लेखनीय क्षमता रखता है।

दूसरा सीज़न नाटकीय क्लाइमेक्स के पाँच महीने बाद शुरू होता है, और भी अधिक दिमाग घुमा देने वाले मोड़ के साथ सहजता से आगे बढ़ता है। दर्शक प्रमुख कथानक विकासों के साथ-साथ पात्रों को विचित्र कार्यालयी घटनाओं, जैसे बकरियों से भरा एक कमरा या जटिल पेपर क्लिप प्रशिक्षण से जूझते हुए देखेंगे। मार्क को पता चलता है कि उसकी कथित मृत पत्नी जेम्मा जीवित हो सकती है और ल्यूमन में काम कर रही है, जबकि इरविंग एक कलाकार के रूप में सामने आता है जिसके पास कंपनी के गुप्त दस्तावेज़ हैं। ल्यूमन की उत्तराधिकारी हेलेना ईगन का स्वयं का सार्वजनिक "सेवरेंस" इस प्रक्रिया के प्रभाव को और भी उजागर करता है।
meta_description: When it premiered in 2022, Apple TV+'s surreal workplace show was a hit. Now it's finally back – and from the playful storytelling to the layered performances, there's a lot to savour.

title_src: Coldplay get giddy as they smash Wembley Stadium record
text_src: Coldplay get giddy as they smash Wembley Stadium record 1 day ago Share Save Mark Savage Music correspondent Share Save Getty Images The band are taking a break after smashing box office records on their latest tour Coldplay celebrated the end of their record-breaking 10-show run at Wembley Stadium with a dazzling, multi-coloured night of musical magic. Playing hits from every era of their 25-year career, they filled the stadium with light, and even indulged themselves with a giddy version of Whitney Houston's I Wanna Dance With Somebody. "This is the song I warm up to in the car park," joked singer Chris Martin. The show closed the latest leg of their Music Of The Spheres Tour, which has circled the world four times since 2022. It is now the highest-attended tour in history, with more than 13m tickets sold. On stage, Martin promised it would resume "somewhere in southern Africa in about 18 months". Friday's show was held almost a week late, after a strike by London transport workers forced the band to postpone. "I know it caused a lot of inconvenience for a lot of you," Martin told the crowd. "In return we're going to play a show fifteen times better than any show we've ever played before. That's the pledge." They might not have achieved that goal - Coldplay have already set themselves a ridiculously high bar - but this was stadium stagecraft at its absolute finest. Getty Images Coldplay are the first band to power a concert at Wembley Stadium entirely by renewable energy with no generator use. The concert is a sensory overload, full of LED writstbands, raining confetti, laser lights, spinning inflatables, 3D glasses that turn everything into hearts and stars, and even a brief puppet show (the operators, Drew and Nicolette, happily got engaged during last Saturday's concert). Martin is the glue that holds it together. He bounds across the stage like a puppy - or is it a youth pastor? - covering the length of the catwalk several times within the first few songs. His plan isn't just to bridge the gap between the band and the audience, it's to dismantle it entirely. "I see you," he says repeatedly, identifying uber-fans at the front and distant figures in the vertigo seats. "I see you over here with a Brazilian flag. And I see you, too, in the top corner with lights on your bodies. You look like you're from the movie Tron." It's a schtick, for sure, but it fosters an incredible sense of unity. Those LED wristbands play a huge part, too, making everyone in the audience part of a giant tapestry of light. And there's a communal euphoria in singing along to hits like Paradise, The Scientist, Yellow and Sky Full of Stars. After the first 30 minutes, I realised that I'd barely looked at the giant screens above the stage. The audience is the show. Coldplay The Wembley concerts alone were attended by more than 800,000 people That's a contrast to most stadium concerts, where the message is more like: "Look upon me, puny mortals, and be astonished by my divine talents and somewhat improbable physique." Coldplay don't bother with any of that. Martin's bandmates Guy Berryman, Will Champion and Jonny Buckland would rather that no-one noticed them at all. Instead, they'd rather make a fuss over their special guests. In London, that means Venezuela's Simón Bolívar Orchestra - a group of youth players who've supported the band at all of their Wembley dates. They come out twice, for Viva La Vida and feelslikeimfallinginlove, twirling their cellos and jumping up and down as they provide the stirring string accompaniment. Palestinian-Chilean singer Elyanna, meanwhile, hogs the spotlight during We Pray, hitting some quite extraordinary high notes. Who has played the most shows at Wembley Stadium? Getty Images Coldplay - 16 nights on the Music of the Spheres tour, 2022-25* Taylor Swift - Eight nights on the Eras tour, 2024 Take That - Eight nights on the Progress tour, 2011 Oasis - Seven nights on the Live '25 tour, 2025 Michael Jackson - Seven nights on the Bad tour, 1988 * Including six nights in 2022 and 10 nights in 2025 Getty Images Coldplay formed in London in the late 1990s, initially under the name Starfish Musically, Coldplay's set-list is stacked. There's a thrilling version of Clocks that shudders with discordant guitar riffs before resolving into a powerful chorus; and an extended acoustic version of Sparks has fans swooning. Something Just Like This, an abominable song on record, becomes a euphoric mini-rave on stage; while Fix You is simply majestic. With the tour about to go on hiatus (or maybe because he keeps self-administering throat spray) Martin is on whimsical form. He describes Coldplay as "the third best soft rock band in London"; randomly sings the opening lines of Wonderwall; and, during Paradise, invokes the dancehall star Shaggy, for no discernible reason. "That song was by Shaggy," he declares, inaccurately. Towards the end of the show, he stops everything to celebrate Buckland's 48th birthday, presenting the guitarist with a Lego Batmobile and promising, "I'll give you £1m if you build it before Fix You". Then, preparing to play the album track Jupiter for the first time, he announces: "This could be terrible. But if it is terrible, don't worry, we're going to play Yellow in a minute. "Will Champion could fart in the microphone, as long as we play Yellow." Coldplay were the first group to use LED wristbands at their concerts, and the technology has evolved to allow incredibly sophisticated light shows Martin later admits that his sense of humour "gets me into trouble every day". But not as much trouble as married tech CEO Andy Byron, who was caught in a loving embrace with his HR executive on the giant screens of a Coldplay concert in the US earlier this year. The moment - during part of the show where Martin serenades audience members with an improvised song - went viral, and has reportedly led to at least one divorce. So when the jumbotron section of the show starts on Friday, Martin issues a tongue-in-cheek disclaimer. "Whatever happens here, stays here. Guaranteed. So if you've just embezzled the company funds, come on camera now. It's fine." Before long, a young couple flashes up on the screen. "Holy crap, don't put me through this again," the singer grimaces, only agreeing to play a song after they've flashed their wedding rings at the camera. Coldplay The band are due to take a well-deserved break The spontaneity and humour is part of what makes every Coldplay show unique, even when most of the set is painstakingly planned out. On Friday, fans at the final London date showed their appreciation. During the final encore of All My Love, thousands of them unfolded paper red hearts and held them above their heads - the culmination of a secret online project organised by a German fan called Hannah. It was a bittersweet moment. Fans know the band have a long break planned. And even if they use their gap year to make new music, Martin has announced it will be their penultimate album. "The Coldplay catalogue, as it were, finishes," after 12 records he told BBC Radio 2's Jo Whiley in 2021. "After that I think we will only tour." On tonight's evidence, it doesn't matter. They could play the same setlist for the next 100 years and fans would flock to every show. See you there. Coldplay setlist
summary_src:
Coldplay recently wrapped up a triumphant 10-show residency at Wembley Stadium, concluding the latest leg of their record-breaking "Music Of The Spheres" Tour. The tour has sold over 13 million tickets globally, becoming the highest-attended in history, and the band is now taking a hiatus before resuming in Southern Africa in approximately 18 months.

The Wembley concerts were hailed as a dazzling, multi-sensory experience, showcasing hits from their 25-year career, an impromptu Whitney Houston cover, and innovative stagecraft. Notably, they were the first band to power a Wembley show entirely by renewable energy. Frontman Chris Martin served as the energetic "glue," actively engaging with the audience through personalized greetings and whimsical humor. His dynamic stage presence aimed to dismantle the traditional barrier between band and crowd, fostering a "communal euphoria" enhanced by interactive LED wristbands that turned the audience into a vibrant tapestry of light.

The shows also featured special guests, including Venezuela's Simón Bolívar Orchestra and Palestinian-Chilean singer Elyanna. Martin even playfully referenced a viral jumbotron incident from a previous show, issuing a humorous disclaimer about events staying within the venue.

The final London performance, postponed from an earlier date due to a transport strike, culminated in a bittersweet moment as fans collectively displayed red paper hearts during the final encore, a gesture organized by a German fan. Looking to the future, Martin revealed that their next album will be their penultimate, after which Coldplay plans to focus exclusively on touring.

यहां अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

कोल्डप्ले ने हाल ही में वेम्बली स्टेडियम में 10 शानदार शो की श्रंखला सफलतापूर्वक संपन्न की, जो उनके रिकॉर्ड-ब्रेकिंग "म्यूजिक ऑफ द स्फियर्स" टूर के नवीनतम चरण का समापन था। इस टूर के दुनिया भर में 1.3 करोड़ से अधिक टिकट बिक चुके हैं, जिससे यह इतिहास में सबसे अधिक दर्शक-उपस्थित टूर बन गया है। बैंड अब लगभग 18 महीनों के लिए विराम ले रहा है, जिसके बाद वे दक्षिणी अफ्रीका में फिर से अपना प्रदर्शन शुरू करेंगे।

वेम्बली कॉन्सर्ट्स को एक शानदार, बहु-संवेदी अनुभव के रूप में सराहा गया, जिसमें उनके 25 साल के करियर के हिट गाने, व्हिटनी ह्यूस्टन का एक तात्कालिक कवर और अभिनव मंच-कला का प्रदर्शन किया गया। गौरतलब है कि वे पहले ऐसे बैंड थे जिन्होंने वेम्बली में अपने शो को पूरी तरह से नवीकरणीय ऊर्जा से संचालित किया। फ्रंटमैन क्रिस मार्टिन ने एक ऊर्जावान सूत्रधार की भूमिका निभाई, दर्शकों के साथ व्यक्तिगत शुभकामनाओं और मनमौजी हास्य के माध्यम से सक्रिय रूप से जुड़े रहे। उनकी गतिशील मंच उपस्थिति का उद्देश्य बैंड और दर्शकों के बीच की पारंपरिक बाधा को तोड़ना था, जिससे एक 'सामुदायिक उत्साह' पैदा हो सके। इसे इंटरैक्टिव एलईडी रिस्टबैंड ने और बढ़ा दिया, जिसने दर्शकों को प्रकाश की एक जीवंत छटा में बदल दिया।

इन शो में विशेष अतिथि भी शामिल थे, जिनमें वेनेजुएला का साइमन बोलिवार ऑर्केस्ट्रा और फिलिस्तीनी-चिली गायिका इलियाना प्रमुख थीं। मार्टिन ने मज़ाकिया अंदाज़ में पिछले शो की एक वायरल जंबोट्रॉन घटना का भी ज़िक्र किया और हास्यपूर्ण चेतावनी दी कि घटनाएँ स्थल के भीतर ही रहें।

परिवहन हड़ताल के कारण पहले की तारीख से स्थगित किया गया लंदन का अंतिम प्रदर्शन एक भावुक क्षण में समाप्त हुआ, जब प्रशंसकों ने अंतिम एनकोर के दौरान सामूहिक रूप से लाल कागज़ के दिल प्रदर्शित किए। यह भाव एक जर्मन प्रशंसक द्वारा आयोजित किया गया था। भविष्य के लिए मार्टिन ने खुलासा किया कि उनका अगला एल्बम उनका दूसरा अंतिम एल्बम होगा, जिसके बाद कोल्डप्ले पूरी तरह से केवल टूरिंग पर ध्यान केंद्रित करने की योजना बना रहा है।

title_src: You just fight with your brain': How F1 driver Niki Lauda survived a devastating Grand Prix crash
text_src: The F1 champion Niki Lauda had a horrifying accident in Germany in August 1976, 49 years ago this week. He was not expected to live, let alone race again. After defying all expectations, he told the BBC in 1977 how he willed himself to stay alive. When Formula 1 racing driver Niki Lauda spoke to the BBC in 1977, his face bore testimony to the trauma he had endured during the German Grand Prix. Trapped inside the burning wreckage of his smashed Ferrari on the Nürburgring circuit, Lauda had been badly scarred and had lost part of his ear to the flames. But the Austrian driver confessed to having no recollection of the crash that almost cost him his life on 1 August 1976. "When I had the accident, I must have got a big bang on my head, and I lost the memory for I don't know, the last three minutes. And the following 20 minutes after the accident," he told the BBC just a year later. Warning: This article contains injury details that some may find disturbing or upsetting. When Lauda took part in the race, he was the reigning F1 world champion, having won his first title the year before. The 1976 season was shaping up to be a dramatic one, as Lauda and his rival, British driver James Hunt, battled it out for the top spot. (Their friendship and rivalry would become the subject of the Ron Howard film Rush in 2013, starring Daniel Brühl as Lauda and Chris Hemsworth as Hunt.) Lauda had already secured five wins going into the German Grand Prix, and was on course to clinch the world champion title again. But the sport was shockingly dangerous. By 1976, 63 drivers had been killed in Grand Prix motor racing, and on average one to two drivers were dying every season.
summary_src:
F1 champion Niki Lauda suffered a horrific, near-fatal accident at the Nürburgring circuit in Germany in August 1976. Trapped in the burning wreckage of his Ferrari, he sustained severe injuries, including facial trauma and losing part of his ear. Doctors initially gave him mere hours to live, and he was not expected to race again.

However, Lauda, who later told the BBC he "willed myself to stay alive," defied all expectations, making a remarkable recovery despite confessing to having no recollection of the crash itself, only remembering a "big bang on my head" and being in a "state of shock" for the immediate aftermath.

At the time of the incident, Lauda was the reigning F1 world champion, having secured five wins and leading the 1976 season in a fierce rivalry with British driver James Hunt. The accident tragically underscored the shocking dangers of Grand Prix racing, a sport that had claimed 63 drivers' lives by 1976. Lauda's incredible comeback and his legendary rivalry with Hunt were later dramatized in the 2013 Ron Howard film, "Rush."
summary_tgt:
अगस्त 1976 में, F1 चैंपियन निकी लाउडा जर्मनी के नर्बर्गिंग सर्किट में एक भयानक, लगभग जानलेवा दुर्घटना का शिकार हो गए। अपनी जलती हुई फेरारी के मलबे में फंसे होने के कारण, उन्हें चेहरे पर गंभीर चोट और कान का कुछ हिस्सा खोने सहित गंभीर चोटें आईं। डॉक्टरों ने शुरू में उन्हें कुछ ही घंटों का मेहमान बताया था, और उनके फिर से रेसिंग करने की कोई उम्मीद नहीं थी।

हालांकि, लाउडा, जिन्होंने बाद में बीबीसी को बताया कि उन्होंने "खुद को जीवित रहने के लिए मजबूर किया", सभी उम्मीदों को धता बताते हुए एक उल्लेखनीय वापसी की। उन्होंने कबूल किया कि उन्हें दुर्घटना खुद याद नहीं थी, बस "मेरे सिर पर एक जोरदार धमाका" और तुरंत बाद की स्थिति में "सदमे की स्थिति" में होना याद था।

इस घटना के समय, लाउडा मौजूदा F1 विश्व चैंपियन थे, जिन्होंने पांच जीत हासिल की थीं और ब्रिटिश ड्राइवर जेम्स हंट के साथ कड़ी प्रतिद्वंद्विता में 1976 के सीज़न में आगे चल रहे थे। इस दुर्घटना ने ग्रैंड प्रिक्स रेसिंग के चौंकाने वाले खतरों को दुखद रूप से रेखांकित किया, एक ऐसा खेल जिसने 1976 तक 63 ड्राइवरों की जान ले ली थी। लाउडा की अविश्वसनीय वापसी और हंट के साथ उनकी महान प्रतिद्वंद्विता को बाद में 2013 की रॉन हॉवर्ड की फिल्म "रश" में नाटकीय रूप दिया गया।
meta_description: The F1 champion Niki Lauda had a near-fatal accident in Germany in August 1976. After defying all expectations, he told the BBC in 1977 how he willed himself to stay alive.

title_src: It provoked a fierce public debate': The 1957 homosexuality report that divided the UK
text_src: When the Wolfenden Report was published 68 years ago this week, it pushed for decriminalising male homosexuality – but it also led to a crackdown on sex workers. Sir John Wolfenden was unprepared for the backlash that his dry, academic 155-page government report would provoke. "All sorts of people said all sorts of things, and all sorts of people wrote all sorts of things on the pavement outside our house," he told BBC radio. "I have from one religious sect an official curse. Typed." He was surprised by how "violent" the press reaction was: "I didn't expect it to make as much splash as it did." When The Report of the Departmental Committee on Homosexual Offences and Prostitution – better known as the Wolfenden Report – came out on 4 September 1957, it flew off the shelves, selling out its first print run of 5,000 copies within hours. It also provoked a fierce public debate in Britain, contrary to what the government had hoped. WATCH: 'We are concerned primarily with public order and not with private morality'. Home Secretary Sir David Maxwell Fyfe had been prompted to set up the committee by the government's discomfort with two issues. The first was the visibility of sex workers on London's streets, the second was the rising number of men arrested for homosexual acts, which were illegal at the time in the UK. This rise had been triggered by Maxwell Fyfe's own policy of the deliberate entrapment and arrest of gay men by the police.
summary_src:
Sixty-eight years ago this week, on September 4, 1957, the landmark Wolfenden Report was published, advocating for the decriminalization of male homosexuality while also leading to a crackdown on sex workers. Authored by Sir John Wolfenden, the "Report of the Departmental Committee on Homosexual Offences and Prostitution" was commissioned by Home Secretary Sir David Maxwell Fyfe. This was prompted by government discomfort over the increasing visibility of sex workers and a rise in arrests for homosexual acts—a surge partly attributed to Maxwell Fyfe's own policy of police entrapment.

Despite its dry, academic nature and Wolfenden's stated principle of focusing on "public order and not with private morality," the report triggered an unexpectedly "violent" and widespread public backlash and press uproar. It sold out its initial print run within hours but also earned Wolfenden personal condemnation, including a religious curse.
summary_tgt:
अड़सठ साल पहले इसी सप्ताह, 4 सितंबर, 1957 को, ऐतिहासिक वुल्फेंडेन रिपोर्ट प्रकाशित हुई थी, जिसने पुरुष समलैंगिकता को अपराध की श्रेणी से बाहर करने की वकालत की, लेकिन साथ ही सेक्स वर्करों पर शिकंजा कसने का भी कारण बनी। सर जॉन वुल्फेंडेन द्वारा लिखित, "समलैंगिक अपराधों और वेश्यावृत्ति पर विभागीय समिति की रिपोर्ट" गृह सचिव सर डेविड मैक्सवेल फ़ाइफ़ के आदेश पर तैयार की गई थी।

यह पहल सरकार की उस असहजता के कारण हुई थी जो सेक्स वर्करों की बढ़ती दृश्यता और समलैंगिक कृत्यों के लिए गिरफ़्तारियों में वृद्धि से उपजी थी—एक ऐसी वृद्धि जिसे आंशिक रूप से मैक्सवेल फ़ाइफ़ की अपनी पुलिस द्वारा जाल बिछाकर फँसाने की नीति का परिणाम माना जाता है।

अपनी नीरस, अकादमिक प्रकृति और वुल्फेंडेन के इस घोषित सिद्धांत के बावजूद कि इसका ध्यान "सार्वजनिक व्यवस्था पर है, न कि निजी नैतिकता पर," इस रिपोर्ट ने अप्रत्याशित रूप से "हिंसक" और व्यापक जन आक्रोश तथा प्रेस में हंगामा खड़ा कर दिया। इसकी पहली छपाई कुछ ही घंटों में बिक गई, लेकिन वुल्फेंडेन को व्यक्तिगत निंदा का भी सामना करना पड़ा, जिसमें एक धार्मिक अभिशाप भी शामिल था।
meta_description: When the Wolfenden Report was published 68 years ago this week, it pushed for decriminalising male homosexuality – but it also led to a crackdown on sex workers.

title_src: I know about hit songs, hit numbers, hit sounds': The man who turned The Beatles into superstars
text_src: As their manager, Epstein formed a deeply personal connection with The Beatles, especially Lennon. It was Epstein who was Lennon's best man when he married his first wife Cynthia Powell in 1962, paying for their celebratory meal afterwards and providing his flat on Falkner Street in Liverpool for the couple to live in rent-free while they had their first child, Julian. "I think they're all great people, and I really mean that," Epstein told Grundy. "It was recently written about me that I probably enjoy best the company of my artists, and I think that's quite true, actually. It was written in a context where I don't have much of a social life and that most of my time is spent with my artists." Within 10 months of Epstein starting to manage The Beatles, they had released their first single, Love Me Do. In March 1963, their second single, Please Please Me, from their album of the same name, would reach number one in the UK charts. By the end of 1963, Epstein was negotiating to secure The Beatles their first US television appearance on Ed Sullivan's top-rated CBS entertainment show. The band's February 1964 performance would prove to be a cultural watershed, drawing some 73 million viewers. There was an explosion of fan hysteria, with The Beatles simultaneously holding the top five positions on the Billboard chart by April. The talent was theirs, but he gave them every opportunity to use it – Mark Lewisohn But in the years that followed, as The Beatles grew ever more successful internationally, Epstein's personal life became increasingly chaotic. To cope with his workload, he began to take stimulants, which he would then balance with sedatives to help him sleep. By the end of 1966, the band themselves were fatigued and decided to stop touring. Throughout 1967, while The Beatles worked on their groundbreaking Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band album, Epstein would be in and out of a private clinic in London, the Priory, in an attempt to deal with his drug dependency. But he would still keep up his demanding schedule, leaving the Priory to host the Sgt Pepper's launch party at his Belgravia, London home in May 1967, and negotiating for The Beatles to perform of All You Need Is Love for 400 million viewers in 25 countries on the world's first satellite television link. A little over a month after his father died, Epstein was found dead at the age of 32 in August 1967, having taken what was ruled to be an accidental drug overdose. The Beatles were left reeling. While the wisdom of some of his business decisions has been questioned, not least by The Beatles themselves, he had kept the band on track. "I knew that we were in trouble then," John Lennon told Rolling Stone's Jann Wenner in a 1970 interview. Lennon believed that Epstein's death had triggered the band's disintegration. "I didn't really have any misconceptions about our ability to do anything other than play music, and I was scared. I thought, 'We've had it now.'" Less than three years after his death, The Beatles had broken up.
summary_src:
Brian Epstein, the visionary manager of The Beatles, played a pivotal and deeply personal role in the band's meteoric rise to global stardom before his untimely death in 1967.

Establishing a close bond, particularly with John Lennon – for whom he served as best man and provided housing – Epstein viewed his artists as his primary social circle, stating he "probably enjoy best the company of my artists."

His astute management quickly transformed the band's prospects. Within 10 months of taking the helm, The Beatles released their first single, "Love Me Do," followed by the UK chart-topping "Please Please Me" in March 1963. Epstein was instrumental in securing their iconic U.S. television debut on "The Ed Sullivan Show" in February 1964, a cultural watershed viewed by 73 million and initiating "Beatlemania," with the band soon dominating the Billboard charts.

However, the immense pressure took its toll on Epstein's personal life, which grew increasingly chaotic. He relied on a regimen of stimulants and sedatives and frequently sought treatment at private clinics, even as the band themselves became fatigued and ceased touring by late 1966.

In August 1967, at just 32 years old, Epstein died from an accidental drug overdose, shortly after hosting the launch party for "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band." His death left The Beatles reeling, with John Lennon later stating he "knew we were in trouble then" and attributing the band's subsequent disintegration – which occurred less than three years later – to Epstein's absence.

Despite some later criticisms of his business decisions, Epstein is widely credited for keeping the band focused and enabling their extraordinary talent to reach the world.
summary_tgt:
बीटल्स के दूरदर्शी प्रबंधक ब्रायन एपस्टीन ने 1967 में अपनी असामयिक मृत्यु से पहले बैंड को वैश्विक स्टारडम तक पहुंचाने में एक केंद्रीय और बेहद व्यक्तिगत भूमिका निभाई।

उन्होंने जॉन लेनन के साथ एक गहरा संबंध स्थापित किया, जिनके वे बेस्ट मैन भी बने और जिन्हें उन्होंने आवास भी प्रदान किया। एपस्टीन अपने कलाकारों को अपना प्राथमिक सामाजिक दायरा मानते थे, उन्होंने कहा था कि "मैं शायद अपने कलाकारों की संगति का सबसे अधिक आनंद लेता हूँ।"

उनके कुशल प्रबंधन ने बैंड की संभावनाओं को तेज़ी से बदल दिया। बागडोर संभालने के 10 महीनों के भीतर, बीटल्स ने अपना पहला एकल गीत "लव मी डू" जारी किया, जिसके बाद मार्च 1963 में यूके चार्ट में शीर्ष पर रहने वाला "प्लीज प्लीज मी" आया। फरवरी 1964 में "द एड सुलिवन शो" में उनके प्रतिष्ठित अमेरिकी टेलीविजन पदार्पण को सुनिश्चित करने में एपस्टीन की महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका थी। यह एक सांस्कृतिक मोड़ था जिसे 73 मिलियन लोगों ने देखा और इसने "बीटलमेनिया" की शुरुआत की, जिसके साथ बैंड ने जल्द ही बिलबोर्ड चार्ट पर अपना दबदबा बना लिया।

हालांकि, इस भारी दबाव ने एपस्टीन के निजी जीवन पर बुरा असर डाला, जो तेज़ी से अस्त-व्यस्त होता चला गया। वह उत्तेजक और शामक दवाओं के एक नियम पर निर्भर रहने लगे और अक्सर निजी क्लीनिकों में इलाज के लिए जाते थे, जबकि बैंड खुद भी थक चुका था और 1966 के अंत तक उसने दौरा करना बंद कर दिया था।

अगस्त 1967 में, मात्र 32 वर्ष की आयु में, एपस्टीन की "सार्जेंट पेपर'स लोनली हार्ट्स क्लब बैंड" के लॉन्च पार्टी की मेजबानी करने के तुरंत बाद आकस्मिक ड्रग ओवरडोज से मृत्यु हो गई। उनकी मृत्यु से बीटल्स को गहरा सदमा लगा, जॉन लेनन ने बाद में कहा कि "मुझे पता था कि हम तब मुश्किल में थे" और बैंड के बाद के विघटन - जो तीन साल से भी कम समय बाद हुआ - का कारण एपस्टीन की अनुपस्थिति को बताया।

उनके व्यावसायिक निर्णयों की कुछ बाद की आलोचनाओं के बावजूद, एपस्टीन को बैंड को केंद्रित रखने और उनकी असाधारण प्रतिभा को दुनिया तक पहुंचाने में सक्षम बनाने का व्यापक रूप से श्रेय दिया जाता है।
meta_description: Brian Epstein guided the Fab Four from the Cavern Club to global fame. When he died 58 years ago this week, the band was left suddenly adrift.

title_src: The aircraft spiralled downwards, tail first': The CIA spy shot down over Russia in 1960
text_src: On 19 August 1960, 65 years ago this week, a court in Moscow handed a US pilot, Francis Gary Powers, a 10-year sentence after he was apprehended by Soviet security forces. The BBC reported on what became a Cold War diplomatic disaster. Francis Gary Powers was on a CIA spying mission over Soviet Russia when his U-2 plane was hit by a surface-to-air missile. "I looked up, looked out, and just everything was orange, everywhere," Powers recalled. "I don't know whether it was the reflection in the canopy itself or just the whole sky. And I can remember saying to myself, 'By God, I've had it now.'" In fact, Powers managed to parachute to safety, but his troubles were far from over. Having been arrested and interrogated by the KGB, he was put on trial in Moscow, where his family could only watch helplessly. "He said that he knew that we were present at his trial," his wife Barbara Powers told the BBC. "He didn't know beforehand. But he saw me wave. And he said he just couldn't bear to look towards the box where we were all sitting, because it upset him too much, and he knew it would upset us." On 19 August 1960, 65 years ago this week, Powers was sentenced to 10 years – three in a Russian prison and seven in a labour camp. His capture and trial would have a devastating impact on East-West relations at the height of the Cold War. Powers was 30 at the time. A coal miner's son from Kentucky, US, he studied chemistry and biology before joining the US Air Force in 1950. In 1956, he was recruited by the CIA to pilot U-2 spy planes over enemy territory. These U-2s could fly at 70,000ft (21.3km), which was supposedly above the range of Soviet defences, and yet the cutting-edge camera on board could take detailed photographs of military installations far below. On 1 May 1960, Powers took off from Peshawar, Pakistan, with a brief to fly across the USSR and land in Norway. "The planned route would take us deeper into Russia than we had ever gone, while traversing important targets never before photographed," he wrote in his memoir, Operation Overflight.
summary_src:
The 1960 capture and trial of US pilot Francis Gary Powers became a major Cold War diplomatic disaster, significantly worsening East-West relations. Powers, a former US Air Force pilot recruited by the CIA in 1956 to fly U-2 spy planes at 70,000ft over enemy territory, was on a mission to photograph Soviet military installations when his plane was hit by a surface-to-air missile on May 1, 1960.

Powers managed to parachute to safety but was immediately apprehended by Soviet security forces. Following interrogation by the KGB, he was put on trial in Moscow, a distressing event for his wife who was present. On August 19, 1960, Powers was sentenced to 10 years—three in a Russian prison and seven in a labor camp.
summary_tgt:
1960 में अमेरिकी पायलट फ्रांसिस गैरी पावर्स की गिरफ्तारी और उन पर चला मुकदमा एक बड़ी शीत युद्ध राजनयिक आपदा बन गया, जिसने पूर्व और पश्चिम के संबंधों को काफी खराब कर दिया। पावर्स, जो अमेरिकी वायु सेना के पूर्व पायलट थे, उन्हें 1956 में CIA ने दुश्मन के इलाके में 70,000 फीट की ऊंचाई पर U-2 जासूसी विमान उड़ाने के लिए भर्ती किया था। वह सोवियत सैन्य प्रतिष्ठानों की तस्वीरें लेने के मिशन पर थे, जब 1 मई, 1960 को उनके विमान को एक सतह से हवा में मार करने वाली मिसाइल ने निशाना बनाया।

पावर्स सुरक्षित पैराशूट से उतरने में कामयाब रहे, लेकिन उन्हें तुरंत सोवियत सुरक्षा बलों ने पकड़ लिया। KGB द्वारा पूछताछ के बाद, उन पर मॉस्को में मुकदमा चलाया गया, जो वहां मौजूद उनकी पत्नी के लिए एक दुखद घटना थी। 19 अगस्त, 1960 को, पावर्स को 10 साल की सजा सुनाई गई – जिसमें तीन साल रूसी जेल में और सात साल एक श्रम शिविर में बिताने थे।
meta_description: On 19 August 1960, a Moscow court handed a US airman, Francis Gary Powers, a 10-year sentence. The BBC reported on what became a Cold War diplomatic disaster.

title_src: Daisy May and Charlie Cooper announce new BBC series Nightwatch
text_src: This Country stars go ghost hunting in new series Charlie and Daisy May Cooper are best known for BBC mockumentary series This Country A new factual entertainment series from Daisy May and Charlie Cooper is to air on BBC Two and iPlayer. The six-part series called Nightwatch will see the Gloucestershire-born siblings, who are best known for the BBC mockumentary series This Country, locked in some of the reputedly most haunted places in the country. The first location to appear on screen is the closed down HMP Gloucester. Future episodes will see them in an old pub frequented by highwaymen in Cannock Chase, bat infested ruins and a cinema in York. Each episode will last 30 minutes, with a release date yet to be announced.
summary_src:
Stars of the BBC mockumentary "This Country," siblings Charlie and Daisy May Cooper, are set to launch a new factual entertainment series called "Nightwatch." The six-part series, airing on BBC Two and iPlayer, will see the Gloucestershire-born duo locked overnight in some of the country's most reputedly haunted locations. Each episode will last 30 minutes.

The first episode will feature the closed-down HMP Gloucester. Future episodes will include an old pub frequented by highwaymen in Cannock Chase, bat-infested ruins, and a cinema in York. A release date for "Nightwatch" is yet to be announced.
summary_tgt:
बीबीसी की मॉक्यूमेंटरि 'दिस कंट्री' के सितारे, भाई-बहन चार्ली और डेज़ी मे कूपर, 'नाइटवॉच' नामक एक नई फ़ैक्चुअल एंटरटेनमेंट सीरीज़ लॉन्च करने जा रहे हैं।

बीबीसी टू और आईप्लेयर पर प्रसारित होने वाली यह छह-एपिसोड की सीरीज़ ग्लॉस्टरशायर में जन्मे इन दोनों कलाकारों को देश के कुछ सबसे कथित तौर पर भूतिया स्थानों पर रात भर बंद रखेगी। प्रत्येक एपिसोड 30 मिनट का होगा।

पहले एपिसोड में बंद हो चुकी एचएमपी ग्लॉस्टर (जेल) को दिखाया जाएगा। आने वाले एपिसोड में कैनॉक चेज़ का एक पुराना पब (जहां डाकू अक्सर आते-जाते थे), चमगादड़ों से भरे खंडहर और यॉर्क का एक सिनेमाघर जैसी जगहें भी शामिल होंगी।

'नाइटवॉच' की रिलीज़ की तारीख अभी तक घोषित नहीं की गई है।
meta_description: The show follows the siblings as they are locked in some of the most haunted places in the country.

title_src: Artist to protest Wallsal's leather museum relocation plans
text_src: Artist to protest leather museum relocation plans Vicky Roden says she plans to stand up and perform a one hour monologue She wants the museum to stay where it is and is planning to make her protest at the town's MakerFest event, which showcases artisan goods and food, on Saturday. That proposal was put on hold, but Vicky Roden said she is concerned the decision will be reviewed for the coming financial year. Last year, Walsall Council said it wanted to move it from its current location on Littleton Street West to an unconfirmed council-owned building in the town centre. An artist is planning to demonstrate against proposals to relocate a town's leather museum at a major cultural event. Ms Roden said the museum was important to the town and also to her personally. She said: "Being able to access this locally and without financial cost meant I was able to go there when feeling low and find something to relate to at some of the worst points in my life." On Saturday, she plans to stand on a soapbox at 14:00 BST to deliver an hour-long "impassioned public speech about the value of culture and heritage in Walsall". She said her aim was to "raise awareness of the incredibly shaky future of both Walsall Leather Museum and museum services in Walsall". The museum, which celebrates the town's leather-making history, is based in a Victorian building that was once a leather-making factory. It explains the leatherworking process, featuring artefacts from local people and telling personal stories. The council proposal to move it to a new location could save the council £190,000, but following protests it was halted in February by former leader Garry Perry. Ms Roden said the protests earlier in the year had been a "magnificent display of people power". She said she now wanted the council to be transparent about the plans and what could happen next. MakerFest, which the council describes as a "vibrant celebration of the creativity and talent" attracted more than 50,000 people into the town centre last year. A spokesperson for Walsall Council said: "While we fully respect the right to peaceful protest, it's disappointing that a protest may occur during MakerFest this Saturday." It said a lot of planning had gone into the day and it added: "Discussions regarding Walsall Leather Museum are ongoing, and we hope Vicky and all our residents will continue to engage with us."
summary_src:
Artist Vicky Roden is planning a public protest at Walsall's major cultural event, MakerFest, this Saturday to oppose the potential relocation of the Walsall Leather Museum. The museum, housed in a historic Victorian leather factory, celebrates the town's rich leather-making heritage and holds significant cultural and personal value, offering free local access.

Walsall Council had previously proposed moving the museum from its Littleton Street West location to an unconfirmed council-owned building to save £190,000, but these plans were halted in February following public outcry. However, Roden fears the decision may be revisited for the upcoming financial year and demands transparency from the council regarding its future.

She plans to deliver a one-hour monologue on a soapbox at 2 PM BST, aiming to raise awareness about the "incredibly shaky future" of the museum and local museum services. While Walsall Council respects the right to peaceful protest, a spokesperson expressed disappointment that it would occur during MakerFest, a "vibrant celebration" attracting over 50,000 people. The council stated that discussions regarding the museum are ongoing and encouraged continued engagement.
summary_tgt:
**कलाकार विक्की रोडन इस शनिवार को वॉलसॉल के प्रमुख सांस्कृतिक कार्यक्रम मेकरफेस्ट में एक सार्वजनिक विरोध प्रदर्शन की योजना बना रही हैं, जिसका उद्देश्य वॉलसॉल लेदर म्यूज़ियम के संभावित स्थानांतरण का विरोध करना है। यह संग्रहालय, जो एक ऐतिहासिक विक्टोरियन चमड़े के कारखाने में स्थित है, शहर की समृद्ध चमड़ा बनाने की विरासत का सम्मान करता है और महत्वपूर्ण सांस्कृतिक तथा व्यक्तिगत मूल्य रखता है, साथ ही स्थानीय लोगों को निःशुल्क पहुँच प्रदान करता है।**

**वॉलसॉल परिषद ने पहले संग्रहालय को उसके लिटलटन स्ट्रीट वेस्ट स्थान से एक अज्ञात परिषद-स्वामित्व वाली इमारत में स्थानांतरित करने का प्रस्ताव दिया था, ताकि £190,000 की बचत की जा सके, लेकिन सार्वजनिक विरोध के बाद फरवरी में इन योजनाओं पर रोक लगा दी गई थी। हालांकि, रोडन को डर है कि आगामी वित्तीय वर्ष के लिए इस निर्णय पर फिर से विचार किया जा सकता है, और वह परिषद से इसके भविष्य के संबंध में पारदर्शिता की मांग करती हैं।**

**वह ब्रिटिश समयानुसार दोपहर 2 बजे एक सोपबॉक्स (ऊंचे मंच) पर एक घंटे का एकालाप (मोनोलॉग) प्रस्तुत करने की योजना बना रही हैं, जिसका उद्देश्य संग्रहालय और स्थानीय संग्रहालय सेवाओं के "बेहद अनिश्चित भविष्य" के बारे में जागरूकता बढ़ाना है। वॉलसॉल परिषद शांतिपूर्ण विरोध के अधिकार का सम्मान करती है, वहीं उसके एक प्रवक्ता ने निराशा व्यक्त की कि यह विरोध मेकरफेस्ट के दौरान होगा, जो 50,000 से अधिक लोगों को आकर्षित करने वाला एक "जीवंत उत्सव" है। परिषद ने बताया कि संग्रहालय के संबंध में चर्चाएँ जारी हैं और उसने निरंतर जुड़ाव को प्रोत्साहित किया।**

title_src: Eurovision: UK should withdraw if Israel takes part
text_src: UK should withdraw from Eurovision if Israel takes part - Phil Coulter 2 days ago Share Save Claire Quinn BBC News NI Share Save Getty Images Phil Coulter has written or co-written several songs for Eurovision, including the UK's winning 1967 song Puppet on a String, which was sampled last year by Jade Thirlwall in Angel of my Dreams The UK should withdraw from Eurovision 2026 if Israel participates, musician and songwriter Phil Coulter has said. This would follow the lead of the Irish broadcaster, RTÉ, which has said it will not take part if Israel does "given the ongoing and appalling loss of lives in Gaza". Mr Coulter said he was "100% behind RTÉ" in their decision to withdraw from the contest, and that people in the UK and Ireland are both "disgusted by what's going on in Gaza". He has written or co-written several songs for Eurovision, including the UK's winning song "Puppet on a String" in 1967, which singer Jade Thirlwall used a sample of in a song last year. The BBC has declined to comment. RTÉ will make a final decision once the Eurovision organiser, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), makes its decision. The Netherlands has joined the potential boycott and other nations have confirmed they are considering it, depending on the EBU's decision. Nicky Stevens, from British band and Eurovision 1976 winner Brotherhood of Man, said while she is horrified by what is happening in Gaza, it would be "a shame" for politics to be "brought into" Eurovision. "Let's all get together for one night and just focus on the music," she said. Bambie Thug, Ireland's Eurovision entry in 2024, echoed Mr Coulter's sentiment. "I fully support RTE's decision to not take part in the 2026 Eurovision Song Contest and I hope this can set an example for other countries," they said. Last year, Bambie Thug was one of a number of contestants to complain of a "tense" and "horrible" atmosphere backstage. After the grand final, Bambie Thug also accused Israel's national broadcaster, Kan, of "inciting violence" against them during its coverage. Kan said the Israeli delegation faced an "unprecedented display of hatred" from other countries and their entrants. EPA Yuval Raphael flew the flag for Israel at this year's song contest in Switzerland Speaking to BBC Radio Ulster's Good Morning Ulster programme, Mr Coulter said he feels "very strongly" about Ireland not participating in Eurovision if Israel does, due to the ongoing conflict in Gaza. "Musicians, songwriters and performers are human beings with consciences. "I think the only sensible thing and the only decent thing for RTÉ to do is to withdraw from the contest if Israel is allowed to perform." He said there was a "double standard" that Israel was being allowed to participate whereas Russia was expelled from the 2022 contest due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. "What's the difference between that tragic event and what's happening in Gaza?" Mr Coulter asked. He also said that the BBC should take a similar position to RTÉ and not participate in next year's Eurovision. "I think it is a question of conscience, and as RTÉ have made this step - it reflects the feeling of the general public and I'm quite sure that throughout the United Kingdom people are equally disgusted by what's going on in Gaza," Mr Coulter told the programme. Asked later to clarify whether he meant the BBC should withdraw if Israel continues to participate, he said yes. Next year's contest will be held in May in Vienna. Dutch broadcaster AVROTROS announced on Friday that it will also boycott next year's contest if Israel is included. Spain and Slovenia are considering similar moves, while a spokeswoman for the Finnish national broadcaster said a decision regarding the broadcaster's participation in next year's Eurovision will be "made in December". "Israel's participation in Eurovision has been a significant topic of discussion in Finland," she said. "The humanitarian situation in Gaza is tragic, and we sincerely hope for an end to the suffering as soon as possible." A spokesman for Iceland's national broadcaster said its involvement in the 2026 contest was "subject to the outcome of the ongoing consultation process within the EBU, due to the participation of the Israeli state broadcaster KAN in the competition" and that they "reserve the right to withdraw from participation in it if the EBU does not respond satisfactorily". In a statement on Thursday, RTÉ said: "It is RTÉ's position that Ireland will not take part in the 2026 Eurovision Song Contest, if the participation of Israel goes ahead, and the final decision regarding Ireland's participation will be made once the EBU's decision is made". It added: "RTÉ is also deeply concerned by the targeted killing of journalists in Gaza, the denial of access to international journalists to the territory, and the plight of the remaining hostages." Ireland has won the contest seven times in total, most recently in 1996. Getty Images Director of the Eurovision Song Contest, Martin Green said the EBU "understand the concerns"
summary_src:
Veteran UK songwriter Phil Coulter has called for the UK to withdraw from the Eurovision Song Contest if Israel participates, mirroring the stance of Irish broadcaster RTÉ. RTÉ has announced it will not take part due to the "ongoing and appalling loss of lives in Gaza," a decision strongly supported by Ireland's 2024 entry, Bambie Thug, who also cited past negative experiences with Israel's national broadcaster, Kan.

Coulter highlighted a "double standard," noting that Russia was expelled from the 2022 contest following its invasion of Ukraine, questioning the allowance of Israel's participation amidst the Gaza conflict. The Netherlands has joined a potential boycott, with Spain, Slovenia, Finland, and Iceland also considering similar moves or reserving the right to withdraw, pending a decision from the European Broadcasting Union (EBU).

The BBC has declined to comment on Coulter's suggestions. While singer Nicky Stevens expressed horror over the situation in Gaza, she advocated for keeping politics out of Eurovision to allow a focus on music. The EBU, which "understands the concerns," will make the final decision regarding Israel's participation and the entries of other nations.

**यूरोविज़न गीत प्रतियोगिता: इज़राइल की भागीदारी पर विवाद गहराया, यूके और आयरलैंड बहिष्कार की मांग कर रहे हैं**

अनुभवी ब्रिटिश गीतकार फिल कूल्टर ने यूके से आग्रह किया है कि अगर इज़राइल यूरोविज़न गीत प्रतियोगिता में भाग लेता है तो वह इससे हट जाए, जो आयरिश ब्रॉडकास्टर आरटीई के समान ही रुख है। आरटीई ने गाजा में "जानमाल के लगातार और भयानक नुकसान" का हवाला देते हुए घोषणा की है कि वह इसमें भाग नहीं लेगा। आयरलैंड की 2024 की प्रविष्टि, बैम्बी ठग, ने इस निर्णय का दृढ़ता से समर्थन किया है, और उन्होंने इज़राइल के राष्ट्रीय प्रसारक, कान, के साथ अपने पिछले नकारात्मक अनुभवों का भी उल्लेख किया।

कूल्टर ने "दोहरे मापदंड" की बात कही, यह ध्यान दिलाते हुए कि रूस को यूक्रेन पर उसके आक्रमण के बाद 2022 की प्रतियोगिता से बाहर कर दिया गया था, और गाजा संघर्ष के बीच इज़राइल की भागीदारी की अनुमति पर सवाल उठाया। नीदरलैंड्स एक संभावित बहिष्कार में शामिल हो गया है, जबकि स्पेन, स्लोवेनिया, फिनलैंड और आइसलैंड भी यूरोपीय प्रसारण संघ (ईबीयू) के फैसले का इंतज़ार करते हुए इसी तरह के कदम उठाने या हटने का अधिकार सुरक्षित रखने पर विचार कर रहे हैं।

बीबीसी ने कूल्टर के सुझावों पर टिप्पणी करने से इनकार कर दिया है। हालांकि, गायिका निक्की स्टीवंस ने गाजा की स्थिति पर अपनी पीड़ा व्यक्त की, उन्होंने यूरोविज़न से राजनीति को दूर रखने की वकालत की ताकि संगीत पर ध्यान केंद्रित किया जा सके। ईबीयू, जो "चिंताओं को समझता है", इज़राइल की भागीदारी और अन्य राष्ट्रों की प्रविष्टियों के संबंध में अंतिम निर्णय लेगा।
