title_src: Blue: 'Mental health back then wasn't a thing'
text_src: Blue: 'Mental health wasn't a thing back then' 1 day ago Share Save Alix Hattenstone Share Save Getty Images The members of Blue (L to R: Duncan, Simon, Lee and Antony) say between them, they now have more children, more responsibilities and more tattoos For many '90s and noughties kids, the boyband Blue were part of growing up. Their hits featured in the soundtrack to school discos, people would flick through magazines for posters and debate who their favourite member was. After notching up three number one singles, three number one albums and two Brit awards, the band struggled to find the same charts success again and were dropped by their record label. In a year when nostalgia for their golden era is driving comebacks and bands including Five, Pulp and Oasis are back on the road, Blue members Simon Webbe, Duncan James, Antony Costa and Lee Ryan are preparing for one of their own. Their upcoming tour marks 25 years since the band first got together - so a quarter of a century later, what's changed? "My body every morning – it's like Rice Krispies," moans Manchester-born Simon Webb. "It's snap, crackle and pop when I get out of bed." It's a very different picture from their early music videos, with the band performing synchronised dance moves in dark rooms under bright lights, or striding through the streets in tank tops preaching the virtues of One Love. Blue have been reflecting on how attitudes have changed as they prepare to head back on the road The singers agree growing up means priorities have changed. They are touring, says London's Antony Costa, not only because they love it, but also because "we've got to work to provide for our families and put food on the table". "We have a different mindset now from when we were doing it last time because we were just kids," says Duncan James. All four members are dads now. "My daughter's 20, she lives in Germany - she's a ballerina," says the Wiltshire-born singer. "My responsibilities are looking after her and, of course, my mum." 'Love letter' For Duncan, their new single One Last Time and its themes of grief and being there for loved ones in hard times are personal. "My best mate Terry, he was a dancer on our first ever tour back in the day 25 years ago," Duncan says. "We just became best mates and I lost him very tragically and sadly last year and I was gutted. But I wrote this song in his memory and it was almost like a bit of a love letter to him." Terry John, a model, dancer and choreographer, has been previously described by Duncan as the most loving, giving and caring person he knew. Meanwhile, he says Simon's wife broke down in tears when she heard the song. "It's not easy to talk about but we lost her dad about a year or so ago suddenly as well and it's just the shock factor of that," says Simon. "This song is one of those songs that takes you back to that one special person – or those special people in your lives that have passed on or those who you might not have seen for a long time and are hoping to do so." The band have all experienced grief, but didn't want to make One Last Time a sad song. "We wanted to put an uplifting beat on it," Duncan says as they speak about how positivity has helped them through difficult times. 'No luxury of talking' Writing previously in The Radio Times, Blue's former manager Daniel Glatman said if he was managing boybands now he would hire 24/7 therapists. "We didn't have that luxury of talking at the time," Antony explains. "It was just literally in and out and it was just graft, graft, graft. So it's nice that we can sit down and take a step back and if we want to talk, we can." "We've got each other now," Simon says. "I've had a few dark shadows linger over me and Duncan's always been there and so has Antony and so has Lee." Getty Images Simon says Duncan and the other band members have been there for him at difficult times Listening to them chat, the conversation flows easily. They go from emotional talk to banter, taking the mick out of each other and themselves. "I think they all decide on who's going to talk to me next," Simon laughs. "Who's going to say something to Simon? They spin the bottle in that aspect. "But we do have that with each other anyway – there's always the light at the end of the tunnel." "Mental health back then wasn't a thing," says Duncan. "It wasn't something that anybody talked about." Now they speak about the benefits of having the discipline to keep talking to others, whether a therapist, colleague or friend. "Talking about your problems is really important – don't ever filter feelings," says Duncan. "Don't sit there on your own thinking you've got no-one to talk to." He says at different times in their careers, each of the band members had found talking "a real saving grace".
summary_src:
Pop group Blue is making a comeback with a 25th-anniversary tour, driven by both nostalgia and the financial responsibilities of being fathers. The band members—Simon Webbe, Duncan James, Antony Costa, and Lee Ryan—note significant personal changes, including increased family duties and the physical toll of aging, a stark contrast to their early careers when they were "just kids."

Their new single, "One Last Time," delves into themes of grief and support for loved ones. This is deeply personal for Duncan James, who wrote the song in memory of his best friend and former tour dancer, Terry John, who tragically passed away last year. Simon Webbe also connected to the song after his wife's father's sudden death. Despite these sad origins, the band aimed for an uplifting beat and positive message.

A major reflection point for Blue is the profound shift in attitudes towards mental health. They recall a time when "mental health wasn't a thing" and they lacked "the luxury of talking" while relentlessly working. Their former manager even stated he'd now hire 24/7 therapists for boybands. Today, the band emphasizes the crucial importance of open communication, whether with therapists, friends, or each other, calling it a "saving grace." They highlight the strong support system within the band, having helped each other through "dark shadows" and underscoring their evolution into adults advocating for well-being.
summary_tgt:
पॉप ग्रुप ब्लू अपनी 25वीं वर्षगांठ के दौरे के साथ वापसी कर रहा है, जिसकी प्रेरणा उन्हें पुरानी यादों को ताज़ा करने की इच्छा और पिता होने की आर्थिक ज़िम्मेदारियों दोनों से मिली है। बैंड के सदस्य—साइमन वेब, डंकन जेम्स, एंटनी कोस्टा और ली रयान—बताते हैं कि उनके व्यक्तिगत जीवन में महत्वपूर्ण बदलाव आए हैं, जिनमें बढ़ी हुई पारिवारिक ज़िम्मेदारियाँ और बढ़ती उम्र का शारीरिक प्रभाव शामिल है। यह उनके शुरुआती करियर के बिलकुल विपरीत है, जब वे 'सिर्फ बच्चे' थे।

उनका नया सिंगल, 'वन लास्ट टाइम', प्रियजनों के लिए दुख और समर्थन के विषयों पर आधारित है। यह डंकन जेम्स के लिए बेहद व्यक्तिगत है, जिन्होंने यह गीत अपने सबसे अच्छे दोस्त और पूर्व टूर डांसर, टेरी जॉन की याद में लिखा था, जिनका पिछले साल दुखद निधन हो गया था। साइमन वेब भी अपनी पत्नी के पिता के अचानक निधन के बाद इस गीत से भावनात्मक रूप से जुड़े। इन दुखद मूलों के बावजूद, बैंड ने एक उत्साहवर्धक धुन और सकारात्मक संदेश देने का लक्ष्य रखा।

ब्लू के लिए एक प्रमुख विचार बिंदु मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के प्रति दृष्टिकोण में आया गहरा बदलाव है। वे उस समय को याद करते हैं जब 'मानसिक स्वास्थ्य जैसी कोई बात नहीं थी' और लगातार काम करते हुए उनके पास 'खुले तौर पर बात करने की सुविधा' नहीं थी। उनके पूर्व प्रबंधक ने तो यहाँ तक कहा कि अब वह बॉयबैंड्स के लिए 24/7 थेरेपिस्ट रखेंगे। आज, बैंड खुले संचार के महत्वपूर्ण महत्व पर जोर देता है, चाहे थेरेपिस्ट, दोस्तों या एक-दूसरे के साथ, इसे 'सबसे बड़ा सहारा' बताते हुए। वे बैंड के भीतर मजबूत समर्थन प्रणाली को उजागर करते हैं, जिसमें उन्होंने एक-दूसरे को 'अंधेरे सायों' (मुश्किल समय) से निकलने में मदद की है और यह दर्शाता है कि वे अब ऐसे वयस्क बन गए हैं जो मानसिक भलाई की वकालत करते हैं।
meta_description: Noughties boy band Blue say there was no discussion about their wellbeing when they started out.

title_src: I spent £1,000 on a hen party. You feel like you have to do it
text_src: I spent £1,000 on a hen party. You feel like you have to do it 2 hours ago Share Save Noor Nanji Culture reporter Share Save £100 or £1,000: How much would you spend on a hen or stag do? "Hey ladies, it's that time again. Please transfer £300 by 7pm tonight for accommodation, matching outfits, and surprise gifts for the bride :)" It's the message lots of us in our 20s and 30s are used to getting. That includes Hayley, 29, who says she spent more than £1,000 attending a hen party in Marbella, Spain. "In the WhatsApp groups, it's always initially the flights and the hotel," Hayley says, "and then afterwards it's like, 'OK, we're going to this beach club, we're getting that T-shirt, we're going to do that cocktail club'. "You feel like you have to do it." Hen and stag dos, like weddings and baby showers, are a chance to celebrate big milestones in our friends' lives. But what was once a night down the pub has, for many, become an entire weekend away. And for some, the costs are too much. "Don't mind me, just choosing whether to attend or pay my rent for the next three months *crying face emoji*," wrote one TikTok user, in a video about expensive hen parties. Twenty-nine-year-old Lucy, told me the rising price of friendship feels like it's spiralling out of control. "It's that time of life where everyone is getting engaged, married or having kids," Lucy says. "And the costs of celebrating all of that adds up." "Money doesn't grow on trees," adds Charles, who's 27. "Lots of my friends work in the public sector, and it's a struggle to keep up.” So what are the pitfalls when organising a hen, a stag, or even a wedding? And is there a way to keep everyone happy? 'You can't say no' Getty Images One common theme is that people feel pressured into saying "yes" to attending to avoid upsetting friends, or worse, looking cheap. "I see TikToks all the time, saying: 'Just say no, it's so simple,'" says Anna, who asked the BBC not to use her real name. "But it causes so much falling out, it's ridiculous." The 29-year-old says her cousin chose to hold her hen party in Spain, at a cost of about £300 per person for flights and accommodation, before factoring in spending money. Anna says she told her cousin she couldn't afford it, but was then hit with passive aggressive messages. "[She said] 'Just save £20 a month for the next year,'" Anna says. "But I didn't have that. Then she said, 'Ask your dad'." Begrudgingly, Anna agreed to go - but the hen was then cancelled due to Covid. She's since been invited to a number of other hen parties and weddings. She feels she can't justify the costs - but doesn't want to be labelled as the friend who can't afford it. "I could imagine the comments behind [my] back," Anna says. ‘It’s £100 here, £100 there' Then there are the costs when you actually get to said hen, stag or wedding. My best friend Claire got married recently and as a lifelong raver, had decided to hold her hen party in Ibiza. As her bridesmaids, we tried to keep costs down. Hotels were prohibitively expensive, so we opted for a hostel instead. It looked decent online, but turned out to be not dissimilar to a prison cell. With flights, accommodation and spending in bars and clubs, the whole trip set us back about £1,000 each. Still, according to research, we did comparatively well. Jasmine, left, is getting married and her friends, Hayley and Lily, and sister Ruby, are planning her hen party According to a study from Aviva in 2023, stag and hen invitees spent an average of £779 per person in the UK, and £1,208 abroad. The average price abroad was £1,664 this year, according to a separate study by the insurer. For Jasmine, who's 28, it's the unexpected costs that are the worst. She's been to hen parties where there's been a set price, but then additional payments of up to £100 per person were asked for. "And you've already committed and you don't want to pull out," she says. Jasmine, who's engaged to be married, thinks an appropriate amount to spend should be in the region of £100-200, "as you'd spend that on a day or night out anyway". To split... or not to split? Getty Images Then there's the thorny question of splitting bills. Another woman, who we're calling Jemima, says on a recent hen weekend, she had to contribute to a central kitty for bars - even though she doesn't drink. "It made no sense, but you have to go along with the flow," the 34-year-old says. "The bills kept racking up and up." This is not just a British problem, either. TikTok creator, Sydney Jo from New York, recently told me as she and her friends approach their 30s, bachelorettes and weddings have become a major source of drama. And that's provided excellent content for her viral series about a girls’ group chat. In a recent episode, set during a bachelorette trip to Costa Rica, one of the characters declares that her friend is "driving her insane". "The money stuff?" her friend guesses. "Yes, THANK YOU," the 27-year-old replies. "It's like, refusing to order Ubers, being so annoying about the cheque at every single meal... Seriously? I'm going to lose it." That's before you even get to the wedding Once you're done with the hen and stag do, then you have to factor in the cost of going to the big day itself. Lucy went to a friend's wedding in Switzerland last year which she says cost her about £700. It was in a "really random town", she says, which involved taking a train and a bus, and accommodation options were very limited which meant she had to stay in an expensive hotel, driving up costs. Food was covered, but everyone had to pay for their own drinks. "It was a lovely day," Lucy says. "But very expensive." The couple are now getting divorced. "So that was a waste of money," she adds. Elle Elle got married abroad, but now regrets that Elle got married in Cyprus when she was in her early 30s. She's also now divorced, and says, on reflection, it wasn't worth it. Family and friends had flown out, and in the lead up to the wedding activities like paragliding and boat days had been booked, so the costs had really added up. "Looking back, I wouldn't have done a destination wedding. I know how much pressure it put people under," Elle says. "One of my bridesmaids was upset as she couldn't afford it and for a while she was too scared to tell me. Eventually she did, and I felt really bad." Hen and stag dos and don'ts Getty Images
summary_src:
Celebratory events such as hen and stag parties, along with destination weddings, have become a significant financial and social burden for attendees, shifting from simple gatherings to costly multi-day, often international, extravaganzas. Individuals frequently report spending upwards of £1,000 for a single event, with UK averages at £779 and international trips costing £1,208 to £1,664 per person, often compounded by unexpected additional payments.

This escalating cost is accompanied by immense social pressure, particularly among those in their 20s and 30s, who feel compelled to participate to avoid upsetting friends or being perceived as cheap. This "can't say no" mentality leads to significant financial strain, with some struggling to prioritize event attendance over essential living expenses like rent. The situation frequently causes emotional drama, from passive-aggressive messages for declining invitations to disputes over bill splitting (even for non-drinkers), and feelings of guilt or regret.

The problem is not unique to the UK, with similar issues sparking conflict in friend groups and viral content in the US. The financial and emotional toll extends to destination weddings, where even brides acknowledge the pressure placed on guests. Some attendees, like those who spent hundreds on a wedding for a couple who later divorced, view the expenses as a "waste of money." Ultimately, these milestones, intended for celebration, are increasingly overshadowed by overwhelming financial expectations and relational stress, highlighting a concerning "rising price of friendship."
summary_tgt:
यहां अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद दिया गया है:

बैचलर पार्टियों (हेन और स्टैग पार्टी) और डेस्टिनेशन वेडिंग्स जैसे उत्सव संबंधी आयोजन, अब मेहमानों के लिए एक महत्वपूर्ण वित्तीय और सामाजिक बोझ बन गए हैं। साधारण मिलन समारोहों से बढ़कर, ये खर्चीले, कई दिनों तक चलने वाले और अक्सर अंतर्राष्ट्रीय स्तर के भव्य आयोजनों में बदल गए हैं। लोग अक्सर एक ही आयोजन पर £1,000 से अधिक खर्च करने की बात कहते हैं, जबकि यूके में औसत खर्च £779 है। अंतर्राष्ट्रीय यात्राओं पर प्रति व्यक्ति £1,208 से £1,664 का खर्च आता है, जो अक्सर अप्रत्याशित अतिरिक्त भुगतानों से और भी बढ़ जाता है।

इस बढ़ती लागत के साथ भारी सामाजिक दबाव भी जुड़ा है, खासकर 20 और 30 के दशक के लोगों में। वे दोस्तों को नाराज़ करने या कंजूस समझे जाने से बचने के लिए इनमें शामिल होने को मजबूर महसूस करते हैं। यह "ना नहीं कह पाने" की मानसिकता महत्वपूर्ण वित्तीय तनाव पैदा करती है, जहाँ कुछ लोग किराए जैसे आवश्यक जीवन-यापन के खर्चों की तुलना में इन आयोजनों में शामिल होने को प्राथमिकता देने में संघर्ष करते हैं। यह स्थिति अक्सर भावनात्मक मनमुटाव का कारण बनती है – निमंत्रण अस्वीकार करने पर निष्क्रिय-आक्रामक संदेशों से लेकर बिल बांटने को लेकर झगड़ों तक (यहाँ तक कि शराब न पीने वालों के लिए भी), और अपराधबोध या पछतावे की भावनाएँ भी आती हैं।

यह समस्या केवल यूके तक ही सीमित नहीं है; अमेरिका में भी इसी तरह के मुद्दे मित्र-समूहों में कलह और वायरल सामग्री को जन्म दे रहे हैं। इसका वित्तीय और भावनात्मक प्रभाव डेस्टिनेशन वेडिंग्स तक भी फैला हुआ है, जहाँ दुल्हनें भी मेहमानों पर पड़ने वाले दबाव को स्वीकार करती हैं। कुछ मेहमान, जैसे कि वे जिन्होंने एक ऐसे जोड़े की शादी पर सैकड़ों खर्च किए जो बाद में तलाक ले चुके थे, इन खर्चों को "पैसे की बर्बादी" मानते हैं। अंततः, जश्न मनाने के उद्देश्य से रखे गए ये महत्वपूर्ण आयोजन, भारी वित्तीय अपेक्षाओं और संबंधों में तनाव से लगातार धूमिल हो रहे हैं, जो "दोस्ती की बढ़ती कीमत" नामक एक चिंताजनक सच्चाई को उजागर करते हैं।

title_src: Whether rich or poor, it was the longest of nights': How a 2003 blackout brought New York City to a standstill
text_src: On 14 August 2003, 22 years ago this week, the electricity cut out for more than 50 million people in the US and Canada, as North America experienced a massive power cut. The BBC was in New York City when the lights went out. On a sweltering summer afternoon in 2003, a colossal electricity grid failure tore through the US and Canada's interconnected power systems. The chain reaction caused multiple power plants covering an area as far west as Cleveland and Detroit and as far north as Toronto and Ottawa to shut down. Within minutes, more than 50 million people found themselves without electricity. New York, the largest city in the US, was just one of the many places where everyday life was brought to a sudden standstill on 14 August 2003, 22 years ago this week. "The blackout began just before yesterday evening's rush hour, bringing chaos to the traffic-clogged streets," reported BBC correspondent Nick Bryant. "Members of the public were forced to deputise as makeshift cops. Avenues normally jammed with cars and trucks were quickly flooded with people, and thousands more were stranded for many hours on the city's underground trains in stifling heat of almost 100 degrees." WATCH: 'I don’t even know what time it is anymore'. The disruption to New York was widespread and chaotic. It would take emergency services hours to evacuate passengers from around 600 subway and commuter rail cars that were stranded between stations. Many people would have to inch their way in near darkness along subway tunnels to get out. Hundreds more were trapped in lifts when the electricity stopped flowing – or, in the case of the Empire State Building, at the top of the tallest building in the city. Cash machines stopped operating. Areas which used electric pumps stopped receiving water. Refrigerated food and drink in shops and restaurants rapidly perished in the summer heat.
summary_src:
On August 14, 2003, a colossal electricity grid failure plunged large parts of North America into darkness, affecting over 50 million people in the U.S. and Canada. This massive power cut, caused by a chain reaction that shut down power plants from Cleveland and Detroit as far north as Toronto and Ottawa, struck on a sweltering summer afternoon.

New York City experienced its first power cut lasting more than 24 hours, suffering widespread and chaotic disruption. The blackout began just before rush hour, bringing traffic to a standstill and forcing members of the public to act as makeshift cops. Thousands were stranded for hours on underground trains in stifling heat, requiring emergency services to evacuate around 600 subway and commuter rail cars, with many people having to inch their way through dark tunnels. Hundreds more were trapped in lifts, including at the top of the Empire State Building.

The outage crippled essential services, as cash machines stopped operating, areas reliant on electric pumps lost water supply, and refrigerated food and drink in shops and restaurants rapidly perished in the summer heat.
summary_tgt:
**14 अगस्त 2003 को, एक विशाल बिजली ग्रिड विफलता ने उत्तरी अमेरिका के बड़े हिस्सों को अंधेरे में डुबो दिया, जिससे अमेरिका और कनाडा के 5 करोड़ से अधिक लोग प्रभावित हुए। यह भारी बिजली कटौती, क्लीवलैंड और डेट्रॉइट से लेकर उत्तर में टोरंटो और ओटावा तक के बिजली संयंत्रों को ठप करने वाली एक श्रृंखला प्रतिक्रिया के कारण, भीषण गर्मी की दोपहर में हुई।**

**न्यूयॉर्क शहर ने 24 घंटे से अधिक समय तक चलने वाली अपनी पहली बिजली कटौती का अनुभव किया, जिससे व्यापक और अराजक व्यवधान हुआ। यह ब्लैकआउट ठीक भीड़-भाड़ के समय (रश आवर) से पहले शुरू हुआ, जिससे यातायात ठप हो गया और आम जनता को अस्थायी पुलिसकर्मियों के रूप में काम करना पड़ा। हजारों लोग घंटों तक भीषण गर्मी में भूमिगत ट्रेनों में फंसे रहे। आपातकालीन सेवाओं को लगभग 600 सबवे और कम्यूटर रेल कारों को खाली करना पड़ा, जिसमें कई लोगों को अंधेरी सुरंगों से रेंगते हुए बाहर आना पड़ा। सैकड़ों अन्य लोग लिफ्टों में फंस गए, जिनमें एम्पायर स्टेट बिल्डिंग की सबसे ऊपरी मंजिल पर फंसे लोग भी शामिल थे।**

**इस बिजली कटौती ने आवश्यक सेवाओं को पंगु बना दिया, क्योंकि कैश मशीनें बंद हो गईं, इलेक्ट्रिक पंपों पर निर्भर क्षेत्रों में पानी की आपूर्ति बाधित हो गई, और दुकानों और रेस्तरां में रखा ठंडा भोजन और पेय पदार्थ भीषण गर्मी में तेजी से खराब हो गए।**
meta_description: On 14 August 2003, 22 years ago this week, the electricity cut out for more than 50 million people in the US and Canada. The BBC was in New York City when the lights went out.

title_src: Swindon Brass band 'excited' to compete in Cheltenham finals
text_src: Brass band 'excited' for national competition 24 hours ago Share Save Jasmine Ketibuah-Foley BBC News, West of England Share Save Swindon Brass Swindon Brass is competing in this weekend's event at Cheltenham Racecourse Local musicians are competing to be crowned champions of this year's National Brass Band Championships this weekend. The event, which takes place on Cheltenham Racecourse, will see Swindon Brass from Wiltshire take on their first finals in section three. For the competition, 94 bands are taking part with each region divided into five competitive sections - the championship section and sections one to four. Swindon Brass director Steven Yorke said it is a "huge opportunity" for his group to take part in what he described as the brass band equivalent of the football leagues. "For a lot of people [in the band] it's the first time they've taken part in a competition at this level, so there is obviously some anxiety around but it's mostly excitement," he said. "We're going to go there and enjoy the experience no matter what. "We've done a lot of work. We hope it's going to pay off." Swindon Brass Mr Yorke said the band has done "a lot of work" to get to the finals Beginning in 1900, the event in its current format started in 1945 at the Royal Albert Hall, making this year its 80th anniversary. About 500 bands from across the UK have been taking part in regional heats, all leading up to the two final events, with the National Champion Band of Great Britain to be crowned at the Royal Albert Hall in October. The most successful band in the competition's history is west Yorkshire's the Black Dyke Band with 24 titles, and this year's defending champions is the Flowers Band from Gloucester. Mr Yorke explained if Swindon Brass do make it through and win a place in the second section, they would celebrate in some kind of way, but said what that would be "remains a surprise". Follow BBC Wiltshire on Facebook, X and Instagram. Send your story ideas to us on email or via WhatsApp on 0800 313 4630.
summary_src: Swindon Brass band is eagerly preparing for their first national finals appearance this weekend at Cheltenham Racecourse, a "huge opportunity" described by director Steven Yorke as the brass band equivalent of the football leagues. Competing against 93 other bands across five sections, the group expresses a mix of anxiety and excitement, having put in extensive work and aiming to enjoy the experience regardless of the outcome. The competition, which celebrates its 80th anniversary in its current format, culminates in the crowning of a National Champion Band in October. Swindon Brass hopes to advance to the second section, with a surprise celebration promised if they achieve this goal.

स्विंडन ब्रास बैंड इस सप्ताहांत चेल्टेनहैम रेसकोर्स में अपनी पहली राष्ट्रीय फ़ाइनल प्रतियोगिता के लिए बेसब्री से तैयारी कर रहा है। निदेशक स्टीवन यॉर्क ने इसे "बड़ा अवसर" बताया है, जिसकी तुलना उन्होंने ब्रास बैंड की दुनिया के फ़ुटबॉल लीग से की है।

पाँच सेक्शनों में 93 अन्य बैंडों के खिलाफ़ प्रतिस्पर्धा करते हुए, समूह ने गहन तैयारी की है और अब वे चिंता और उत्साह दोनों महसूस कर रहे हैं। उनका लक्ष्य है कि परिणाम जो भी हो, वे इस अनुभव का आनंद लें।

यह प्रतियोगिता अपने वर्तमान प्रारूप में अपनी 80वीं वर्षगांठ मना रही है, और इसका समापन अक्टूबर में एक राष्ट्रीय चैंपियन बैंड के ताजपोशी के साथ होगा। स्विंडन ब्रास को दूसरे सेक्शन में आगे बढ़ने की उम्मीद है, और अगर वे यह लक्ष्य हासिल करते हैं तो एक सरप्राइज जश्न का वादा किया गया है।

title_src: Task to The Paper: 12 of the best TV shows to watch this September
text_src: Wayward premieres 25 September on Netflix internationally Apple TV+ (Credit: Apple TV+) 11. The Savant Jessica Chastain stars in this timely thriller as Jodie, whose intuitive skills make her excellent at her top-secret job: tracing white supremacists and other hate groups on-line in order to prevent any violent attacks. She should be safely infiltrating the groups from her desk, interacting with them using a false persona, but her work becomes more immediate than she expected. The show reveals its strain on her home life, which includes two children and a husband in the military. And along with glimpses of the chilling videos the hate groups post, some scenes take us deep into the off-line world of one particular terror group Jodie is tracking. She is certain they are planning something major, and we know before she does that she is right. In a surreal touch, Jeremy Bobb plays the man Jodie pretends to be, and we sometimes see him at a computer instead of her. The ambitious series was created by Melissa James Gibson, a writer on The Americans. And it is not just a fictional idea. Jodie is based on a real person profiled in a 2019 article in Cosmopolitan headlined, "Is It Possible to Stop a Mass Shooting Before it Happens?" The Savant premieres 26 September on Apple TV+ internationally Disney+ (Credit: Disney+) 12. Chad Powers Glen Powell has plenty of big film options, especially after last year's summer blockbuster hit Twisters, but here he is in this goofy, warm-hearted series. He plays Russ Holliday, a college football player banned for losing his temper in a way so awful it became a viral video. Eight years later, he puts on a wig and tries out for a different college team, pretending to be a genial guy named Chad Powers. The show is based on an episode of famous football star Eli Manning's ESPN series Eli's Places, in which he disguised himself as the fictional Chad Powers and tried out for a college team. Powell has said that viewers knowing it was Manning in disguise all along was a key inspiration in making the series, which he created with Michael Waldron (Loki). He describes their thinking as, "Let's use the lie at the centre of this thing, which creates inherent fun conflict." Or, as he put it: "We're going to Tootsie this thing. Let's Mrs. Doubtfire it." It looks like they Ted Lasso'd it too. That warm-hearted sports comedy was based on an even less likely source, a character in a television promo. Chad Powers premieres 30 September on Hulu in the US and Disney+ internationally -- If you liked this story, sign up for The Essential List newsletter – a handpicked selection of features, videos and can't-miss news, delivered to your inbox twice a week. For more Culture stories from the BBC, follow us on Facebook and Instagram.
summary_src:
Here's a comprehensive and concise news article summary:

Two new series are set to debut in late September, offering a mix of high-stakes thriller and warm-hearted sports comedy.

**The Savant (Jessica Chastain)**
Jessica Chastain stars as Jodie in "The Savant," a timely thriller premiering September 26 internationally on Apple TV+. Jodie's intuitive skills make her excellent at her top-secret job of infiltrating online hate groups using a false persona. However, her work becomes more immediate, straining her home life with two children and a military husband as she tracks a terror group she's certain is planning a major attack. A surreal element sees Jeremy Bobb playing Jodie's online persona. Created by Melissa James Gibson ("The Americans"), the ambitious series is based on a real person profiled in a 2019 Cosmopolitan article about preventing mass shootings.

**Chad Powers (Glen Powell)**
Also arriving is the warm-hearted sports comedy "Chad Powers," starring Glen Powell, premiering September 30 on Hulu in the US and Disney+ internationally. Powell plays Russ Holliday, a college football player banned after a viral temper tantrum. Eight years later, he attempts to rejoin the sport by disguising himself with a wig and genial persona as "Chad Powers" to try out for a different team. The show is inspired by a real-life stunt from Eli Manning's ESPN series "Eli's Places," where Manning famously pulled a similar disguise. Powell, who co-created the series with Michael Waldron ("Loki"), explained their approach was to "use the lie at the centre of this thing" to create "inherent fun conflict," likening it to films like "Tootsie" and "Mrs. Doubtfire," and the series "Ted Lasso."

Separately, CNN.com will feature weekly "Travel Snapshots" galleries sourced from iReporter photos.
summary_tgt:
यहाँ उस इंग्लिश समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद दिया गया है:

सितंबर के अंत में दो नई सीरीज़ रिलीज़ होने वाली हैं, जिनमें एक रोमांचक थ्रिलर और एक दिल को छू लेने वाली स्पोर्ट्स कॉमेडी शामिल है।

**द सैवेंट (जेसिका चैस्टेन)**
जेसिका चैस्टेन 'द सैवेंट' में जोडी की भूमिका में हैं, जो 26 सितंबर को एप्पल टीवी+ पर अंतरराष्ट्रीय स्तर पर प्रीमियर होने वाला एक सामयिक थ्रिलर है। जोडी अपनी सहज क्षमताओं का उपयोग करके ऑनलाइन नफरत फैलाने वाले समूहों में एक नकली पहचान के साथ घुसपैठ करने के अपने बेहद गोपनीय काम में माहिर है। हालाँकि, जब वह एक आतंकी समूह का पता लगाती है जिसके बारे में उसे यकीन है कि वह एक बड़े हमले की योजना बना रहा है, तो उसका काम अधिक तत्काल हो जाता है, जिससे उसके दो बच्चों और एक सैन्य पति के साथ उसके घरेलू जीवन में तनाव आ जाता है। दिलचस्प बात यह है कि जेरेमी बॉब जोडी के ऑनलाइन व्यक्तित्व का किरदार निभाते हैं। मेलिसा जेम्स गिब्सन ('द अमेरिकन्स' फेम) द्वारा बनाई गई यह महत्वाकांक्षी सीरीज़ 2019 के कॉस्मोपॉलिटन लेख में जनसंहार (mass shootings) को रोकने के बारे में प्रोफाइल किए गए एक वास्तविक व्यक्ति पर आधारित है।

**चैड पावर्स (ग्लेन पॉवेल)**
इसके अलावा, ग्लेन पॉवेल अभिनीत दिल को छू लेने वाली स्पोर्ट्स कॉमेडी 'चैड पावर्स' भी आ रही है, जिसका प्रीमियर 30 सितंबर को अमेरिका में हुलु (Hulu) और अंतरराष्ट्रीय स्तर पर डिज़्नी+ (Disney+) पर होगा। पॉवेल रस्स हॉलिडे का किरदार निभाते हैं, एक कॉलेज फुटबॉल खिलाड़ी जिसे वायरल हुए गुस्से के प्रदर्शन (temper tantrum) के बाद प्रतिबंधित कर दिया गया था। आठ साल बाद, वह विग और एक सौम्य व्यक्तित्व के साथ खुद को 'चैड पावर्स' के रूप में भेस बदलकर एक अलग टीम के लिए कोशिश करने के लिए खेल में फिर से शामिल होने का प्रयास करता है। यह शो एली मैनिंग की ईएसपीएन सीरीज़ 'एलीज़ प्लेसेज़' के एक वास्तविक जीवन के स्टंट से प्रेरित है, जहाँ मैनिंग ने इसी तरह का भेस बनाया था। पॉवेल, जिन्होंने माइकल वाल्ड्रॉन ('लोकी' फेम) के साथ इस सीरीज़ का सह-निर्माण किया है, ने बताया कि उन्होंने "इस कहानी के केंद्र में मौजूद झूठ का उपयोग" करके "अंतर्निहित मजेदार टकराव" पैदा करने का लक्ष्य रखा, इसकी तुलना 'टूट्सी' और 'मिसेज डाउटफायर' जैसी फिल्मों और 'टेड लासो' जैसी सीरीज़ से करते हुए।

अलग से, CNN.com साप्ताहिक 'ट्रैवल स्नैपशॉट्स' गैलरी पेश करेगा, जिसमें iReporter की तस्वीरें होंगी।
meta_description: From a new FBI thriller by the creator of Mare of Easttown to a sequel to The Office and a sports comedy starring Hollywood A-lister Glen Powell.

title_src: Wake Up Dead Man review: The 'funniest and most playful' Knives Out mystery yet
text_src: Daniel Craig returns as Benoit Blanc and Josh O'Connor nearly steals the show in the "darkest" but also "most playful" instalment of the Knives Out franchise so far. Can anyone steal a Knives Out film from the great detective Benoit Blanc? As it turns out, yes, almost. The biggest revelation of Wake Up Dead Man, the third in Rian Johnson's series of deliciously entertaining mysteries, is that Josh O'Connor, so great at drama, is also an excellent comic. He plays Father Jud Duplenticy, a former boxer turned priest, who as punishment for a violent outburst is sent from upstate New York to a tiny parish in the village of Chimney Rock. It's a setting that looks as if it has been transported from a screen adaptation of an Agatha Christie novel, with a small neo-Gothic church and adjacent graveyard. It's exactly the kind of place where too many murders take place. But instead of meeting some kindly vicar, Jud goes to work for Monsignor Jefferson Wicks, played by Josh Brolin as a wild-haired, fiery cynic. It's not quite fair to say that O'Connor steals the film from Daniel Craig's Blanc. Craig is a scene-stealer himself With its Gothic atmosphere and deeper themes, Wake Up Dead Man has a darker tone than the previous Knives Out films. Yet it is also the funniest and most playful so far. Along with the usual murder(s) and large glittery cast, it has religion, and a touch of meta in its literary allusions and film references. Johnson has acknowledged wanting to go back to the roots of mystery stories with this instalment, citing Edgar Allan Poe, so it's good to keep in mind Poe's themes of men haunted by guilt and of creepy burials. But with more assurance than ever, he walks a perfectly balanced line as he borrows old tropes and adapts them. There is plenty of irreverent dialogue here, and rude graffiti on a mausoleum. It's not quite fair to say that O'Connor steals the film from Daniel Craig's Blanc. Craig is a scene-stealer himself. Blanc turns up to solve a murder in Chimney Rock with his southern accent and confident swagger, looking more dapper than ever. But it seems that with each Knives Out film he has fewer scenes, and at times he is like an orchestra conductor weaving us through the various characters and possibilities in the ever-twisting plot. Blanc even enlists Jud's help in solving the murder. There's no question that Father Jud is the film's throughline, and O'Connor swerves gracefully from comic to serious. Johnson begins by playing with point of view. We get Jud's account, requested by Blanc, of the events leading to what Jud calls the Good Friday murder. Using a device he acknowledges is borrowed from mystery novels, he introduces Blanc and us to the congregants, most of them with a cultish devotion to Wicks.
summary_src:
"Wake Up Dead Man," the third installment in Rian Johnson's *Knives Out* series, is hailed as the franchise's "darkest" yet "most playful" entry. While Daniel Craig returns as the dapper detective Benoit Blanc, it's Josh O'Connor, showcasing surprising comedic talent as Father Jud Duplenticy (a former boxer turned priest), who is lauded for almost stealing the film.

The mystery unfolds in the atmospheric, neo-Gothic village of Chimney Rock, a setting reminiscent of an Agatha Christie novel, where Jud is assigned to work under the fiery cynic Monsignor Jefferson Wicks (Josh Brolin). Johnson successfully blends a darker tone with deeper themes and a Gothic atmosphere, all while delivering the franchise's funniest and most playful script, rich with irreverent dialogue, literary allusions, and meta-commentary.

Drawing inspiration from the roots of mystery stories and Edgar Allan Poe's themes of guilt, Johnson skillfully adapts classic tropes with confident assurance. While Blanc arrives with his characteristic swagger to solve a murder, his role is more akin to an "orchestra conductor," guiding the narrative and its diverse characters, and he even enlists Jud's help. Jud, portrayed by O'Connor with a graceful balance of comic and serious, becomes the film's central throughline. The narrative creatively employs a point-of-view device, presenting key events, including a "Good Friday murder," from Jud's perspective, thereby introducing the congregants who harbor a cultish devotion to Wicks.
summary_tgt:
रियान जॉनसन की *नाइव्स आउट* श्रंखला की तीसरी किस्त, "वेक अप डेड मैन," को फ्रेंचाइजी की अब तक की "सबसे गहरी" लेकिन "सबसे चंचल" एंट्री के रूप में सराहा जा रहा है। जहाँ डैनियल क्रेग डैशिंग जासूस बेनोइट ब्लैंक के रूप में वापसी कर रहे हैं, वहीं जोश ओ'कॉनर ने फ़ादर जड डुपलेन्टिसी (एक पूर्व बॉक्सर से पादरी बने) के रूप में अपनी आश्चर्यजनक हास्य प्रतिभा का प्रदर्शन करते हुए फिल्म में लगभग पूरी तरह से अपनी छाप छोड़ी है और उनकी खूब प्रशंसा की जा रही है।

यह रहस्य चिमनी रॉक के एक रहस्यमय, नव-गॉथिक गाँव में खुलता है, जो अगाथा क्रिस्टी के उपन्यासों की याद दिलाता है। यहाँ जड को जोश ब्रोलिन द्वारा निभाए गए तेजतर्रार और निंदक मॉन्सिग्नोर जेफरसन विक्स के अधीन काम करने के लिए नियुक्त किया जाता है। जॉनसन एक गहरे स्वर को गहन विषयों और गॉथिक माहौल के साथ सफलतापूर्वक मिलाते हैं, और साथ ही वे फ्रेंचाइजी की अब तक की सबसे मजेदार और चंचल पटकथा पेश करते हैं। यह पटकथा गैर-पारंपरिक संवादों, साहित्यिक संदर्भों और मेटा-कमेंट्री से भरपूर है।

रहस्य कहानियों की जड़ों और एडगर एलन पो के अपराधबोध के विषयों से प्रेरणा लेते हुए, जॉनसन आत्मविश्वास के साथ क्लासिक ट्रॉप्स (प्रतिमानों) को कुशलता से ढालते हैं। जहाँ ब्लैंक अपनी विशिष्ट अकड़ (स्वाभाविक अंदाज) के साथ एक हत्या को सुलझाने के लिए पहुँचते हैं, वहीं उनकी भूमिका एक "ऑर्केस्ट्रा कंडक्टर" के समान अधिक है, जो कहानी और उसके विविध पात्रों का मार्गदर्शन करते हैं, और वह जड की मदद भी लेते हैं। ओ'कॉनर द्वारा हास्य और गंभीरता के सुंदर संतुलन के साथ निभाए गए जड, फिल्म के केंद्रीय सूत्रधार बन जाते हैं। कथा रचनात्मक रूप से एक दृष्टिकोण (पॉइंट-ऑफ-व्यू) उपकरण का उपयोग करती है, जो "गुड फ्राइडे हत्या" सहित प्रमुख घटनाओं को जड के परिप्रेक्ष्य से प्रस्तुत करती है, जिससे उन मंडली के सदस्यों को पेश किया जाता है जिनमें विक्स के प्रति पंथ जैसी भक्ति है।

title_src: First there is trust, then passion, then death': Why the 'Virgin Queen' never married
text_src: No expense was spared. It cost Dudley £1,000 ($1,400) a day – millions in today's money, and the whole extravaganza has been interpreted as an elaborate and expensive courtship display; the 16th-Century ruling class's equivalent of hiring a plane to fly a "Marry Me" banner. "The 1575 festivities were an attempt to woo Elizabeth – marriage is a theme in some of the events," Jeremy Ashbee, head curator of properties at English Heritage, tells the BBC. "Dr Elizabeth Goldring, who has made a detailed study of Lord Leicester, has called it 'his last throw of the dice'." Dudley's gamble seemed to be going swimmingly, but then everything changed. The highlight of the stay was to have been a masque – or performance – on Wednesday 20 July. It never took place. Was it simply a case of bad weather preventing the event, as the official version had it? Or had the monarch got wind of the subject matter and been angered? The masque featured Diana, goddess of chastity, searching for one of her chaste nymphs, pointedly called Zabetta – a version of the name Elizabeth. Alamy In the 1998 film Elizabeth, the bond between the pair was explored (Credit: Alamy) It concluded with a messenger of Juno, goddess of marriage, directly addressing Elizabeth, and imploring her not to follow the path of Diana but to marry instead. Dudley had a certain amount of leeway with the Queen, but this perhaps was going too far. Whatever the reason, the masque never took place, and the revelries were over. The Queen remained in her quarters for a few more days before leaving on 27 July. 'Proud and fiery' Now, the artist Lindsey Mendick has marked the 450th anniversary of the visit by creating Wicked Game, a large sculptural installation at the castle. Wicked Game takes inspiration from ancient mythology as well as from the events of Elizabeth's visit, and the way in which she used her unwed state in her shrewd political manoeuvres throughout her 45-year reign. There are 13 different tableaux. Some are sinister, others are suffused with dark humour. The fragmented ceramic sculptures strikingly depict the Queen and those around her as animals. In the central piece, Elizabeth is a lion and Dudley is a bear. The tableaux are positioned on pieces of an exploded giant chessboard.
summary_src:
The White House's construction spared no expense, with an estimated cost of $1.5 billion. Similarly extravagant, Robert Dudley hosted Queen Elizabeth I at Kenilworth Castle in 1575, spending £1,000 ($1,400) daily—millions in today's money—in a lavish attempt to woo her and propose marriage. Scholars describe this as Dudley's "last throw of the dice."

A highlight of the week-long festivities was to be a masque on July 20th, featuring Diana, goddess of chastity, searching for a nymph named "Zabetta" (a version of Elizabeth). The 1998 film "Elizabeth" suggests the masque concluded with a messenger of Juno, goddess of marriage, directly imploring Elizabeth to marry, rather than follow Diana's chaste path.

However, the masque never took place. While the official reason cited bad weather, speculation suggests the monarch was angered by the masque's thinly veiled subject matter, perceiving it as Dudley overstepping his bounds in pressuring her for marriage. The revelries concluded, and the Queen departed on July 27th.

The 450th anniversary of this historic visit is now commemorated by artist Lindsey Mendick's "Wicked Game," a large sculptural installation at Kenilworth Castle. Inspired by ancient mythology, Elizabeth's visit, and her shrewd political use of her unwed status throughout her 45-year reign, the installation features 13 fragmented ceramic tableaux. These sinister and darkly humorous pieces depict the Queen and those around her as animals, with Elizabeth as a lion and Dudley as a bear, all positioned on pieces of an exploded giant chessboard.
summary_tgt:
यहाँ उस अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

व्हाइट हाउस के निर्माण में कोई खर्च नहीं छोड़ा गया, जिसकी अनुमानित लागत $1.5 बिलियन थी। इसी तरह की फिजूलखर्ची करते हुए, रॉबर्ट डडली ने 1575 में केनिलवर्थ कैसल में महारानी एलिजाबेथ प्रथम की मेज़बानी की थी। उन्हें रिझाने और शादी का प्रस्ताव देने के एक भव्य प्रयास में, उन्होंने प्रतिदिन £1,000 ($1,400) खर्च किए, जो आज के समय में लाखों-करोड़ों रुपये के बराबर होंगे। विद्वान इसे डडली का "आखिरी दाँव" बताते हैं।

एक सप्ताह तक चलने वाले इन उत्सवों का एक मुख्य आकर्षण 20 जुलाई को होने वाला एक मुखौटा नाटक था। इसमें पवित्रता की देवी डायना को "ज़ाबेटा" (एलिजाबेथ का एक रूप) नामक एक अप्सरा की तलाश करते हुए दिखाया जाना था। 1998 की फिल्म 'एलिजाबेथ' बताती है कि इस मुखौटा नाटक का समापन विवाह की देवी जूनो के एक दूत द्वारा सीधे एलिजाबेथ से शादी करने का आग्रह करने के साथ हुआ, बजाय इसके कि वह डायना के पवित्र मार्ग का अनुसरण करें।

हालाँकि, यह मुखौटा नाटक कभी हो नहीं सका। इसका आधिकारिक कारण खराब मौसम बताया गया, लेकिन अटकलें बताती हैं कि महारानी इस मुखौटा नाटक की कमोबेश स्पष्ट विषय-वस्तु से क्रोधित थीं। उन्होंने इसे डडली द्वारा शादी के लिए उन पर दबाव डालने में अपनी सीमाओं का उल्लंघन माना। उत्सव समाप्त हो गए, और महारानी 27 जुलाई को प्रस्थान कर गईं।

इस ऐतिहासिक यात्रा की 450वीं वर्षगाँठ को अब कलाकार लिंडसे मेंडिक के 'विकेड गेम' नामक एक विशाल मूर्तिकला प्रतिष्ठान द्वारा केनिलवर्थ कैसल में स्मरण किया जा रहा है। प्राचीन पौराणिक कथाओं, एलिजाबेथ की यात्रा, और अपने 45 साल के शासनकाल के दौरान अपनी अविवाहित स्थिति के उनके चतुर राजनीतिक उपयोग से प्रेरित होकर, इस प्रतिष्ठान में 13 खंडित सिरेमिक झाँकियाँ शामिल हैं। ये भयावह और गहरे विनोदी टुकड़े महारानी और उनके आसपास के लोगों को जानवरों के रूप में दर्शाते हैं, जिसमें एलिजाबेथ को एक शेरनी और डडली को एक भालू के रूप में दिखाया गया है। ये सभी एक फटे हुए विशाल शतरंज बोर्ड के टुकड़ों पर स्थित हैं।
meta_description: Elizabeth I is the only English queen never to have married. The iconic Tudor monarch's last visit to Kenilworth Castle 450 years ago may hold some clues.

title_src: Watford Palace Theatre launches first new spaces in 115 years
text_src: Theatre unveils first new spaces in 115 years 2 hours ago Share Save Eric Johnson East of England Share Save Watford Palace Theatre The new creative spaces marks Watford Palace Theatre's first major expansion since opening in 1908 A theatre has launched five new creative spaces, including a studio for podcasting and digital content creation. Watford Palace Theatre said the new facilities would launch local artists "to the world", offering flexible environments for livestreaming, rehearsal, and performance. It added it was reacting to industry pressures to "find new audiences and new ways to be essential" to the community. Built in 1908, it gave early career opportunities to actors such as Ben Kingsley, Alison Steadman and Vicky McClure - and marks the venue's first major expansion in more than a century. New additions include the 1908 Cabaret, two studios, the Watford Palace Workshop, refreshed front-of-house areas, and a restored main house. CEO Steve Marmion called the transformation a pivotal moment for the 115-year-old theatre. "These new future facing spaces will allow us to perform to new audiences on new stages and screens," he said. Watford Palace Theatre Front-of-house spaces now feature arcade machines, bar games, and quirky touches like a musical toilet named The Sir Elton John John The 1908 Cabaret will serve as a co-working space by day and a cabaret venue by night, with 'pay what you can' events like Sip and Craft Mondays and Open Mic Wednesdays on offer. Studio 1 will support podcasting and digital media, while Studio 2 becomes a hub for rehearsals and showcases, with both available to emerging talent such as the Watford Palace Young Company. The Watford Palace Workshop, once a barn, is now a space for community groups and houses the theatre's backstage and admin teams. Front-of-house areas now feature arcade machines, bar games, and quirky touches like a fortune-telling pig and a musical toilet named The Sir Elton John John. Watford Palace Theatre The transformation reimagines the historic venue as a multi-media creative hub The transformation was made possible through funding from the Salix Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme and The Backstage Trust. Environmental upgrades, such as replacing gas boilers and chillers with energy-efficient air source heat pumps, will make the building more sustainable while supporting Watford Borough Council's wider climate goals. The improvements will cut the theatre's carbon emissions by around 75%, saving nearly 1,300 tonnes of CO₂ over 20 years. Mr Marmion said, "The industry is under pressure like never before with decreasing funding and less money in people's pockets. We have to react and find new audiences and new ways to be essential to our communities". "Our bars and front of house spaces have had a full glow-up and are resplendent with new offers, games and fun shiny things to play with," he added. Follow Beds, Herts and Bucks news on BBC Sounds, Facebook, Instagram and X. More on this story Diwali theatre show celebrates cultural diversity
summary_src:
Watford Palace Theatre has completed its first major expansion in 115 years, transforming the 1908 venue into a multi-media creative hub. The redevelopment introduces flexible new spaces for livestreaming, rehearsal, and performance, including the 1908 Cabaret (serving as a co-working and evening venue), two dedicated studios for podcasting/digital media and rehearsals, and the Watford Palace Workshop for community groups. Refreshed front-of-house areas now feature arcade machines, bar games, and quirky touches.

CEO Steve Marmion called the transformation a "pivotal moment," driven by industry pressures to "find new audiences and new ways to be essential" amidst decreasing funding. The theatre aims to launch local artists globally and engage new audiences through these "future facing spaces."

Crucially, the project includes significant environmental upgrades, replacing gas boilers with energy-efficient air source heat pumps. These improvements are projected to cut the theatre's carbon emissions by 75%, saving nearly 1,300 tonnes of CO₂ over 20 years, aligning with Watford Borough Council's climate goals. The transformation was made possible through funding from the Salix Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme and The Backstage Trust.
summary_tgt:
**वाटफोर्ड पैलेस थिएटर का 115 वर्षों में पहला बड़ा विस्तार: एक मल्टी-मीडिया रचनात्मक केंद्र में रूपांतरण**

वाटफोर्ड पैलेस थिएटर ने 115 वर्षों में अपना पहला बड़ा विस्तार पूरा कर लिया है, जिसने 1908 के इस स्थल को एक मल्टी-मीडिया रचनात्मक केंद्र में बदल दिया है। इस पुनर्विकास के तहत लाइवस्ट्रीमिंग, पूर्वाभ्यास और प्रदर्शन के लिए लचीले नए स्थान बनाए गए हैं। इनमें 1908 कैबरे (जो सह-कार्यस्थल और शाम के कार्यक्रम स्थल के रूप में कार्य करेगा), पॉडकास्टिंग/डिजिटल मीडिया और पूर्वाभ्यास के लिए दो समर्पित स्टूडियो, और सामुदायिक समूहों के लिए वाटफोर्ड पैलेस वर्कशॉप शामिल हैं। नवीनीकृत फ्रंट-ऑफ-हाउस क्षेत्रों में अब आर्केड मशीनें, बार गेम्स और कुछ अनोखे आकर्षण मौजूद हैं।

सीईओ स्टीव मार्मियन ने इस बदलाव को "एक महत्वपूर्ण मोड़" बताया। उन्होंने कहा कि यह उद्योग के उन दबावों के कारण हुआ है जिसमें घटती फंडिंग के बीच "नए दर्शकों को खोजने और आवश्यक बने रहने के नए तरीके खोजने" की आवश्यकता थी। थिएटर का लक्ष्य इन "भविष्योन्मुखी स्थानों" के माध्यम से स्थानीय कलाकारों को विश्व स्तर पर लॉन्च करना और नए दर्शकों को जोड़ना है।

महत्वपूर्ण बात यह है कि इस परियोजना में महत्वपूर्ण पर्यावरणीय उन्नयन (अपग्रेड) शामिल हैं, जिसमें गैस बॉयलर को ऊर्जा-कुशल एयर सोर्स हीट पंपों से बदल दिया गया है। इन सुधारों से थिएटर के कार्बन उत्सर्जन में 75% की कमी आने का अनुमान है, जिससे 20 वर्षों में लगभग 1,300 टन CO₂ की बचत होगी। यह वाटफोर्ड बोरो काउंसिल के जलवायु लक्ष्यों के अनुरूप भी है। यह परिवर्तन सैलिक्स पब्लिक सेक्टर डीकार्बोनाइजेशन स्कीम और द बैकस्टेज ट्रस्ट से प्राप्त फंडिंग के माध्यम से संभव हुआ।
meta_description: Watford Palace Theatre takes centre stage as it unveils five newly developed creative spaces.

title_src: The lost 1934 novel that gave a chilling warning about the horrors of Nazi Germany
text_src: The celebrated US novelist EL Doctorow, author of Ragtime, Billy Bathgate and other works of fiction set in the past, once said: "The historian will tell you what happened. The novelist can tell you what it felt like." And Carson's achievement is to bring to vivid life the fictional Kluger family, residing near the mountains south of Munich who over the course of six months – Christmas Eve 1932 to Midsummer Night 1933 – see their lives shattered. Carson wrote Crooked Cross – the title refers to the swastika symbol adopted by the Nazis – at speed. It was published in 1934, a year after the events she recounts. Reviews were laudatory, and Carson turned her novel into a play that premiered at the Birmingham Repertory Theatre in 1935, transferring to London's West End two years later. Carson proved remarkably prescient about the horrors to come, and yet after her premature death, in 1941 from breast cancer, her novel sank into obscurity. Persephone's decision to reissue it now is a wise and welcome one. Persephone Books Sylvia "Sally" Carson was inspired to write a novel about the dawn of Nazi tyranny in a small German town (Credit: Persephone Books) The action opens when Hans and Rosa Kluger, and their three adult children – daughter Lexa, and sons Helmy and Erich – gather for the Christmas holiday. Life is hard in Depression-era Germany. Herr Kluger's salary at the Post Office has been cut, eldest son Helmy is out of work, and Erich's seasonal job as a ski instructor requires humiliating catering to the whims of rich women. But Christmas is "a time for the knitting together of personal happiness, and of completing the magic circle of their family," Carson writes. Lexa's handsome and successful fiancé, the young surgeon Moritz Weissman, is included in all the celebrations. When Helmy and Lexa take charge of decorating the tree – the two siblings have always been close – the festive setting is described precisely, with a passing reference to "Helmy's picture of Hitler" that sits on the piano, decorated with fir twigs, like everything else in the cosy house. The scene lulls the reader into believing, despite the flicker of menace, that nothing can break this loyal, decent and loving clan.
summary_src:
Inspired by US novelist EL Doctorow's distinction between a historian telling "what happened" and a novelist conveying "what it felt like," Sally Carson's remarkably prescient 1934 novel, *Crooked Cross* (a reference to the swastika), is being reissued by Persephone after decades of obscurity.

Carson, who also wrote about the Great Depression, penned the book quickly, publishing it just a year after the events it depicts. It vividly portrays the fictional Kluger family, residing near Munich, whose lives are shattered over six pivotal months, from Christmas Eve 1932 to Midsummer Night 1933, as Nazi tyranny begins to take hold.

The novel opens during a difficult Depression-era Christmas for the Klugers, a time of financial struggles for Hans and Rosa and their adult children, Lexa, Helmy, and Erich, despite their efforts to preserve family happiness. Lexa's handsome surgeon fiancé, Moritz Weissman, joins their celebrations, while subtle ominous details like "Helmy's picture of Hitler" on the piano hint at the looming menace.

Despite receiving laudatory reviews and being adapted into a successful play that transferred to London's West End, Carson's insightful work, written before her premature death in 1941, faded from public memory. Its current reissue is a timely and welcome decision, allowing a new generation to experience its powerful depiction of a family's unraveling at the dawn of Nazi Germany.
summary_tgt:
अमेरिकी उपन्यासकार ईएल डॉक्टरोव के इस अंतर से प्रेरित होकर कि एक इतिहासकार 'जो हुआ' बताता है और एक उपन्यासकार 'जो महसूस हुआ' उसे व्यक्त करता है, सैली कार्सन का असाधारण रूप से दूरदर्शी 1934 का उपन्यास, *क्रुक्ड क्रॉस* (जो स्वस्तिक का संदर्भ है), दशकों की गुमनामी के बाद पर्सेफनी द्वारा पुन: प्रकाशित किया जा रहा है।

कार्सन, जिन्होंने महामंदी पर भी लिखा था, ने यह किताब तेज़ी से लिखी और जिन घटनाओं को यह दर्शाती है, उनके ठीक एक साल बाद इसे प्रकाशित कर दिया। यह म्यूनिख के पास रहने वाले काल्पनिक क्लूगर परिवार का सजीव चित्रण करती है, जिनका जीवन क्रिसमस ईव 1932 से मिडसमर नाइट 1933 तक के छह महत्वपूर्ण महीनों में बिखर जाता है, जब नाज़ी अत्याचार अपनी पकड़ बनाना शुरू करते हैं।

उपन्यास की शुरुआत क्लूगर परिवार के लिए महामंदी के दौर की एक मुश्किल क्रिसमस से होती है। यह हैंस और रोज़ा तथा उनके वयस्क बच्चों लेक्सा, हेल्मी और एरिख के लिए वित्तीय संघर्ष का समय है, परिवार की खुशियों को बनाए रखने के उनके प्रयासों के बावजूद। लेक्सा का सुंदर सर्जन मंगेतर, मोरिट्ज़ वीसमैन, उनके समारोहों में शामिल होता है, जबकि पियानो पर 'हेल्मी की हिटलर की तस्वीर' जैसे सूक्ष्म अशुभ विवरण आसन्न खतरे का संकेत देते हैं।

सराहनीय समीक्षाएँ मिलने और एक सफल नाटक में रूपांतरित होने के बावजूद, जिसे लंदन के वेस्ट एंड में भी प्रदर्शित किया गया था, कार्सन का यह गहन कार्य, जो 1941 में उनकी असामयिक मृत्यु से पहले लिखा गया था, सार्वजनिक स्मृति से ओझल हो गया। इसका वर्तमान पुन:प्रकाशन एक सामयिक और स्वागत योग्य निर्णय है, जो एक नई पीढ़ी को नाज़ी जर्मनी के उदय के समय एक परिवार के बिखरने के इसके शक्तिशाली चित्रण का अनुभव करने का अवसर देता है।
meta_description: Published years before WW2, Sally Carson's prescient novel captures the dawn of Nazi tyranny in a small German town – and remains relevant today.

title_src: How opera is aiming for net zero
text_src: The power of Glyndebourne In 2012, executive chairman Gus Christie oversaw the installation of a 67m (220ft)-tall wind turbine on a hill adjacent to the opera house, which between then and 2022 has generated the equivalent of 102% of the electricity used by the company in the same period. The turbine serves as an important statement of intent for Glyndebourne. Alison Tickell, the founder and chief executive of Julie's Bicycle, a non-profit organisation dedicated to mobilising the UK arts and culture sectors in a fight against climate change, says in the documentary: "I know that many opera companies… don't have the luxury of space. But [the turbine] still remains a beacon for us all [demonstrating] that climate action really matters." Getty Images The grounds at Glyndebourne have been carefully tended for decades, and are central to the audience's experience (Credit: Getty Images) Glyndebourne has innovated in sustainable practice in the years since. In 2021, it joined the global Race to Zero, pledging to halve its direct carbon emissions by 2030, and to reach net zero by 2050. "We are zero waste to landfill now, so any waste we have goes down to [an] incinerator, which provides power for local homes," Christie says of some of the measures he and his team have taken to achieve this. "We compost all our garden waste, we recycle as much of our stage-set material, costumes, props [as we can]. We have about 32 electric vehicle charging points [for visitors] which are all charged from the wind turbine." They are drawing from their resources in other ways, too: by the end of this year, they predict, all water served at Glyndebourne will come from the property's own natural spring, while plants grown in their gardens are being used to produce dyes for the company's costumes. "Rivers around the world are polluted by dyes a lot," says dye room supervisor Jenny Mercer in the documentary. "This way everything goes back into the ground."
summary_src:
Glyndebourne opera house has established itself as a global leader in environmental sustainability, spearheaded by executive chairman Gus Christie. A 67-meter wind turbine, installed in 2012, has been central to these efforts, generating 102% of the company's electricity between 2012 and 2022. This pioneering turbine is seen as a "beacon" for climate action, demonstrating the arts sector's potential to address climate change, as highlighted by Alison Tickell of Julie's Bicycle.

Beyond the turbine, Glyndebourne has adopted a comprehensive approach to eco-conscious operations. In 2021, it joined the global Race to Zero, committing to halve its direct carbon emissions by 2030 and achieve net zero by 2050. Current initiatives include achieving zero waste to landfill, with waste providing power for local homes, and extensive recycling of stage-set materials, costumes, and props. The site also offers 32 electric vehicle charging points powered directly by the wind turbine.

Further innovations by year-end include sourcing all water from its natural spring and using garden-grown plants to produce dyes for costumes, a move praised by dye room supervisor Jenny Mercer for reducing river pollution and ensuring materials return to the ground.

यहाँ ग्लाइंडबोर्न ओपेरा हाउस की अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

**ग्लाइंडबोर्न ओपेरा हाउस पर्यावरणीय स्थिरता में वैश्विक अगुआ के रूप में स्थापित हुआ**

ग्लाइंडबोर्न ओपेरा हाउस ने कार्यकारी अध्यक्ष गस क्रिस्टी की अगुवाई में, पर्यावरणीय स्थिरता के क्षेत्र में एक वैश्विक अगुआ के रूप में अपनी पहचान बनाई है। 2012 में स्थापित 67 मीटर का एक पवन टरबाइन इन प्रयासों के केंद्र में रहा है, जिसने 2012 से 2022 के बीच कंपनी की कुल बिजली आवश्यकता का 102% उत्पन्न किया। जूलीज़ बाइसिकल की एलिसन टिकेल द्वारा रेखांकित किए गए अनुसार, इस अग्रणी टरबाइन को जलवायु कार्रवाई के लिए एक 'प्रकाशस्तंभ' के रूप में देखा जाता है, जो जलवायु परिवर्तन से निपटने में कला क्षेत्र की क्षमता को दर्शाता है।

टरबाइन के अलावा, ग्लाइंडबोर्न ने पर्यावरण-अनुकूल संचालन के लिए एक व्यापक दृष्टिकोण अपनाया है। 2021 में, यह वैश्विक 'रेस टू ज़ीरो' में शामिल हुआ, जिसने 2030 तक अपने प्रत्यक्ष कार्बन उत्सर्जन को आधा करने और 2050 तक नेट ज़ीरो हासिल करने की प्रतिबद्धता जताई है। वर्तमान पहलों में लैंडफिल में शून्य अपशिष्ट का लक्ष्य हासिल करना शामिल है, जिसमें कचरे का उपयोग स्थानीय घरों को बिजली प्रदान करने के लिए किया जाता है, साथ ही स्टेज-सेट सामग्री, वेशभूषा और प्रॉप्स का व्यापक पुनर्चक्रण भी किया जाता है। यह साइट 32 इलेक्ट्रिक वाहन चार्जिंग पॉइंट भी प्रदान करती है, जो सीधे पवन टरबाइन से संचालित होते हैं।

वर्ष के अंत तक के अन्य नवाचारों में अपने प्राकृतिक झरने से सारा पानी प्राप्त करना और वेशभूषा के लिए रंग बनाने हेतु बगीचे में उगाए गए पौधों का उपयोग करना शामिल है। डाई रूम सुपरवाइजर जेनी मर्सर ने इस कदम की प्रशंसा की है क्योंकि यह नदी प्रदूषण को कम करता है और यह सुनिश्चित करता है कि सामग्री वापस ज़मीन में मिल जाए।
meta_description: Many opera companies are working towards full sustainability, and Glyndebourne is among those aiming to be a force for good, according to a new documentary.

title_src: Coventry's Albany Theatre showcases work by local writers
text_src: City theatre showcases work by local writers 1 hour ago Share Save Tanya Gupta West Midlands Share Save Ross Kernahan At Last explores the aftermath of a far-right government's fall after 10 years in office Dramatists have tackled subjects from a UK dystopia to the life of a dominatrix, in plays to be showcased next weekend. Coventry's Albany Theatre received funds from the Arts Council to put on a weekend celebrating local talent. Three new plays will be shown on Saturday and Sunday in the Spotlight Studio Theatre. The two-day festival, In the Spotlight, is the first major public showcase led by new theatre director Alan Pollock, who grew up in the city. He said he wanted to inspire more people in the city to explore their creative talents. Albany Theatre The studio theatre was created as part of the Albany's £3m redevelopment "We hear a lot about discovering new voices," he said, "but what I'm really interested in are Coventry voices and Midlands stories." He said the industry was good at spotting talent, but it needed to be sustained. He said the festival aimed to inspire the next generation of local writers and performers. "As a Coventry kid myself, this is exactly the kind of work I believe in – offering meaningful platforms, nurturing creative careers, and helping our city's talent shine," he said. Rugby-based writer Siobhan Healey has written Unleashed, which applies "raw honesty and wit" to themes of shame and sexuality. Lara J West, from Earlsdon in Coventry, has created a one-woman musical, One Kiss, which featured at the Edinburgh Fringe. Both will be performed on Saturday. The third play, At Last, will close the festival on Sunday, following a question and answer session with a creative panel. At Last has been billed as a "haunting new play", directed by Walgrave-born David Brady, exploring the aftermath of a far-right government's fall after 10 years in office. The studio theatre was created as part of the Albany's £3m redevelopment, which was completed in 2024. Follow BBC Coventry & Warwickshire on BBC Sounds, Facebook, X and Instagram.
summary_src:
Coventry's Albany Theatre is set to host "In the Spotlight," a two-day festival this weekend (Saturday and Sunday), showcasing new plays by local West Midlands writers. Supported by Arts Council funding, the event marks the first major public showcase led by new theatre director Alan Pollock, a Coventry native.

Pollock aims to inspire local residents to explore their creative talents, nurturing careers and highlighting "Coventry voices and Midlands stories." The festival takes place in the new Spotlight Studio Theatre, part of the Albany's ongoing £3 million redevelopment, which is expected to be completed in 2024.

The festival features three new plays:
*   **"Unleashed"** by Rugby-based writer Siobhan Healey, which explores themes of shame and sexuality.
*   **"One Kiss,"** a one-woman musical by Coventry's Lara J West, previously featured at the Edinburgh Fringe. Both "Unleashed" and "One Kiss" will be performed on Saturday.
*   **"At Last,"** a "haunting" new play directed by David Brady, which delves into the aftermath of a far-right government's fall. This play will close the festival on Sunday, followed by a question and answer session with a creative panel.
summary_tgt:
**कोवेंट्री के अल्बानी थिएटर में 'इन द स्पॉटलाइट' नामक दो दिवसीय महोत्सव का आयोजन इस सप्ताहांत (शनिवार और रविवार) किया जाएगा, जिसमें वेस्ट मिडलैंड्स के स्थानीय लेखकों के नए नाटक प्रदर्शित किए जाएंगे। आर्ट्स काउंसिल से मिले वित्तपोषण के साथ, यह महोत्सव नए थिएटर निर्देशक एलन पॉलक, जो कोवेंट्री के ही मूल निवासी हैं, के नेतृत्व में पहला प्रमुख सार्वजनिक प्रदर्शन है।**

पॉलोक का लक्ष्य स्थानीय निवासियों को अपनी रचनात्मक प्रतिभाओं को तलाशने, करियर को बढ़ावा देने और 'कोवेंट्री की आवाज़ों और मिडलैंड्स की कहानियों' को उजागर करने के लिए प्रेरित करना है। यह महोत्सव नए स्पॉटलाइट स्टूडियो थिएटर में आयोजित होगा, जो अल्बानी के चल रहे 3 मिलियन पाउंड के पुनर्विकास का हिस्सा है, और जिसके 2024 में पूरा होने की उम्मीद है।

इस महोत्सव में तीन नए नाटक शामिल हैं:

*   **"अनलीश्ड"** - रग्बी स्थित लेखिका सिओभान हीली द्वारा लिखित, जो शर्म और यौनता (sexuality) के विषयों की पड़ताल करता है।
*   **"वन किस"** - कोवेंट्री की लारा जे वेस्ट का एक एकल-महिला संगीत नाटक, जिसे पहले एडिनबर्ग फ्रिंज में भी प्रदर्शित किया जा चुका है। "अनलीश्ड" और "वन किस" दोनों नाटक शनिवार को प्रदर्शित किए जाएंगे।
*   **"एट लास्ट"** - डेविड ब्रेडी द्वारा निर्देशित एक "विचारोत्तेजक" नया नाटक, जो एक धुर-दक्षिणपंथी सरकार के पतन के बाद की घटनाओं की पड़ताल करता है। यह नाटक रविवार को महोत्सव का समापन करेगा, जिसके बाद एक रचनात्मक पैनल के साथ प्रश्नोत्तर सत्र होगा।

title_src: The cryptic symbolism of Van Gogh's Sunflowers – and what they really mean
text_src: They helped to make Vincent van Gogh among the most famous and influential painters in the history of art. Why did sunflowers obsess him and so many other artists before and since? When we think about Vincent van Gogh, most people will instantly call to mind his iconic, boldly executed and citrus-warm sunflowers. It's a piece of brand recognition that the artist fully intended. "The sunflower is mine", he once wrote, betraying his desire to be publicly associated with this brazen, man-sized plant and its swaggering, flame-maned crown of petals. Sunflowers clearly had a deep significance for him. So what, if anything, did Vincent intend to symbolise with his beloved helianthus annuus? Alongside Starry Night, the National Gallery in London's Sunflowers is perhaps his most recognisable artwork. But the artist also painted 10 other canvases that focused on these flowers. They came in three short bursts of inspiration. First was a series of four created in Paris in 1887. The second batch of four canvases were created in less than a week after his move to the southern French city of Arles in 1888. The third phase (in early 1889) involved copying three of the previous year's compositions. The most famous versions from 1888 were painted in a flurry of confidence and sensual joy, "with the gusto of a Marseillaise eating bouillabaisse," as he put it. And yet, when he wrote about sunflowers in his letters, Van Gogh never made clear statements about what they truly meant to him. The National Gallery, London Alongside Starry Night, Sunflowers is Van Gogh's most recognisable artwork (Credit: The National Gallery, London) On one hand they appear to be a vehicle for experimenting with colour combinations – particularly the pairings of different shades of yellow. But they were also intended to fill a house where a fellow artist, Paul Gauguin, was due to live. Gauguin had admired Van Gogh's previous sunflower paintings, so perhaps they embodied the artist's irrepressible hopes for solidarity and friendship – desires that would ultimately be thwarted along with Vincent's yearning for artistic recognition in his lifetime. Gauguin left Van Gogh after only two months, and Vincent would die at the age of 37 having failed to sell many of his own artworks.
summary_src:
Vincent van Gogh's iconic "Sunflowers" series is central to his renown and influence, with the artist actively seeking public association with the vibrant plant, famously declaring, "The sunflower is mine." These flowers held deep personal significance for him, symbolizing love and hope.

While the National Gallery's "Sunflowers" is among his most recognizable works, Van Gogh actually painted at least ten other canvases featuring the flowers in three distinct creative bursts. The first series of four was produced in Paris in 1887, followed by another four in Arles in 1888, painted with a "flurry of confidence and sensual joy." A final phase in 1889 involved copying earlier compositions.

Despite his clear obsession, Van Gogh never explicitly detailed the sunflowers' meaning in his letters. However, some were intended to decorate a house for fellow artist Paul Gauguin, suggesting they may have embodied his hopes for solidarity and friendship. Tragically, Gauguin's eventual departure and Van Gogh's early death at 37, having sold few of his works, stand in stark contrast to the enduring global fame and symbolic power of his beloved sunflowers.
summary_tgt:
**विन्सेंट वैन गॉग की प्रतिष्ठित 'सनफ्लावर्स' (सूरजमुखी) श्रृंखला उनकी प्रसिद्धि और प्रभाव का केंद्र है। कलाकार सक्रिय रूप से इस चमकीले पौधे के साथ सार्वजनिक जुड़ाव चाहते थे, और उन्होंने प्रसिद्ध रूप से घोषणा की थी, "सूरजमुखी मेरा है।" ये फूल उनके लिए गहरा व्यक्तिगत महत्व रखते थे, जो प्रेम और आशा का प्रतीक थे।**

**हालाँकि नेशनल गैलरी की 'सनफ्लावर्स' उनकी सबसे अधिक पहचानी जाने वाली कृतियों में से एक है, वैन गॉग ने वास्तव में तीन अलग-अलग रचनात्मक चरणों में इन फूलों को दर्शाने वाले कम से कम दस अन्य कैनवस चित्रित किए थे। चार चित्रों की पहली श्रृंखला 1887 में पेरिस में बनाई गई थी, जिसके बाद 1888 में आर्ल्स में चार और चित्र "आत्मविश्वास और इंद्रिय सुख की लहर" के साथ चित्रित किए गए। 1889 में एक अंतिम चरण में, उन्होंने अपनी पहले की रचनाओं की नकल की थी।**

**अपनी स्पष्ट धुन (जुनून) के बावजूद, वैन गॉग ने अपने पत्रों में सूरजमुखी के अर्थ का कभी स्पष्ट रूप से विस्तार से वर्णन नहीं किया। हालाँकि, कुछ चित्र साथी कलाकार पॉल गाउगुइन के घर को सजाने के उद्देश्य से बनाए गए थे, जिससे यह पता चलता है कि वे एकजुटता और दोस्ती के लिए उनकी आशाओं का प्रतीक रहे होंगे। दुखद रूप से, गाउगुइन का अंततः चले जाना और वैन गॉग की 37 वर्ष की कम उम्र में मृत्यु (जब उन्होंने अपने बहुत कम काम बेचे थे), उनके प्रिय सूरजमुखी की स्थायी वैश्विक प्रसिद्धि और प्रतीकात्मक शक्ति के बिल्कुल विपरीत है।**
