According to Dr Baba Mallaye, a team member involved in the discovery, not only has Toumaï's age been scientifically validated by radio chronological analysis, but the team also found many other fossilised remains of Toumaï's cousins in the same area, proving that this was not an isolated case. To reach Ennedi, Bonomo and I drove through savannah with desert roses, yellow grasses and acacia trees gleaming gold. We passed nomadic Wodaabe and Oulad-Rachid people on the move. Women and children rode up on camels, seated inside colourful chariots decorated with vivid fabrics, carved calabashes and rows of bronze bowls. Men walked alongside, leather amulets strapped across their chests like small suitcases to protect them from evil. Then the tarmac road stopped, the land emptied of trees and entering Ennedi was like stepping through a portal into a place between worlds. Ennedi's rock art reveals the changes that have happened over millennia to this land. Like the whole of the Sahara, the area was once green and glittered with lakes. Many people once lived here, but now few do. As I wandered among the red monoliths, I saw images of elephants, rhinos, giraffes and ostriches – all common wild animals in Ennedi until relevantly recently. After the area became drier more than 6,000 years ago, these animals either moved south or died out. Yet, Ennedi remains known as the Eden of the Sahara because it receives more rain than the rest of the desert, creating wadis like green ribbons and permanent water sources fed by crystal-clear springs. Tropical plants bloom and relics of its more temperate times survive, like its desert crocodiles.
summary_src:
The Ennedi region in Chad, a Switzerland-sized area, was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2016 and is now a protected Natural and Cultural Reserve overseen by African Parks due to its immense biodiversity.

It holds significant archaeological importance, with a recently initiated long-term study mapping extensive rock art and investigating surrounding ground that has already yielded a 7,000-year-old piece of pottery, suggesting vast undiscovered potential. This builds on the 2001 discovery of Toumaï, a scientifically validated 7-million-year-old fossilised skull found nearby, which, being older than "Lucy," has led some to propose Chad as a possible origin of humanity.

Ennedi's rock art vividly illustrates its ancient past when the Sahara was a green landscape with lakes and abundant megafauna like elephants and giraffes. These animals either migrated or died out as the region became significantly drier over 6,000 years ago, leading to a decline in human population.

Despite this environmental transformation, Ennedi is known as the "Eden of the Sahara" due to its unique microclimate receiving more rain, sustaining permanent wadis, crystal-clear springs, tropical plants, and relict species such as desert crocodiles. Accessing this remote yet culturally rich area involves traveling through savannas and encountering nomadic Wodaabe and Oulad-Rachid communities.
summary_tgt:
चाड का एनेडी क्षेत्र, जो स्विट्जरलैंड के आकार का है, 2016 में यूनेस्को विश्व धरोहर स्थल घोषित किया गया था। अपनी अपार जैव विविधता के कारण, यह अब अफ्रीकन पार्क्स द्वारा देखरेख किया जाने वाला एक संरक्षित प्राकृतिक और सांस्कृतिक आरक्षित क्षेत्र है।

यह पुरातात्विक रूप से भी अत्यधिक महत्वपूर्ण है। हाल ही में शुरू हुए एक दीर्घकालिक अध्ययन में यहाँ की व्यापक शैल कला (rock art) का मानचित्रण किया जा रहा है और आसपास की भूमि की भी जाँच की जा रही है, जिससे पहले ही 7,000 साल पुराना एक मिट्टी का बर्तन मिला है, जो विशाल अज्ञात क्षमता की ओर इशारा करता है। इसका महत्व पास में 2001 में तुम्हेई (Toumaï) की खोज से और बढ़ जाता है, जो एक वैज्ञानिक रूप से मान्य 70 लाख (7 मिलियन) साल पुरानी जीवाश्म खोपड़ी थी। 'लूसी' से भी पुरानी होने के कारण, इस खोज ने कुछ लोगों को चाड को मानवता का संभावित मूल स्थान मानने के लिए प्रेरित किया है।

एनेडी की शैल कला इसके प्राचीन अतीत को स्पष्ट रूप से दर्शाती है, जब सहारा झीलों और हाथियों व जिराफ जैसे प्रचुर विशालकाय जीवों (megafauna) के साथ एक हरा-भरा परिदृश्य था। 6,000 साल पहले यह क्षेत्र काफी शुष्क होने के कारण ये जानवर या तो पलायन कर गए या विलुप्त हो गए, जिससे मानवीय आबादी में भी गिरावट आई।

इस पर्यावरणीय परिवर्तन के बावजूद, एनेडी को "सहारा का स्वर्ग" (या "सहारा का ईडन") कहा जाता है। इसका कारण इसकी अनूठी सूक्ष्म जलवायु है जहाँ अधिक वर्षा होती है, जिससे यहाँ स्थायी वादी (सूखी नदी घाटियां), क्रिस्टल-साफ झरने, उष्णकटिबंधीय पौधे और मरुस्थलीय मगरमच्छ जैसी अवशेष प्रजातियाँ मौजूद हैं। इस दूरस्थ लेकिन सांस्कृतिक रूप से समृद्ध क्षेत्र तक पहुँचने के लिए सवाना से होकर यात्रा करनी पड़ती है और यहाँ खानाबदोश वोडाबे (Wodaabe) और औलाद-रशीद (Oulad-Rachid) समुदायों से भी मिलना होता है।
meta_description: It contains one of the world's largest concentrations of prehistoric art, yet is barely known to the rest of the world.

title_src: The Himalayan village where you can see the cosmos
text_src: In the Moon-like landscape of Hanle, the jet-black skies reveal otherworldly starry skies that lure travellers from far and wide. But can locals preserve the natural darkness? I'm walking downhill as evening gives way to night, transfixed by what is unfolding above. As though someone is slowly rolling a screen in a shadow puppet show, an inky blue canvas emerges, where stars pop left and right. Mouth agape, I realise that the hazy band of light stretching above me is the Milky Way. A howl from a dog perched on a rock ledge brings me back to terra firma. I'm on Mount Digpa Ratsa Ri in the village of Hanle, where the Earth and cosmos are in close communion. Situated at 5,290m above sea level in the barren, Moon-like landscape of northern India's Ladakh region, Hanle rates "one" (the darkest) on the Bortle dark sky scale, with 270 clear nights a year. Here, locals routinely switch off the lights after sunset to reveal the nightly eye-popping displays of stars. Over the last few years, travellers have been drawn to Hanle not just for the jet-black skies but also for the chance to experience astronomy intimately, guided by locals who are now making the cosmos their livelihood. Since 2022, when the Hanle Dark Sky Reserve (HDSR) was founded here – spanning 1,074 sq km, six villages, a monastery and 10 stationary telescopes – a network of homestays has flourished. Local-led stargazing expeditions unfold on rooftops, courtyards and below the dome-shaped Indian Astronomical Observatory, which houses one of the world's highest optical telescopes. Another stellar event is Hanle's annual Star Party, held each September at the end of the brief four-month window when the village is accessible to outsiders before the harsh winter sets in. The nocturnal festival draws serious stargazers and astrophotographers from across India, who come armed with telescopes and specialised cameras for deep sky observations.
summary_src:
The remote village of Hanle in India's Ladakh region, renowned for its barren, moon-like landscape and situated at 5,290m above sea level, is emerging as a premier destination for dark sky tourism. Boasting a Bortle dark sky scale rating of "one" and 270 clear nights annually, Hanle offers unparalleled views of the cosmos, including the Milky Way, thanks to locals routinely switching off lights after sunset to preserve the natural darkness.

Since the establishment of the Hanle Dark Sky Reserve (HDSR) in 2022—spanning 1,074 sq km and encompassing six villages, a monastery, and 10 stationary telescopes—tourism has flourished, transforming the cosmos into a livelihood for residents. Visitors are drawn not only by the jet-black skies but also by the opportunity for intimate astronomy experiences. A network of homestays has developed, and local-led stargazing expeditions are conducted on rooftops, courtyards, and near the Indian Astronomical Observatory, which houses one of the world's highest optical telescopes. Hanle also hosts an annual Star Party each September, drawing serious stargazers and astrophotographers from across India for deep sky observations.
summary_tgt:
यहाँ अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

भारत के लद्दाख क्षेत्र में स्थित सुदूर गाँव हानले, जो अपने बंजर, चंद्रमा जैसे परिदृश्य के लिए विख्यात है और समुद्र तल से 5,290 मीटर की ऊँचाई पर स्थित है, डार्क स्काई पर्यटन के लिए एक प्रमुख गंतव्य के रूप में उभर रहा है। बॉर्टल डार्क स्काई स्केल पर "एक" की रेटिंग और सालाना 270 साफ़ रातों के साथ, हानले ब्रह्मांड के अद्वितीय दृश्य प्रदान करता है, जिसमें आकाशगंगा (मिल्की वे) भी शामिल है। यह स्थानीय लोगों द्वारा सूर्यास्त के बाद प्राकृतिक अँधेरे को बनाए रखने के लिए नियमित रूप से बत्तियाँ बंद करने के कारण संभव होता है।

2022 में हानले डार्क स्काई रिज़र्व (एचडीएसआर) की स्थापना के बाद से—जो 1,074 वर्ग किलोमीटर में फैला हुआ है और जिसमें छह गाँव, एक मठ और 10 स्थिर दूरबीनें शामिल हैं—पर्यटन में वृद्धि हुई है, जिससे ब्रह्मांड स्थानीय निवासियों के लिए आजीविका का साधन बन गया है। आगंतुक न केवल स्याह काले आसमान से आकर्षित होते हैं, बल्कि अंतरंग खगोलीय अनुभवों के अवसर से भी लुभाते हैं। होमस्टे का एक नेटवर्क विकसित हो गया है, और स्थानीय लोगों के नेतृत्व में तारें देखने के अभियान छतों, आँगनों और भारतीय खगोलीय वेधशाला के पास आयोजित किए जाते हैं, जहाँ दुनिया की सबसे ऊँची ऑप्टिकल दूरबीनों में से एक स्थापित है। हानले हर सितंबर में एक वार्षिक 'स्टार पार्टी' की भी मेज़बानी करता है, जो पूरे भारत से गंभीर खगोल प्रेमियों और एस्ट्रोफोटोग्राफरों को गहरे आकाश के अवलोकन के लिए आकर्षित करती है।
meta_description: In the Moon-like landscape of Hanle, the jet-black skies reveal otherworldly starry skies that lure travellers from far and wide. But can locals preserve the natural darkness?

title_src: From trash to tasting menu: The market that feeds Mexico City's best restaurants
text_src: How Central de Abasto, the world's largest market hidden in Mexico City's so-called "trash district", has become the unlikely backbone of its fine-dining revolution. Mexico City's status as one of the world's top culinary capitals is often credited to the creative tasting menus and celebrity chef collaborations found in its upscale Roma Norte neighbourhood. But the flavours served on those affluent, tree-lined streets often begin their journey to the plate at dawn – in a sprawling, chaotic market in one of the city's poorest boroughs. Located in Iztapalapa, Central de Abasto is the largest wholesale market in the world, covering 3.27 sq km – roughly the size of New York City's Central Park – and supplying 80% of the capital's produce. Between 04:00 and 08:00, the sprawl feels like a scene from Blade Runner, with buyers elbowing their way through narrow paths to haggle at thousands of warehouses and slapdash produce stalls. Diableros (hand-truck porters) sprint through the maze of crowds and beeping trucks, careful not to bump into colleagues balancing wooden crates on their heads. Whenever I hear a trilling whistle, I jump aside to let a "little devil" race past with a comically overloaded bundle. Central de Abasto opened in 1982 to replace La Merced, CDMX's colonial-era trading centre. Every day, it welcomes half a million visitors and handles more than 30,000 tons of produce from across Mexico. The ramshackle vibe is characteristic of Iztapalapa, historically derided as a "trash district" for its landfills and prisons. Today, 43% of its two million residents live in moderate to extreme poverty, making it one of the capital's poorest boroughs. Yet Central's pivotal role in feeding the capital's world-class restaurants is shifting perceptions. Although home shoppers also visit, Central's focus is on large-scale buying – with supersized displays to match. I gawk at a wall of watermelons piled higher than my head and a giant stacks of carrots. I smell the garlic shop before I see it: it has boxes of bulbs stacked to the ceiling, braids dangling from the rafters. Then, I follow my nose to a vendor hawking juicy tacos campechanos (grilled beef and sausage with cactus, potatoes and pico de gallo). The sheer variety of the mercado's selection reflects Mexico's multitudes of microclimates, and vendors come from all over the region to sell uniquely Mexican produce. Rey Lopez Central de Abasto supplies nearly 80% of Mexico City's food (Credit: Rey Lopez) Chefs have long bought staples at Central de Abasto, but over the past 10 to 15 years a new wave of fine-dining pioneers began coming not just for bulk produce, but for rarer, organic and indigenous ingredients. Farmers like Alfredo Cruz Camacho illustrate the shift. At one of the market's many long tables, he proudly displays candy cane beetroot with red and white inner rings and glossy baby heirloom tomatoes. His specialty crops caught the attention of Michelin-starred chefs browsing the stalls, including Israel Montero of Siembra Comedor. "He invited me to his restaurant in [the upscale neighbourhood of] Polanco, an area unknown to me as I only lived off the chinampas in Tláhuac [floating farms pioneered by the Aztecs]," Camacho recalls.
summary_src:
Mexico City's Central de Abasto, the world's largest wholesale market, has emerged as the unexpected cornerstone of the city's acclaimed fine-dining revolution. Despite being located in Iztapalapa, historically derided as a "trash district" and one of the capital's poorest boroughs, this sprawling and chaotic market is where 80% of Mexico City's food begins its journey, often at dawn.

Spanning 3.27 sq km – roughly the size of NYC's Central Park – Central de Abasto opened in 1982 and operates like a bustling city, welcoming half a million visitors and handling over 30,000 tons of produce daily. While upscale neighborhoods like Roma Norte often receive credit for the city's culinary status, it is Central's vast selection, reflecting Mexico's diverse microclimates, that truly fuels its world-class restaurants.

Increasingly, fine-dining pioneers are visiting not just for bulk produce but also for rare, organic, and indigenous ingredients. This shift is highlighted by farmers like Alfredo Cruz Camacho, whose specialty crops, such as candy cane beetroot and heirloom tomatoes, have caught the attention of Michelin-starred chefs like Israel Montero, further elevating Central de Abasto's pivotal role and gradually transforming perceptions of its surrounding impoverished borough.
summary_tgt:
यहाँ उस अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

**मेक्सिको सिटी का सेंट्रल डी अबास्टो: एक अप्रत्याशित पाक क्रांति का आधारशिला**

मेक्सिको सिटी का सेंट्रल डी अबास्टो, जो दुनिया का सबसे बड़ा थोक बाज़ार है, शहर की प्रशंसित फ़ाइन-डाइनिंग क्रांति का एक अप्रत्याशित आधारशिला बन गया है। इज़्टापालपा में स्थित होने के बावजूद, जिसे ऐतिहासिक रूप से "कचरा ज़िला" कहकर उपहास किया जाता था और जो राजधानी के सबसे गरीब नगरपालिकाओं में से एक है, यह विशाल और अव्यवस्थित बाज़ार वह जगह है जहाँ मेक्सिको सिटी के 80% भोजन की यात्रा शुरू होती है, अक्सर भोर में।

3.27 वर्ग किलोमीटर में फैला हुआ – लगभग न्यूयॉर्क सिटी के सेंट्रल पार्क जितना बड़ा – सेंट्रल डी अबास्टो 1982 में खुला और एक हलचल भरे शहर की तरह काम करता है, जहाँ प्रतिदिन आधे मिलियन आगंतुक आते हैं और 30,000 टन से अधिक उपज का प्रबंधन किया जाता है। जबकि रोमा नॉर्ट जैसे पॉश पड़ोस को अक्सर शहर की पाक कला स्थिति का श्रेय दिया जाता है, यह सेंट्रल की विशाल विविधता है, जो मेक्सिको के विविध सूक्ष्म जलवायु को दर्शाती है, जो वास्तव में इसके विश्व-स्तरीय रेस्तरां को बढ़ावा देती है।

तेजी से, फ़ाइन-डाइनिंग के अग्रणी सिर्फ़ थोक उपज के लिए ही नहीं, बल्कि दुर्लभ, जैविक और स्वदेशी सामग्री के लिए भी यहाँ आ रहे हैं। इस बदलाव को अल्फ्रेडो क्रूज़ कामाचो जैसे किसान उजागर करते हैं, जिनकी विशेष फसलें, जैसे कैंडी केन चुकंदर और हीरलूम टमाटर, ने इज़राइल मोंटेरो जैसे मिशेलिन-स्टार वाले शेफ का ध्यान खींचा है। यह सेंट्रल डी अबास्टो की महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका को और बढ़ा रहा है और धीरे-धीरे इसके आस-पास के गरीब बोरो की धारणाओं को बदल रहा है।
meta_description: How Central de Abasto, the world's largest market hidden in Mexico City's so-called "trash district", has become the unlikely backbone of its fine-dining revolution.

title_src: Five of the world's safest countries for 2025
text_src: In a year marked by conflict, five nations continue to rank among the world's most peaceful. Residents reveal how policies and culture shape daily life and create a sense of calm. In 2025, peace can feel like a rare commodity. Global wars are escalating, border security is tightening, and trade tensions continue to mount. According to the 2025 Global Peace Index (GPI), the number of state-based conflicts has reached its highest level since World War Two, with three more breaking out this year alone. Many countries are responding with increased militarisation. Yet despite those grim statistics, some nations continue to prioritise peace. The GPI, produced by the Institute for Economics & Peace, tracks 23 indicators, from external conflicts and military expenditure to safety and security measures like terrorism and homicide. The countries ranked at the top of the index have been remarkably consistent for nearly two decades, showing the stability that peaceful policies can bring over the long haul. We spoke to residents in some of the world's most peaceful counties to learn about how those policies shape day-to-day life – and what gives them a unique sense of security and calm. Iceland Ranked number one since 2008, Iceland remains the world's most peaceful nation, leading across all three domains: safety and security, ongoing conflict and militarisation. It even recorded a 2% improvement this year, widening the gap from the second-place country on the list.
summary_src:
Despite escalating global conflicts reaching their highest level since World War Two, the 2025 Global Peace Index (GPI) highlights a persistent dedication to peace in several nations, led by Iceland, which has held the top spot since 2008.

The GPI, produced by the Institute for Economics & Peace and tracking 23 indicators, reveals a global landscape where peace is a rare commodity. Escalating wars, tightening border security, and mounting trade tensions, including a U.S.-China trade war, contribute to increased militarization and military spending worldwide, with three new conflicts emerging this year alone.

Yet, some nations consistently prioritize peace. Iceland recorded a 2% improvement this year, maintaining its leadership across safety, ongoing conflict, and militarization domains. Other consistently peaceful nations, including the U.S., Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and South Africa, demonstrate how effective policies and culture shape daily life, fostering a unique sense of calm and security for their residents. The consistency of these top-ranked countries over nearly two decades underscores the long-term stability that peaceful governance can bring, even as global conflicts intensify.
summary_tgt:
**हिंदी अनुवाद:**

द्वितीय विश्व युद्ध के बाद से अपने उच्चतम स्तर पर पहुँचते बढ़ते वैश्विक संघर्षों के बावजूद, 2025 वैश्विक शांति सूचकांक (जीपीआई) कई देशों में शांति के प्रति लगातार समर्पण को उजागर करता है, जिसका नेतृत्व आइसलैंड कर रहा है और जिसने 2008 से शीर्ष स्थान बनाए रखा है।

अर्थशास्त्र और शांति संस्थान द्वारा तैयार किया गया और 23 संकेतकों पर नज़र रखने वाला जीपीआई, एक ऐसी वैश्विक स्थिति का खुलासा करता है जहाँ शांति एक दुर्लभ वस्तु है। बढ़ते युद्ध, कड़ी होती सीमा सुरक्षा और बढ़ते व्यापारिक तनाव – जिसमें अमेरिका-चीन व्यापार युद्ध भी शामिल है – दुनिया भर में बढ़ते सैन्यीकरण और सैन्य खर्च में योगदान करते हैं। इस साल अकेले तीन नए संघर्ष सामने आए हैं।

फिर भी, कुछ देश लगातार शांति को प्राथमिकता देते हैं। आइसलैंड ने इस साल 2% का सुधार दर्ज किया, जिससे उसने सुरक्षा, चल रहे संघर्ष और सैन्यीकरण के क्षेत्रों में अपना नेतृत्व बनाए रखा। अमेरिका, ऑस्ट्रेलिया, कनाडा, न्यूजीलैंड और दक्षिण अफ्रीका सहित अन्य लगातार शांतिपूर्ण देश यह दर्शाते हैं कि कैसे प्रभावी नीतियाँ और संस्कृति दैनिक जीवन को आकार देती हैं, जिससे उनके निवासियों के लिए शांति और सुरक्षा की एक अनूठी भावना को बढ़ावा मिलता है। लगभग दो दशकों से इन शीर्ष क्रम वाले देशों की निरंतरता उस दीर्घकालिक स्थिरता पर जोर देती है जो शांतिपूर्ण शासन ला सकता है, भले ही वैश्विक संघर्ष तेज हो जाएँ।
meta_description: In a year marked by conflict, five nations continue to rank among the world's most peaceful. Residents reveal how policies and culture shape daily life and create a sense of calm.

title_src: Tracee Ellis Ross' top tips for travelling solo
text_src: Courtesy of The Roku Channel There's no off time for Ross, but she does answer texts more slowly when she's on holiday (Credit: Courtesy of The Roku Channel) In the episode where you travel to Mexico, you wind up working. Does that happen often? I think it depends what's happening in my life, but the truth is that I'm a founder and CEO of a big, huge beauty company. There's no off time. This is my big, beautiful life so I don't find it to be a burden. I do answer texts more slowly when I'm on vacation. I don’t have my phone with me every move I make. And I sometimes day drink. [laughs] So if you day drink, you can't be on that phone working! What are the first things you do in a new place? I settle in. I like to unpack; I'm an unpack girl. I also like to take a bath, because I feel like it settles my body off the plane, and I now actually have my feet on the ground. I love to look for a lymphatic drainage massage. How do you plan your trip? Usually, I have researched in advance if there's a particular restaurant I want to try or if there's a gallery or a museum that I want to visit so that I'm not spending my time researching. My favourite thing to do is find those places by asking [local] people versus TikTok, you know? Because I lived in Europe growing up and went to school in Europe, I know people and I can usually collect a really good sort of itinerary for myself. What's one thing you never do? I don't overbook. If I go on a trip, it might be like one restaurant that I try. I don't like to jam pack my days in any way, shape or form. You don’t want to need a vacation from the vacation. I come home from my solo trips and I'm, like, ready to jive back into my life. Courtesy of The Roku Channel Ross never overbooks her solo trips to make sure she comes back to real life refreshed (Credit: Courtesy of The Roku Channel) There are some great scenes of you celebrating local food culture in the series. I try to keep it simple and order things that I know and love. [But in] Morocco, my mouth was so happy and I had no idea what I was eating. [There] were flavours that my mouth had never tasted! And it was delicious! I was, like, 'I don't even know what these things are!' So I love that part of it. And then you just wanna have some fries. What's the best way to experience a city on your own? I listen to the sounds. I find it so soothing to listen to the sounds of an environment, because they sound different everywhere. Wind sounds different. The birds sound different. The traffic sounds different. So I do a lot of listening when I'm travelling. One of my favourite sounds in the world is wind on trees. Truly, it's just magic to me. -- If you liked this story, sign up for The Essential List newsletter – a handpicked selection of features, videos and can't-miss news, delivered to your inbox twice a week. For more Travel stories from the BBC, follow us on Facebook and Instagram.
summary_src:
A CEO featured on Roku Channel's "Roku Vacation" offers insights into her unique approach to travel and work-life balance. Despite traveling, she frequently finds herself working, viewing this "no off time" as an integral and happy part of her demanding life, rather than a burden. She admits to slower text responses on vacation and enjoys "day drinking," which she humorously notes precludes working on her phone.

Upon arriving in a new place, her routine includes settling in, unpacking, bathing, and seeking a lymphatic drainage massage before resuming work. For trip planning, she prefers researching specific restaurants or consulting locals over social media, often utilizing her past experience living in Europe. Her travel philosophy emphasizes avoiding overbooking to ensure she returns refreshed, not needing a "vacation from the vacation."

While she generally sticks to familiar foods, she also embraces adventurous culinary experiences, such as the "delicious" and "unknown" flavors she encountered in Morocco. When exploring a city solo, her preferred method is immersing herself by listening to the unique sounds of the environment – from wind on trees to local traffic – which she finds profoundly soothing and "magic." Throughout the discussion, readers are invited to share their own travel stories, tips, and photos with CNN iReport.
summary_tgt:
यहां अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद दिया गया है:

रोकू चैनल के "रोकू वेकेशन" कार्यक्रम में शामिल एक सीईओ यात्रा और काम-जीवन संतुलन के प्रति अपने अनोखे दृष्टिकोण के बारे में जानकारी देती हैं। यात्रा के बावजूद, वह अक्सर खुद को काम करते हुए पाती हैं, और इस "छुट्टी रहित समय" को अपनी व्यस्त जीवनशैली का बोझ मानने के बजाय एक अभिन्न और खुशी भरा हिस्सा मानती हैं। वह स्वीकार करती हैं कि छुट्टी पर उनके टेक्स्ट संदेशों के जवाब धीमे होते हैं और वह "दिन में शराब पीने" का आनंद लेती हैं, जिसे वह मज़ाकिया अंदाज़ में कहती हैं कि यह उन्हें फोन पर काम करने से रोकती है।

किसी नई जगह पहुंचने पर, उनकी दिनचर्या में व्यवस्थित होना, सामान खोलना, नहाना और काम दोबारा शुरू करने से पहले लिंफैटिक ड्रेनेज मसाज करवाना शामिल है। यात्रा की योजना बनाते समय, वह सोशल मीडिया के बजाय विशिष्ट रेस्तरां पर शोध करना या स्थानीय लोगों से सलाह लेना पसंद करती हैं, जिसमें वह अक्सर यूरोप में रहने के अपने पिछले अनुभव का उपयोग करती हैं। उनके यात्रा दर्शन में अत्यधिक बुकिंग से बचने पर जोर दिया जाता है ताकि यह सुनिश्चित हो सके कि वह तरोताज़ा होकर लौटें और उन्हें "छुट्टी से छुट्टी" की आवश्यकता न पड़े।

हालांकि वह आमतौर पर परिचित भोजन ही पसंद करती हैं, वह साहसिक पाक अनुभवों को भी अपनाती हैं, जैसे कि मोरक्को में मिले "स्वादिष्ट" और "अज्ञात" स्वाद। अकेले शहर घूमते समय, उनकी पसंदीदा विधि पर्यावरण की अनूठी आवाज़ों - पेड़ों पर हवा से लेकर स्थानीय यातायात तक - को सुनकर खुद को उसमें डुबो देना है, जिसे वह अत्यंत शांत करने वाला और "जादुई" मानती हैं। इस पूरी चर्चा के दौरान, पाठकों को सीएनएन आईरिपोर्ट के साथ अपनी यात्रा की कहानियां, सुझाव और तस्वीरें साझा करने के लिए आमंत्रित किया जाता है।
meta_description: The black-ish actor is her own favourite travel companion. Here are her top tips for taking on the world one destination at a time, all on your own.

title_src: The Trans Dinarica: A new 5,500km bike trail connecting one of Europe's most remote regions
text_src: Linking eight Balkan nations, the new Trans Dinarica cycling trail twists through some of the continent's most stunning – and least-visited – landscapes. The asphalt vanished as the road gently climbed through the pastures. Two small dogs ran towards me from a wooden Montenegrin shepherd's hut, happily wagging their tails. I was tempted to play with them, but a long gravel ascent lay ahead and I wanted to be on the other side of the Sinjajevina mountain before the looming storm. "Go home!", I told the dogs, worried they would get lost if they followed me, but they didn't listen. Quickly moving their tiny paws, they tirelessly kept me company until I reached the pass. The first thunder caught me in Tušinja, a small Montenegrin village with just a handful of houses and an Orthodox church on a hill. I had no energy to pedal up another steep incline, so I hopped off and began pushing my bike when I heard a man shouting and waving at me, inviting me to his garden.
summary_src: The newly established Trans Dinarica cycling trail links eight Balkan nations, guiding cyclists through some of the continent's most stunning yet least-visited landscapes. During a journey on the trail, the paved road transitioned into a grassy ascent, leading to a long gravel climb over Sinjajevina mountain with an approaching storm. Two small, friendly dogs from a Montenegrin shepherd's hut joined the cyclist. Despite concerns for their safety and pleas for them to return home, the dogs tirelessly accompanied the cyclist to the mountain pass. As the first thunder hit in the small Montenegrin village of Tušinja, an exhausted cyclist, now pushing their bike up a steep incline, was welcomed with an invitation into a local's garden.
summary_tgt: नवनिर्मित ट्रांस दिनारिका साइक्लिंग ट्रेल आठ बाल्कन देशों को जोड़ती है, जो साइकिल चालकों को महाद्वीप के कुछ सबसे शानदार, फिर भी सबसे कम विज़िट किए गए परिदृश्यों से होकर ले जाती है। ट्रेल पर एक यात्रा के दौरान, पक्की सड़क एक घास वाली चढ़ाई में बदल गई, जो सिन्जाजेविना पर्वत पर एक लंबी बजरी वाली चढ़ाई तक ले गई, जबकि एक तूफान भी आ रहा था। मोंटेनिग्रो के एक चरवाहे की झोपड़ी से दो छोटे, मिलनसार कुत्ते साइकिल चालक के साथ हो लिए। उनकी सुरक्षा की चिंता और उन्हें घर लौटने की विनतियों के बावजूद, कुत्तों ने अथक रूप से साइकिल चालक का पहाड़ के दर्रे तक साथ दिया। जैसे ही तुशिन्जा (Tušinja) के छोटे मोंटेनिग्रो गाँव में पहली गड़गड़ाहट हुई, एक थके हुए साइकिल चालक को, जो अब अपनी साइकिल को एक खड़ी चढ़ाई पर धकेल रहा था, एक स्थानीय निवासी के बगीचे में आने का निमंत्रण देकर स्वागत किया गया।
meta_description: Linking eight Balkan nations, the new Trans Dinarica cycling trail twists through some of the continent's most stunning – and least-visited – landscapes.

title_src: Whey to go: Is cheese the new reason to travel?
text_src: From Paris's newly opened cheese museum to ageing caves in the Jura and sheep pastures in Corsica, travellers are discovering that cheese can be a guidebook through landscapes, traditions and histories they might otherwise miss. In France, terroir is more than a word; it's a way of seeing the world. Long associated with wine, the concept that geography, climate, soil and human skill shape flavour is just as true for another French icon: cheese. And while the French have always known this, a growing number of travellers are discovering the country – and its culture – one wheel at a time. Last spring, Paris opened the Musée Vivant du Fromage, joining dozens of attractions across the country dedicated to cheese, from ageing caves and cheese museums to visitor centres and tasting tours. There are regional Route de Fromage trails to follow, producers to meet and pastures to walk through – each offering a deeper understanding of how place shapes flavour. The appetite for food-focussed travel is only set to grow: Future Market Insights predicts that the market for culinary experiences in France will rise by nearly 16% over the next decade. The new museum, a short stroll from the newly restored Notre-Dame Cathedral, is small but rich in scope. Exhibits in both English and French explain how cheeses are made, the people and traditions behind them and the science of ageing and flavour. Interactive screens encourage deeper exploration, while the shop counter offers a veritable "Tour de France" of cheeses. It all unfolds to an atmospheric soundtrack of cowbells, as if the meadows themselves were just outside. Museum manager Guillaume Gaubert says the trend started with the French themselves. "We've noticed that a section of the population is less interested these days in going to the Bahamas, for example, and more inclined to take nature-based holidays in France, to discover the local terroirs," he explained. "The French are really attached to their land. The cheese connects them to their terroir – so the Alsatian wants his Munster, the Norman his Camembert, the Basque his Ossau-Iraty. And the Savoyard? His Beaufort."
summary_src:
France is experiencing a burgeoning trend in 'cheese tourism,' where travellers use the country's diverse array of cheeses as a unique guide through its landscapes, traditions, and history. The deep-rooted French concept of 'terroir'—encompassing geography, climate, soil, and human skill—is increasingly being applied to cheese, much like wine, to explain how place shapes flavour.

A growing number of visitors, and increasingly the French themselves, are discovering the country one cheese wheel at a time. This trend is bolstered by new attractions like Paris's recently opened Musée Vivant du Fromage, located near Notre-Dame. This small but rich museum, housed in a former munitions factory, features English and French exhibits detailing cheesemaking, its cultural heritage, and the science of ageing, all set to an atmospheric soundtrack of cowbells. Its shop offers a "Tour de France" of cheeses.

Beyond the museum, France boasts dozens of other cheese-focused attractions, including regional Route de Fromage trails, producer visits, and pasture walks, all offering deeper cultural insights. This culinary tourism market is projected to grow by nearly 16% in France over the next decade.

The surge in interest is partly driven by a renewed sense of national pride among the French, who are shifting towards nature-based domestic holidays to discover local terroirs. As locals identify strongly with their regional cheeses—like the Alsatian with Munster, the Norman with Camembert, or the Savoyard with Beaufort—cheese has become a powerful connector to their land and heritage.
summary_tgt:
**फ्रांस में 'चीज़ पर्यटन' का बढ़ता रुझान**

फ्रांस में 'चीज़ पर्यटन' का एक उभरता चलन देखा जा रहा है, जहाँ यात्री देश की विभिन्न प्रकार की चीज़ों को एक अनूठे मार्गदर्शक के रूप में इस्तेमाल करते हुए इसके परिदृश्य, परंपराओं और इतिहास की खोज करते हैं। फ्रांस की गहरी जड़ें जमाई 'टेरॉइर' (terroir) की अवधारणा – जिसमें भूगोल, जलवायु, मिट्टी और मानवीय कौशल शामिल हैं – को अब चीज़ पर भी तेज़ी से लागू किया जा रहा है, ठीक शराब की तरह, यह समझाने के लिए कि कैसे कोई स्थान स्वाद को आकार देता है।

आगंतुकों की बढ़ती संख्या, और अब स्वयं फ्रांसीसी लोग भी, एक बार में चीज़ के एक-एक पहिये के माध्यम से अपने देश की खोज कर रहे हैं। इस प्रवृत्ति को पेरिस के हाल ही में खुले म्यूज़े विवांत डू फ्रॉमैज (Musée Vivant du Fromage) जैसे नए आकर्षणों से बल मिला है, जो नोट्रे-डेम के पास स्थित है। यह छोटा लेकिन समृद्ध संग्रहालय, जो एक पूर्व गोला-बारूद कारखाने में स्थित है, इसमें चीज़ बनाने की प्रक्रिया, इसकी सांस्कृतिक विरासत और चीज़ के पुराने होने के विज्ञान का विवरण देने वाली अंग्रेजी और फ्रेंच में प्रदर्शनियाँ हैं, यह सब गायों की घंटियों की वातावरणीय ध्वनि के साथ प्रस्तुत किया गया है। इसकी दुकान चीज़ों का एक "टूर डी फ्रांस" (Tour de France) प्रदान करती है।

संग्रहालय के अलावा, फ्रांस में दर्जनों अन्य चीज़-केंद्रित आकर्षण हैं, जिनमें क्षेत्रीय 'रूट डी फ्रॉमैज' (Route de Fromage) ट्रेल्स, उत्पादक दौरे और चरागाह की सैर शामिल हैं, ये सभी गहरी सांस्कृतिक अंतर्दृष्टि प्रदान करते हैं। अनुमान है कि अगले दशक में फ्रांस में यह पाक-कला पर्यटन बाज़ार लगभग 16% बढ़ेगा।

रुचि में यह उछाल आंशिक रूप से फ्रांसीसियों के बीच राष्ट्रीय गौरव की एक नई भावना से प्रेरित है, जो स्थानीय 'टेरॉइर' की खोज के लिए प्रकृति-आधारित घरेलू छुट्टियों की ओर बढ़ रहे हैं। चूंकि स्थानीय लोग अपनी क्षेत्रीय चीज़ों से दृढ़ता से जुड़े हुए हैं – जैसे एल्साशियन मुन्स्टर (Munster) से, नॉर्मन कैमेम्बर्ट (Camembert) से, या सवोयार्ड ब्यूफोर्ट (Beaufort) से – चीज़ उनकी भूमि और विरासत से जुड़ने का एक शक्तिशाली माध्यम बन गया है।
meta_description: From Alpine caves to Corsica's mountains, travellers are discovering France's landscapes and traditions through its most famous dairy delicacy.

title_src: The Wing King's guide to the best wings in Buffalo
text_src: National Buffalo Wing Festival founder Drew Cerza has made it his mission to promote his hometown's iconic dish. Here are what he deems the best wings in town. Born and raised in the city of Buffalo, New York, Drew Cerza is a passionate ambassador for his hometown's eponymous dish: the Buffalo wing. The SpeciaList Drew Cerza, Buffalo, NY's "Wing King", is the founder of the National Buffalo Wing Festival, and co-creator of the Buffalo Wing Trail; a self-guided tour through 14 storied wing joints. A tireless ambassador for Buffalo wings, he has been featured on Food Network and the Travel Channel. Whether he's judging competitions, promoting local eateries or handing out hot wings in a chicken suit, Cerza has one mission: to give wings the global spotlight they deserve. (Credit: Jalen Wright) "Fiery, crisp and delicious, the Buffalo wing is an American culinary icon," says Cerza, better known as the "Wing King". "It's more than bar food; it's the centrepiece of festivals, Super Bowl parties and food challenges, showcasing our love of bold flavour and communal eating." Buffalo wings – chicken (not buffalo) wings doused in a mixture of Frank's Red Hot sauce and melted butter – were created serendipitously at the city's Anchor Bar in the 1960s, where the tangy, spicy combination, served with celery sticks and blue cheese dressing, was an instant hit. "In time, the bar's late-night improvisation became a game-day staple – and a global phenomenon," says Cerza.
summary_src:
Drew Cerza, known as the "Wing King" and founder of the National Buffalo Wing Festival, is a passionate ambassador for his hometown's iconic dish: the Buffalo wing. Born and raised in Buffalo, New York, Cerza has dedicated his mission to elevating the Buffalo wing to the global spotlight it deserves.

He champions the Buffalo wing – defined as chicken wings doused in a mixture of Frank's Red Hot sauce and melted butter, served with celery sticks and blue cheese dressing – as an "American culinary icon." Cerza emphasizes that it's "more than bar food," having evolved from a late-night improvisation into a "game-day staple" and "global phenomenon," central to festivals and communal eating.

Cerza's tireless efforts include co-creating the Buffalo Wing Trail, a self-guided tour through 14 storied wing joints, judging competitions, promoting local eateries, and appearing on networks like Food Network and the Travel Channel. His ultimate goal is to ensure this "fiery, crisp and delicious" dish receives worldwide recognition.
summary_tgt:
यहां दिए गए अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

ड्रू सेर्ज़ा, जिन्हें "विंग किंग" के नाम से जाना जाता है और जो राष्ट्रीय बफ़ेलो विंग महोत्सव के संस्थापक हैं, अपने गृह नगर के प्रतिष्ठित व्यंजन: बफ़ेलो विंग के लिए एक भावुक राजदूत हैं। न्यूयॉर्क के बफ़ेलो में जन्मे और पले-बढ़े सेर्ज़ा ने बफ़ेलो विंग को वह वैश्विक पहचान दिलाने के अपने मिशन को समर्पित किया है जिसके वह हकदार हैं।

वह बफ़ेलो विंग को एक "अमेरिकी पाक कला का प्रतीक" मानते हैं – जिसे फ्रैंक की रेड हॉट सॉस और पिघले हुए मक्खन के मिश्रण में डुबोए गए चिकन विंग्स के रूप में परिभाषित किया जाता है, जिसे अजवाइन की डंडियों (सेलेरी स्टिक्स) और ब्लू चीज़ ड्रेसिंग के साथ परोसा जाता है। सेर्ज़ा इस बात पर जोर देते हैं कि यह "सिर्फ बार का खाना नहीं" है, बल्कि देर रात के एक तात्कालिक व्यंजन से विकसित होकर एक "गेम-डे का मुख्य व्यंजन" और "वैश्विक घटना" बन गया है, जो त्योहारों और सामुदायिक भोजन का एक केंद्रीय हिस्सा है।

सेर्ज़ा के अथक प्रयासों में बफ़ेलो विंग ट्रेल का सह-निर्माण शामिल है, जो 14 प्रसिद्ध विंग जॉइंट्स के माध्यम से एक स्व-निर्देशित यात्रा है, साथ ही वे प्रतियोगिताओं में निर्णायक की भूमिका निभाते हैं, स्थानीय भोजनालयों को बढ़ावा देते हैं और फूड नेटवर्क व ट्रैवल चैनल जैसे नेटवर्कों पर भी दिखाई देते हैं। उनका अंतिम लक्ष्य यह सुनिश्चित करना है कि इस "तीखे, कुरकुरे और स्वादिष्ट" व्यंजन को दुनिया भर में पहचान मिले।
