title_src: Colombia: Court rules Meta was wrong to bar porn star's Instagram account
text_src: Colombian court rules Meta was wrong to bar porn star's Instagram account Esperanza Gómez successfully claimed Meta had affected her ability to work and infringed her freedom of expression Meta argued in the case that she had violated its rules on nudity. The company, which also owns Facebook and WhatsApp, did not immediately react to the ruling. The 45-year-old, whose account had more than five million followers, is one of Colombia's best known adult content actresses. The South American nation's Constitutional Court said on Friday that the tech firm had removed Esperanza Gómez's account "without a clear and transparent justification" and without offering similar treatment to other, similar accounts. Colombia's highest court has ruled that Meta violated a porn star's right to freedom of expression when it deleted her Instagram account. Ms Gómez had alleged that the decision to close her account had affected her ability to work and had been influenced by her pornographic work beyond the platform. She also claimed Meta had not followed due process. In its ruling, the court said that, while it recognised the social media platform's need to moderate content, this did not justify closing a porn star's account "without a clear and transparent justification". It also found Meta "applied its policies on nudity and sexual services inconsistently", with other accounts with similar content remaining active. The court said social media posts were protected under Colombia's constitution and should only be limited in a proportionate way where necessary. It ordered Meta to "review and adjust Instagram's terms of use and privacy policy so that users are clearly aware of the mechanisms for challenging moderation decisions" and "more precisely define" its rules on implicit sexual content. If social media platforms use offline activities as a criterion for content moderation, they must clearly state these, the court said. The court did not specify sanctions for non-compliance, nor whether Ms Gómez would receive any redress. The BBC has contacted Meta for comment. It is not the first time that a South American court has required a social network to change its policies. Brazil's Supreme Court recent ruled that social media were directly liable for illegal content, including hate speech, and must immediately act to remove it and accounts proliferating it. That ruling followed a judge ordering the suspension of dozens of X accounts for allegedly spreading disinformation. It led to the social media platform briefly being banned in Brazil, before it began complying with the ruling and paid a $5.1 (£3.8m) fine.
summary_src:
Colombia's Constitutional Court has ruled that Meta violated the right to freedom of expression of adult content actress Esperanza Gómez by deleting her Instagram account. The court found that Meta removed Gómez's account "without a clear and transparent justification" and applied its policies on nudity and sexual services "inconsistently," as other accounts with similar content remained active.

Gómez had successfully argued that the removal affected her ability to work and that Meta had not followed due process. The court emphasized that while content moderation is necessary, it does not justify closing an account without proper cause, as social media posts are protected under Colombia's constitution and can only be limited proportionately.

Meta has been ordered to review and adjust Instagram's terms of use and privacy policy, specifically to "more precisely define" its rules on implicit sexual content. Crucially, the court mandated that if social media platforms use offline activities as a criterion for content moderation, they must clearly state these.

This ruling underscores a growing trend in South America, where courts are increasingly challenging social media policies. Brazil's Supreme Court, for instance, recently held social media platforms directly liable for illegal content, including hate speech, leading to the temporary suspension and fining of platforms like X for non-compliance. Meta has not yet reacted to the Colombian ruling, and no specific sanctions for non-compliance were immediately specified.

यहाँ अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

कोलंबिया के संवैधानिक न्यायालय ने फैसला सुनाया है कि मेटा ने वयस्क सामग्री अभिनेत्री एस्पेरांज़ा गोमेज़ का इंस्टाग्राम अकाउंट हटाकर उनकी अभिव्यक्ति की स्वतंत्रता के अधिकार का उल्लंघन किया। न्यायालय ने पाया कि मेटा ने गोमेज़ का अकाउंट "बिना किसी स्पष्ट और पारदर्शी औचित्य" के हटा दिया था और नग्नता तथा यौन सेवाओं से संबंधित अपनी नीतियों को "असंगत रूप से" लागू किया था, क्योंकि समान सामग्री वाले अन्य खाते अभी भी सक्रिय थे।

गोमेज़ ने सफलतापूर्वक तर्क दिया था कि इस अकाउंट को हटाने से उनकी काम करने की क्षमता प्रभावित हुई थी और मेटा ने उचित प्रक्रिया का पालन नहीं किया था। न्यायालय ने इस बात पर जोर दिया कि जहाँ सामग्री मॉडरेशन आवश्यक है, वहीं यह बिना किसी उचित कारण के किसी खाते को बंद करने का औचित्य नहीं देता, क्योंकि सोशल मीडिया पोस्ट कोलंबिया के संविधान के तहत संरक्षित हैं और उन्हें केवल आनुपातिक रूप से ही सीमित किया जा सकता है।

मेटा को आदेश दिया गया है कि वह इंस्टाग्राम के उपयोग की शर्तों और गोपनीयता नीति की समीक्षा करे और उनमें बदलाव करे, विशेष रूप से निहित यौन सामग्री पर अपने नियमों को "अधिक सटीक रूप से परिभाषित" करने के लिए। महत्वपूर्ण रूप से, न्यायालय ने यह भी आदेश दिया कि यदि सोशल मीडिया प्लेटफॉर्म सामग्री मॉडरेशन के लिए ऑफ़लाइन गतिविधियों को मानदंड के रूप में उपयोग करते हैं, तो उन्हें इन्हें स्पष्ट रूप से बताना होगा।

यह फैसला दक्षिण अमेरिका में एक बढ़ती हुई प्रवृत्ति को रेखांकित करता है, जहाँ अदालतें सोशल मीडिया नीतियों को लगातार चुनौती दे रही हैं। उदाहरण के लिए, ब्राजील के सुप्रीम कोर्ट ने हाल ही में सोशल मीडिया प्लेटफॉर्म को अवैध सामग्री, जिसमें नफरत फैलाने वाले भाषण भी शामिल हैं, के लिए सीधे तौर पर जिम्मेदार ठहराया था, जिससे गैर-अनुपालन के लिए X जैसे प्लेटफार्मों को अस्थायी रूप से निलंबित किया गया और उन पर जुर्माना लगाया गया। मेटा ने अभी तक कोलंबियाई फैसले पर कोई प्रतिक्रिया नहीं दी है, और गैर-अनुपालन के लिए कोई विशिष्ट प्रतिबंध तुरंत निर्दिष्ट नहीं किए गए हैं।

title_src: Rosa Roisinblit: Argentine human rights activist dies, aged 106
text_src: Argentine rights activist Rosa Roisinblit dies aged 106 8 days ago Share Save Ruth Comerford BBC News Share Save AFP via Getty Images The Argentine human rights activist Rosa Roisinblit has died at the age of 106, her organisation says. She was honorary president and a founding member of the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, a group that searched for children stolen during Argentina's military dictatorship between 1976 and 1983. "We only have words of gratitude for her dedication... and the love with which she searched for the grandsons and granddaughters until the very end," the campaign group said in a statement. Some 30,000 people were killed or forcibly disappeared during Argentina's "Dirty War". Children of detained opposition activists were seized and given up for adoption. Rosa Roisinblit was born in 1919 in Moises Ville, a town of Jewish immigrants in central Argentina. She worked as an obstetrician and moved to Buenos Aires in 1949, where she married in 1951. Getty Images Rosa Roisinblit (left) with Estela de Carlotto, co-founder of the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, in 1987 After the military coup of March 1976, the junta moved to eradicate the opposition. Tens of thousands of activists were snatched in raids and held in clandestine detention and torture centres. Many were thrown into the sea on notorious "death flights". An estimated 500 of their babies were stolen. Roisinblit's pregnant daughter Patricia, son-in-law José Pérez Rojo and 15-month old granddaughter Mariana, were kidnapped in 1978. The couple had been left-wing activists. The family was transferred to a school, known as Esma, which was the largest detention centre in Buenos Aires. Patricia Roisinblit was kept alive long enough to give birth to her son in a basement. The couple's bodies were never found, and Mariana was returned to Rosa, who raised her. The new-born baby was given to an air-force intelligence officer to bring up. AFP via Getty Images Reunited with her grandchildren: Rosa stands outside outside the court following the sentence of the men who abducted Guillermo. After her family's abduction, Roisinblit joined the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo and served as treasurer for six years before working as vice-president from 1989 to 2022. Her grandson was tracked down in 2000 by his sister Mariana and through the work of the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo. He was reunited with Rosa and Mariana after DNA tests confirmed they were related. He had been given the name Guillermo Francisco Gómez by the adoptive parents: Francisco Gómez and Teodora Jofre. Roisinblit was in the courtroom in 2016, when Goméz was jailed for life over the boy's abduction. Jofre was separately jailed for three years. Later that year, two men - a former air force chief an ex-intelligence officer - were sentenced to 25 years for the abduction and torture of Patricia and José. They were among hundreds of soldiers and leaders prosecuted for human-rights abuses. At the age of 96, Roisinblit attended the trial with Guillermo and Mariana. A year later, she told AFP news agency: "This wound never heals... But to say I'm stopping? No, I'll never stop." Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo José Pérez Rojo and Patricia Roisinblit were seized by the military on 6 October 1978
summary_src:
Rosa Roisinblit, a revered Argentine human rights activist and a founding member of the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, has died at the age of 106. Her organization confirmed her passing from natural causes, recognizing her tireless dedication to finding children stolen during Argentina's 1976-1983 military dictatorship, known as the "Dirty War."

During this brutal period, an estimated 30,000 people were killed or forcibly disappeared, and children of detained opposition activists were seized and given up for illegal adoption, with around 500 babies stolen. Roisinblit's personal tragedy fueled her activism. In 1978, her pregnant daughter Patricia, son-in-law José Pérez Rojo, and 15-month-old granddaughter Mariana were kidnapped by the junta. Patricia was kept alive long enough to give birth to a son in a clandestine detention centre before she and José vanished forever. Mariana was eventually returned to Rosa, who raised her, but the newborn son was given to an air-force intelligence officer.

After her family's abduction, Roisinblit became a driving force within the Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, serving as a long-time vice-president. Her perseverance led to a profound victory in 2000 when her grandson, raised under the name Guillermo Francisco Gómez, was tracked down by his sister Mariana and reunited with Rosa after DNA confirmation.

Roisinblit continued her fight for justice into her later years, attending the courtroom at age 96 in 2016 to witness Gómez's adoptive father, Francisco Gowmez, jailed for life over the abduction. Later that year, former military officials were also sentenced for the abduction and torture of Patricia and José, part of hundreds of prosecutions for human rights abuses from the era. Despite the pain, Roisinblit remained resolute, once telling AFP, "This wound never heals..." but affirming her unwavering commitment: "No, I'll never stop."
summary_tgt:
अर्जेंटीना की सम्मानित मानवाधिकार कार्यकर्ता और प्लाजा डी मायो की ग्रैंडमदर्स की संस्थापक सदस्य रोज़ा रोइसिनब्लिट का 106 वर्ष की आयु में निधन हो गया है। उनके संगठन ने प्राकृतिक कारणों से उनके निधन की पुष्टि की, और अर्जेंटीना के 1976-1983 के सैन्य तानाशाही, जिसे "डर्टी वॉर" के नाम से जाना जाता है, के दौरान चुराए गए बच्चों को खोजने के प्रति उनके अथक समर्पण को रेखांकित किया।

इस क्रूर अवधि के दौरान, अनुमानित 30,000 लोगों की हत्या कर दी गई या उन्हें जबरन गायब कर दिया गया, और हिरासत में लिए गए विपक्षी कार्यकर्ताओं के बच्चों को जब्त कर लिया गया और अवैध गोद लेने के लिए दे दिया गया, जिसमें लगभग 500 शिशुओं को चुराया गया था। रोइसिनब्लिट की व्यक्तिगत त्रासदी ने उनके सक्रियतावाद को और अधिक प्रेरित किया। 1978 में, उनकी गर्भवती बेटी पेट्रीसिया, दामाद जोस पेरेज़ रोजो और 15 महीने की पोती मारियाना को जुंटा द्वारा अगवा कर लिया गया था। पेट्रीसिया को एक गुप्त हिरासत केंद्र में एक बेटे को जन्म देने के लिए पर्याप्त समय तक जीवित रखा गया था, इससे पहले कि वह और जोस हमेशा के लिए गायब हो गए। मारियाना को आखिरकार रोज़ा को वापस कर दिया गया, जिन्होंने उसे पाला, लेकिन नवजात बेटे को एक वायु सेना खुफिया अधिकारी को दे दिया गया था।

अपने परिवार के अपहरण के बाद, रोइसिनब्लिट प्लाजा डी मायो की ग्रैंडमदर्स के भीतर एक प्रेरक शक्ति बन गईं, और उन्होंने लंबे समय तक उपाध्यक्ष के रूप में कार्य किया। उनकी दृढ़ता के कारण 2000 में एक गहन जीत मिली, जब उनके पोते, जिन्हें गुइलर्मो फ्रांसिस्को गोमेज़ के नाम से पाला गया था, को उनकी बहन मारियाना ने खोज निकाला और डीएनए पुष्टि के बाद रोज़ा से फिर से मिलवाया गया।

रोइसिनब्लिट ने अपने बाद के वर्षों में भी न्याय के लिए अपनी लड़ाई जारी रखी, और 2016 में 96 साल की उम्र में अदालत में उपस्थित होकर गोमेज़ के दत्तक पिता, फ्रांसिस्को गोमेज़ को अपहरण के लिए आजीवन कारावास दिए जाने की गवाह बनीं। उसी वर्ष बाद में, उस युग के मानवाधिकार हनन के सैकड़ों अभियोगों के हिस्से के रूप में, पूर्व सैन्य अधिकारियों को भी पेट्रीसिया और जोस के अपहरण और यातना के लिए सजा सुनाई गई। दर्द के बावजूद, रोइसिनब्लिट दृढ़ रहीं, उन्होंने एक बार एएफपी को बताया था, "यह घाव कभी नहीं भरता...", लेकिन अपनी अटूट प्रतिबद्धता की पुष्टि करते हुए कहा: "नहीं, मैं कभी नहीं रुकूंगी।"

title_src: What does Trump want in the Caribbean as US deploys warships?
text_src: What is Trump's goal as US bombs 'Venezuela drugs boat' and deploys warships? 4 September 2025 Share Save Gerardo Lissardy and Caitlin Wilson BBC Mundo and BBC News Share Save Getty Images The US has moved additional warships into the Caribbean First, the US deployed multiple warships to the Caribbean. Then, Donald Trump announced a deadly strike on a boat he said was carrying drugs. What Washington has planned next is not entirely clear, but some analysts tell the BBC that the risk of escalation in the region is growing by the day. Since the US president's return to office in January, the Trump administration has steadily intensified its anti-drug-trafficking efforts in Latin America. As part of that, the US has seemingly centred on Venezuela - an effort that has led to the mobilisation of military forces from both countries in recent weeks. After Tuesday's bombing of a small vessel in the Caribbean that was allegedly travelling from Venezuela, officials in the US made it clear that military action in the region was not over - hinting at more operations that could target drug trafficking. Venezuela's government has reacted with anger. President Nicolás Maduro denies American accusations that he is involved with drugs trafficking, while another official has questioned the veracity of footage posted by Trump. Trump said the footage showed the killing of 11 "narcoterrorists" from the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang, who he said were aboard a small boat. He said the vessel was carrying "massive amounts of drugs" and was heading toward the US. In the Oval Office, Trump accused the South American country of being "very bad, both in terms of drugs and sending some of the worst criminals anywhere in the world into our country". The move came weeks after the US announced a $50m (£37m) reward for any information leading to the arrest of Maduro - whose election to lead the country has been widely rejected by the international community - on drug-trafficking charges. The analysts who spoke to the BBC suggested that Trump's latest move could have more than one purpose in mind. 'Trump is trying to intimidate the regime' Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth told Fox News on Wednesday morning that US military activity in the area "won't stop... with just this strike". It was a clear attempt to put pressure on Maduro, one commentator said. The prior naval build-up was on a scale not seen in the region since 1965, according to Prof Alan McPherson, who specialises in US-Latin American relations at Temple University. The Pentagon has so far deployed guided missile destroyers, the Iwo Jima amphibious group and a nuclear-powered submarine, along with P-8 intelligence planes and around 4,500 troops to the region. The build-up "recalls the days of 'gunboat diplomacy' more than a century ago," Prof McPherson said. Getty Images Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has regularly clashed with the Trump administration The Pentagon said the deployments aimed to help halt drug trafficking and the actions of criminals, and would aid the US pressure drug networks in the region. But the US Navy might be hoping to strike more directly at Maduro or encourage an internal revolt in the Venezuelan army, Prof McPherson said - though he acknowledged that "neither of those would require such a flotilla". "Whatever the case, clearly, the Trump administration wants to intimidate the [Venezuelan] regime." Stephen Donehoo, a former US military intelligence official specialising in Latin America, told the BBC that he has "never seen such a large deployment of naval forces in the [US] Southern Command" region. Still, it was "not a force to invade a foreign country," Mr Donehoo explained. "There could be other missions that they have, much more precise," such as "armed drone missions flying over Venezuelan airspace," he added. Maduro has rejected US claims he is directly involved in drug trafficking, which he considers a pretence to overthrow his government. He has also said he would mobilise 4.5 million members of the country's militia in response to the US deployment of the war ships. But analysts say Maduro's number is wildly inflated - and that the militia is barely trained and is usually only used to boost numbers at political rallies and parades, so is not a fighting force. Maduro also vowed that Venezuela would immediately "declare a republic in arms" if it was attacked. An unusual drugs bust US officials have presented the strike as an effort to halt the flow of drugs to the US - which has been a key mission of Trump's second term. But it was an unusual operation, according to Rebecca Bill Chavez, head of the Inter-American Dialogue think tank in Washington. "If this [the US movements] is a counter-narcotics deployment, this is unlike any counter-narcotics deployment I've ever seen," Ms Chavez, a former US undersecretary of state for the Western Hemisphere, told the BBC. US maritime anti-drug operations are usually led by the Coast Guard, working with regional partners to intercept suspicious vessels. It is unclear whether the US was in contact with other Caribbean officials about Tuesday's strike beforehand. "The risk of escalation at sea is real," Ms Chavez said. The president himself told reporters in the Oval Office that "you see the bags of drugs all over the boat", referring to video footage which he said showed the strike. Venezuela is often used as a stop off for transporting cocaine - but the drug is mostly transported to the US via the Pacific Ocean rather than the Caribbean, according to a 2023 UN report. Officials have so far not explained how they determined those on board the boat targeted on Tuesday were members of Tren de Aragua, or what kind of drugs they believe the vessel was transporting. The military strike marked the strongest action the Trump administration has taken against drug trafficking - and is something that legal experts say may have violated international human rights and maritime law. Secretary of State Marco Rubio defended the operation, and indicated the US could take similar action again in the future. "What will stop them is when you blow [drug traffickers] up," he said during a visit to Mexico, lamenting that previous US efforts to stem the trade had not been effective. Getty Images US Secretary of State Marco Rubio has defended the vessel strike 'People are very confused about the real purpose'
summary_src:
On September 4, 2025, the US significantly escalated military pressure on Venezuela, deploying an unprecedented number of warships to the Caribbean and conducting a deadly strike on a vessel it claimed was carrying drugs and "narcoterrorists." This comes as the Trump administration, since the President's return to office in January, has intensified anti-drug trafficking efforts focused on Venezuela, with bombings reportedly ongoing since April.

The substantial military deployment, described as the largest in the region since 1965, includes guided missile destroyers, an amphibious group, a nuclear-powered submarine, 4,500 troops, and P-8 intelligence planes. President Trump announced the strike on a boat he said carried "massive amounts of drugs" and 11 "narcoterrorists" from Venezuela's Tren de Aragua gang, later also referencing illegal immigrants. This action followed a $50 million reward offered weeks prior for the arrest of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on drug trafficking charges. US officials, including Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth and Secretary of State Marco Rubio, defended the operation, hinting at further strikes and arguing that previous anti-drug efforts were ineffective.

Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro vehemently denied US accusations of drug involvement, calling them a "pretense to overthrow his government." He reacted with anger to the attack, vowing to mobilize 4.5 million militia members and declare a "republic in arms" if Venezuela is attacked. An official also questioned the veracity of footage posted by Trump.

Analysts suggest Trump's latest moves aim to intimidate the Maduro regime, apply pressure, or bolster the opposition. While the naval buildup is substantial, experts note it is not an invasion force but could be intended for "more precise" missions, potentially including armed drone operations. Rebecca Bill Chavez of the Inter-American Dialogue described the strike as "unusual" for counter-narcotics operations, typically led by the Coast Guard, and warned of a "real risk of escalation at sea." Legal experts have questioned whether the military strike violated international human rights and maritime law, while US Secretary of State Marco Rubio has indicated similar actions could be taken in the future.
summary_tgt:
**वेनेज़ुएला पर अमेरिकी सैन्य दबाव में भारी वृद्धि: ड्रग विरोधी अभियान के तहत घातक हमला और क्षेत्र में सबसे बड़ी तैनाती**

4 सितंबर, 2025 को, अमेरिका ने वेनेज़ुएला पर सैन्य दबाव काफी बढ़ा दिया, कैरिबियन में अभूतपूर्व संख्या में युद्धपोत तैनात किए और एक ऐसे पोत पर जानलेवा हमला किया, जिसके बारे में उसका दावा था कि वह ड्रग्स और "नारकोटेररिस्ट" ले जा रहा था। यह ऐसे समय हुआ है जब राष्ट्रपति ट्रम्प के जनवरी में सत्ता में लौटने के बाद से, उनके प्रशासन ने वेनेज़ुएला पर केंद्रित मादक पदार्थ तस्करी विरोधी प्रयासों को तेज कर दिया है, और अप्रैल से कथित तौर पर बमबारी जारी है।

इस महत्वपूर्ण सैन्य तैनाती को 1965 के बाद से क्षेत्र में सबसे बड़ी बताया गया है। इसमें गाइडेड मिसाइल विध्वंसक, एक उभयचर समूह, एक परमाणु-संचालित पनडुब्बी, 4,500 सैनिक और P-8 खुफिया विमान शामिल हैं। राष्ट्रपति ट्रम्प ने एक नाव पर हमले की घोषणा की, जिसके बारे में उन्होंने कहा कि उसमें "भारी मात्रा में ड्रग्स" और वेनेज़ुएला के ट्रॅन डी अरागुआ गिरोह के 11 "नारकोटेररिस्ट" थे, बाद में उन्होंने अवैध अप्रवासियों का भी जिक्र किया। यह कार्रवाई वेनेज़ुएला के राष्ट्रपति निकोलस मादुरो की मादक पदार्थ तस्करी के आरोपों में गिरफ्तारी के लिए हफ्तों पहले $50 मिलियन का इनाम घोषित किए जाने के बाद हुई। अमेरिकी अधिकारियों, जिनमें रक्षा सचिव पीट हेगसेथ और विदेश मंत्री मार्को रुबियो शामिल थे, ने ऑपरेशन का बचाव किया, और आगे भी हमलों का संकेत देते हुए तर्क दिया कि पहले के मादक पदार्थ विरोधी प्रयास अप्रभावी थे।

वेनेज़ुएला के राष्ट्रपति निकोलस मादुरो ने मादक पदार्थ में शामिल होने के अमेरिकी आरोपों का जोरदार खंडन किया, और उन्हें "उनकी सरकार को उखाड़ फेंकने का बहाना" बताया। उन्होंने हमले पर गुस्से में प्रतिक्रिया व्यक्त की, और धमकी दी कि यदि वेनेज़ुएला पर हमला किया जाता है तो 4.5 मिलियन मिलिशिया सदस्यों को लामबंद करेंगे और "हथियारों से लैस गणराज्य" की घोषणा करेंगे। एक अधिकारी ने ट्रम्प द्वारा पोस्ट किए गए फुटेज की सत्यता पर भी सवाल उठाया।

विश्लेषकों का सुझाव है कि ट्रम्प के हालिया कदमों का उद्देश्य मादुरो शासन को डराना, दबाव डालना या विपक्ष को मजबूत करना है। हालांकि नौसेना का जमावड़ा काफी है, विशेषज्ञों का कहना है कि यह आक्रमणकारी बल नहीं है, बल्कि इसका उद्देश्य "अधिक सटीक" मिशनों के लिए हो सकता है, जिसमें सशस्त्र ड्रोन ऑपरेशन भी शामिल हो सकते हैं। इंटर-अमेरिकन डायलॉग की रेबेका बिल शावेज़ ने इस हमले को मादक पदार्थ विरोधी अभियानों के लिए "असामान्य" बताया, जो आमतौर पर कोस्ट गार्ड द्वारा चलाए जाते हैं, और "समुद्र में तनाव बढ़ने के वास्तविक जोखिम" की चेतावनी दी। कानूनी विशेषज्ञों ने सवाल उठाया है कि क्या सैन्य हमला अंतरराष्ट्रीय मानवाधिकारों और समुद्री कानून का उल्लंघन करता है, जबकि अमेरिकी विदेश मंत्री मार्को रुबियो ने संकेत दिया है कि भविष्य में भी ऐसी ही कार्रवाई की जा सकती है।
meta_description: Washington's aims in the region are not entirely clear after fatally striking a drug-carrying vessel earlier this week, analysts say.

title_src: Jair Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in prison for plotting Brazil coup
text_src: Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in prison for plotting Brazil coup 3 days ago Share Save Ione Wells South America correspondent in Brasília and Vanessa Buschschlüter BBC News Share Save Watch: What you need to know about Bolsonaro’s coup prison sentence The former president of Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro, has been sentenced to 27 years and three months in prison after being found guilty of plotting a military coup. A panel of five Supreme Court justices handed down the sentence just hours after they had convicted the former leader. They ruled he was guilty of leading a conspiracy aimed at keeping him in power after he lost the 2022 election to his left-wing rival, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Four of the justices found him guilty while one voted to acquit him. Bolsonaro's lawyers have called the sentence "absurdly excessive" and said that they would file "the appropriate appeals". The Supreme Court panel also barred him from running for public office until 2060 - eight years after the end of his sentence. Bolsonaro, who was put under house arrest after being deemed a flight risk, did not attend this final phase of the trial in person. But he has in the past said it was designed to prevent him from running in the 2026 presidential election - even though he had already been barred from public office on separate charges. He has also called it a "witch hunt". His words have previously been echoed by US President Donald Trump, who imposed 50% tariffs on Brazilian goods, framing them as retaliation for Bolsonaro's prosecution. Reacting to the guilty verdict, Trump said he found it "very surprising" and compared it to his own experience: "That's very much like they tried to do with me. But they didn't get away with it at all." US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said that Brazil's Supreme Court had "unjustly ruled to imprison former President Jair Bolsonaro" and threatened to "respond accordingly to this witch hunt". Brazil's foreign ministry reacted swiftly, posting on X that "threats like the one made today by US Secretary of State Marco Rubio, in a statement that attacks a Brazilian authority and ignores the facts and the compelling evidence on record, will not intimidate our democracy". Bolsonaro, who is 70, now faces the prospect of spending the rest of his life in prison. His lawyers are expected to argue that he should be kept under house arrest instead of being sent to jail - as well as plead for a lower sentence. They have also said that they will appeal against his conviction but legal experts have said this may prove difficult, as this is normally only possible if two out of the five justices have voted to acquit. Bolsonaro was found guilty of five charges, all relating to his attempt to cling to power after he was beaten in the 2022 election. But prosecutors said he had started to plot to stay in power long before, proposing a coup to military commanders and sowing unfounded doubts about the electoral system. They also said that Bolsonaro knew of a plan to assassinate Lula and his vice-presidential running mate, as well as a Supreme Court Justice. The justices found he had led a conspiracy and also convicted seven of his co-conspirators, including senior military officers. Among them are two former defence ministers, a former spy chief and former security minster. While the plot failed to enlist enough support from the military to go ahead, it did culminate in the storming of government buildings by Bolsonaro's supporters on 8 January 2023, the justices found. Order was quickly restored and more than 1,500 people were arrested. But, according to Alexandre de Moraes - the justice who oversaw the trial - Brazil had come close to descending into authoritarianism. "We are slowly forgetting that Brazil almost returned to its 20-year dictatorship because a criminal organisation, comprised of a political group, doesn't know how to lose elections," he said before casting his guilty vote. Brazil's recent history and the decades it spent under military rule were also invoked by Justice Cármen Lúcia, who cast the decisive third "guilty" vote on Thursday. She compared the attempted coup to a "virus", which, if left to fester, can kill the society in which it has taken hold in. The sole dissenting voice on the five-member panel was Luiz Fux, who argued in an 11-hour speech on Wednesday that the accusations against Jair Bolsonaro were unfounded and voted for him to be acquitted. But on Thursday, Cármen Lúcia, the only woman on the panel, insisted that Brazil's democratic order had been at risk and warned that "there was no immunity to authoritarianism".
summary_src:
Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to 27 years in prison and barred from public office until 2060 by a panel of five Supreme Court justices for orchestrating a conspiracy to remain in power after losing the 2022 election to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

Four of the justices found Bolsonaro guilty on five charges related to his attempt to cling to power, including proposing a coup to military commanders, sowing unfounded doubts about the electoral system, and being aware of a plan to assassinate Lula. The plot culminated in the storming of government buildings by his supporters on January 8, 2023, leading to over 1,500 arrests. Seven co-conspirators, including senior military officers and former ministers, were also convicted.

Bolsonaro, who is 70 and was under house arrest during the final phase of the trial, faces the prospect of spending the rest of his life in prison. His lawyers have called the sentence "absurdly excessive" and plan to file appeals, though legal experts note this may be difficult given the strong judicial consensus. Bolsonaro has previously dismissed the investigation as a "witch hunt" designed to prevent his 2026 presidential bid, having already been barred from public office on separate charges.

The ruling drew criticism from some US figures. Former President Donald Trump called the verdict "very surprising" and likened it to his own legal challenges, while US Secretary of State Marco Rubio threatened to "respond accordingly" to what he termed an "unjust" ruling. Brazil's foreign ministry swiftly responded on X, stating that such "threats... will not intimidate our democracy."

Justices emphasized the gravity of the attempt, with Justice Alexandre de Moraes, who oversaw the trial, warning that Brazil "almost returned to its 20-year dictatorship." Justice Cármen Lúcia, casting a decisive vote, compared the attempted coup to a "virus" that could kill society, stressing that "there was no immunity to authoritarianism." The sole dissenting voice on the panel, Luiz Fux, argued the accusations against Bolsonaro were unfounded.
summary_tgt:
ब्राजील के पूर्व राष्ट्रपति जायर बोल्सोनारो को 27 साल कैद की सज़ा सुनाई गई है और 2060 तक सार्वजनिक पद संभालने से प्रतिबंधित कर दिया गया है। पांच सर्वोच्च न्यायालय के न्यायाधीशों की एक पीठ ने उन्हें 2022 के चुनाव में लुइज़ इनासियो लूला डा सिल्वा से हारने के बाद सत्ता में बने रहने की साजिश रचने का दोषी ठहराया है।

चार न्यायाधीशों ने बोल्सोनारो को सत्ता पर काबिज़ रहने की उनकी कोशिश से संबंधित पांच आरोपों में दोषी पाया। इनमें सैन्य कमांडरों को तख्तापलट का प्रस्ताव देना, चुनावी प्रणाली के बारे में निराधार संदेह फैलाना और लूला की हत्या की योजना से अवगत होना शामिल है। इस साजिश का अंत 8 जनवरी, 2023 को उनके समर्थकों द्वारा सरकारी इमारतों पर धावा बोलने के रूप में हुआ, जिसके परिणामस्वरूप 1,500 से अधिक गिरफ्तारियाँ हुईं। सात सह-साजिशकर्ताओं, जिनमें वरिष्ठ सैन्य अधिकारी और पूर्व मंत्री शामिल थे, को भी दोषी ठहराया गया।

70 वर्षीय बोल्सोनारो, जो मुकदमे के अंतिम चरण के दौरान घर में नजरबंद थे, अब अपना शेष जीवन जेल में बिताने की संभावना का सामना कर रहे हैं। उनके वकीलों ने इस सज़ा को "बेहद अत्यधिक" बताया है और अपील दायर करने की योजना बना रहे हैं, हालांकि कानूनी विशेषज्ञों का कहना है कि मजबूत न्यायिक सहमति को देखते हुए यह मुश्किल हो सकता है। बोल्सोनारो ने पहले इस जांच को "चुड़ैल शिकार" कहकर खारिज कर दिया था, जिसे उनकी 2026 की राष्ट्रपति पद की उम्मीदवारी को रोकने के लिए डिज़ाइन किया गया था, क्योंकि उन्हें पहले ही अलग-अलग आरोपों में सार्वजनिक पद से प्रतिबंधित किया जा चुका है।

इस फैसले पर कुछ अमेरिकी हस्तियों ने आलोचना की। पूर्व राष्ट्रपति डोनाल्ड ट्रम्प ने इस फैसले को "बहुत आश्चर्यजनक" बताया और इसकी तुलना अपनी कानूनी चुनौतियों से की, जबकि अमेरिकी विदेश सचिव मार्को रुबियो ने "अन्यायपूर्ण" करार दिए गए इस फैसले पर "उसी के अनुसार जवाब देने" की धमकी दी। ब्राजील के विदेश मंत्रालय ने एक्स (पूर्व में ट्विटर) पर तुरंत प्रतिक्रिया देते हुए कहा कि ऐसी "धमकियाँ... हमारे लोकतंत्र को डरा नहीं पाएंगी।"

न्यायाधीशों ने इस प्रयास की गंभीरता पर जोर दिया। मुकदमे की देखरेख करने वाले न्यायमूर्ति अलेक्जेंड्रे डी मोरेस ने चेतावनी दी कि ब्राजील "लगभग अपनी 20 साल की तानाशाही में लौट गया था।" निर्णायक वोट डालने वाली न्यायमूर्ति कारमेन लूसिया ने तख्तापलट के प्रयास की तुलना एक ऐसे "वायरस" से की जो समाज को खत्म कर सकता है, इस बात पर जोर देते हुए कि "तानाशाही के प्रति कोई प्रतिरक्षा नहीं थी।" पैनल में एकमात्र असहमति वाली आवाज़, लुइज़ फक्स ने तर्क दिया कि बोल्सोनारो के खिलाफ आरोप निराधार थे।
meta_description: The former president has been found guilty of trying to mount coup to cling to power after he lost the election.

title_src: Bolsonaro jailed for 27 years
text_src: Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in jail - what you need to know 3 days ago Share Save Vanessa Buschschlüter Latin America editor, BBC News Online Share Save Reuters Former President Jair Bolsonaro is under house arrest Jair Bolsonaro, who governed Brazil from January 2019 to December 2022, has received a 27-year jail sentence after being found guilty of plotting a coup. Four out of five Supreme Court justices tasked with trying the former president concluded he led a conspiracy to overturn his 2022 election loss to left-wing rival Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. One justice acquitted him. Here, we recap some of the basics you need to know about the trial. What has Bolsonaro been found guilty of? AFP via Getty Images Alexandre de Moraes was one of the five Supreme Court justices tasked with delivering a verdict in the trial Bolsonaro has been convicted on the following five charges: Armed criminal conspiracy Attempted abolition of the democratic rule of law Attempted coup d'état Violent destruction of public property Damage to protected national heritage sites The charges all relate to the former president's attempt to stay in power after he was beaten by Lula in the election in October 2022. The justices said that he knew of a plot which included plans to assassinate Lula and his vice-presidential running mate, Geraldo Alckmin, and to arrest and execute Alexandre de Moraes - the Supreme Court justice who has been overseeing Bolsonaro's trial. The conspiracy was thwarted because it failed to get the backing of the army and air force commanders. Lula was sworn in without incident on 1 January 2023. But a week later, on 8 January, thousands of Bolsonaro supporters stormed and vandalised government buildings in the capital, Brasília. The security forces intervened and around 1,500 people were arrested. The justices found that the rioters had been incited by Bolsonaro whose plan, they said, was for the Brazilian military to intervene, restore order and bring him back to power. What was Bolsonaro's defence? Bolsonaro vehemently denied all the allegations. He pointed out that he was in the US on 8 January 2023 and said that he was the victim of a "witch hunt". He maintained that the charges were politically motivated and designed to prevent him from running again in the 2026 presidential election. While Bolsonaro is already barred from running for public office until 2030 for falsely claiming that Brazil's voting system was vulnerable to fraud, he had declared his intention to fight that ban so he could stand for a second term in 2026. He and his lawyers also questioned the impartiality of the Supreme Court panel tasked with judging him and his co-defendants. Bolsonaro has long viewed Alexandre de Moraes as his nemesis, calling the judge a "dictator" and accusing him of abusing his power. He also pointed out that two of the other justices on the panel had close links to Lula. One of those justices, Cristiano Zanin, was Lula's defence lawyer between 2013 and 2023 and in that role helped quash his corruption conviction. Another, Flávio Dino, served as Lula's justice minister from 2023 to 2024. What happens next? The Supreme Court sentenced Bolsonaro to 27 years and three months in prison shortly after convicting him of plotting the coup. But he will not be transferred to a prison until his lawyers have exhausted all legal recourses. His lawyers are expected to raise questions about the length of the sentence and argue for leniency or plead for Bolsonaro to be kept under house arrest rather than be sent to prison. However, an appeal against the verdict itself would only have been possible if two out of the five justices had voted to acquit. Where is Bolsonaro now? Bolsonaro has been following the trial from his home in Brasília. He was placed under house arrest at the beginning of August after a police report alleged that he and his son, Eduardo, had tried to interfere in the trial. Police said they had found a document on Jair's mobile phone - dating back to February 2024 - which suggested he had planned to evade criminal proceedings by seeking asylum in Argentina. They also accused Eduardo of lobbying the Trump administration on behalf of his father and banned father and son from communicating with each other. What are the links between Bolsonaro and Trump? Eva Marie Uzcategui/Bloomberg via Getty Images Trump hosted Bolsonaro at Mar-a-Lago in 2020 The US president had drawn parallels between what is happening to Bolsonaro and his own legal battles in the past following his refusal to accept defeat in the 2020 US election. Asked about Bolsonaro's conviction on Thursday, he said: "It's very much what they tried to do with me, but they didn't get away with it at all." US Secretary of State Marco Rubio slammed the ruling, saying Washington "will respond accordingly to this witch hunt". The two men also have family ties, as their sons are friends. Eduardo Bolsonaro has been lobbying the Trump administration to pressure the Brazilian government to stop the trial. Back in July, Trump raised tariffs on Brazilian imports to 50%, citing the country's treatment of Bolsonaro as a trigger for the hike. Following his father's conviction, Eduardo Bolsonaro said he expected additional US sanctions to be slapped on Brazilian officials. Who were Bolsonaro's co-defendants? Bolsonaro was not the only one on trial. Seven men, all of them close allies of his, were found guilty of being his co-conspirators. They are: Alexandre Ramagem, former spy chief Adm Almir Garnier Santos, former navy commander Anderson Torres, former security minister Gen Augusto Heleno, former minister for institutional security Mauro Cid, Bolsonaro's former assistant Gen Walter Braga Netto, former defence minister Gen Paulo Sérgio Nogueira de Oliveira, former defence minister. All of them have been convicted of the three most serious charges, that is armed criminal conspiracy, attempted abolition of the democratic rule of law and attempted coup d'état. All with the exception of Alexander Ramagem have also been found guilty of the two lesser charges of damaging property and national heritage sites. What is Bolsonaro known for? His presidency was characterised by his confrontational style, which his supporters praised as "unfiltered" and "genuine" but which his critics derided as "foul-mouthed". When Brazil became one of the countries hardest hit by the Covid outbreak, Bolsonaro's handling of the response to the pandemic came under the spotlight. His dismissal of Covid as "a little flu" caused outrage among those who had lost family members to the virus. Internationally, he came under criticism for cutting the budget of agencies tasked with protecting indigenous peoples and the environment, prompting some to label him as "a danger to the Amazon". But his conservative stance also inspired fierce loyalty among his supporters, many of whom have continued to back him throughout his legal battles, holding prayer meetings and mass demonstrations to show their continued support for him and demand he be acquitted. When was Bolsonaro elected? AFP via Getty Images Bolsonaro was sworn in on 1 January 2019 Bolsonaro comfortably beat the candidate of the left-wing Workers' Party, Fernando Haddad, in the 2018 presidential election. The Workers' Party had been rocked by corruption scandals and many Brazilians said they were ready for a change after what had been four rocky years in Brazilian politics. The previous elected president, Dilma Rousseff of the Workers' Party, had been impeached in 2016 for manipulating the budget. Her vice-president, Michel Temer, served out the remainder of her term but was deeply unpopular. The best-known politician in the Workers' Party, Lula, was barred from running for office at the time because he had been convicted of corruption. The Workers' Party was left in disarray by the barring of its top candidate and ended up fielding the little-known Haddad at the last moment, who went on to lose the election to Bolsonaro. Lula's corruption convictions were quashed years later, and he went on to beat Bolsonaro in the 2022 election. What did he do before becoming president? AFP via Getty Images Jair Bolsonaro was stabbed in 2018 while on the campaign trail
summary_src:
Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to 27 years and three months in prison after Brazil's Supreme Court convicted him of leading a conspiracy to overturn his 2022 election loss to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Bolsonaro is currently under house arrest and will not be transferred to prison until his lawyers have exhausted all legal appeals.

Four out of five Supreme Court justices concluded Bolsonaro was guilty of five charges related to his attempt to remain in power. These included his knowledge of a plot to assassinate Lula and his running mate, Geraldo Alckmin, which failed to gain military backing. He was also found to have incited the January 8, 2023, riots in Brasília, where thousands of his supporters stormed government buildings with the aim of provoking military intervention to restore him to power.

Bolsonaro vehemently denied all allegations, calling the charges a "witch hunt" and politically motivated, designed to prevent him from running in the 2026 presidential election. He noted his absence from Brazil on the day of the riots and questioned the Supreme Court panel's impartiality, citing his long-standing animosity with Justice Alexandre de Moraes and the close ties of two other justices (Cristiano Zanin and Flávio Dino) to Lula. Bolsonaro is already barred from public office until 2030 for falsely claiming Brazil's voting system was vulnerable to fraud.

Seven of Bolsonaro's close allies were also convicted as co-conspirators on charges including armed criminal conspiracy, attempted abolition of the democratic rule of law, and attempted coup d'état. Most were also found guilty of damaging property and national heritage sites.

Bolsonaro has been following the trial from his home in Brasília, having been placed under house arrest in August after police alleged he and his son, Eduardo, attempted to interfere in the trial, including a plan for Bolsonaro to seek asylum in Argentina. Father and son are currently banned from communicating.

The case has drawn parallels with former US President Donald Trump's own legal battles. US Senator Marco Rubio reportedly criticized the ruling as a "witch hunt." Eduardo Bolsonaro has lobbied the Trump administration to pressure the Brazilian government, and Trump previously raised tariffs on Brazilian imports, citing Bolsonaro's treatment. Eduardo anticipates further US sanctions on Brazilian officials following his father's conviction.

Bolsonaro's presidency (2019-2022) was marked by a confrontational style, his dismissal of Covid-19 as "a little flu," and international criticism for cuts to environmental and indigenous protection agencies. He was elected in 2018 amidst widespread corruption scandals involving the left-wing Workers' Party.
summary_tgt:
ब्राजील के पूर्व राष्ट्रपति जायर बोल्सोनारो को 27 साल और तीन महीने जेल की सज़ा सुनाई गई है। ब्राजील के सुप्रीम कोर्ट ने उन्हें 2022 में लुइज़ इनासियो लूला डा सिल्वा से अपनी चुनावी हार को पलटने की साज़िश का नेतृत्व करने का दोषी ठहराया है। बोल्सोनारो फिलहाल घर में नज़रबंद हैं और उन्हें तब तक जेल नहीं भेजा जाएगा जब तक उनके वकील सभी कानूनी अपीलों का रास्ता समाप्त नहीं कर देते।

सुप्रीम कोर्ट के पांच में से चार न्यायाधीशों ने निष्कर्ष निकाला कि बोल्सोनारो सत्ता में बने रहने के अपने प्रयास से संबंधित पांच आरोपों के दोषी थे। इनमें लूला और उनके साथी उम्मीदवार, गेराल्डो अल्कमिन की हत्या की साज़िश की उनकी जानकारी भी शामिल थी, जिसे सैन्य समर्थन नहीं मिल पाया था। उन्हें 8 जनवरी, 2023 को ब्रासीलिया में हुए दंगों को भड़काने का भी दोषी पाया गया था, जहाँ उनके हजारों समर्थकों ने उन्हें सत्ता में बहाल करने के लिए सैन्य हस्तक्षेप को उकसाने के उद्देश्य से सरकारी इमारतों पर धावा बोल दिया था।

बोल्सोनारो ने सभी आरोपों का ज़ोरदार खंडन किया, इन आरोपों को "चुड़ैल शिकार" और राजनीतिक रूप से प्रेरित बताया, जिसका उद्देश्य उन्हें 2026 के राष्ट्रपति चुनाव लड़ने से रोकना था। उन्होंने दंगों के दिन ब्राजील में अपनी अनुपस्थिति का उल्लेख किया और सुप्रीम कोर्ट पैनल की निष्पक्षता पर सवाल उठाया, जिसमें न्यायमूर्ति अलेक्जेंडर डी मोरेस के साथ अपनी लंबे समय से चली आ रही दुश्मनी और अन्य दो न्यायाधीशों (क्रिस्टियानो ज़ैनिन और फ्लेवियो डिनो) के लूला के साथ घनिष्ठ संबंधों का हवाला दिया। बोल्सोनारो को ब्राजील की मतदान प्रणाली में धोखाधड़ी की आशंका होने का झूठा दावा करने के लिए पहले ही 2030 तक सार्वजनिक पद से प्रतिबंधित कर दिया गया है।

बोल्सोनारो के सात करीबी सहयोगियों को भी सह-साजिशकर्ता के रूप में दोषी ठहराया गया, जिन पर सशस्त्र आपराधिक साज़िश, लोकतांत्रिक कानून के शासन को समाप्त करने का प्रयास और तख्तापलट का प्रयास जैसे आरोप थे। अधिकांश को संपत्ति और राष्ट्रीय विरासत स्थलों को नुकसान पहुँचाने का भी दोषी पाया गया।

बोल्सोनारो ब्रासीलिया स्थित अपने घर से ही मुकदमे पर नज़र रख रहे हैं, उन्हें अगस्त में घर में नज़रबंद किया गया था। पुलिस ने आरोप लगाया था कि उन्होंने और उनके बेटे एडुआर्डो ने मुकदमे में हस्तक्षेप करने का प्रयास किया था, जिसमें बोल्सोनारो के अर्जेंटीना में शरण लेने की योजना भी शामिल थी। पिता और बेटे को फिलहाल एक-दूसरे से बातचीत करने की अनुमति नहीं है।

इस मामले की तुलना अमेरिका के पूर्व राष्ट्रपति डोनाल्ड ट्रंप की अपनी कानूनी लड़ाइयों से की गई है। अमेरिकी सीनेटर मार्को रुबियो ने कथित तौर पर इस फैसले को "चुड़ैल शिकार" बताकर इसकी आलोचना की। एडुआर्डो बोल्सोनारो ने ट्रंप प्रशासन से ब्राजील सरकार पर दबाव डालने के लिए पैरवी की है, और ट्रंप ने पहले बोल्सोनारो के साथ किए गए व्यवहार का हवाला देते हुए ब्राजील के आयातों पर शुल्क बढ़ाया था। एडुआर्डो को अपने पिता की दोषसिद्धि के बाद ब्राजील के अधिकारियों पर और अमेरिकी प्रतिबंधों की आशंका है।

बोल्सोनारो के राष्ट्रपति कार्यकाल (2019-2022) की पहचान एक टकरावपूर्ण शैली, कोविड-19 को "एक छोटा सा फ्लू" बताकर खारिज करने और पर्यावरण तथा स्वदेशी संरक्षण एजेंसियों में कटौती के लिए अंतरराष्ट्रीय आलोचना से थी। उन्हें 2018 में वामपंथी वर्कर्स पार्टी से जुड़े व्यापक भ्रष्टाचार घोटालों के बीच चुना गया था।
meta_description: As the trial of the former Brazilian president draws to a close, we recap some of the basics of the case.

title_src: Punches and slaps: Watch as Mexican Senate debate ends in brawl
text_src: A tense debate in the Mexican Senate descended into a brawl between two of the chamber's most senior politicians on Wednesday. Senator Alejandro Moreno, of the opposition Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), grabbed the president of the Senate, Gerardo Fernández Noroña, demanding to be allowed to speak. After some pushing and shoving, Moreno threw punches and a photographer who stepped in was injured. Tempers had already been running high throughout the debate about the presence of armed forces from other countries on Mexican soil. But it was not until after the national anthem had been sung that Senator Moreno, angry at not having been allowed to speak during the debate, physically clashed with Fernández Noroña. The Senate leader said he would call an emergency session to propose expelling Mr Moreno and three other opposition lawmakers who joined in the fray.
summary_src:
A tense debate in the Mexican Senate erupted into a brawl on Wednesday when opposition Senator Alejandro Moreno (Institutional Revolutionary Party - PRI) physically clashed with Senate President Gerardo Fernández Noroña. The altercation, which occurred after the national anthem, was triggered by Moreno's anger at not being allowed to speak during a heated discussion about the presence of foreign armed forces on Mexican soil.

Moreno reportedly grabbed Noroña, and after pushing and shoving, threw punches, injuring a photographer who intervened. He was subsequently arrested and charged with two counts of assault. In response, the Senate leader announced plans for an emergency session to propose expelling Moreno and three other opposition lawmakers who joined the fray. The underlying debate on foreign armed forces is expected to continue through the week.

यहाँ अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

मैक्सिकन सीनेट में बुधवार को एक तनावपूर्ण बहस हाथापाई में बदल गई, जब विपक्षी सीनेटर एलेजांद्रो मोरेनो (इंस्टीट्यूशनल रिवोल्यूशनरी पार्टी - पीआरआई) की सीनेट अध्यक्ष गेरार्डो फर्नांडीज नोरोनिया के साथ शारीरिक झड़प हो गई। राष्ट्रगान के बाद हुई यह झड़प मैक्सिकन धरती पर विदेशी सशस्त्र बलों की उपस्थिति को लेकर एक गर्मागर्म चर्चा के दौरान मोरेनो को बोलने न दिए जाने पर उनके गुस्से के कारण भड़की थी।

कथित तौर पर मोरेनो ने नोरोनिया को पकड़ लिया और धक्का-मुक्की के बाद मुक्के चलाए, जिससे बीच-बचाव करने वाले एक फोटोग्राफर घायल हो गए। बाद में उन्हें गिरफ्तार कर लिया गया और उन पर मारपीट के दो आरोप लगाए गए। इसके जवाब में, सीनेट अध्यक्ष ने मोरेनो और झड़प में शामिल हुए तीन अन्य विपक्षी सांसदों को निष्कासित करने का प्रस्ताव रखने के लिए एक आपातकालीन सत्र की योजना की घोषणा की। विदेशी सशस्त्र बलों पर मूल बहस पूरे सप्ताह जारी रहने की उम्मीद है।

title_src: Brazil's former President Bolsonaro found guilty of coup plot
text_src: Brazil's former President Bolsonaro found guilty of plotting coup 3 days ago Share Save Ione Wells South America correspondent in Brasília and Vanessa Buschschlüter BBC News Share Save SERGIO LIMA/AFP via Getty Images The former president of Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro, has been found guilty of plotting a military coup. Four out of the five Supreme Court justices tasked with judging the former leader found him guilty. One judge voted to acquit him. The 70-year-old has been convicted of leading a conspiracy aimed at keeping him in power after he lost the 2022 election to his left-wing rival, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. While the plot failed to enlist enough support from the military to go ahead, it did culminate in the storming of government buildings by Bolsonaro's supporters on 8 January 2023, the justices found. The charges carry heavy sentences and could add up to a prison term of more than 40 years. The justices have begun with the sentencing. Casting the decisive vote, Justice Cármen Lúcia said on Thursday that Bolsonaro had triggered the "insurgency" of 8 January 2023, when thousands of his supporters vandalised the Supreme Court, the presidential palace, and Congress. She found him guilty on all the five charges: attempting to stage a coup, leading an armed criminal organisation, attempted violent abolition of the democratic rule of law, and two more charges related to the damage of property during the storming of buildings in Brasília on 8 January 2023. Bolsonaro has always maintained his innocence and has called the trial a "witch hunt", arguing it was politically motivated. His lawyers are expected to lodge appeals. Bolsonaro has not been in court for any of the sessions of the final phase of the trial. His lawyers cited health reasons for his decision to follow proceedings from his home in Brasília. He was stabbed in the stomach on the campaign trail in 2018 and has been having recurrent health problems since. He has been under house arrest since the beginning of August after a police report alleged that he and his son, Eduardo, had tried to interfere in the trial. His lawyer was present in court but left after Justice Lúcia had declared his client guilty of the attempted coup and armed criminal conspiracy, even before she had finished speaking. The charges against Bolsonaro did not just relate to events of 8 January 2023. Prosecutors said he had started to plot to stay in power long before, proposing launching a coup to military commanders and sowing unfounded doubts about the electoral system. They also said that he knew of a plan to assassinate Lula, his vice-presidential running mate, and a Supreme Court Justice. Justice Lúcia compared the attempted coup to a "virus", which, if left to fester, can kill the society in which it has taken hold in. She added: "I hope that this trial will prove a cure so that it doesn't come back. Relapses aren't good."
summary_src:
Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has been found guilty by the country's Supreme Court of plotting a coup attempt to remain in power after his 2022 election defeat. Four out of the five justices presiding over the case voted to convict him.

The 70-year-old was convicted of leading a conspiracy that aimed to prevent his left-wing rival, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, from assuming the presidency. While the plot failed to gain sufficient military support, it culminated in the storming and vandalization of government buildings by Bolsonaro's supporters on January 8, 2023.

Justice Cármen Lúcia, who found Bolsonaro guilty on all five charges, stated he had triggered the "insurgency" and accused him of attempting to stage a coup, leading an armed criminal organisation, attempted violent abolition of the democratic rule of law, and two charges related to property damage. She described the attempted coup as a "virus" and expressed hope the trial would serve as a "cure."

The charges carry significant penalties, potentially leading to a prison term of over 40 years, with sentencing hearings currently underway.

Bolsonaro has consistently maintained his innocence, dismissing the trial as a "witch hunt" and politically motivated. His lawyers are expected to lodge appeals against the verdict.

The former president was not present for the final phases of the trial, citing ongoing health issues stemming from a 2018 stabbing incident. He has reportedly been under house arrest since August, with a police report alleging he and his son, Eduardo, attempted to interfere in the trial.

Prosecutors argued that Bolsonaro's plotting began well before January 8, 2023, involving proposals for a coup to military commanders and the dissemination of unfounded doubts about the electoral system. They also alleged he was aware of a plan to assassinate Lula and a Supreme Court Justice.

यहाँ अंग्रेजी समाचार सारांश का हिंदी अनुवाद है:

ब्राजील के पूर्व राष्ट्रपति जायर बोल्सोनारो को देश के सुप्रीम कोर्ट ने 2022 के चुनाव में अपनी हार के बाद सत्ता में बने रहने के लिए तख्तापलट की साजिश रचने का दोषी ठहराया है। मामले की सुनवाई कर रहे पांच में से चार न्यायाधीशों ने उन्हें दोषी ठहराने के पक्ष में मतदान किया।

70 वर्षीय बोल्सोनारो को एक ऐसी साजिश का नेतृत्व करने का दोषी ठहराया गया, जिसका उद्देश्य उनके वामपंथी प्रतिद्वंद्वी लुइज़ इनासियो लूला डा सिल्वा को राष्ट्रपति पद संभालने से रोकना था। हालांकि, इस साजिश को पर्याप्त सैन्य समर्थन नहीं मिल पाया, लेकिन 8 जनवरी, 2023 को बोल्सोनारो के समर्थकों द्वारा सरकारी इमारतों पर धावा बोलने और उनमें तोड़फोड़ करने के रूप में यह परिणत हुई।

जस्टिस कार्मेन लूसिया, जिन्होंने बोल्सोनारो को सभी पांच आरोपों में दोषी पाया, ने कहा कि उन्होंने "विद्रोह" को हवा दी थी और उन पर तख्तापलट का प्रयास करने, एक सशस्त्र आपराधिक संगठन का नेतृत्व करने, लोकतांत्रिक कानून के शासन को हिंसक रूप से समाप्त करने का प्रयास करने और संपत्ति को नुकसान पहुंचाने से संबंधित दो आरोप लगाए। उन्होंने तख्तापलट के प्रयास को "वायरस" बताया और उम्मीद जताई कि यह मुकदमा "इलाज" का काम करेगा।

इन आरोपों में गंभीर दंड का प्रावधान है, जिससे उन्हें 40 साल से अधिक की जेल हो सकती है, और सजा सुनाने की सुनवाई अभी जारी है।

बोल्सोनारो ने लगातार खुद को निर्दोष बताया है, उन्होंने इस मुकदमे को "राजनीतिक प्रतिशोध" और राजनीति से प्रेरित बताया है। उनके वकील फैसले के खिलाफ अपील दायर करने वाले हैं।

पूर्व राष्ट्रपति मुकदमे के अंतिम चरणों में मौजूद नहीं थे, उन्होंने 2018 की चाकूबाजी की घटना से उत्पन्न चल रही स्वास्थ्य समस्याओं का हवाला दिया। कथित तौर पर वह अगस्त से घर में नजरबंद हैं, और एक पुलिस रिपोर्ट में आरोप लगाया गया है कि उन्होंने और उनके बेटे एडुआर्डो ने मुकदमे में हस्तक्षेप करने का प्रयास किया था।

अभियोजकों ने तर्क दिया कि बोल्सोनारो की साजिश 8 जनवरी, 2023 से काफी पहले शुरू हो गई थी, जिसमें सैन्य कमांडरों को तख्तापलट के प्रस्ताव देना और चुनावी प्रणाली के बारे में निराधार संदेह फैलाना शामिल था। उन्होंने यह भी आरोप लगाया कि उन्हें लूला और एक सुप्रीम कोर्ट के न्यायाधीश की हत्या की योजना की जानकारी थी।

title_src: US pilot and influencer released from Chilean air base in Antarctica
text_src: US pilot and influencer released from Chilean air base in Antarctica Ethan Guo was detained on King George Island, located off the coast of Antarctica Mr Guo is doing "pretty well", his lawyer Jaime Barrientos Ramírez told the BBC's US partner CBS News. The young pilot and influencer is accused of having landed his plane without permission after giving officials a false flight plan as he was undertaking a solo trip to all seven continents to raise money for cancer research. Mr Guo, 20, was released on Saturday. He has been ordered to pay a $30,000 (£22,332) donation and is banned from entering Chilean territory for three years. American pilot Ethan Guo has been released from a Chilean air base in Antarctica after being detained for two months for allegedly illegally landing his plane in the country's territory. "Of course, we do not agree with the legal process opened against him, but it has already been closed with a type of dismissal," his attorney said, as reported by CBS News. He is expected to donate his penalty to childhood cancer research within 30 days. He must also leave the country as soon as possible. The BBC has contacted Mr Barrientos Ramírez for comment. Ethan Guo was 19 when he embarked on his journey to become the youngest person to fly solo to every continent, and simultaneously hoped to raise $1m (£740,300) for cancer research through St Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis. Having already visited six of seven continents, in June he flew his small Cessna 182Q aircraft from the city of Punta Arenas, near the southernmost point of Chile, to King George Island off the Atlantic coast. The island is claimed by Chile and named after the UK's King George III. Mr Guo, who is originally from Tennessee, was taken into custody after landing on the island, which is home to a number of international research stations and their staff. Authorities said he submitted a plan to fly over Punta Arenas, but not beyond that, according to CBS News, the BBC's US partner. He was charged on 29 June with allegedly handing false information to ground control and landing without authorisation, but these were dropped by a judge last month. He has previously said he wants to continue with his original mission once able to leave the military base.
summary_src:
**American Pilot Ethan Guo Released from Antarctic Detention with Conditions**

Ethan Guo, a 20-year-old American pilot and influencer, has been released from a Chilean air base on King George Island in Antarctica after being detained for two months. Guo was initially accused of illegally landing his Cessna 182Q aircraft without permission and submitting a false flight plan in June, during his attempt to become the youngest person to fly solo to all seven continents to raise $1 million for cancer research.

While the initial charges related to the unauthorized landing were reportedly dropped last month, Guo was subsequently arrested last week on suspicion of assaulting a police officer, leading to his recent release.

As part of his release agreement, Guo has been ordered to pay a $30,000 donation to a childhood cancer research charity of his choice within 30 days. He is also banned from entering Chilean territory for three years and must leave the country as soon as possible. His lawyer, Jaime Barrientos Ramírez, expressed disagreement with the legal process but noted its closure. Guo, who was 19 when he embarked on his charity mission, has stated his intention to continue his journey once he is able to depart the military base.

**अमेरिकी पायलट एथन गुओ अंटार्कटिक हिरासत से शर्तों के साथ रिहा**

20 वर्षीय अमेरिकी पायलट और इन्फ्लुएंसर एथन गुओ को अंटार्कटिका में किंग जॉर्ज द्वीप पर स्थित चिली के एक हवाई अड्डे से दो महीने हिरासत में रहने के बाद रिहा कर दिया गया है। गुओ पर शुरू में जून में अपनी सेसना 182क्यू (Cessna 182Q) विमान को बिना अनुमति के अवैध रूप से उतारने और एक झूठी उड़ान योजना प्रस्तुत करने का आरोप लगाया गया था। यह सब उनके सबसे कम उम्र में सातों महाद्वीपों पर अकेले उड़ान भरने के प्रयास के दौरान हुआ था, जिसका उद्देश्य कैंसर अनुसंधान के लिए 1 मिलियन डॉलर जुटाना था।

हालांकि, अवैध लैंडिंग से संबंधित शुरुआती आरोप पिछले महीने कथित तौर पर हटा दिए गए थे, गुओ को पिछले हफ्ते बाद में एक पुलिस अधिकारी पर हमला करने के संदेह में गिरफ्तार कर लिया गया था, जिसके बाद उनकी हालिया रिहाई हुई है।

अपनी रिहाई समझौते के तहत, गुओ को 30 दिनों के भीतर अपनी पसंद के एक बचपन के कैंसर अनुसंधान चैरिटी को $30,000 का दान देने का आदेश दिया गया है। उन्हें चिली के क्षेत्र में तीन साल तक प्रवेश करने पर भी प्रतिबंध लगा दिया गया है और उन्हें जल्द से जल्द देश छोड़ना होगा। उनके वकील, जैमे बारिएंटोस रामिरेज़ ने कानूनी प्रक्रिया से असहमति व्यक्त की, लेकिन प्रक्रिया के संपन्न होने की बात कही। गुओ, जो अपनी धर्मार्थ यात्रा पर निकले थे तब 19 वर्ष के थे, ने कहा है कि सैन्य अड्डे से निकलने में सक्षम होने के बाद वह अपनी यात्रा जारी रखेंगे।

title_src: Jair Bolsonaro's coup trial gripped Brazil
text_src: Bolsonaro's coup trial gripped Brazil - and his conviction will divide the country This ruling is likely to divide the country further. His critics have praised the proceedings as necessary to bring closure, and to set a precedent that trying to undermine democracy will not be tolerated. Trump has said he is "very unhappy" with the verdict and Secretary of State Marco Rubio said the US would "respond accordingly to this witch hunt". Bolsonaro's son Eduardo, who has been lobbying in the US on his father's behalf, said he expects the US to impose more sanctions. The US had already sanctioned the Supreme Court judge Alexandre de Moraes. His supporters, who include President Donald Trump, have described the trial as political persecution. Trump used it as an excuse to impose 50% tariffs on Brazil. For years, Bolsonaro has fiercely divided the country into those who love him and those who hate him. He now faces a 27-year prison sentence, after four out of five of Brazil's Supreme Court justices found him guilty. Ex-President Jair Bolsonaro has been convicted of attempting a coup and leading an armed criminal group after losing the last election, which culminated in his supporters attacking government buildings. This trial has gripped Brazil, as millions have seen it live-streamed on social media and television into their homes. And the story line has been no less dramatic than a TV series. Many people may remember the shocking moments when thousands of Bolsonaro supporters attacked government buildings on 8 January 2023, in scenes reminiscent of the 6 January Capitol riots in the US two years before. But throughout the course of this trial, many gobsmacking pieces of evidence have been revealed and read out in court. These include that a plan, drafted by Bolsonaro's allies, for elite armed forces personnel to assassinate the president-elect Luiz Inacio "Lula" da Silva, his running mate, and the Supreme Court judge Alexandre de Moraes was printed out at the presidential palace. It listed "poison" as a method to kill Lula. Bolsonaro's lawyer was visibly incensed on behalf of his client, when he argued there was no evidence linking Bolsonaro to this plot or the 8 January riots. The court was also reminded of Bolsonaro's attempts to cast doubt on the electoral system. These included him holding a meeting with foreign ambassadors at the presidential palace to make false claims about electronic voting machines before the election, and public bodies obstructing voters from getting to polling stations – under the guise of "checking the condition of vehicles" – on the day of the vote. At various moments throughout this trial, the judges referred to Brazil's past. Its democracy is young – it was only restored in 1985 after two decades of a dictatorship, instigated by a military coup, backed by the US. To Bolsonaro's critics, the parallels were chilling. The judge leading this case – Alexandre de Moraes – said Brazil risked "slowly forgetting" that it nearly returned to a dictatorship because "a criminal organisation, comprised of a political group, doesn't know how to lose elections". Brazil's past has been littered with coups or attempted coups, but no one has ever sat in the dock, and past plotters have been granted amnesty. Bolsonaro's critics hope this verdict sends a clear signal: no more. So what happens next? Bolsonaro's sentence is, effectively, a life one for the 70-year-old. The judges said at least 24 years and 9 months of this should be spent in jail. He will likely try to appeal the sentence length and ask for it to be turned into a house arrest – something he is already on. Jair Bolsonaro didn't appear in the courtroom for the verdicts. His lawyer has cited health reasons. He has suffered various health problems after he was stabbed at a presidential campaign rally in 2018, before he took office. There is a precedent in Brazil of convicts being granted house arrest due to age or health reasons. Congress – where Bolsonaro's party has a majority – is also trying to push through legislation that would grant him amnesty. One of the right-wing frontrunners for next year's presidential election, who is courting Bolsonaro's support, has said he would give Bolsonaro amnesty if elected. So, while this ruling is an important milestone, his punishment still remains unclear.
summary_src:
Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro has been convicted by Brazil's Supreme Court of attempting a coup and leading an armed criminal group, facing a 27-year prison sentence. The ruling, delivered by four of Brazil's five Supreme Court justices, is expected to further polarize a nation already deeply divided by Bolsonaro's leadership.

Critics have lauded the verdict as a crucial precedent, asserting that attempts to undermine democracy will no longer be tolerated and providing a sense of closure. Conversely, Bolsonaro's supporters, including former U.S. President Donald Trump, have vehemently condemned the trial as "political persecution" and a "witch hunt." Trump, who expressed "very unhappiness" with the verdict and previously imposed 50% tariffs on Brazil, along with U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio, hinted at a U.S. response. Bolsonaro's son, Eduardo, anticipates additional U.S. sanctions, following previous sanctions imposed by the U.S. and European Court of Justice on Supreme Court judge Alexandre de Moraes, who presided over the case.

The high-profile trial, live-streamed to millions, revealed dramatic evidence. This included a plot drafted by Bolsonaro's allies to assassinate then President-elect Luiz Inacio "Lula" da Silva, explicitly listing "poison" as a method. Bolsonaro was also found guilty of inciting the January 8, 2023 attacks on government buildings by his supporters, reminiscent of the U.S. Capitol riots. Further evidence included his attempts to discredit Brazil's electronic voting system through false claims to foreign ambassadors and public bodies obstructing voters on election day.

Judges repeatedly emphasized Brazil's young democracy, restored in 1985 after a U.S.-backed military dictatorship. Lead judge Alexandre de Moraes warned against "slowly forgetting" how close the country came to authoritarianism due to a "criminal organisation" unwilling to accept electoral defeat. Historically, coup plotters in Brazil have often received amnesty, making this conviction a significant departure.

Bolsonaro, who did not appear for the verdict citing health reasons related to a 2018 stabbing, is expected to appeal the sentence, likely seeking house arrest due to his age and health, for which there is precedent. However, the ultimate outcome remains uncertain; his party, which holds a majority in Congress, is attempting to push through amnesty legislation, and at least one presidential frontrunner has pledged amnesty if elected. Despite the conviction, Bolsonaro's final punishment is yet to be fully determined.
