title_src: Stephen Miran: Senate confirms Trump pick to Fed board ahead of key interest rate vote
text_src: Senate clears Trump pick Miran to Fed board ahead of key interest rate vote Stephen Miran will be the first sitting White House official to join the Fed's board in decades The economist's entry has raised concerns over the central bank's longstanding independence and follows Trump's bid to reshape the Federal Reserve . He was narrowly confirmed on Monday with a vote of 48-47. Miran, who is chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, will be the first sitting White House official to join the Fed's board since its creation in its current form in the 1930s. The US Senate has cleared President Donald Trump's pick Stephen Miran to join the Federal Reserve's board of governors - part of a panel responsible for setting the country's interest rates. Miran is expected to take part in a key Fed policy meeting this week as one of 12 voting members, playing a central role in Trump's bid for a large interest rate cut. The Fed is expected to approve a quarter-percentage point rate cut to support a weakening labour market. Miran is a supporter of Trump's global tariffs, arguing the import duties won't fuel inflation and that policies like stricter immigration will reduce housing demand and lower prices. The White House economist's fast-tracked confirmation vote has proceeded in just a few weeks, when it typically takes months for a Fed governor nominee to be confirmed by the Senate. Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat, raised concerns that Miran would be seen as a "puppet" who would not be trusted as an independent voice on the Fed board. Trump has put pressure on the Fed for months, demanding interest rate cuts to give the US economy a boost and make it cheaper for the government to borrow. The president has taken aim at Fed chair Jerome Powell, calling him a "numbskull" and "too late". The Miran vote also comes as Trump is also attempting to fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook from the central bank, citing allegations of mortgage fraud and constitutional powers to remove her. Cook, the first black woman to serve as a Fed governor, has denied the allegations and sued to block her removal. She has voted in recent months to keep interest rates on hold this year. On Monday, a US appeals court denied the justice department's request to lift an earlier ruling to temporarily block Trump from removing Cook. The Trump administration is also pursuing mortgage fraud investigations against Senator Adam Schiff and New York Attorney General Letitia James, both political antagonists of the president.
summary_src: The Senate narrowly confirmed Stephen Miran, a White House economist and Chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, to the Federal Reserve Board in a 48-47 vote.  This makes Miran the first sitting White House official to join the Fed's board in decades.  His swift confirmation, just weeks after nomination, allows him to participate in a key interest rate meeting this week, where a rate cut is anticipated.  Miran's appointment, pushed by President Trump who has publicly pressured the Fed for rate cuts, has drawn criticism from Democrats, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, who voiced concerns about his independence.  The confirmation comes amidst Trump's ongoing attempts to remove Fed Governor Lisa Cook, a move blocked by a court order, and parallel investigations into political opponents.  Miran, a supporter of Trump's trade policies, is expected to play a significant role in shaping the Fed's monetary policy.
summary_tgt:
सीनेट ने एक संकीर्ण 48-47 के मत से व्हाइट हाउस के अर्थशास्त्री और आर्थिक सलाहकार परिषद के अध्यक्ष स्टीफन मिरान को फेडरल रिजर्व बोर्ड में शामिल करने की पुष्टि कर दी। यह दशकों में पहला मौका है जब किसी कार्यरत व्हाइट हाउस अधिकारी को फेड के बोर्ड में शामिल किया गया है।  नामांकन के कुछ ही हफ़्तों बाद उनकी त्वरित पुष्टि से उन्हें इस सप्ताह होने वाली एक महत्वपूर्ण ब्याज दर बैठक में भाग लेने की अनुमति मिल गई है, जहाँ ब्याज दर में कटौती की उम्मीद है।

राष्ट्रपति ट्रम्प द्वारा धकेले गए मिरान की नियुक्ति, जिन्होंने सार्वजनिक रूप से फेड पर ब्याज दरों में कटौती का दबाव डाला है,  डेमोक्रेट्स से आलोचना का सामना कर रही है, जिसमें सीनेटर एलिजाबेथ वॉरेन भी शामिल हैं, जिन्होंने उनकी स्वतंत्रता को लेकर चिंता व्यक्त की है।  यह पुष्टि ट्रम्प द्वारा फेड गवर्नर लिसा कुक को हटाने के चल रहे प्रयासों के बीच हुई है, जिसे एक अदालती आदेश द्वारा रोक दिया गया था, और साथ ही राजनीतिक विरोधियों के खिलाफ समानांतर जांच भी चल रही है।  ट्रम्प की व्यापार नीतियों के समर्थक मिरान से फेड की मौद्रिक नीति को आकार देने में महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका निभाने की उम्मीद है।
meta_description: His entry has raised concerns over the Fed's independence, following Trump's bid to reshape the central bank.

title_src: South Korea to probe potential human rights abuses in US Hyundai raid
text_src: South Korea to probe potential human rights abuses in US raid 1 day ago Share Save Osmond Chia Business reporter, Singapore Share Save Reuters More than 300 South Koreans who were detained in a massive immigration raid in Georgia arrived home last Friday The South Korean government says it is investigating potential human rights violations during the raid and detention of Korean workers by US authorities. South Korea has expressed "strong regret" to the US and has officially asked that its citizens' rights and interests are not infringed during law enforcement proceedings, said a presidential spokesperson on Monday. More than 300 South Korean workers returned home on Friday after being held for a week following a raid at an electric vehicle battery plant in the US state of Georgia. The incident has tested ties between the countries, even as South Korean firms are set to invest billions in America under a trade deal to avoid steep US tariffs. South Korean authorities will work with the relevant companies to "thoroughly investigate any potential human rights violations or other issues", said the presidential spokesperson during a press briefing. The BBC has contacted the US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for comment. The raid has raised tensions between the US and South Korea, where many of those detained were from, with President Lee Jae-myung warning that it will discourage foreign investment into the US. He called the situation "bewildering", adding that it is a common practice for Korean companies to send workers to help set up overseas factories. Last week, Hyundai said the plant's opening will be delayed by at least two months. South Korea's trade unions have called on Trump to issue an official apology. How the massive immigration raid on a Georgia car plant unfolded
summary_src: Over 300 South Korean workers deported after a week-long detention following a US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raid at a Georgia electric vehicle battery plant have returned home.  South Korea has formally protested the raid, expressing "strong regret" and demanding investigation into potential human rights violations.  The incident, which has strained US-South Korean relations, prompted President Lee Jae-myung to warn of negative impacts on future foreign investment in the US.  Hyundai, whose plant's opening has been delayed by at least two months due to the raid, is among the South Korean companies cooperating with the investigation.  ICE has yet to respond to requests for comment.  South Korean trade unions are calling for a formal apology from the White House.
summary_tgt: जॉर्जिया के एक इलेक्ट्रिक वाहन बैटरी संयंत्र में अमेरिका के आव्रजन और सीमा शुल्क प्रवर्तन (ICE) के छापे के बाद एक हफ़्ते की हिरासत के बाद, 300 से अधिक दक्षिण कोरियाई कामगारों को देश निकाला दिए जाने के बाद वे अपने देश वापस लौट आए हैं। दक्षिण कोरिया ने इस छापे के खिलाफ़ औपचारिक विरोध दर्ज कराया है, जिसमें "गहरा खेद" व्यक्त किया गया है और संभावित मानवाधिकारों के उल्लंघन की जाँच की माँग की गई है। इस घटना ने अमेरिका-दक्षिण कोरियाई संबंधों में तनाव पैदा कर दिया है, जिसके कारण राष्ट्रपति ली जे-म्युंग ने अमेरिका में भविष्य के विदेशी निवेश पर नकारात्मक प्रभाव की चेतावनी दी है।  हुंडई, जिसके संयंत्र का उद्घाटन इस छापे के कारण कम से कम दो महीने के लिए विलंबित हो गया है, उन दक्षिण कोरियाई कंपनियों में शामिल है जो जाँच में सहयोग कर रही हैं। ICE ने अभी तक टिप्पणी के अनुरोधों का कोई जवाब नहीं दिया है। दक्षिण कोरियाई ट्रेड यूनियन व्हाइट हाउस से औपचारिक माफी की मांग कर रहे हैं।
meta_description: More than 300 South Korean workers returned home on Friday after being held for a week in the US following the raid.

title_src: Belarus and Russia stage joint military drills
text_src: Belarusian and Russian forces are taking part in joint manoeuvres some 45 miles (72km) from Minsk as part of the Zapad 2025 (West 2025) military drills. The countries say the operations are "purely defensive in nature" but they come at a tense time, with Russian drones entering Nato territory and the war between Russia and Ukraine raging, as Steve Rosenberg reports.
summary_src: Joint Belarusian and Russian military exercises, codenamed Zapad 2025 (West 2025), are underway approximately 72 kilometers from Minsk.  While both nations claim the drills are purely defensive, the maneuvers occur amidst heightened tensions stemming from recent Russian drone incursions into NATO airspace and the ongoing war in Ukraine, raising concerns among neighboring countries.
summary_tgt: मिनस्क से लगभग 72 किलोमीटर दूर, बेलारूस और रूस के संयुक्त सैन्य अभ्यास, जिनका कोडनेम "ज़ापाद 2025" (पश्चिम 2025) है, चल रहे हैं। दोनों देशों का दावा है कि यह अभ्यास पूरी तरह से रक्षात्मक हैं, लेकिन ये युद्धाभ्यास हाल ही में रूसी ड्रोन द्वारा नाटो के हवाई क्षेत्र में घुसपैठ और यूक्रेन में जारी युद्ध के कारण बढ़े हुए तनाव के बीच हो रहे हैं, जिससे पड़ोसी देशों में चिंताएँ बढ़ गई हैं।
meta_description: The BBC's Russia editor, Steve Rosenberg, reports from joint manoeuvres by Russia and Belarus, as part of the Zapad 2025 (West 2025) military drills.

title_src: Israel escalates bombardment as defence minister says 'Gaza is burning'
text_src: Israel escalates bombardment as defence minister says 'Gaza is burning' 44 minutes ago Share Save Yolande Knell Middle East correspondent, Jerusalem and Tom Bateman State Department correspondent, Jerusalem Share Save Watch: Blasts over Gaza skyline seen from southern Israel Israel has heavily bombed Gaza City overnight with unconfirmed reports from the US news site Axios and the Jerusalem Post that the military has now launched its ground offensive to occupy the entire city. Israeli strikes are also reported in central Gaza, in the direction in which thousands of people are fleeing. Palestinian officials say there are rising numbers of deaths and injuries. The intensification came ahead of a long-threatened full-scale ground invasion of the city, which is home to hundreds of thousands of people. It came hours after Secretary of State Marco Rubio assured Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of unwavering US support during a trip to Jerusalem on Monday. Early on Tuesday morning, Israel's defence minister, Israel Katz, wrote on X, "Gaza is burning" and threatened that Israel, "will not relent and we will not go back - until the completion of the mission." Local journalists in Gaza say there have been almost constant Israeli air strikes and artillery and gunfire in Gaza City. Homes are said to have been destroyed, with people trapped in the rubble. There has been no official confirmation of a new ground incursion from the Israeli military. Israel has demanded that Gaza City's residents leave and head south to a central area of the strip. The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) estimate about 250,000 Palestinians have fled, though hundreds of thousands are believed to remain in the area. Some say they cannot afford to go south, while others say southern Gaza is not safe as Israel has carried out air strikes there too. Some have said they attempted to go south but were unable to pitch their tents, so returned to Gaza City. Reuters Israeli strikes on Gaza continued into Tuesday Rubio meanwhile was heading to visit Qatar next, where Arab leaders on Monday condemned Israel's attack last week on the capital Doha targeting, but reportedly failing to kill, Hamas leaders. Speaking from the tarmac at Ben Gurion airport, Rubio said Qatar was still the only country able to mediate on Gaza. Pressed by the BBC on the condemnation of Israel from Arab and Muslim countries in Doha on Monday, he said the US prefers that war ends in a negotiated settlement and hoped partners in the region "stay engaged". Rubio also said that there was "a very short window" in which a deal on Gaza could be made, Reuters and AFP reported. He added that Hamas had to "cease to exist as an armed group". In Israel, hostage families camped outside the Israeli prime minister's house overnight because they believe the current military strategy is putting their loved ones in danger. Some 48 hostages are believed to remain in Gaza with 20 believed to be alive. The escalation in bombardment on Gaza also comes after Netanyahu refused to rule out further strikes on Hamas leaders abroad despite international criticism of the attack on Qatar. Days earlier the White House said Trump had assured Qatar "that such a thing will not happen again on their soil" - an assertion that he repeated on Monday night. Qatar hosts a major US airbase and has played a key role in brokering diplomatic efforts to end the war in Gaza, serving as a mediator of indirect negotiations between Hamas and Israel. It has hosted the Hamas political bureau since 2012. EPA Palestinians look for survivors in the rubble of the Al-Ghafari residential tower after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike in Gaza City, 15 September 2025.
summary_src: Israel has dramatically escalated its bombardment of Gaza City, with Defense Minister Israel Katz declaring "Gaza is burning" and vowing a relentless campaign until its objectives are met.  Unconfirmed reports suggest a ground offensive has begun, aiming to occupy the entire city, while thousands flee towards areas also under attack.  Palestinian officials report a rising death toll and widespread injuries.  The intensified assault follows Secretary of State Marco Rubio's reaffirmation of unwavering US support for Israel during a visit to Jerusalem.  Amidst near-constant airstrikes and shelling, homes have been destroyed, leaving many trapped under rubble.  Israel has urged Gaza's residents to evacuate to southern Gaza, but many are unable or unwilling due to unsafe conditions and lack of resources.  An estimated 250,000 Palestinians have fled, but hundreds of thousands remain.  Meanwhile, hostage families in Israel protest the military strategy, fearing for the lives of the approximately 20 hostages still believed to be alive in Gaza.  Netanyahu's refusal to rule out further strikes on Hamas leaders abroad, despite international condemnation, further fuels the escalating conflict.  Despite Arab condemnation of Israel's recent attack on Qatar, Secretary Rubio emphasized the need for a negotiated settlement, highlighting a "very short window" for a deal contingent on Hamas's disarmament.  Qatar, a key mediator, remains a central player in potential negotiations.
summary_tgt: इज़राइल ने गाजा शहर पर अपने बमबारी अभियान को नाटकीय रूप से तेज कर दिया है, जिसमें रक्षा मंत्री इज़राइल काट्ज़ ने घोषणा की है कि "गाज़ा जल रहा है" और अपने उद्देश्यों के पूरा होने तक एक निरंतर अभियान की कसम खाई है।  अप्रमाणित रिपोर्टों से पता चलता है कि पूरे शहर पर कब्ज़ा करने के उद्देश्य से एक जमीनी हमला शुरू हो गया है, जबकि हज़ारों लोग उन इलाकों की ओर भाग रहे हैं जो पहले से ही हमले के अधीन हैं।  फ़िलिस्तीनी अधिकारियों ने बढ़ती हुई मौतों और व्यापक चोटों की सूचना दी है।  यह तीव्र हमला विदेश मंत्री मार्को रुबियो के यरूशलेम की यात्रा के दौरान इज़राइल के लिए अटूट अमेरिकी समर्थन की पुनर्पुष्टि के बाद हुआ है।  लगभग लगातार हवाई हमलों और गोलाबारी के बीच, घरों को नष्ट कर दिया गया है, जिससे कई लोग मलबे के नीचे फंसे हुए हैं।  इज़राइल ने गाजा के निवासियों से दक्षिणी गाजा में जाने का आग्रह किया है, लेकिन कई लोग असुरक्षित परिस्थितियों और संसाधनों की कमी के कारण ऐसा करने में असमर्थ या अनिच्छुक हैं।  लगभग 250,000 फ़िलिस्तीनी भाग गए हैं, लेकिन लाखों लोग अभी भी वहाँ हैं।  इस बीच, इज़राइल में बंधक परिवारों ने सैन्य रणनीति का विरोध किया है, गाजा में लगभग 20 बंधकों के जीवन के लिए जो अभी भी जीवित माने जा रहे हैं, चिंता व्यक्त की है।  अंतर्राष्ट्रीय निंदा के बावजूद, नेतन्याहू ने विदेशों में हमास नेताओं पर आगे के हमलों से इनकार करने से परहेज किया, जिससे बढ़ता हुआ संघर्ष और बढ़ गया है।  अरब देशों द्वारा कतर पर इज़राइल के हालिया हमले की निंदा के बावजूद, सचिव रुबियो ने एक बातचीत के समझौते की आवश्यकता पर जोर दिया, जिसमें हमास के निरस्त्रीकरण पर निर्भर एक "बहुत ही कम समय की खिड़की" को उजागर किया गया।  एक प्रमुख मध्यस्थ, कतर, संभावित वार्ताओं में एक केंद्रीय खिलाड़ी बना हुआ है।
meta_description: It came hours after US Secretary of State Rubio assured Israeli PM Netanyahu of unwavering US support.

title_src: Albertosaurus outsmarts prey to win the pack's respect
text_src: Rose, the Albertosaurus, knows she can't take down a giant alone, but by guiding her prey to the matriarch, she proves her worth and earns a seat at the table.
summary_src: Young Albertosaurus Rose, unable to hunt large prey solo, cleverly guides a victim to her experienced matriarch.  This strategic move demonstrates her hunting prowess and secures her place within the pack.
summary_tgt: युवा एल्बर्टोसॉरस रोज़, जो अकेले बड़े शिकार का शिकार करने में असमर्थ थी, चालाकी से एक शिकार को अपनी अनुभवी माता (या नेतृत्वकर्ता मादा) के पास ले जाती है।  इस रणनीतिक कदम से उसकी शिकार कौशल का प्रदर्शन होता है और वह अपने दल में अपनी जगह पक्की करती है।
meta_description: A young Albertosaurus knows she can't take down a giant alone but she can guide her prey to the matriarch.

title_src: The Japanese landscapes that inspired Studio Ghibli films
text_src: As Studio Ghibli turns 40, we visit the forests, springs and villages that inspired its most beloved films, and meet those preserving their magic. From moss-draped cedar forests to steamy bathhouses and suburban woodlands, the animated worlds of Studio Ghibli often feel fantastical yet familiar. Across 23 feature films, the Japanese studio's vividly drawn landscapes – where kurosuke (soot sprites) scuttle and giant cat-buses roam – have transported generations of viewers into realms where nature and fantasy blur. But many of these beloved settings weren't born from pure imagination. They were inspired by real places across Japan – some sacred, others endangered but all profoundly cherished. As Studio Ghibli celebrates its 40th anniversary this year, we're exploring the real-world places behind some of its most iconic films.
summary_src: Studio Ghibli celebrates its 40th anniversary this year.  The animation studio's fantastical worlds, seen in films like *My Neighbor Totoro* and *Spirited Away*, are deeply rooted in the real landscapes of Japan.  From moss-covered forests to traditional bathhouses, the films draw inspiration from specific locations, many of which are cherished and, in some cases, endangered. This anniversary offers a look at the real-world places that have fueled Ghibli's iconic imagery and imaginative storytelling for four decades.
summary_tgt: इस साल स्टूडियो घिबली अपनी 40वीं वर्षगाँठ मना रहा है।  *माई नेबर टोटोरोज* और *स्प्रिटेड अवे* जैसी फिल्मों में दिखाई देने वाली इस एनिमेशन स्टूडियो की काल्पनिक दुनियाएँ, जापान के वास्तविक परिदृश्यों में गहराई से निहित हैं।  काई से ढँके जंगलों से लेकर पारंपरिक स्नानगृहों तक,  फिल्में विशिष्ट स्थानों से प्रेरणा लेती हैं, जिनमें से कई को संजो कर रखा गया है और कुछ  खतरे में भी हैं। यह वर्षगाँठ वास्तविक दुनिया के उन स्थानों पर एक नज़र डालने का अवसर प्रदान करती है जिन्होंने चार दशकों से घिबली की प्रतिष्ठित कल्पना और रचनात्मक कहानी कहने को बढ़ावा दिया है।
meta_description: As Studio Ghibli turns 40, we visit the forests, springs and villages that inspired its most beloved films, and meet those preserving their magic.

title_src: Brain fog and four easy ways to help fix it
text_src: Struggling with brain fog? Here's how to fix it 1 day ago Share Save Yasmin Rufo BBC News Share Save BBC When life gets busy and stress levels rise, it's not uncommon to find yourself walking into a room and forgetting why you went there, losing your train of thought mid-sentence or struggling to stay focused on simple tasks. Especially after the weekend, it can be hard to get back into work or study mode. This mental cloudiness is often called brain fog and while it isn't a medical condition in itself, it refers to a collection of cognitive symptoms such as difficulty concentrating, forgetfulness, and mental slowness. Common causes of it can include menopause or perimenopause, and conditions such as long Covid and autoimmune conditions like lupus disease, but it can also strike when you've got too much on your mind at once. Medical doctor and Morning Live expert, Dr. Tharaka has these four tips and a special acronym to help cut through the haze. 1. Be kind to yourself Brain fog can happen to anyone and it's not a personal failing or a sign that you're not coping. Often, it's simply your brain's way of saying it's tired, stressed or overstretched. Remind yourself that brain fog is usually temporary and it's okay to slow down, delegate tasks or ask for help when you need it. If you are concerned then you should contact your GP. 2. Create routines Reduce decision fatigue by having a set rhythm to your days - a predictable structure can take pressure off your working memory. Knowing what's coming next stops your brain from constantly asking, "What am I doing today?" It's worth creating a morning and evening routine and even something as simple as laying out clothes or prepping breakfast ahead of time frees your mind from constant decision-making. 3. Take breaks Getty Images Taking some time between tasks can help reset your brain and focus It's easy to fill your diary with back-to-back commitments - meetings, social events, errands and daily tasks - without leaving any breathing room. But constantly jumping from one thing to the next can leave your brain no time to reset, making brain fog more likely. Try deliberately scheduling short breaks between activities, even just 5–10 minutes to stretch, get a drink, step outside or sit quietly. Think of these firebreaks like mental buffers: they give your mind a chance to process what you've just done, let go of lingering stress and prepare for what's next. 4. Use calendars and reminders Trying to hold every appointment, task and reminder in your head can quickly lead to mental clutter and forgetfulness. Let tech do the remembering for you - use calendars and reminders to free up mental space. Schedule recurring tasks so they happen automatically - for example, block out lunch in your diary each day or set weekly reminders for bills and chores. This means you're not constantly thinking, "What do I need to remember next?" Swans Getty Images Staying hydrated and eating whole foods can help clear brain fog
summary_src: Brain fog, characterized by difficulty concentrating, forgetfulness, and mental slowness, affects many.  While not a medical condition itself, it's often linked to stress, overwork, and hormonal changes like menopause.  Dr. Tharaka, a medical expert, offers advice to combat brain fog:  Establish daily routines to reduce decision fatigue; schedule short breaks between tasks to allow mental reset; utilize calendars and reminders to minimize mental clutter; and prioritize hydration and a healthy diet.  While brain fog is often temporary, persistent concerns should prompt consultation with a GP.
summary_tgt: दिमागी धुंधलापन, जिसमें ध्यान केंद्रित करने में कठिनाई, भूलने की बीमारी और मानसिक सुस्ती शामिल है, कई लोगों को प्रभावित करता है। हालांकि यह अपने आप में कोई चिकित्सीय स्थिति नहीं है, यह अक्सर तनाव, अधिक काम और हार्मोनल परिवर्तन जैसे रजोनिवृत्ति से जुड़ा होता है।  डॉ. थरका, एक चिकित्सा विशेषज्ञ, दिमागी धुंधलापन से निपटने के लिए सलाह देते हैं: निर्णय थकान को कम करने के लिए दैनिक दिनचर्या स्थापित करें; मानसिक पुनर्निर्माण की अनुमति देने के लिए कार्यों के बीच छोटे ब्रेक निर्धारित करें; मानसिक अव्यवस्था को कम करने के लिए कैलेंडर और रिमाइंडर का उपयोग करें; और हाइड्रेशन और स्वस्थ आहार को प्राथमिकता दें। जबकि दिमागी धुंधलापन अक्सर अस्थायी होता है, लगातार चिंताएँ सामान्य चिकित्सक से परामर्श करने के लिए प्रेरित करनी चाहिए।
meta_description: It's common to become forgetful or mentally sluggish but there are easy ways to cut through the haze.

title_src: Israel escalates bombardment as defence minister says 'Gaza is burning' - follow latest
text_src: Israeli forces committed sexual violence, UN genocide report finds Tom Bennett Reporting from Jerusalem Image source, Getty Images Image caption, The report highlights an Israeli attack against Gaza's largest fertility clinic This new report, commissioned by the UN's Human Rights Council, says Israel is committing genocide in Gaza, in “the strongest and most authoritative UN finding to date." Among its findings are that Israeli security forces perpetrated “sexual and gender-based violence” against Palestinians in Gaza. It says this includes “rape, sexualised torture and other forms of sexual violence” which cause “extreme physical and psychological harm to victims”. It says this violence has been used as “part of a pattern of collective punishment to fracture, humiliate and subjugate the Palestinian population in its entirety.” The commission also finds that Israeli forces have imposed measures intended to prevent births - pointing to an attack against Gaza’s largest fertility clinic, which reportedly destroyed around 4,000 embryos and 1,000 sperm samples and unfertilised eggs.
summary_src: A UN Human Rights Council report has accused Israel of committing genocide in Gaza, citing evidence of widespread human rights abuses including sexual violence.  The report, described as the strongest and most authoritative UN finding to date, details Israeli security forces perpetrating rape, sexualized torture, and other forms of sexual violence against Palestinians.  The commission also alleges that Israel is employing measures to prevent births, pointing to the destruction of thousands of embryos and sperm samples at Gaza's largest fertility clinic.
summary_tgt: संयुक्त राष्ट्र मानवाधिकार परिषद की एक रिपोर्ट में इज़राइल पर गाजा में नरसंहार करने का आरोप लगाया गया है, जिसमें यौन हिंसा सहित व्यापक मानवाधिकारों के उल्लंघन के सबूतों का हवाला दिया गया है।  रिपोर्ट, जिसे अब तक का सबसे मज़बूत और सबसे अधिक आधिकारिक संयुक्त राष्ट्र निष्कर्ष बताया जा रहा है, में इज़राइली सुरक्षा बलों द्वारा फिलिस्तीनियों के साथ बलात्कार, यौन उत्पीड़न और यौन हिंसा के अन्य रूपों को अंजाम देने का विवरण दिया गया है। आयोग ने यह भी आरोप लगाया है कि इज़राइल जन्मों को रोकने के उपाय कर रहा है, और गाजा के सबसे बड़े प्रजनन क्लीनिक में हज़ारों भ्रूणों और शुक्राणु के नमूनों के विनाश की ओर इशारा किया है।

title_src: Charlie Kirk suspect linked to crime scene by DNA, says FBI chief
text_src: Charlie Kirk suspect linked to crime scene by DNA, says FBI chief 13 hours ago Share Save Zahra Fatima BBC News Share Save Reuters/Cheney Orr DNA on a towel wrapped around the suspected gun used to kill Charlie Kirk has been matched to the suspect in custody, the director of the FBI said on Monday. Tyler Robinson, 22, was arrested over the death of the right-wing influencer at an event at Utah Valley University on Wednesday. A bolt-action rifle was recovered near the shooting, and a screwdriver was found on the roof from where the fatal shot was fired. "I can report today that the DNA hits from the towel that was wrapped around the firearm and the DNA on the screwdriver are positively processed for the suspect in custody," Kash Patel told Fox and Friends. A formal charge is expected this week. A motive has yet to be determined. Watch: Charlie Kirk remembered at Kennedy Center vigil The FBI director - who is expected to face questions at a hearing in Congress on Tuesday - also mentioned a note that was discovered at the suspect's home, which vowed to "take out" Kirk. It's "basically saying... 'I have the opportunity to take out Charlie Kirk', and I'm going to take it that note was written before the shooting," said Patel. He added, "even though it has been destroyed, we have found forensic evidence of the note". Investigators are also looking at social media accounts used by Mr Robinson, according to the BBC's US news partner CBS, and any signs that anyone may have known about or encouraged the shooting beforehand. According to a Utah County Sheriff inmate booking sheet obtained by the BBC, Mr Robinson is accused of aggravated murder, obstruction of justice, and felony discharge of a firearm. The breakthrough comes after Utah Governor Spencer Cox said on Sunday that Mr Robinson - who had been persuaded to surrender by his father - had been refusing to co-operate with investigators and had not confessed to carrying out the shooting. Cox added that Mr Robinson's roommate and partner had been helping with the investigation. Watch: JD Vance hosts Charlie Kirk’s daily talk radio show
summary_src: FBI Director Kash Patel announced today that DNA evidence from a towel wrapped around the murder weapon used to kill right-wing influencer Charlie Kirk links 22-year-old Tyler Robinson, currently in custody, to the crime.  Robinson, facing charges of aggravated murder, obstruction of justice, and felony discharge of a firearm,  was arrested following Wednesday's shooting at Utah Valley University.  A bolt-action rifle and a screwdriver, also linked to Robinson via DNA, were recovered at the scene.  A note found at a deceased woman's home, who was in a relationship with Robinson, expressed intent to kill Kirk.  While a motive remains unclear, authorities are investigating Robinson's social media activity and exploring potential accomplices.  Robinson, who reportedly refused to cooperate with investigators, faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted.  Patel will address Congress on Tuesday.
summary_tgt: एफबीआई निदेशक काश पटेल ने आज घोषणा की कि दक्षिणपंथी प्रभावशाली व्यक्ति चार्ली किर्क की हत्या में प्रयुक्त हथियार के चारों ओर लिपटे एक तौलिये से मिले डीएनए साक्ष्य, वर्तमान में हिरासत में मौजूद 22 वर्षीय टायलर रॉबिन्सन को इस अपराध से जोड़ते हैं।  रॉबिन्सन पर aggravated murder (जघन्य हत्या), न्याय में बाधा डालने और आग्नेयास्त्र का अवैध उपयोग जैसे आरोप हैं, बुधवार को यूटा वैली विश्वविद्यालय में हुई गोलीबारी के बाद उसे गिरफ्तार किया गया था। घटनास्थल से एक बोल्ट-एक्शन राइफल और एक स्क्रूड्राइवर भी बरामद हुए हैं, जिनका डीएनए से रॉबिन्सन से संबंध पाया गया है। एक महिला के घर से एक सुसाइड नोट मिला है, जिसके साथ रॉबिन्सन का संबंध था, और उसमें किर्क को मारने की मंशा व्यक्त की गई है। जबकि मकसद अभी स्पष्ट नहीं है, अधिकारी रॉबिन्सन की सोशल मीडिया गतिविधि की जांच कर रहे हैं और संभावित सहयोगियों की तलाश कर रहे हैं। रॉबिन्सन ने कथित तौर पर जांचकर्ताओं के साथ सहयोग करने से इनकार कर दिया है, अगर दोषी पाया जाता है तो उसे 10 साल तक की जेल हो सकती है। पटेल मंगलवार को कांग्रेस को संबोधित करेंगे।
meta_description: Kash Patel says Tyler Robinson's DNA was found on towel wrapping suspected murder weapon.

title_src: Rubbish and dull. Pointless': How Lord of the Flies was rescued from the reject pile
text_src: William Golding's novel Lord of the Flies was first published on 17 September 1954, and is now recognised as a classic. In History looks at how Golding's story of English schoolboys and their descent into barbarism narrowly escaped being thrown in the bin. "Write what you know" is advice often given to aspiring authors, and Lord of the Flies is a spectacular example of how clichés can still contain essential truths. A teacher at a boys' school who had witnessed first-hand the inhumanity of World War Two, William Golding condensed this knowledge and experience into his debut novel, a deceptively simple tale of shipwrecked boys reverting to savagery on a desert island. Its subversion of a familiar plot went on to resonate with generations of readers, and serve as a grim warning that the evils of Nazi Germany could be repeated anywhere. Golding was about to turn 43 when Lord of the Flies was first published. His big idea was a sinister 20th-Century reimagining of The Coral Island, RM Ballantyne's 1857 tale of derring-do in which a group of shipwrecked British schoolboys civilise a desert island, making it a playground for fun and games. Much of his original manuscript was handwritten on exercise books during school time. He even worked on the novel during lessons, while his pupils were occupied with their textbooks. A few of them were tasked with counting the number of words he'd written per page. WATCH: 'What matters to me is that there shall be a beginning, a middle and an end'. In 1953, Golding sent his novel to nine publishers, all of whom rejected it. Undaunted, he offered the manuscript to Faber and Faber, one of the most prestigious London firms. It was picked up by Charles Monteith, a junior editor who had only worked at the publishing house for a few months. The signs were not promising.
summary_src: William Golding's seminal novel, *Lord of the Flies*, narrowly avoided oblivion before its publication on September 17, 1954.  Initially rejected by nine publishers, the manuscript, largely written during school hours while Golding taught, was eventually accepted by Faber and Faber.  This dark reimagining of R.M. Ballantyne's *The Coral Island* depicts the descent into savagery of British schoolboys stranded on a desert island, reflecting Golding's wartime experiences and serving as a chilling warning against the potential for barbarism.  Despite its initial struggles, *Lord of the Flies* became a critical and commercial success, establishing Golding's legacy as a major literary figure.  The novel remains a celebrated classic, continuing to resonate with readers decades after its publication.
summary_tgt: विलियम गोल्डिंग का महत्वपूर्ण उपन्यास, "लॉर्ड ऑफ़ द फ्लाइज़", 17 सितंबर, 1954 को प्रकाशित होने से पहले ही विस्मृति के कगार पर था।  शुरुआत में नौ प्रकाशकों ने इसे अस्वीकार कर दिया था।  यह पांडुलिपि, जिसे गोल्डिंग ने मुख्यतः स्कूल के समय में पढ़ाने के दौरान लिखा था, अंततः फैबर एंड फैबर ने स्वीकार किया। आर.एम. बैलेंटाइन के "द कोरल आइलैंड" का यह गहरा पुनर्कथन, एक निर्जन द्वीप पर फंसे ब्रिटिश स्कूली बच्चों के बर्बरता में गिरने का चित्रण करता है, जो गोल्डिंग के युद्धकालीन अनुभवों को दर्शाता है और बर्बरता की संभावना के प्रति एक भयावह चेतावनी के रूप में कार्य करता है।  अपनी प्रारंभिक संघर्षों के बावजूद, "लॉर्ड ऑफ़ द फ्लाइज़" एक आलोचनात्मक और व्यावसायिक सफलता बन गया, जिससे गोल्डिंग की एक प्रमुख साहित्यिक हस्ती के रूप में विरासत स्थापित हुई।  यह उपन्यास एक प्रसिद्ध क्लासिक बना हुआ है, जो अपने प्रकाशन के दशकों बाद भी पाठकों के साथ प्रतिध्वनित होता रहता है।
meta_description: William Golding's novel Lord of the Flies was first published on 17 September 1954, and is now recognised as a classic.

title_src: Ukrainian civilian freed in prisoner swap tells of 'constant cruelty'
text_src: Beaten and held in Russia for three years - but never charged with a crime 3 hours ago Share Save Sarah Rainsford Southern and eastern Europe correspondent, Kyiv region Share Save Francesco Tosto/BBC Dmytro Khyliuk spent three and a half years in Russian captivity Since his release from a Russian prison, Dmytro Khyliuk has barely been off the phone. The Ukrainian journalist was detained by Russian forces in the first days of their full-scale invasion. Three and a half years later he's been released in a prisoner swap, one of eight civilians freed in a surprise move. While Russia and Ukraine have swapped military prisoners of war before, it is very rare for Russia to release Ukrainian civilians. Dmytro has been catching up frantically on all he's missed. But he's also phoning the families of every Ukrainian he met in captivity: he memorised all their names and each detail. He knows that for some, his call may be the first confirmation that their relative is alive. The welcome home There were celebrations here last month when Dmytro was returned from Russia in a group of 146 Ukrainians. A crowd came out waving blue and yellow national flags, cheering as the buses carrying the freed men passed hooting their horns. Most on board were soldiers with sunken cheeks, emaciated after their years behind bars. Officials won't say exactly how they got the eight Ukrainian civilians back in the same exchange, only that it involved sending back in return "people Russia was interested in". One source said those included residents of the Kursk region in Russia, evacuated when Ukrainian forces launched their 2024 incursion. The group's exact status after that is unclear. Ombudsman's Office Ukrainian officials released photos of the prisoners who finally returned home last month - including Dmytro Stepping off the bus to a cheering crowd, Dmytro's first phone call was to tell his mother he was free. Both his parents are elderly and unwell and his greatest fear had been never seeing them again. "The hardest was not knowing when you'll be allowed back. You could be freed the next day or stay prisoner for 10 years. Nobody knows how long it's for." Constant cruelty We met Dmytro shortly after his release as he recuperated at a Kyiv hospital. The details he shared of his captivity are chilling. "They grabbed us and literally dragged us to the prison and on the way they beat us with rubber batons shouting things like, 'How many people have you killed?'" he said, describing his transfer to Russia. He was held in multiple facilities and his account chimes with many others we've heard over the years. "Sometimes they'd let the guard dog off its leash so that it could bite us. The cruelty was really shocking and it was constant." He tells me he was bitten and left bleeding. "I was so stressed I only felt the pain 20 minutes later." The journalist was never charged with any crime. Francesco Tosto/BBC Dmytro managed to send one note while he was in Russian captivity, reading: "I'm alive, I'm well. Everything's ok" Physically the first year was the hardest. "We were starving. We were given very little food for a long time," he remembers. He lost more than 20kg in the first few months, causing him dizzy spells. But the soldiers he was held with were treated far worse. "They would call them for interrogation, and they were beaten and tortured with electric shock," Dmytro remembers. He heard their pain and saw the bruises. His parents' fear The journalist's family home is a world away from all that, in the pretty village of Kozarovychi just outside Kyiv. It feels peaceful, apart from the air raids, with gardens full of poultry, blackberry bushes and fruit trees. But the back wall of Dmytro's house still has chunks torn out of it by shrapnel and the lawn was only just repaired where Russian troops had parked a tank. In 2022, right at the start of their full-scale invasion when the Russians were advancing on Kyiv, they took over the village. A few days later, as Dmytro and his father, Vasyl, tried to check the damage to their home, they were detained. Francesco Tosto/BBC Halyna (left) and Vasyl (right) are Dmytro's parents - Vasyl was also briefly taken prisoner by the Russians Russian troops forced both men to the ground, bound and blindfolded them, and marched them into captivity. The pair now know they were held in a basement beneath the local warehouses where the Russians had made their base. The men were moved several times as the number of civilian detainees increased. Vasyl was eventually set free but for many months he feared the worst for his son. "I didn't know where he'd been taken and I was scared," the pensioner tells me. "There were gunshots at night. One man was taken outside, then a shot was fired. He didn't come back. I still don't know the fate of all the people who were there." Then he and his wife got a tiny scrap of paper from a Russian prison. "I'm alive, I'm well. Everything's ok," Dmytro wrote to them both, in Ukrainian. They would receive just one more note in his entire time in captivity. Ukraine's missing Other families have had no news at all. Across Ukraine, officials say more than 16,000 civilians are currently missing. So far, they've only located a fraction of them in Russian prisons. Moscow doesn't publish lists because detaining civilians with no cause is illegal. But that makes getting them back extremely complicated. Forty-three men are still being held from the area around Dmytro's village alone. They include Volodymyr Loburets, detained at the same time, held in the same basements and then moved to Russia. He now has a new grandson he's never met and a family who miss him badly. "It's hard. It's really hard. We smile, yes, and thank goodness, I have a new grandson," Volodymyr's wife Vera says, as baby Yaroslav gurgles beside her on a play mat. "But I had a husband – and now I don't." "The government says it won't swap our relatives for Russian soldiers, so we are left waiting for the fourth year running until there is some way to get them back." Francesco Tosto/BBC Vera's husband Volodymyr remains in Russian captivity Vera is deeply frustrated. But so is Ukraine's human rights ombudsman. Dmytro Lubinets describes dealing with Russia as like playing chess: you stick to all the rules, only for your opponent to stand up, pull on boxing gloves and punch you. The problem is, Ukraine can't hit back. It has no pool of Russian civilian prisoners because it's against the rules of war under the Geneva Convention. Sending Russian soldiers back in return for Ukrainian civilians would be a disaster. "The very next day Russia would take thousands of civilians hostage in occupied areas, just to swap for its soldiers," the ombudsman points out. "So Russia is capturing our civilians and there is no legal mechanism to return them." There has been one trade involving Ukrainian citizens detained and sentenced here for collaborating with the enemy: a group – said to be volunteers – was swapped for Ukrainian civilians held in Russia. It's not clear whether that has been repeated. Lasting damage
summary_src: Ukrainian journalist Dmytro Khyliuk, detained in Mariupol during the initial days of the 2022 Russian invasion, was released after three and a half years in captivity as part of a prisoner exchange involving the US.  His release is highly unusual, as Russia rarely releases Ukrainian civilians.  While in captivity, Khyliuk endured beatings, starvation, and was held in multiple facilities, never facing charges. He diligently memorized details of fellow captives' stories, contacting their families upon his release to share news of their survival.  The exchange involved releasing "people Russia was interested in," possibly residents of the Kursk region evacuated from Ukrainian incursions.  Khyliuk's release was celebrated in Ukraine, but the fate of other Ukrainian civilians held in Russia remains uncertain, highlighting the complexities and ethical dilemmas of prisoner swaps in a war zone.  The Ukrainian ombudsman describes negotiations with Russia as unfairly one-sided, lacking legal mechanisms to secure the return of Ukrainian civilians held without charges.  Thousands of Ukrainian civilians remain missing.
summary_tgt: 2022 में रूसी आक्रमण के शुरुआती दिनों में मारियुपोल में हिरासत में लिए गए यूक्रेनी पत्रकार दिमित्री खिल्युक को साढ़े तीन साल की कैद के बाद अमेरिका की भागीदारी वाले कैदी आदान-प्रदान के माध्यम से रिहा कर दिया गया है।  रूस द्वारा शायद ही कभी यूक्रेनी नागरिकों को रिहा किया जाता है, इसलिए उनकी रिहाई बेहद असामान्य है।  कैद के दौरान, खिल्युक को पिटाई, भुखमरी का सामना करना पड़ा और उन्हें कई सुविधाओं में रखा गया, बिना किसी आरोप के। उन्होंने साथी कैदियों की कहानियों का बारीकी से ध्यान रखा और रिहाई के बाद उनके परिवारों से उनके जीवित होने की खबर साझा की।  इस आदान-प्रदान में "वे लोग शामिल थे जिनमें रूस की रुचि थी," संभवतः यूक्रेनी हमलों से निकाले गए कुर्स्क क्षेत्र के निवासी।  यूक्रेन में खिल्युक की रिहाई का जश्न मनाया गया, लेकिन रूस में रखे गए अन्य यूक्रेनी नागरिकों का भाग्य अनिश्चित बना हुआ है, जो युद्ध क्षेत्र में कैदी आदान-प्रदान की जटिलताओं और नैतिक दुविधाओं को उजागर करता है।  यूक्रेनी लोकपाल ने रूस के साथ बातचीत को एकतरफा बताया है, जिसमें बिना किसी आरोप के रखे गए यूक्रेनी नागरिकों की वापसी सुनिश्चित करने के लिए कानूनी तंत्र का अभाव है।  हजारों यूक्रेनी नागरिक अभी भी लापता हैं।
meta_description: Russia imprisoned Dmytro shortly after its invasion of Ukraine in 2022. He was freed last month.

title_src: Nigeria's Hilda Baci breaks world record for largest jollof rice dish
text_src: Nigerian chef breaks world record for largest jollof rice dish Watch: Aerial footage shows huge pot of jollof rice during world record attempt Ms Baci celebrated the triumph by thanking her team and supporters: "This moment isn't just mine... it belongs to all of us." After nine hours of cooking, the effort was almost thrown into jeopardy after the giant pot used to make the dish broke as it was being hoisted onto a crane to be weighed - thankfully, none of the rice was spilled. Guinness World Records (GWR) confirmed the achievement on social media, saying Ms Baci's concoction of the popular West African dish weighed in at a staggering 8,780kg. Nigerian chef Hilda Baci has broken the world record for cooking the largest ever pot of jollof rice in Lagos last week. Despite the massive pot buckling twice during its weigh-in, a member of Baci's team told the BBC last week they were collecting evidence from different cameras to send to GWR so it could be officially recognised. Baci paid tribute to the "tireless team" that made the achievement possible and shared a video of her reacting to the news on social media. "This Guinness World Record was built on unity, love, and collective strength," she wrote. "We made history together, for Nigeria, for Africa, and for everyone who believes in the power of food to bring us closer this win is yours too." Baci's recipe for the crowning jollof dish included 4,000kg of rice, 500 cartons of tomato paste, 600kg of onions and 168kg of goat meat - all poured into a custom-made pot that can hold 23,000 litres. Last week, thousands of people had gathered to watch Baci's latest world record bid - in 2023 she held the title for the longest cooking marathon at nearly four days. Their support was well rewarded as the mammoth dish later divided into individual portions and distributed to the huge crowd and passersby. The chef previously told BBC Pidgin that it took her a year to plan how she would tackle the mammoth challenge. "We [Nigerians] are the giant of Africa, and jollof is a food that everybody knows Africans for," she said. "It would make sense if we had the biggest pot of jollof rice, it would be nice for the country." She was assisted by 10 other chefs in red uniforms wielding long wooden spoons to stir the food. Manufacturing the giant steel vessel to hold her dish took a team of 300 people two months to make but one of its legs gave way at the crucial time. Jollof rice is a staple in several West African countries, featuring rice simmered in a tomato sauce, often paired with meat or seafood. Baci won a competition for her version of jollof rice in 2021, and then became a national sensation in 2023 when she claimed the world cooking marathon record - an exhausting 93 hours and 11 minutes. However, she was later surpassed by Irish chef Alan Fisher. The current record-holder is Evette Quoibia from Australia, with 140 hours and 11 minutes, according to GWR.
summary_src: Nigerian chef Hilda Baci has set a new Guinness World Record for the largest jollof rice dish, weighing in at a staggering 8,780kg.  The feat, achieved after nine hours of cooking, involved a massive pot that buckled twice during the weighing process, though the rice remained intact.  Baci, who previously held the record for the longest cooking marathon,  credited her "tireless team" and expressed that the record "belongs to all of us."  The enormous dish, made with 4,000kg of rice, 500 cartons of tomato paste, and other ingredients, was later distributed to the watching crowd.  The creation of the giant cooking vessel itself took a team of 300 two months to complete.  Baci's achievement celebrates jollof rice, a staple across West Africa, and highlights Nigerian culinary prowess.
summary_tgt: नाइजीरियाई शेफ हिल्डा बासी ने 8,780 किलोग्राम वज़न के विशाल जोल्लोफ राइस डिश के साथ गिनीज़ वर्ल्ड रिकॉर्ड बना दिया है।  नौ घंटे की लगातार खाना पकाने के बाद हासिल की गई इस उपलब्धि में एक विशाल बर्तन का इस्तेमाल किया गया, जो तौलने की प्रक्रिया के दौरान दो बार मुड़ गया, फिर भी चावल बरकरार रहे।  पहले सबसे लंबे समय तक खाना पकाने के मैराथन का रिकॉर्ड रखने वाली बासी ने अपनी "अथक टीम" को श्रेय दिया और कहा कि यह रिकॉर्ड "हम सभी का है"।  4,000 किलोग्राम चावल, 500 कार्टन टमाटर पेस्ट और अन्य सामग्रियों से बने इस विशाल व्यंजन को बाद में मौजूद भीड़ में बांटा गया।  इस विशालकाय खाना पकाने के बर्तन को बनाने में ही 300 लोगों की एक टीम को दो महीने लगे।  बासी की उपलब्धि पश्चिम अफ्रीका में मुख्य भोजन जोल्लोफ राइस का जश्न मनाती है और नाइजीरियाई पाक कला कौशल को उजागर करती है।
meta_description: Guinness World Records has confirmed the achievement, saying the rice weighed in at a staggering 8,780kg.

title_src: The shortcut to close bonds? Asking meaningful questions
text_src: The right questions can help us connect with strangers – and create closer bonds between parents and children. In 2024, a team of psychologists at the University of Amsterdam in the Netherlands tested a deceptively simple idea: could being asked 14 specially designed questions by their parents help children feel more loved? The experiment was based on some well-evidenced psychological insights: as the researchers pointed out in their paper, feeling loved by their parents is known to be "critical for children's health and well-being." Finding ways to nurture that feeling could therefore potentially benefit families in many ways. Previous experiments with adults by other researchers had suggested that asking the right questions can help people feel closer to each other. Known as the "fast-friends procedure", this process gained global attention far beyond research departments some years ago after a journalist tested the questions on a romantic date. In its classic format, the fast-friends procedure involves pairs of adults asking each other profound, thought-provoking, personal questions such as: "If a crystal ball could tell you the truth about yourself, your life, the future or anything else, what would you want to know?" This encourages the participants to reveal more about their innermost feelings, which can foster a sense of connection. In adults, the procedure has been successfully replicated in many different contexts. But would it work for the bond between parents and children?
summary_src: A University of Amsterdam study explored whether asking children 14 specific questions could strengthen their bond with parents.  Building on research showing that open-ended questions foster connection (the "fast-friends procedure," popularized after a journalist used it on a date), researchers investigated if this approach could improve children's feelings of parental love.  The study hypothesized that increased feelings of parental love are crucial for children's well-being. While previous research focused on adult relationships, this study examined the impact on parent-child dynamics, suggesting a potential new method for strengthening family bonds.
summary_tgt: ऐम्स्टर्डम विश्वविद्यालय के एक अध्ययन ने यह पता लगाने का प्रयास किया है कि क्या बच्चों से 14 विशिष्ट प्रश्न पूछने से माता-पिता के साथ उनके बंधन को मजबूत किया जा सकता है।  खुले अंत वाले प्रश्नों से जुड़ाव को बढ़ावा देने के शोध (जिसे "फास्ट-फ्रेंड्स प्रक्रिया" के रूप में जाना जाता है, जो एक पत्रकार द्वारा डेट पर इस्तेमाल किए जाने के बाद लोकप्रिय हुई) पर आधारित होकर, शोधकर्ताओं ने जांच की कि क्या यह तरीका बच्चों में माता-पिता के प्रेम की भावना को बेहतर बना सकता है। अध्ययन में यह परिकल्पना की गई थी कि माता-पिता के प्रेम की बढ़ी हुई भावना बच्चों के कल्याण के लिए अत्यंत महत्वपूर्ण है। जबकि पिछले शोध में वयस्कों के रिश्तों पर ध्यान केंद्रित किया गया था, इस अध्ययन ने माता-पिता और बच्चे के बीच के संबंधों पर इसके प्रभाव की जांच की, जिससे पारिवारिक बंधनों को मजबूत करने के एक संभावित नए तरीके का सुझाव मिलता है।
meta_description: The right questions can help us connect with strangers – and create closer bonds between parents and children.
