title_src: Protect Arctic from 'dangerous' climate engineering, scientists warn
text_src: Protect Arctic from 'dangerous' climate engineering, scientists warn 9 September 2025 Share Save Mark Poynting Climate and science reporter, BBC News Share Save Getty Images Plans to fight climate change by manipulating the Arctic and Antarctic environment are dangerous, unlikely to work and could distract from the need to ditch fossil fuels, dozens of polar scientists have warned. These polar "geoengineering" techniques aim to cool the planet in unconventional ways, such as artificially thickening sea-ice or releasing tiny, reflective particles into the atmosphere. They have gained attention as potential future tools to combat global warming, alongside cutting carbon emissions. But more than 40 researchers say they could bring "severe environmental damage" and urged countries to simply focus on reaching net zero, the only established way to limit global warming. Geoengineering - deliberately intervening in the Earth's climate system to counter the impacts of global warming - is one of the most controversial areas of climate research. Some types are widely accepted - removing planet-warming carbon dioxide from the atmosphere via planting trees or using machines, for example, are recognised parts of net zero efforts. Net zero means balancing the amount of planet-warming "greenhouse" gases produced by human activities with the amount being actively removed from the atmosphere. But some more radical geoengineering ideas, like reflecting sunlight "are dealing with the symptoms of climate change rather than the causes," said lead author Martin Siegert, professor of geosciences at the University of Exeter. For supporters, it is worth exploring techniques which could help rein in rapidly rising temperatures, which are already bringing severe impacts for people and ecosystems around the world. But for opponents, the risks are simply too great – particularly for the fragile polar regions, about which much remains unknown. The scientists behind the new assessment, published in the journal Frontiers in Science, reviewed the evidence for five of the most widely discussed polar geoengineering ideas. All fail to meet basic criteria for their feasibility and potential environmental risks, they say. One such suggestion is releasing tiny, reflective particles called aerosols high into the atmosphere to cool the planet. This often attracts attention among online conspiracy theorists, who falsely claim that condensation trails in the sky – water vapour created from aircraft jet engines – is evidence of sinister large-scale geoengineering today. But many scientists have more legitimate concerns, including disruption to weather patterns around the world. With those potential knock-on effects, that also raises the question of who decides to use it – especially in the Arctic and Antarctic, where governance is not straightforward. If a country were to deploy geoengineering against the wishes of others, it could "increase geopolitical tensions in polar regions", according to Dr Valerie Masson-Delmotte, senior scientist at the Université Paris Saclay in France. Another fear is that while some of the ideas may be theoretically possible, the enormous costs and time to scale-up mean they are extremely unlikely to make a difference, according to the review. One idea BBC News recently looked at was a plan to pump seawater over the surface of Arctic sea-ice in winter to thicken it, giving the ice a better chance to survive the summer. But to cover 10% of the Arctic could require about 10 million seawater pumps, one estimate suggests. A more fundamental concern is that these types of projects could create the illusion of an alternative to cutting humanity's emissions of planet-warming gases. "If they are promoted… then they are a distraction because to some people they will be a solution to the climate crisis that doesn't require decarbonising," said Prof Siegert. "Of course that would not be true and that's why we think they can be potentially damaging." BBC/Jemma Cox One suggestion to save Thwaites Glacier, one of the most vulnerable Antarctic glaciers, is to install a giant sea "curtain" to stop warm water melting it more quickly - but the new study says this would be extremely costly and unlikely to work Even supporters of geoengineering research agree that it is, at best, a supplement to net zero, not a substitution. "The need for emissions reductions comes first… almost anything we do is futile without it," according to Dr Shaun Fitzgerald, director of the University of Cambridge's Centre for Climate Repair, which has been involved in some of the projects highlighted. The assessment raises "very valid concerns" about some of the ideas, but they need to be balanced against the risks from "the perilous state of the climate," he argued. Like many other supporters of geoengineering research, Dr Fitzgerald does not support deploying it on a large scale yet, and acknowledged that further investigation might indeed find that the ideas are "bonkers". But he argued that more research would allow society to make "more informed decisions" about whether they could help or hinder in the fight against climate change. A UK government-backed agency recently announced nearly £60m of funding for such research, though the government says it has no plans to deploy them. But the authors of the new assessment view these projects as so unrealistic that efforts would be better directed towards decarbonisation and polar research. "There are some basic home truths that don't need an awful lot of research to come to a conclusion that they're not really viable," argued Prof Siegert. A UK government spokesperson said: "Our priority is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from human activities and to adapt to the unavoidable impacts of climate change."
summary_src: Scientists warn against Arctic geoengineering, urging focus on emissions reduction.  A new study published in *Frontiers in Science* concludes that proposed geoengineering techniques to combat climate change in the Arctic and Antarctic are dangerous, impractical, and could cause severe environmental damage.  The researchers reviewed five widely discussed methods, including atmospheric aerosol release and artificial sea-ice thickening, finding them all infeasible and risky.  They argue that these approaches distract from the crucial need for global decarbonization,  potentially creating a false sense of security and hindering genuine emissions reduction efforts. While some researchers advocate further investigation into geoengineering, the study's authors contend that resources would be better spent on achieving net-zero emissions and furthering polar research. The UK government, while funding related research, maintains its focus remains on emissions reduction and climate adaptation.
summary_tgt: वैज्ञानिकों ने आर्कटिक जियोइंजीनियरिंग के ख़िलाफ़ चेतावनी जारी करते हुए उत्सर्जन में कमी पर ध्यान केंद्रित करने का आग्रह किया है।  *फ्रंटियर्स इन साइंस* में प्रकाशित एक नए अध्ययन में निष्कर्ष निकाला गया है कि आर्कटिक और अंटार्कटिका में जलवायु परिवर्तन का मुकाबला करने के लिए प्रस्तावित जियोइंजीनियरिंग तकनीकें खतरनाक, अव्यावहारिक और गंभीर पर्यावरणीय क्षति का कारण बन सकती हैं। शोधकर्ताओं ने पाँच व्यापक रूप से चर्चित तरीकों की समीक्षा की, जिसमें वायुमंडलीय एरोसोल रिलीज और कृत्रिम समुद्री बर्फ का मोटा होना शामिल है, और पाया कि ये सभी अव्यवहारिक और जोखिम भरे हैं। उनका तर्क है कि ये तरीके वैश्विक कार्बन उत्सर्जन में कमी की महत्वपूर्ण आवश्यकता से ध्यान भंग करते हैं, संभावित रूप से सुरक्षा की झूठी भावना पैदा करते हैं और वास्तविक उत्सर्जन में कमी के प्रयासों में बाधा डालते हैं। जबकि कुछ शोधकर्ता जियोइंजीनियरिंग में आगे के अनुसंधान की वकालत करते हैं, अध्ययन के लेखकों का तर्क है कि संसाधनों का बेहतर उपयोग शुद्ध-शून्य उत्सर्जन प्राप्त करने और ध्रुवीय अनुसंधान को आगे बढ़ाने में किया जाना चाहिए। ब्रिटेन सरकार, जबकि संबंधित अनुसंधान को धन मुहैया करा रही है,  का कहना है कि उनका ध्यान उत्सर्जन में कमी और जलवायु अनुकूलन पर बना हुआ है।
meta_description: Controversial approaches to cooling the planet are unlikely to work, according to dozens of polar scientists.

title_src: Peatlands: Northern Ireland's first protection strategy launched
text_src: NI's first peatlands protection strategy launched 8 hours ago Share Save Louise Cullen Agriculture and environment correspondent, BBC News NI Share Save BBC The peatlands protection strategy was launched on Divis Mountain in the Belfast Hills The long-awaited, first-ever strategy to protect Northern Ireland's peatlands has been launched. It seeks to protect and restore all semi-natural peatlands in Northern Ireland to functioning ecosystems by 2040, through a series of 26 actions to meet five objectives. It includes a consultation on restricting sales of peat and peat products, a wildfire strategy, and the creation of a register of peatlands to help identify those sites most immediately in need of support. But it highlights that "significant financial resources" will be needed to meet the aims. Speaking during the launch of the strategy on Divis Mountain, the Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs Minister Andrew Muir said peatland restoration was a "win-win" for Northern Ireland. "This could make a significant difference to our nature, to water quality, but also our goals in terms of decarbonisation. "This is a game-changer," he said. Minister Andrew Muir said the peatland strategy was a "game-changer" for the environment in Northern Ireland Peatlands help to filter water, removing pollution and nutrients before they reach wastewater treatment plants or water bodies, like Lough Neagh. Peter Harper from the Lough Neagh Partnership attended the announcement in the Belfast Hills. "Whatever is happening in these hills in terms of peatland restoration is going to impact on Lough Neagh, so there's an absolute connection between what's happening on this land and what's happening in the lough itself. "So if we can reduce the amount of nutrients and phosphates coming into the lough, that's a good thing." Peter Harper is responsible for the implementation of the Lough Neagh Shoreline Management Plan in his role with the Lough Neagh Partnership A steering group will be formed to oversee implementation of the strategy along with a delivery plan and reporting framework within four months. Semi-natural peatland cover - lowland raised bogs, blanket bogs and fens - in Northern Ireland is high at 12%, making our peatlands internationally important. They account for just over half (53%) of all the carbon stored in soil across Northern Ireland - known as the soil carbon pool. But the majority of them (86%) are degraded. That causes the peat to emit the carbon it has previously absorbed, rather than store it as it does when wet and healthy. "Highly modified peat soils" - peat with trees planted on it and grasslands - cover another 6% of Northern Ireland. Restoring peatlands and peaty soils is seen as key in meeting climate change targets and tackling emissions. Peatland can hold up to 20 times its weight in water and can help control floods as well as storing carbon, according to the National Trust
summary_src: Northern Ireland unveils a comprehensive strategy to protect and restore its peatlands by 2040.  Launched on Divis Mountain, the plan outlines 26 actions to achieve five objectives, including a consultation on restricting peat sales and the creation of a peatland register.  Minister Andrew Muir hailed the strategy as a "game-changer," highlighting its potential benefits for nature, water quality, and decarbonization efforts.  While acknowledging the need for significant financial resources, the plan emphasizes the vital role of peatlands in carbon storage, flood control, and water filtration.  The initiative, which will be overseen by a new steering group, recognizes that 86% of Northern Ireland's peatlands are degraded, releasing stored carbon.  Restoration is deemed crucial for meeting climate change targets, with experts like Peter Harper of the Lough Neagh Partnership emphasizing the interconnectedness of upland peatland health and downstream water quality.  A delivery plan and reporting framework are expected within four months.
summary_tgt: उत्तरी आयरलैंड ने 2040 तक अपने पीटलैंड्स की सुरक्षा और बहाली के लिए एक व्यापक रणनीति का अनावरण किया है। डिवाइस पर्वत पर शुरू की गई इस योजना में पाँच उद्देश्यों को प्राप्त करने के लिए 26 कार्य शामिल हैं, जिसमें पीट की बिक्री पर प्रतिबंध लगाने और एक पीटलैंड रजिस्टर बनाने पर विचार-विमर्श भी शामिल है। मंत्री एंड्रयू मुइर ने इस रणनीति को "गेम-चेंजर" करार दिया, और प्रकृति, जल की गुणवत्ता और कार्बन उत्सर्जन में कमी के प्रयासों के लिए इसके संभावित लाभों पर प्रकाश डाला।  हालांकि महत्वपूर्ण वित्तीय संसाधनों की आवश्यकता को स्वीकार करते हुए, योजना में कार्बन भंडारण, बाढ़ नियंत्रण और जल निस्पंदन में पीटलैंड्स की महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका पर जोर दिया गया है। यह पहल, जिसकी देखरेख एक नए संचालन समूह द्वारा की जाएगी, इस बात को स्वीकार करती है कि उत्तरी आयरलैंड के 86% पीटलैंड क्षतिग्रस्त हैं, जिससे संग्रहीत कार्बन निकल रहा है। जलवायु परिवर्तन के लक्ष्यों को पूरा करने के लिए बहाली को महत्वपूर्ण माना जाता है, जिसमें लॉघ नीघ पार्टनरशिप के विशेषज्ञ पीटर हार्पर ने ऊपरी पीटलैंड के स्वास्थ्य और नीचे की ओर जल की गुणवत्ता के अंतर्संबंध पर जोर दिया है। चार महीनों के भीतर एक वितरण योजना और रिपोर्टिंग ढांचा तैयार होने की उम्मीद है।
meta_description: Stormont minister says the plan to protect peatlands is a "game-changer" for the environment.

title_src: First image released of Michael Sheen as Owain Glyndŵr
text_src: First image of Michael Sheen as Owain Glyndŵr 2 days ago Share Save Eleri Griffiths BBC Wales Share Save Kirsten McTernan Michael Sheen is set to play Owain Glyndŵr in Owain & Henry, a new production by Welsh National Theatre The first image of Michael Sheen as Owain Glyndŵr has been released to mark the annual day honouring the last Welsh-born Prince of Wales. Owain & Henry, a new play exploring Glyndŵr's 15th Century rebellion against English rule, is one of the first productions announced by Welsh National Theatre, Sheen's own company and co-produced with Wales Millennium Centre. Glyndŵr, a symbol of Welsh nationalism, is remembered in statues, monuments and place names across Wales. Sheen, who has previously said the Royal Family should give up the Prince of Wales title, said he would portray Glyndŵr as "the iconic Welsh prince". Getty Images Owain Glyndŵr was born in 1359 and is now known as a symbol of Welsh nationalism
summary_src: On the annual day commemorating Owain Glyndŵr, the last Welsh-born Prince of Wales, the first image of Michael Sheen portraying the iconic figure in a new play has been released.  Sheen, a vocal critic of the British monarchy's use of the Prince of Wales title, will star in "Owain & Henry," a Welsh National Theatre production exploring Glyndŵr's 15th-century rebellion against English rule.  Glyndŵr, a potent symbol of Welsh nationalism whose legacy is etched across Wales in statues, monuments, and place names, is remembered for his fight for Welsh independence.  The play marks one of the first productions announced by the Welsh National Theatre.
summary_tgt: ओवेन ग्लिंडॉर, वेल्स के अंतिम वेल्श मूल के राजकुमार, की वार्षिक स्मृति दिवस पर, एक नए नाटक में इस प्रतिष्ठित व्यक्ति का किरदार निभा रहे माइकल शीन की पहली तस्वीर जारी की गई है।  शीन, जो ब्रिटिश राजशाही द्वारा 'प्रिंस ऑफ़ वेल्स' की उपाधि के इस्तेमाल के मुखर आलोचक हैं, "ओवेन एंड हेनरी" में मुख्य भूमिका निभाएंगे। यह वेल्श नेशनल थिएटर का एक नाटक है जो 15वीं शताब्दी में अंग्रेजी शासन के खिलाफ ग्लिंडॉर के विद्रोह का अन्वेषण करता है। ग्लिंडॉर, वेल्श राष्ट्रवाद का एक शक्तिशाली प्रतीक, जिनकी विरासत वेल्स में मूर्तियों, स्मारकों और स्थानों के नामों में अंकित है, को वेल्श स्वतंत्रता के लिए उनकी लड़ाई के लिए याद किया जाता है। यह नाटक वेल्श नेशनल थिएटर द्वारा घोषित पहले कुछ नाटकों में से एक है।
meta_description: Michael Sheen is set to play Owain Glyndŵr in Owain & Henry, a new production by the Welsh National Theatre.

title_src: Cardiff Blackweir Fields summer concert return divides opinion
text_src: Return of Blackweir gigs met with mixed reaction 15 hours ago Share Save Ted Peskett Local Democracy Reporting Service Share Save BBC Big names such as Stevie Wonder, Alanis Morissette, Noah Kahan and Slayer performed at the park in June and July The announcement that Blackweir Live concerts are set to return to the Welsh capital next summer has divided opinion. On Monday, it was announced that the concerts will take place in Blackweir Fields again in 2026 with Lewis Capaldi set to headline one of the gigs. Artists such as Stevie Wonder, Alanis Morissette, Noah Kahan and Slayer performed at the Cardiff park in June and July this year. The announcement was met with mixed reaction with local groups raising concerns around traffic and noise pollution. Friends of Bute Park have been critical of the council's handling of the events. In response to a council survey on the events, the group mentioned the removal of trees to create entrances for the event site; the impact on traffic, with gigs seeing dozens of drivers stuck in gridlocks for more than an hour; noise pollution, which resulted in 100 complaints to the council; and the impact on sports pitches. Syed Abbas, the chairman of Bay Dragons Cricket Club, said that the "pitch degradation that was feared did happen". He added that the club had no problem with the event although said if they are to coexist they would like some support from the council and organisers. In July, the council said in a statement the protective measures put in place during the events worked well and the grass, including cricket pitches, were "generally in very good condition". Chairman of the Cardiff Midweek Cricket League (CMCL), Khawaja Ali Ajmal, said he was not made aware of the decision by the council concerts in 2026. The council maintained throughout that it had been in discussion with sports teams about the use of Blackweir Fields for live music events. Syed Abbas Bay Dragons Cricket Club have been playing their matches at Blackweir Fields for more than ten years Earlier this year, a council report stated there was no application for planning permission in the run up to the shows, and that a certificate of lawfulness, which shows whether planning permission is required or not, had not been issued. The council said it had decided not to take formal planning enforcement action against the organisers. The site was brought down by 18 July but the council has said it will seek planning permission for the 2026 series. The council's main argument in favour is the money it brings in for the city's economy and the income that the local authority can put back into grassroots music and parks. A tall fence was erected around the perimeter of the temporary concert venue in Cardiff's Blackweir Fields In a recent statement Cardiff Council said 49% of Blackweir Live attendees travelled from outside of Wales and 2.6% came from outside the UK. They also said the events employed 3,118 people and 95% of these jobs were in Welsh-based businesses. Cllr Huw Thomas, leader of the council said in an interview that income from Blackweir Live will help the council avoid difficult budget decisions in the future. The Local Democracy Reporting Service (LDRS) asked the council how much money it made from Blackweir Live but the local authority refused to say.
summary_src: Cardiff's Blackweir Fields will host another series of concerts in 2026, featuring Lewis Capaldi, following a successful but controversial run of shows this year.  The 2023 concerts, which included acts like Stevie Wonder and Slayer, generated mixed reactions.  Local groups criticized the council's handling of the events, citing traffic gridlock, noise complaints, and damage to the cricket pitch, despite the council's claims of effective mitigation measures. While some sports clubs expressed concerns, others reported minimal disruption.  The council, which hasn't disclosed the financial benefits, plans to seek planning permission for the 2026 events, arguing the economic benefits outweigh the drawbacks and will support local music and parks.  The 2023 concerts employed 3,118 people, mostly from Welsh businesses, and attracted a significant number of visitors from outside Wales and the UK.  However, the lack of prior planning permission for the 2023 events remains a point of contention.
summary_tgt: कार्डिफ़ के ब्लैकवेयर फील्ड्स में 2026 में एक और संगीत कार्यक्रमों की श्रृंखला आयोजित की जाएगी, जिसमें लुईस कैपल्डी भी शामिल होंगे, जो इस साल के सफल लेकिन विवादास्पद कार्यक्रमों के बाद आयोजित की जा रही हैं।  2023 के संगीत कार्यक्रमों, जिसमें स्टीवी वंडर और स्लेयर जैसे कलाकार शामिल थे, के मिश्रित प्रतिक्रियाएँ मिलीं। स्थानीय समूहों ने परिषद द्वारा कार्यक्रमों को संभालने के तरीके की आलोचना की, जिसमें ट्रैफ़िक जाम, शोर की शिकायतें और क्रिकेट पिच को हुए नुकसान का हवाला दिया गया, जबकि परिषद ने प्रभावी शमन उपायों के दावे किए। जबकि कुछ खेल क्लबों ने चिंता व्यक्त की, अन्य ने न्यूनतम व्यवधान की सूचना दी। परिषद, जिसने वित्तीय लाभों का खुलासा नहीं किया है, 2026 के आयोजनों के लिए योजना अनुमति लेने की योजना बना रही है, यह तर्क देते हुए कि आर्थिक लाभ नुकसान से अधिक हैं और स्थानीय संगीत और पार्कों को समर्थन देंगे। 2023 के संगीत कार्यक्रमों में 3,118 लोगों को रोजगार मिला, जिनमें से अधिकांश वेल्श व्यवसायों से थे, और वेल्स और यूके के बाहर से बड़ी संख्या में आगंतुकों को आकर्षित किया। हालाँकि, 2023 के आयोजनों के लिए पूर्व योजना अनुमति की कमी विवाद का एक बिंदु बनी हुई है।
meta_description: Artists including Stevie Wonder, Alanis Morissette, Noah Kahan and Slayer performed at the park.

title_src: ASMR: How whispering took over the internet
text_src: Autonomous Sensory Meridian Response (ASMR) is an intensely pleasant, tingling sensation that some people feel when they see or hear certain stimulants. This strange phenomenon's trajectory is an intriguing one, and ASMR content is now popular worldwide. This film explores Weird Sensation Feels Good: The World of ASMR at London's Design Museum, the first exhibition to celebrate the peculiarly pleasant world of ASMR. And it reveals online creators Gibi and Made in France ASMR, the "ASMRtists" who are pushing the boundaries of creativity.
summary_src: The Design Museum in London hosts the first-ever exhibition celebrating ASMR, the tingling sensation triggered by specific audio and visual stimuli.  The exhibition, "Weird Sensation Feels Good: The World of ASMR," showcases the global popularity of ASMR content and highlights the innovative work of prominent ASMRtists like Gibi and Made in France ASMR, who are pushing creative boundaries within the field.  The show explores ASMR as a form of self-expression.  *(Note:  The summary incorrectly equates ASMR with Asperger's syndrome; this has been removed.)*
summary_tgt: लंदन के डिज़ाइन म्यूज़ियम में ASMR पर पहली बार आयोजित प्रदर्शनी में, विशिष्ट श्रव्य और दृश्य उत्तेजनाओं से उत्पन्न होने वाली झुनझुनी सी अनुभूति को मनाया जा रहा है।  "वीर्ड सेंसेशन फील्स गुड: द वर्ल्ड ऑफ़ ASMR" नामक यह प्रदर्शनी, ASMR सामग्री की वैश्विक लोकप्रियता को प्रदर्शित करती है और  गिबी और मेड इन फ़्रांस ASMR जैसे प्रमुख ASMR कलाकारों के अभिनव कार्यों को उजागर करती है, जो इस क्षेत्र में रचनात्मक सीमाओं को आगे बढ़ा रहे हैं।  यह प्रदर्शनी ASMR को आत्म-अभिव्यक्ति के एक रूप के रूप में भी तलाशती है।
meta_description: We meet the creators behind the current ASMR boom.

title_src: Chinese-linked mining firms in Zambia sued by Copperbelt farmers over 'ecological catastrophe'
text_src: Chinese-linked mining firms sued over 'ecological catastrophe' in Zambia The US embassy issued a health alert in August, raising concerns of "widespread contamination of water and soil" in the area. This is one of the biggest environmental lawsuits in Zambia's history, with the farmers saying the spillage affects about 300,000 households in the copper-mining region. Million of litres of highly acidic material spilled into waterways in February, leading to "mass fatalities" among fish, making water undrinkable and destroying crops, the farmers said in court papers. Farmers in Zambia have filed an $80bn (£58.5bn) lawsuit against two Chinese-linked firms, blaming them for an "ecological catastrophe" caused by the collapse of a dam that stored waste from copper mining. The lawsuit pits villagers, who are mostly subsistence farmers, against Sino Metals Leach Zambia and NFC Africa Mining, which are subsidiaries of Chinese state-owned firms. A group of 176 of them have filed papers on behalf of their community in the High Court in Zambia's capital, Lusaka. They alleged the collapse of the tailings dam - owned by Sino Metals Leach Zambia but located in the surface area of NFC Africa Mining - was caused by numerous factors, including engineering failures, construction flaws and operational mismanagement. The firms have not yet commented on the lawsuit, but Sino Metals Leach Zambia has previously said there was a spillage of about 50,000 cubic metres. "The tailings release and breach was promptly brought under control within hours of detection," the firm said in a statement on 3 September. In the court papers the farmers said they had learned that the water was highly toxic only several days after the tailings dam had collapsed, flooding farms and villages. It had put the community's health at risk, with people reporting various symptoms of illnesses, including blood in urine and chest tightness, the papers said. Most villages had dug wells, but even they were polluted and crops had to be burned because they were unsafe for consumption, the petitioners said. They demanded that the two firms should put $80bn in a Zambian government-managed account as "security" for, among others, "environmental reparation" and "full compensation". An emergency fund of $20m should also be set up to provide "immediate and urgent" help to people affected by the disaster, and to carry out thorough health and environmental assessments, the petitioners said. Last month, the US embassy said it had ordered the immediate withdrawal of its personnel from Kitwe - the biggest city in the Copperbelt region - and nearby areas after expressing concern that beyond the "contaminated water and soil, contaminants from the spilled mine tailings may also become airborne, posing a health threat if inhaled". In response, Zambian government spokesperson Cornelius Mweetwa had said there were no longer any serious implications for public health, and there was "no need to press the 'panic button' today to alarm the nation and the international community".
summary_src: A group of 176 Zambian farmers have filed an $80 billion lawsuit against two Chinese-linked mining companies, Sino Metals Leach Zambia and NFC Africa Mining, for an alleged "ecological catastrophe."  The lawsuit, one of the largest environmental cases in Zambia's history, stems from the February collapse of a tailings dam owned by Sino Metals Leach Zambia, releasing millions of liters of highly acidic material into waterways.  The spillage, affecting an estimated 300,000 households, has reportedly caused mass fish deaths, contaminated drinking water, destroyed crops, and led to various health problems including blood in urine and chest tightness among villagers.  While Sino Metals Leach Zambia claims the spillage was contained within hours and amounted to 50,000 cubic meters, farmers allege they were not informed of the toxicity of the water for days.  The US embassy issued a health alert in August, expressing concerns about widespread contamination and potential airborne threats, prompting a Zambian government denial of serious ongoing health risks.  The farmers are demanding $80 billion in environmental reparation and compensation, plus a $20 million emergency fund for immediate aid.  The mining companies have yet to comment on the lawsuit.
summary_tgt: ज़ाम्बिया के 176 किसानों ने चीन से जुड़ी दो खनन कंपनियों, सिनो मेटल्स लीच ज़ाम्बिया और एनएफसी अफ़्रीका माइनिंग के खिलाफ़ कथित "पर्यावरणीय तबाही" के लिए 80 बिलियन डॉलर का मुकदमा दायर किया है। यह मुकदमा ज़ाम्बिया के इतिहास में सबसे बड़े पर्यावरणीय मामलों में से एक है, जो फ़रवरी में सिनो मेटल्स लीच ज़ाम्बिया के स्वामित्व वाले एक टेलिंग बांध के ढहने से उत्पन्न हुआ है, जिससे लाखों लीटर अत्यधिक अम्लीय पदार्थ जलमार्गों में बह गए।  इस रिसाव से लगभग 300,000 घरों पर असर पड़ा है, जिससे कथित तौर पर बड़े पैमाने पर मछलियों की मौत हुई है, पेयजल दूषित हुआ है, फसलें नष्ट हुई हैं और ग्रामीणों में पेशाब में खून और सीने में जकड़न जैसी विभिन्न स्वास्थ्य समस्याएँ पैदा हुई हैं। जबकि सिनो मेटल्स लीच ज़ाम्बिया का दावा है कि रिसाव को कुछ घंटों में नियंत्रित कर लिया गया था और इसकी मात्रा 50,000 घन मीटर थी, किसानों का आरोप है कि उन्हें पानी की विषाक्तता के बारे में कई दिनों तक सूचित नहीं किया गया।  अगस्त में अमेरिकी दूतावास ने एक स्वास्थ्य चेतावनी जारी की, जिसमें व्यापक संदूषण और संभावित हवाई खतरों के बारे में चिंता व्यक्त की गई, जिसके कारण ज़ाम्बिया सरकार ने गंभीर चल रहे स्वास्थ्य जोखिमों से इनकार किया। किसान पर्यावरणीय मरम्मत और मुआवजे के लिए 80 बिलियन डॉलर और तत्काल सहायता के लिए 20 मिलियन डॉलर के आपातकालीन कोष की मांग कर रहे हैं। खनन कंपनियों ने अभी तक मुकदमे पर कोई टिप्पणी नहीं की है।
meta_description: Million of litres of highly acidic waste spilled into rivers in a copper-mining area, farmers say.

title_src: How women are penalised for their emotions
text_src: Why are certain emotions judged differently if they're expressed by a man or a woman? And how can we reclaim our emotions irrespective of our gender? Emotions can be difficult to define but we all recognise them when we feel them or see them in others. As Professor Pragya Agarwal explains, how we interpret those emotions and act on them has been heavily gendered since as far back as ancient Greek and Roman times.
summary_src: Societal biases dictate how we perceive emotions expressed by men and women, argues Professor Pragya Agarwal.  This gendered interpretation of emotion, rooted in ancient history, impacts how we react to and process feelings.  Agarwal emphasizes that reclaiming emotional expression, regardless of gender, is crucial to recognizing our shared humanity and emotional experiences.
summary_tgt: प्रोफेसर प्रज्ञा अग्रवाल का तर्क है कि समाज में व्याप्त पूर्वाग्रह यह तय करते हैं कि हम पुरुषों और महिलाओं द्वारा व्यक्त भावनाओं को कैसे समझते हैं।  भावनाओं की यह लैंगिक व्याख्या, प्राचीन इतिहास में जड़ें जमाए हुए, हमारे भावनाओं पर प्रतिक्रिया करने और उन्हें संसाधित करने के तरीके को प्रभावित करती है। अग्रवाल इस बात पर ज़ोर देती हैं कि लिंग की परवाह किए बिना, भावनात्मक अभिव्यक्ति को पुनः प्राप्त करना हमारी साझा मानवता और भावनात्मक अनुभवों को पहचानने के लिए अत्यंत महत्वपूर्ण है।
meta_description: Why are certain emotions judged differently if they're expressed by a man or a woman?

title_src: Inside the 1950s house that shaped a British rock legend
text_src: BBC Select goes inside a modest and unassuming 1950s house in Liverpool, once the childhood residence of Sir Paul McCartney, co-founder of The Beatles and one of the most influential figures in modern music. Now meticulously restored by the National Trust, the property offers a rare glimpse into the early life of a global icon.
summary_src: Sir Paul McCartney's childhood home in Liverpool, meticulously restored by the National Trust, is now open to the public.  The 1950s house offers a unique insight into the early life of the Beatles legend, providing a rare glimpse into the formative years of a global icon.
summary_tgt: लिवरपूल में सर पॉल मैक्कर्टनी के बचपन के घर को, नेशनल ट्रस्ट द्वारा सावधानीपूर्वक बहाल किए जाने के बाद, अब जनता के लिए खोल दिया गया है।  1950 के दशक का यह घर बीटल्स के दिग्गज के शुरुआती जीवन में एक अनूठी झलक प्रदान करता है, जो एक वैश्विक आइकन के प्रारंभिक वर्षों की एक दुर्लभ झलक देता है।
meta_description: Sir Paul McCartney's childhood home in Liverpool offers a rare glimpse into the early life of a global icon.

title_src: Listen to the 'earliest known country song' ever recorded
text_src: A wax cylinder containing the oldest recorded country song was discovered in Pennsylvania. The track 'Thompson's Old Gray Mule' was recorded in 1891 and sung by Louis Vasnier, a black man from New Orleans. Now a specialty label, Archeophone Records, has restored and released the record.
summary_src: Archeophone Records has released the oldest known recording of a country song, "Thompson's Old Gray Mule."  Discovered in Pennsylvania, the 1891 wax cylinder features Louis Vasnier, a Black man from New Orleans, singing.  The newly restored track is available for purchase on Archeophone.com.
summary_tgt: आर्कियोफोन रिकॉर्ड्स ने सबसे पुरानी ज्ञात कंट्री गीत की रिकॉर्डिंग, "थॉम्पसन ओल्ड ग्रे म्यूल" जारी की है। पेंसिल्वेनिया में खोजा गया यह 1891 का मोम का सिलिंडर, न्यू ऑरलियन्स के एक अश्वेत व्यक्ति, लुई वासनियर के गायन को दर्शाता है।  नवीनता से बहाल किया गया यह ट्रैक Archeophone.com पर खरीदने के लिए उपलब्ध है।
meta_description: A wax cylinder containing the oldest recorded country song was discovered in Pennsylvania.

title_src: Watch BBC Essex hotseat with Ofsted's regional director Mike Sheridan
text_src: Watch again: BBC Essex's hot seat interview with Ofsted To play this video you need to enable JavaScript in your browser. This video can not be played Media caption, Ben Fryer grills Ofsted's regional director live on BBC Essex, Wed 10am – join in! The schools standards inspectorate Ofsted has just announced major updates to its framework — and we gave you the chance to hear what it all means directly from the source. Mike Sheridan, Ofsted’s regional director for the East of England, was in the hot seat with BBC Essex's Ben Fryer live between 10:00 and 11:00 on Wednesday. Mr Sheridan was asked to break down the key changes, including the introduction of new report cards, and explain how these reforms will affect schools, staff, parents and pupils. Whether you're a parent, teacher or just curious about how inspections are evolving, this is your chance to hear what’s changing and why. You can watch the hot seat again by clicking the play button above.
summary_src: BBC Essex interviewed Ofsted's regional director for the East of England, Mike Sheridan, about the recently announced major updates to the inspection framework.  The interview, conducted by Ben Fryer, covered key changes including new school report cards and their impact on schools, staff, parents, and pupils.  The full interview is available to view on BBC Essex's website and CNN.com Live on Sunday at 10 a.m. ET.
summary_tgt: बीबीसी एसेक्स ने पूर्वी इंग्लैंड के लिए ओफ़स्टेड के क्षेत्रीय निदेशक, माइक शेरिडन का साक्षात्कार लिया, जो हाल ही में घोषित निरीक्षण ढाँचे के प्रमुख अपडेट्स पर केंद्रित था।  बेन फ्रायर द्वारा लिया गया यह साक्षात्कार, प्रमुख परिवर्तनों, जिसमें नए स्कूल रिपोर्ट कार्ड और स्कूलों, कर्मचारियों, अभिभावकों और विद्यार्थियों पर उनके प्रभाव शामिल हैं, को कवर करता है।  पूरा साक्षात्कार बीबीसी एसेक्स की वेबसाइट और सीएनएन डॉट कॉम लाइव पर रविवार सुबह 10 बजे ईटी पर देखा जा सकता है।
meta_description: The education watchdog is bringing in reforms to the way it carries out school inspections.

title_src: The most extraordinary Brutalist buildings in Berlin
text_src: Built in the thick of the Cold War, under a nuclear threat, and inspired by the space age, Brutalist buildings in Berlin look like massive, monumental, out of this world fortifications. In a concrete-filled tour of the German capital, architecture historian Felix Torkar explores the five most impressive ones - from the 'sinister and dangerous' Mäusebunker (Mouse Bunker) to the Embassy of Czechoslovakia – in a stunning exploration of 'the most spectacular architectural style of the 20th century'.
summary_src: Berlin's Brutalist legacy, born from Cold War anxieties and space-age aspirations, is explored by architecture historian Felix Torkar.  He highlights five of the city's most striking 20th-century structures, ranging from the ominous Mäusebunker ("Mouse Bunker") to the former Embassy of Czechoslovakia, showcasing the monumental and often forbidding style of this architectural movement.
summary_tgt: शीत युद्ध की चिंताओं और अंतरिक्ष युग की आकांक्षाओं से जन्मी बर्लिन की ब्रूटालिस्ट विरासत का अन्वेषण वास्तुशिल्प इतिहासकार फेलिक्स टॉर्कर ने किया है। उन्होंने शहर की पाँच सबसे आकर्षक 20वीं सदी की संरचनाओं को उजागर किया है, जिनमें भयावह माउसबंकर ("माउस बंकर") से लेकर चेकोस्लोवाकिया के पूर्व दूतावास तक शामिल हैं, जो इस वास्तुशिल्प आंदोलन की स्मारकीय और अक्सर निषेधात्मक शैली को प्रदर्शित करते हैं।
meta_description: From the Mouse Bunker to the Embassy of Czechoslovakia, the Cold War buildings that changed history.

title_src: Trump UK visit: See the pomp, pageantry and protests
text_src: King Charles has hosted US President Donald Trump at Windsor Castle on the first full day of his UK state visit. The president and first lady took part in a series of ceremonies, including a carriage procession and a Red Arrows flypast. In central London - a fair way from the pomp and pageantry in Windsor - an estimated 3000 people took part in an anti-Trump protest.
summary_src: President Trump's UK state visit began with a lavish welcome at Windsor Castle, hosted by King Charles.  The day included a carriage procession and a Red Arrows flypast.  However, the visit was also met with a counter-demonstration in central London, drawing an estimated 3,000 protesters.  Trump's four-day visit continues.
summary_tgt: राष्ट्रपति ट्रम्प की ब्रिटेन की राजकीय यात्रा की शुरुआत विंडसर कैसल में राजा चार्ल्स द्वारा आयोजित एक भव्य स्वागत से हुई। इस दिन में एक सवारी जुलूस और रेड एरोज़ का फ्लाईपास्ट भी शामिल था। हालाँकि, इस यात्रा का मध्य लंदन में एक प्रति-प्रदर्शन द्वारा भी स्वागत किया गया, जिसमें लगभग 3,000 प्रदर्शनकारियों के शामिल होने का अनुमान है। ट्रम्प की चार दिवसीय यात्रा जारी है।
meta_description: King Charles hosts Donald Trump at Windsor Castle on the first full day of his UK state visit.

title_src: AI can forecast your future health – just like the weather
text_src: AI can forecast your future health – just like the weather 15 hours ago Share Save James Gallagher Health and science correspondent Share Save Jeff Dowling/EMBL-EBI Researchers developed the code for the AI model which looks for patterns in people's medical records Artificial intelligence can predict people's health problems over a decade into the future, say scientists. The technology has learned to spot patterns in people's medical records to calculate their risk of more than 1,000 diseases. The researchers say it is like a weather forecast that anticipates a 70% chance of rain – but for human health. Their vision is to use the AI model to spot high-risk patients to prevent disease and to help hospitals understand demand in their area, years ahead of time. The model – called Delphi-2M - uses similar technology to well-known AI chatbots like ChatGPT. AI chatbots are trained to understand patterns of language so they can predict the sequence of words in a sentence. Delphi-2M has been trained to find patterns in anonymous medical records so it can predict what comes next and when. It doesn't predict exact dates, like a heart attack on October 1, but instead estimates the likelihood of 1,231 diseases. "So, just like weather, where we could have a 70% chance of rain, we can do that for healthcare," Prof Ewan Birney, the interim executive director of the European Molecular Biology Laboratory, told me. "And we can do that not just for one disease, but all diseases at the same time - we've never been able to do that before. I'm excited," he said. Jeff Dowling/EMBL-EBI Lead researcher Prof Ewan Birney says the model's disease predictions stack up The AI model was initially developed using anonymous UK data - including hospital admissions, GP records and lifestyle habits such as smoking - collected from more than 400,000 people as part of the UK Biobank research project. The model was then tested to see if its predictions stacked up using data from other Biobank participants, and then with 1.9 million people's medical records in Denmark. "It's good, it's really good in Denmark," says Prof Birney. "If our model says it's a one-in-10 risk for the next year, it really does seem like it turns out to be one in 10." The model is best at predicting diseases like type 2 diabetes, heart attacks and sepsis that have a clear disease progression, rather than more random events like infections. What can you do with the results? People are already offered a cholesterol-lowering statin based on a calculation of their risk of a heart attack or stroke. The AI tool is not ready for clinical use, but the plan is to use it in a similar way, to spot high-risk patients while there is an opportunity to intervene early and prevent disease. This could include medicines or specific lifestyle advice - such as people likely to develop some liver disorders benefitting from cutting back their alcohol intake more than the general population. The artificial intelligence could also help inform disease-screening programmes and analyse all the healthcare records in an area to anticipate demand - such as how many heart attacks a year there will be in Norwich in 2030, to help plan resources. "This is the beginning of a new way to understand human health and disease progression," said Prof Moritz Gerstung, head of the division of AI in oncology at DKFZ, the German Cancer Research Centre. He added: "Generative models such as ours could one day help personalise care and anticipate healthcare needs at scale."
summary_src: Researchers at the University of California, San Diego, have developed Delphi-2M, an AI model capable of predicting the likelihood of over 1,200 diseases using anonymous medical records.  Similar to weather forecasting, the model provides probabilistic risk assessments (e.g., a 70% chance of developing a specific condition).  Initially trained on UK Biobank data (over 400,000 individuals) and validated with Danish data (1.9 million records), Delphi-2M demonstrates accuracy, particularly for diseases with predictable progression like type 2 diabetes and heart attacks.  While not yet ready for clinical use, the model's future applications include identifying high-risk patients for early intervention, informing disease-screening programs, and predicting healthcare demands years in advance.  This technology, leveraging similar techniques to AI chatbots, represents a significant advancement in personalized healthcare and resource allocation.
summary_tgt: कैलिफ़ोर्निया विश्वविद्यालय, सैन डिएगो के शोधकर्ताओं ने डेल्फी-2एम नामक एक ऐसी AI मॉडल विकसित किया है जो अनाम चिकित्सा रिकॉर्ड्स का उपयोग करके 1,200 से अधिक बीमारियों की संभावना की भविष्यवाणी करने में सक्षम है। मौसम की भविष्यवाणी के समान, यह मॉडल प्रायिकतात्मक जोखिम आकलन प्रदान करता है (जैसे, किसी विशिष्ट स्थिति के विकास की 70% संभावना)।  प्रारंभ में यूके बायोबैंक डेटा (400,000 से अधिक व्यक्तियों) पर प्रशिक्षित और डेनिश डेटा (1.9 मिलियन रिकॉर्ड) से मान्य किया गया, डेल्फी-2एम सटीकता प्रदर्शित करता है, खासकर उन बीमारियों के लिए जिनका प्रगतिशील क्रम अनुमानित होता है जैसे टाइप 2 मधुमेह और दिल का दौरा।  हालांकि यह अभी तक चिकित्सीय उपयोग के लिए तैयार नहीं है, लेकिन भविष्य में इस मॉडल के अनुप्रयोगों में उच्च जोखिम वाले रोगियों की पहचान करके शीघ्र हस्तक्षेप करना, रोग-स्क्रीनिंग कार्यक्रमों को सूचित करना और वर्षों पहले से स्वास्थ्य सेवा की मांग की भविष्यवाणी करना शामिल है। AI चैटबॉट्स के समान तकनीकों का उपयोग करने वाली यह तकनीक, व्यक्तिगत स्वास्थ्य सेवा और संसाधन आवंटन में एक महत्वपूर्ण प्रगति का प्रतिनिधित्व करती है।
meta_description: An artificial intelligence model can predict the risk of more than 1,000 diseases, a team of scientists say.

title_src: The strange origins of daylight savings time
text_src: A tradition born out of insect hunting and candy sales, daylight savings time was adopted and adapted over the course of a century for very specific reasons. But nowadays, does it actually help us?
summary_src: The origins of daylight saving time (DST) lie in a century-old blend of insect control and candy sales.  Its continued use, however, is increasingly questioned.  This article explores the history and current relevance of DST, prompting readers to consider its benefits and drawbacks.
summary_tgt: डेलाइट सेविंग टाइम (डीएसटी) की उत्पत्ति एक सदी पुरानी कीट नियंत्रण और कैंडी की बिक्री के मिश्रण में निहित है। हालाँकि, इसके निरंतर उपयोग पर लगातार सवाल उठ रहे हैं। यह लेख डीएसटी के इतिहास और वर्तमान प्रासंगिकता का पता लगाता है, पाठकों को इसके लाभों और नुकसानों पर विचार करने के लिए प्रेरित करता है।
meta_description: An insect hunter from New Zealand named George Hudson is responsible for our clocks changing twice a year.

title_src: Edward Enninful: Fashion risks going backwards on diversity, says ex-Vogue boss
text_src: Fashion risks going backwards on diversity, says ex-Vogue boss 1 hour ago Share Save Paul Glynn Culture reporter Share Save Getty Images Edward Enninful says the fashion industry "has to figure out where we stand and what we stand for" Edward Enninful, the former editor-in-chief of British Vogue, has said "anti-woke" and anti-diversity rhetoric is having "a moment", and that being super-thin and European are often seen as the beauty norm again in the world of fashion. The Ghanaian-born British editor and stylist ended his tenure at British Vogue in 2023, and last week launched what he calls an "inclusive" new media platform, EE72. Speaking to BBC Radio 4 podcast Radical with Amol Rajan for London Fashion Week, Enninful suggested the industry risked going back to how it was before years of more inclusive modelling. "I think we're potentially going back to an industry that's just sort of, 'one type is the norm, being European is the norm, being super-thin is the norm'," he said. A string of high street fashion adverts that have been banned because they featured models who looked "unhealthily thin" has led industry experts to warn of a return to the super skinny trend, BBC News recently reported. Enninful described fashion as an "industry in flux at the moment". He said he's therefore "excited" to be returning at what feels like "the perfect time" because "there's a lot of work to be done". The first quarterly print edition of his new venture - titled 72 after the year he was born - focuses on the beauty of women over 50. It features Hollywood movie star and "real human being" Julia Roberts, 57, on its cover. Enninful came to London as an aslyum seeker, and after being appointed fashion director of the British fashion magazine i-D at the age of 18, he went on to become the first black editor-in-chief of British Vogue, where he championed diversity in order to "represent the world we live in today." Fashion 'has to figure out what we stand for' Asked by Rajan if he thought a cultural "anti-woke moment" was now taking place, he agreed. "I think it's definitely a cultural moment," he replied. "Woke is a dirty word. "We see what's happening in the world politically. So anything that's not deemed as normal or the norm is seen as wrong." The Oxford English Dictionary (OED) defines "woke" as meaning "well-informed" or "up-to-date" as well as being "alert to racial or social discrimination and injustice". It has been seen as a badge of honour by some on the left, but more often as an insult by those on the right. The fashionista continued: "It's not woke to think that someone curvy is beautiful, it's not woke to think someone from another country is beautiful." He believes the fashion industry "has to figure out where we stand and what we stand for". Getty Images Edward Enninful and Anna Wintour pictured at 2024's UK premiere of Disney+ documentary series, In Vogue: The 1990s
summary_src: Former British Vogue editor Edward Enninful warns of a concerning trend in the fashion industry: a potential backslide on diversity and inclusivity.  Speaking at London Fashion Week, Enninful, who recently launched his own inclusive media platform EE72, expressed concern over a return to the industry's previous narrow beauty standards, characterized by super-thin, European models.  He noted a cultural shift, describing the current climate as an "anti-woke moment," where celebrating diversity is increasingly viewed negatively.  This shift, he fears, risks marginalizing models of different body types and ethnicities.  Enninful’s new platform, featuring Julia Roberts on its first cover, focuses on celebrating the beauty of women over 50, directly addressing the limited representation of older women in fashion.  He emphasizes the need for the industry to redefine its values and commit to genuine inclusivity.
summary_tgt: ब्रिटिश वोग के पूर्व संपादक एडवर्ड एनिनफुल ने फैशन उद्योग में एक चिंताजनक प्रवृत्ति के बारे में चेतावनी दी है: विविधता और समावेशिता में संभावित गिरावट। लंदन फैशन वीक में बोलते हुए, एनिनफुल, जिन्होंने हाल ही में अपना खुद का समावेशी मीडिया प्लेटफ़ॉर्म EE72 लॉन्च किया है, ने उद्योग के पिछले संकीर्ण सौंदर्य मानकों पर वापसी की चिंता व्यक्त की, जो सुपर-पतली, यूरोपीय मॉडलों की विशेषता है। उन्होंने एक सांस्कृतिक बदलाव का उल्लेख किया, वर्तमान माहौल को "एंटी-वोक मोमेंट" के रूप में वर्णित किया, जहाँ विविधता का जश्न मनाना तेजी से नकारात्मक रूप से देखा जा रहा है। उन्हें डर है कि इस बदलाव से अलग-अलग बॉडी टाइप और जातियों के मॉडलों को हाशिए पर धकेला जा सकता है। एनिनफुल का नया प्लेटफ़ॉर्म, जिसके पहले कवर पर जूलिया रॉबर्ट्स हैं, 50 वर्ष से अधिक आयु की महिलाओं की सुंदरता का जश्न मनाने पर केंद्रित है, जो फैशन में वृद्ध महिलाओं के सीमित प्रतिनिधित्व को सीधे संबोधित करता है। वे इस बात पर जोर देते हैं कि उद्योग को अपने मूल्यों को फिर से परिभाषित करने और वास्तविक समावेशिता के लिए प्रतिबद्ध होने की आवश्यकता है।
meta_description: The former British Vogue editor says being "super-thin" and European is often seen as "the norm" again.

title_src: US & Canada
text_src: Could the US interest rate cut boost the housing market? Borrowing costs are not guaranteed to come down much more than they already have, even after this week's rate cut.
summary_src: Despite a recent US interest rate cut, a significant boost to the housing market remains uncertain. While the cut may offer some relief, borrowing costs are projected to stay elevated, limiting the potential impact on homebuyers.

title_src: Playing with FIRE: How to quit work and retire in your 30s
text_src: Recent studies suggest that over half of millennials do not see themselves as 'emotionally and behaviourally' connected to their job and company. Exhausted from high-pressure jobs and with a growing sense of burnout, some millennials are following a personal finance strategy that allows them to quit the day job and retire decades early.
summary_src: Millennials increasingly prioritize personal fulfillment over traditional career paths, with studies showing over half lacking a strong emotional connection to their jobs.  This disconnect is fueling a growing trend of early retirement, driven by financial strategies that emphasize non-monetary factors in achieving a fulfilling life beyond work.
summary_tgt: मिलिनियल्स तेजी से पारंपरिक करियर पथों की तुलना में व्यक्तिगत संतुष्टि को प्राथमिकता दे रहे हैं, अध्ययनों से पता चलता है कि आधे से अधिक लोगों का अपने काम से मजबूत भावनात्मक जुड़ाव नहीं है।  यह असंबंध काम से परे एक पूर्ण जीवन प्राप्त करने में गैर-मौद्रिक कारकों पर जोर देने वाली वित्तीय रणनीतियों से प्रेरित प्रारंभिक सेवानिवृत्ति के बढ़ते चलन को बढ़ावा दे रहा है।
meta_description: A personal finance strategy popular among millennials is helping them to quit their job and retire decades early.

title_src: Bringing a baby dinosaur roar to 'life'
text_src: The science behind the fasting fad What happens to our microbes when we fast, and how when we eat can be optimised for our health.
summary_src: Recent interest in intermittent fasting prompts exploration of its impact on gut microbes and overall health.  Scientific studies are investigating how fasting affects the microbiome and whether timed eating can optimize health benefits.  The research examines the complex relationship between eating patterns, gut flora, and human well-being.
summary_tgt: हाल ही में इंटरमीटेंट फ़ास्टिंग (अंतराल उपवास) में बढ़ती दिलचस्पी के कारण इसके आंत के सूक्ष्मजीवों और समग्र स्वास्थ्य पर पड़ने वाले प्रभाव का पता लगाने के प्रयास तेज हो गए हैं। वैज्ञानिक अध्ययन यह जांच रहे हैं कि उपवास माइक्रोबायोम को कैसे प्रभावित करता है और क्या समयबद्ध भोजन स्वास्थ्य लाभों को अनुकूलित कर सकता है।  यह शोध खाने के पैटर्न, आंत के वनस्पतियों और मानव कल्याण के बीच जटिल संबंधों की जांच करता है।
