title_src: Rare butterfly spotted near Newcastle for first time since 1850
text_src: Rare butterfly spotted for first time since 1850 5 days ago Share Save Pamela Bilalova North East and Cumbria Share Save Chris Barlow The Silver-washed Fritillary has been growing in numbers in the north-east of England A butterfly has been spotted on the edge of a county for the first time in nearly 200 years. The Silver-washed Fritillary was recorded at Havannah and Three Hills Nature Reserve in Hazlerigg, near Newcastle's border with Northumberland, by local Chris Barlow in August. The Natural History Society of Northumbria said the butterfly had not been seen in the county since 1850. Stephen Kirtley, from charity Butterfly Conservation, said the species had become extinct in the North East in the 19th Century, but its numbers were growing again, especially in County Durham and Teesside. Mr Kirtley said he hoped the Silver-washed Fritillary would grow its presence in south Northumberland and start spreading further north. However, he said the butterfly that was spotted at Havannah and Three Hills Nature Reserve was male and it would not create a colony itself. Chris Barlow The butterfly's return to the region has been celebrated The Silver-washed Fritillary is more widespread in Wales and southern England. Its last sightings in the North East were in the 1850s. It was not spotted again until 2017, when it was recorded in Wynyard Country Park, near Stockton. The species has since been seen near Durham city and Castle Eden, with about 14 sightings recorded this year so far, up from 10 in 2024. "Perhaps at some stage in the mid-19th Century it became too cool for the butterfly to survive here," Mr Kirtley said. "Or perhaps changes in land management and woodland management meant that the places where it used to be found in the 1850s and before were no longer suitable and it's not been found in this area. "I strongly suspect and believe that because of climate warming, the butterfly has started to move north and is able to use habitat in our area that up until recently wasn't suitable for it." Stephen Kirtley The butterfly has been spotted more regularly in County Durham since 2017 Councillor Alex Hay, deputy leader and cabinet member for neighbourhoods at Newcastle City Council, which looks after Havannah and Three Hills Nature Reserve, said the butterfly's return to the north was "a powerful indicator" of the impact of conservation and habitat restoration efforts. "It's a proud moment for the city and a reminder of the importance of protecting our natural environment for future generations," Hay added. Follow BBC North East on X, Facebook, Nextdoor and Instagram. More on this story 'Concerning drop' in number of butterfly species
summary_src: A Silver-washed Fritillary butterfly, unseen in Northumberland since 1850, has been spotted at Havannah and Three Hills Nature Reserve near Newcastle.  This marks a significant return for the species, believed extinct in the North East during the 19th century. While its numbers are growing in County Durham and Teesside, this sighting is a male and won't establish a colony alone. Experts attribute the northward expansion to climate change, making previously unsuitable habitats viable.  The sighting, one of over a dozen this year, is hailed as a conservation success, highlighting the positive impact of environmental protection efforts.
summary_tgt: नॉर्थम्बरलैंड में 1850 के बाद से लुप्त मानी जाने वाली सिल्वर-वॉश्ड फ्रिटिलरी तितली को न्यूकैसल के पास हवाना और थ्री हिल्स नेचर रिजर्व में देखा गया है।  यह इस प्रजाति की महत्वपूर्ण वापसी है, जिसे 19वीं सदी में उत्तर पूर्व में विलुप्त माना जाता था। जबकि इसकी संख्या डरहम काउंटी और टीसाइड में बढ़ रही है, यह देखा गया तितली एक नर है और अकेले ही कोई कॉलोनी स्थापित नहीं कर पाएगा। विशेषज्ञों का मानना ​​है कि जलवायु परिवर्तन के कारण इसका उत्तर की ओर विस्तार हो रहा है, जिससे पहले अनुपयुक्त आवास अब उपयुक्त हो गए हैं। इस वर्ष एक दर्जन से अधिक देखे गए इस तितली को संरक्षण की एक सफलता के रूप में सराहा जा रहा है, जो पर्यावरण संरक्षण के प्रयासों के सकारात्मक प्रभाव को उजागर करता है।
meta_description: The Silver-washed Fritillary has been growing in numbers in County Durham and Teesside.

title_src: BBC Verify Live: What we know about new route out of Gaza City as thousands told to evacuate
text_src: Wednesday with BBC Verify Live Lucy Gilder BBC Verify journalist Thanks for joining us on BBC Verify Live. Today’s live page will be closing soon, but here’s a run down of some stories the team reported on. Using satellite imagery we analysed the path of the Israeli military’s new temporary evacuation route out of Gaza City, as a renewed ground operation in the area intensifies. The team has also looked at imagery of the latest Israeli strikes in northern Gaza, including an attack on a children’s hospital and another on a family seemingly fleeing the fighting. Elsewhere, we showed how we determined that a social media video of Uganda’s president discussing the country’s 2026 election was an AI fake. In the UK, on the first full day of Donald Trump’s state visit, we used geolocation techniques to identify the hotel apparently used to project images of the US president and Jeffrey Epstein onto a Windsor Castle tower last night. For more on Trump’s trip, we’ve fact-checked London Mayor Sadiq Khan’s claim about record numbers of Americans moving to the capital - which you can watch later across the BBC’s social media platforms.
summary_src: BBC Verify Live highlighted several key investigations Wednesday.  Satellite imagery analysis revealed the route of a new Israeli military evacuation path from Gaza City amidst intensified ground operations.  The team also examined imagery of recent Israeli strikes in northern Gaza, including alleged attacks on a children's hospital and a family fleeing conflict.  Furthermore, they debunked a social media video featuring a purported AI-generated speech by Uganda's president about the 2026 election.  Finally, geolocation techniques were used to identify a London hotel that reportedly projected images of U.S. President Biden and Jeffrey Epstein onto Windsor Castle.  A fact-check of London Mayor Sadiq Khan's claim regarding American migration to London was also conducted.  The full program is available on BBC social media.
summary_tgt: बीबीसी वेरिफ़ाई लाइव ने बुधवार को कई महत्वपूर्ण जांचों को उजागर किया। उपग्रह इमेजरी विश्लेषण से गाजा शहर से इज़रायली सेना के एक नए निकासी मार्ग का पता चला है, जो ज़मीनी अभियानों के तेज होने के बीच है। टीम ने उत्तरी गाजा में हाल के इज़रायली हमलों की तस्वीरों की भी जाँच की, जिसमें एक बच्चों के अस्पताल और संघर्ष से भाग रहे एक परिवार पर कथित हमले शामिल हैं। इसके अलावा, उन्होंने युगांडा के राष्ट्रपति के 2026 के चुनाव के बारे में एक कथित AI-जनित भाषण दिखाने वाले सोशल मीडिया वीडियो का भंडाफोड़ किया। अंत में, जियो-लोकेशन तकनीकों का उपयोग उस लंदन होटल की पहचान करने के लिए किया गया, जिसने कथित तौर पर विंडसर कैसल पर अमेरिकी राष्ट्रपति बिडेन और जेफरी एपस्टाइन की तस्वीरें प्रोजेक्ट की थीं। लंदन के मेयर सादिक खान के अमेरिकी प्रवासियों के लंदन में आने के दावे की भी तथ्य-जांच की गई। पूरा कार्यक्रम बीबीसी सोशल मीडिया पर उपलब्ध है।
meta_description: Latest updates from the BBC's specialists in fact-checking, verifying video and tackling disinformation.

title_src: Attabad Lake: The stunning legacy of a natural disaster
text_src: When a massive landslide dammed the Hunza River, it destroyed villages – and created one of the most breathtaking lakes in Pakistan. When Lauren Winslow-Llewellyn saw a photo of Attabad Lake in Pakistan's Hunza Valley pop up on her social media feed, she immediately went into planning mode. "[It] was taken from up high, not from a drone but a hiking trail... someone was precariously sitting on the edge of a cliff above vibrant blue water," she said. Based in south-east England, Winslow-Llewellyn and partner Craig Hubbard, known online as the Non Stop Travelling couple, work seasonal hospitality jobs between their trips to save up for their next adventure. After studying foreign travel advisory sites, mapping safe paths and scouring Google Earth, all that was left was to reach Hunza's capital, Karimabad, as their base camp and hitch a ride to the trailhead. Perched atop an open truck piled high with rugs and appliances, the couple and a local family barrelled through tunnels, wind whipping their faces and laughter spilling into the air – until, suddenly, Attabad Lake burst into view, majestically blue and breathtaking, ringed by arid peaks jutting straight out of glacial water. "It's probably my favourite memory of our time in Pakistan," said Winslow-Llewellyn. "It felt like we were on a crazy rollercoaster ride."
summary_src: A landslide in Pakistan's Hunza Valley, while devastating nearby villages, unexpectedly created the stunning Attabad Lake.  Travel bloggers Lauren Winslow-Llewellyn and Craig Hubbard, known as "Non Stop Travelling," were captivated by a photo of the lake and subsequently journeyed to the region.  Their adventurous trip, involving a precarious truck ride through mountain tunnels, culminated in witnessing the breathtaking turquoise lake surrounded by dramatic peaks.  The couple described the experience as a "crazy rollercoaster ride" and a highlight of their Pakistani travels.
summary_tgt: पाकिस्तान की हुंजा घाटी में एक भूस्खलन हुआ जिसने आस-पास के गाँवों को तबाह कर दिया, लेकिन अप्रत्याशित रूप से आश्चर्यजनक अताबाड झील का निर्माण भी कर दिया।  "नॉन स्टॉप ट्रैवलिंग" के नाम से जाने जाने वाले ट्रैवल ब्लॉगर्स लॉरेन विंसलो-ल्यूवेलिन और क्रेग हबर्ड इस झील की एक तस्वीर से मुग्ध हो गए और बाद में इस क्षेत्र की यात्रा की।  पहाड़ी सुरंगों से होते हुए एक असुरक्षित ट्रक की सवारी शामिल उनकी साहसिक यात्रा, नाटकीय चोटियों से घिरी लुभावनी फ़िरोज़ी झील को देखकर समाप्त हुई।  युगल ने इस अनुभव को "पागल रोलरकोस्टर राइड" और अपनी पाकिस्तानी यात्रा का मुख्य आकर्षण बताया।

title_src: Bank of England: Inside the building that houses 400K gold bars
text_src: Inside the century-old building standing above 400,000 gold bars 2 days ago Share Save Tim Stokes London Share Save BBC The Bank of England covers a three-and-a-half acre site in the City of London The echoing boom of a slammed door rattles around the walls of the Bank of England's grand columned entrance. Across the floor and walls sprawl grand mosaics and sculptures depicting lions, piles of gold, thunderbolts and ancient Roman gods. "When this building was created, it was designed as a working bank building. There were people coming and going all day," explains the Bank of England Museum's curator, Jenni Adam. "And immediately they were greeted with this sense of grandeur along with lots and lots of messages about what's happening in this site." Bank of England Museum. Photo by Monica A Walker Vadillo The parlours of the first floor have a very different atmosphere to the rooms on the floor below One hundred years ago work began to rebuild the Bank of England - a place which had started as a townhouse in the 1700s and expanded over subsequent centuries. To mark this centenary a new exhibition has begun in the bank's museum revealing more about what can be found inside one of Britain's most secure buildings. Ahead of its opening the BBC was given a rare look inside the bank itself, where some of the country's key financial decisions are made and which houses some 400,000 bars of gold in its basement vaults. The Print Collector via Getty Images Sir John Soane introduced the windowless wall in the 1800s which still surrounds the site Corbis via Getty Images Attempts were made to reproduce the grand banking halls of Soane's bank in the redevelopment The bank was first granted a Royal Charter in 1694 when it was "founded for the use and benefit of the public as a way to manage the national debt and maintain stable finances in Britain", says Ms Adam. It proved to be a huge success and by 1734 had moved to its current position in Threadneedle Street, with the premises becoming grander and slowly swallowing up surrounding land to cover a three-and-a-half acre (14,000 sq m) site within a windowless wall. Various renowned architects worked on the bank including Sir John Soane in the 1800s, with his building considered one the jewels of the City. However, by the first decades of the 20th Century, Soane's magnificent work was no longer proving fit for purpose. "By the First World War the staff at the bank had gone from about 1,200 in 1914 to around 4,000 by 1918 and it was clear that there was a real capacity problem," says Ms Adam. "It was doing a colossal job of managing an expensive national debt among many different aspects so it was decided to demolish and rebuild." Bank of England Museum The bank continued to operate on the site throughout the 14-year project to rebuild it Despite efforts to retain much of its historic character, the 14-year project proved controversial with one architectural expert branding the demolition "the greatest architectural crime to befall London in the 20th Century". Even so, upon its completion in 1939 the project led by chief architect Sir Herbert Baker had cost a total of £5m - the equivalent of nearly £285m today - with no expense spared in the creation of the country's central bank. Evidence of such wealth can be seen throughout a development which rises seven floors high and three below. On the ground floor, mosaics by acclaimed Russian artist Boris Anrep spread along a maze of domed grey and black corridors, with figures and sculptures covering the fixtures and fittings throughout. Bank of England Museum A large mosaic featuring two lions protecting a column of gold stands in the centre of the entrance hall while depictions of the Roman god Mercury are everywhere Golden lions - symbolising security - pop up across the space, from specially designed lighting to staircase bannisters, while even the door handles are miniature recreations of Mercury, the Roman deity of communication and finance. "There's a real blend of modern and ancient. It gives you the sense that even though this building is relatively new, it's been here forever," explains Ms Adam. "There's a long legacy, a long heritage. You can trust it, it's going to stick around." There is also a sign of an even older legacy at the bottom of one long spiralling staircase, where a Roman mosaic that was discovered in the 1930s remains on display. Roman mosaics and numerous other artefacts from the time were found during building work With grand banking halls based on those from Soane's building hidden off the corridor, occasional echoing thuds and bangs are the main reminder of the working nature of the building. This enterprise also carries on up another set of staircases but in a very different, almost regal atmosphere. One space, the first floor anteroom, is lined with red and gold silk, with centuries-old paintings hanging on the walls and an elaborately decorative fireplace standing beside a huge floor-to-ceiling window. Leading off it are a thick set of wooden double-doors that head into a plush pale blue octagonal room where a portrait of a past governor glares down upon a reproduction of a room created in the 1780s. Without the microphones placed around a curving table and two TV screens, few would consider this somewhere where discussions are held each month that have ramifications for millions of people. "This is where to the present day, the bank's monetary policy committee meets to make decisions about rates as part of the bank's remit to manage inflation. "That's why you want the double doors to make sure that nobody is listening into these very important market sensitive conversations," Ms Adam explains. Bank of England Museum. Photo by Monica A Walker Vadillo The first floor ante room houses artworks telling the changing story of the bank Bank of England Museum. Photo by Monica A Walker Vadillo Decisions on the Bank of England's interest rate are made each month in the committee room The feel of a grand old building spotted with hints of modernity continues around the floor, with many of the stone elements from the previous bank-like fireplaces and columns reused by Baker. Through another set of double doors is the court room, where a branded lectern stands in front of an 18th Century fireplace beneath an elaborate green ceiling and walls lined with gold. Silhouettes of monarchs from across the lifetime of the bank line the room, while gilded griffins protect piles of gold above the doorways. A wind vane also swings mechanically on one wall recalling a time when London's port was almost on the bank's doorstep and was such a key element of the city's economy. "There's just lots of the symbolism of money and finance throughout the space... and gild as far as the eye can see," adds the museum curator. The court room is used for activities like large meetings and formal receptions The need for tight security means that tours of the building are incredibly rare. The only sight of any of the gold are the two bars held within the museum that are owned by the bank itself. It's why Ms Adam says she's so pleased to be able to put on an exhibition to "open up the architecture" and give people an idea of what's inside. "I've been working in the bank for 15 years and when you come in here every day, it becomes normal," she says. "However, every so often you do go around and think 'this is so spectacular' - and there's just so many stories and details to share." Bank of England Museum. Photo by Monica A Walker Vadillo The yellow dining room on the first floor is still used by directors and governors for meals Building the Bank will run at the Bank of England Museum until Spring 2027 and is free to visit Listen to the best of BBC Radio London on Sounds and follow BBC London on Facebook, X and Instagram. Send your story ideas to hello.bbclondon@bbc.co.uk
summary_src: The Bank of England Museum in London is showcasing a new exhibition, "Building the Bank," celebrating the centenary of the bank's current building.  A rare BBC tour revealed the opulent interior, which houses 400,000 gold bars in its vaults.  The three-and-a-half-acre site, rebuilt between 1925 and 1939 after the demolition of Sir John Soane's earlier structure (a decision criticized as "the greatest architectural crime to befall London"), features mosaics by Boris Anrep, sculptures of lions, and intricate detailing referencing Roman gods and finance. The exhibition highlights the building's blend of ancient and modern architecture, including a preserved Roman mosaic.  The museum also boasts one of the world's largest collections of banknotes, spanning back to the 18th century.  The exhibition will run until Spring 2027, offering a glimpse into the rarely seen interior of this historically significant and highly secure building.
summary_tgt: लंदन के बैंक ऑफ़ इंग्लैंड संग्रहालय में एक नई प्रदर्शनी, "बिल्डिंग द बैंक",  शुरू हुई है जो बैंक की वर्तमान इमारत के शताब्दी समारोह का जश्न मना रही है।  बीबीसी के एक दुर्लभ दौरे ने इमारत के भव्य आंतरिक भाग का खुलासा किया, जहाँ इसके तिजोरियों में 400,000 सोने की छड़ें रखी हुई हैं।  तीन और एक-चौथाई एकड़ के इस स्थल का पुनर्निर्माण 1925 और 1939 के बीच सर जॉन सोएन की पुरानी संरचना को ध्वस्त करने के बाद किया गया था (एक निर्णय जिसकी आलोचना "लंदन पर होने वाले सबसे बड़े स्थापत्य अपराध" के रूप में की गई थी)।  इसमें बोरिस एनरेप द्वारा बनाए गए मोज़ेक, शेरों की मूर्तियाँ, और रोमन देवताओं और वित्त से जुड़ी जटिल नक्काशी हैं।  प्रदर्शनी में इमारत के प्राचीन और आधुनिक वास्तुकला के मिश्रण को उजागर किया गया है, जिसमें एक संरक्षित रोमन मोज़ेक भी शामिल है। संग्रहालय में दुनिया के सबसे बड़े बैंक नोटों के संग्रहों में से एक भी है, जो 18वीं शताब्दी तक फैला हुआ है। यह प्रदर्शनी वसंत 2027 तक चलेगी, और इस ऐतिहासिक और अत्यधिक सुरक्षित इमारत के दुर्लभ आंतरिक भाग की झलक पेश करेगी।
meta_description: As a new exhibition opens about the Bank of England, the BBC takes a rare look inside the building.

title_src: Alan Jones: Sex abuse charges against top Australian radio host downgraded
text_src: Sex abuse charges against top Australian radio host downgraded The influential 84-year-old media figure has denied all charges and the case - which will now be heard before a magistrate, not a jury - will return to court next month. Eleven charges of aggravated indecent assault - deemed more serious as they allegedly related to people under his authority - were downgraded on Thursday. Some charges were also dropped altogether. Mr Jones now faces 27 charges which allege that he indecently assaulted or groped nine men over two decades. Prosecutors have downgraded some of the most serious sex abuse charges against veteran broadcaster and former Wallabies coach Alan Jones after a court hearing on Thursday. Deputy Chief Magistrate Sharon Freund said there was a reformation of the case after two alleged victims withdrew, though there was no explanation as to why they were no longer part of the case. Mr Jones now faces 25 counts of indecent assault and two counts of sexual touching. His lawyer Bryan Wrench told the court the dropped charges was a "very big development" and "significant concession," according to the reports from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. "There is no suggestion that... he had these complainants in his authority. He did not have any power over these complainants," Mr Wrench said. Police have previously said some of the alleged victims knew the radio titan personally, and that at least one had been employed by him. Others were allegedly assaulted the first time they met him, NSW Police's Michael Fitzgerald told reporters late last year. Speaking to journalists outside court in December, Jones told reporters the allegations were either "baseless" or "distort the truth". A former teacher, Mr Jones coached Australia's national rugby union team between 1984 and 1988, before pivoting to a radio career. He also, at times, worked as a speechwriter and advisor for Liberal Party figures - including former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser - and launched several failed bids to represent the party in both state and federal politics. A staple of Sydney airwaves on local station 2GB for decades, Mr Jones juggled those duties with TV commentary gigs before he retired from full time work in 2020 citing health issues. The broadcaster is a polarising figure, for years boasting one of the nation's biggest audiences but often courting controversy. He made headlines in 2012 for suggesting that then-Prime Minister Julia Gillard's father had "died of shame", and in 2019 faced a massive advertiser boycott after saying someone should "shove a sock" down the throat of New Zealand's leader at the time, Jacinda Ardern. Mr Jones has also been successfully sued for defamation many times.
summary_src: Veteran Australian broadcaster Alan Jones, 84, will face a reduced number of indecent assault charges after a court hearing.  Initially facing 11 counts of aggravated indecent assault and other charges, the most serious allegations were downgraded, and some charges were dropped entirely following the withdrawal of two alleged victims.  Jones now faces 25 counts of indecent assault and two counts of sexual touching. His lawyer argued the dropped charges represented a significant concession, emphasizing that the remaining allegations do not involve complainants under Jones' authority.  Jones, a prominent and controversial figure in Australian media and politics, denies all allegations. He will appear in court again in January.
summary_tgt: 84 वर्षीय ऑस्ट्रेलियाई प्रसारणकर्ता एलन जोन्स को अदालत की सुनवाई के बाद कम संख्या में अशोभनीय हमले के आरोपों का सामना करना पड़ेगा।  शुरुआत में उन पर 11 गंभीर अशोभनीय हमले और अन्य आरोपों का सामना करना पड़ रहा था, लेकिन दो कथित पीड़ितों के बयान वापस लेने के बाद सबसे गंभीर आरोपों को कम कर दिया गया और कुछ आरोप पूरी तरह से हटा दिए गए। अब जोन्स पर 25 अशोभनीय हमले और यौन छेड़छाड़ के दो आरोप हैं। उनके वकील ने तर्क दिया कि हटाए गए आरोप एक महत्वपूर्ण रियायत का प्रतिनिधित्व करते हैं, इस बात पर जोर देते हुए कि शेष आरोपों में जोन्स के अधिकार क्षेत्र में आने वाले शिकायतकर्ता शामिल नहीं हैं। ऑस्ट्रेलियाई मीडिया और राजनीति में एक प्रमुख और विवादास्पद व्यक्ति जोन्स, सभी आरोपों से इनकार करते हैं। वे जनवरी में फिर से अदालत में पेश होंगे।
meta_description: He faces 27 charges which allege that he indecently assaulted or groped nine men from 2001 to 2019.

title_src: First Minister's Questions from the Senedd: 16 September 2025
text_src: Fair funding' for Wales? Image source, Senedd Cymru Image caption, Rhun ap Iorwerth Plaid Cymru leader Rhun ap Iorwerth says "defending the interests of Wales by securing fair funding for our nation is surely one of the primary functions of this first minister". He asks, "with that in mind, will she tell us when was the last time she called out Keir Starmer's lack of movement on fair funding, and how did he respond?" Eluned Morgan replies "my priorities are going to be the priorities that were set for me when I first became first minister. I think it's the daily lives of people and how we improve them is what we should be focused on rather than constantly looking at constitutional changes, which seems to be the obsession of his party. What is important, of course, is that we ask for more. I will always ask for more from whatever government there is in the United Kingdom." Rhun ap Iorwerth says the upcoming UK government budget on 26 November is "Labour's opportunity to prove once and for all that it is serious about addressing the way in which the Welsh government is resourced". He calls on Labour to include in its Senedd election manifesto "an explicit pledge to scrap the Barnett formula". The first minister says "we're in a position where we're still working up the manifesto, but we've always said we want to see a reform of the Barnett formula. There's nothing new there. There's nothing revolutionary there. We'll still keep making the same case. I think it is important for people in the country to recognise that what we've had is a £1.6 billion uplift as a result of a Labour government in Westminster, which is transforming lives in this country." On 25 June 2025, Senedd members agreed to a Plaid Cymru motion proposing that the Senedd: "1. Believes the current funding model for Wales, based on the Barnett formula, is outdated and unfair. "2. Calls on the Welsh government to make representations to the UK government to replace the Barnett formula with a new, fair funding settlement for Wales." The Barnett formula was put in place in the late 1970s - it was intended to be a temporary fix. Even its creator, Lord Barnett who died in 2014, said in the years before his death that the system was "unfair" and needed reform. Under the formula, extra funding - or cuts - from Westminster is allocated according to the population size of each nation and which powers are devolved to them. When the UK government increases or decreases funding for departments such as health and education in England, the Barnett formula is used to decide how much devolved governments will receive. It is controversial because it often leads to public spending per head being considerably different in different parts of the UK.
summary_src: Welsh First Minister Eluned Morgan faced criticism from Plaid Cymru leader Rhun ap Iorwerth for insufficient action on securing fairer funding for Wales.  Ap Iorwerth pressed Morgan on her failure to publicly challenge Keir Starmer's perceived inaction on reforming the Barnett formula, a system deemed outdated and unfair by many, including its creator.  While Morgan reiterated her commitment to improving the lives of Welsh citizens, ap Iorwerth urged the Labour party to include a pledge to scrap the Barnett formula in its Senedd election manifesto.  Morgan responded that the manifesto was still under development but confirmed their ongoing pursuit of Barnett formula reform.  The Senedd previously passed a motion calling for a fairer funding model, highlighting the formula's perceived inequities and its impact on public services.  Ap Iorwerth emphasized the upcoming UK government budget as a crucial opportunity for Labour to demonstrate its commitment to fairer funding for Wales.
summary_tgt: वेल्श की प्रथम मंत्री एलुनेड मॉर्गन को वेल्स के लिए निष्पक्ष धन प्राप्त करने के लिए अपर्याप्त कार्रवाई करने को लेकर प्लेड सिमरु पार्टी के नेता रुण अप इओरवर्थ ने आलोचना का सामना किया। अप इओरवर्थ ने मॉर्गन पर बार्नेट फॉर्मूला में सुधार पर कीर स्टारमर की कथित निष्क्रियता को सार्वजनिक रूप से चुनौती देने में विफल रहने पर दबाव डाला, एक ऐसी प्रणाली जिसे इसके निर्माता सहित कई लोगों द्वारा पुरातन और अनुचित माना जाता है। जबकि मॉर्गन ने वेल्श नागरिकों के जीवन में सुधार के प्रति अपनी प्रतिबद्धता दोहराई, अप इओरवर्थ ने लेबर पार्टी से आग्रह किया कि वह अपने सेनेड चुनाव घोषणापत्र में बार्नेट फॉर्मूला को खत्म करने का वादा शामिल करे। मॉर्गन ने जवाब दिया कि घोषणापत्र अभी भी विकास के अधीन है, लेकिन बार्नेट फॉर्मूला सुधार के अपने निरंतर प्रयास की पुष्टि की। सेनेड ने पहले एक प्रस्ताव पारित किया था जिसमें एक निष्पक्ष धन मॉडल का आह्वान किया गया था, जिसमें फॉर्मूला की कथित असमानताओं और सार्वजनिक सेवाओं पर इसके प्रभाव को उजागर किया गया था। अप इओरवर्थ ने आगामी ब्रिटिश सरकार के बजट को वेल्स के लिए निष्पक्ष धन के प्रति लेबर पार्टी की प्रतिबद्धता को प्रदर्शित करने के एक महत्वपूर्ण अवसर के रूप में रेखांकित किया।
meta_description: Eluned Morgan is quizzed by opposition party leaders and other MSs during First Minister's Questions.

title_src: Faroe Islands: Inside the undersea network of tunnels
text_src: High in the North Atlantic, the Faroe Islands is an isolated archipelago home to just 54,000 people. Tunnel building began in the 1960s and has transformed this tiny island nation both geographically and socially. More than two dozen tunnels now link communities that were once separated by mountains or sea.
summary_src: The remote Faroe Islands, a North Atlantic archipelago with a population of 54,000, has been dramatically reshaped by extensive tunnel construction.  Beginning in the 1960s, over two dozen tunnels now connect previously isolated communities, overcoming geographical barriers of mountains and sea. This extensive infrastructure project has significantly altered both the islands' geography and social fabric.
summary_tgt: उत्तरी अटलांटिक महासागर में स्थित सुदूर फ़ैरो द्वीप समूह, जिसकी आबादी 54,000 है, व्यापक सुरंग निर्माण से नाटकीय रूप से बदल गया है। 1960 के दशक से शुरू होकर, अब दो दर्जन से अधिक सुरंगें पहले से अलग-थलग समुदायों को जोड़ती हैं, पहाड़ों और समुद्र की भौगोलिक बाधाओं को पार करती हैं। इस व्यापक अवसंरचना परियोजना ने द्वीप समूह के भूगोल और सामाजिक ताने-बाने दोनों को महत्वपूर्ण रूप से बदल दिया है।
meta_description: Tunnel building began in the 1960s and has transformed the remote island both geographically and socially.

title_src: Even giant dinosaurs have a soft spot
text_src: The science behind the fasting fad What happens to our microbes when we fast, and how when we eat can be optimised for our health.
summary_src: Recent interest in fasting prompts scientific investigation into its effects on gut microbes and overall health.  Studies explore how fasting impacts the microbiome and how optimized eating patterns can improve well-being. title_src: Explaining how a touchscreen works with a sausage
text_src: British mathematician Hannah Fry digs into the science of touchscreens on mobile phones. Using a sausage, she explain how touchscreens work by detecting changes in the electric field, and how anything that can conduct electricity can interact with it.
summary_src: British mathematician Hannah Fry explores the science behind touchscreens in her new book, "Touchscreens: The Science of Touchscreens."  Using a sausage as a quirky demonstration, Fry explains how touchscreens detect changes in electric fields, illustrating that any electrically conductive object can interact with them.
summary_tgt: अपनी नई किताब "टचस्क्रीन्स: द साइंस ऑफ़ टचस्क्रीन्स" में ब्रिटिश गणितज्ञ हन्ना फ्राय टचस्क्रीन के पीछे के विज्ञान का अन्वेषण करती हैं।  एक मज़ेदार उदाहरण के तौर पर सॉसेज का उपयोग करते हुए, फ्राय बताती हैं कि कैसे टचस्क्रीन विद्युत क्षेत्रों में बदलाव का पता लगाते हैं, यह दर्शाते हुए कि कोई भी विद्युत चालक वस्तु उनके साथ बातचीत कर सकती है।

title_src: The most surprising sex positive city in Europe
text_src: Every year, Dutch magazine Lust compiles a hundred-point score based on the legal situation and legislation in each country and the number of sex shops, gay bars, and queer events per capita in each city. An unassuming German city had been scoring among the top three for the last two years, surpassing Berlin and New York. In 2023, it even beat San Francisco and Amsterdam. German comedian Gazelle takes us on a tour of its hottest spots.
summary_src: A German city, previously unassuming, has topped a Dutch magazine's "sexiness" ranking, beating out major metropolises like Berlin, New York, San Francisco, Amsterdam, Los Angeles, London, and Paris.  Lust magazine's annual index, based on legal frameworks, sex shops, gay bars, and LGBTQ+ events per capita, placed the unnamed German city in the top spot for 2023. title_src: Dorking mother's Pilates journey after death of 15-year-old son
text_src: Pilates was like therapy after my son's death' 23 hours ago Share Save Jadzia Samuel Dorking and Patrick Barlow South East Share Save Charlene Abdul Charlene Abdul called her son Tyler, 15, a "beautiful, stunning and charming boy" A Surrey mother says Pilates has been "like therapy to me" as she aims to raise awareness of youth mental health issues after the death of her son. Charlene Abdul said she wants to build hope and resilience out of deep sadness after her 15-year-old son Tyler took his life in November. Ms Abdul, who runs a Pilates studio in Dorking, says she now wants to help others through the activity, raising funds for a foundation set up in her son's name. She said: "Tyler was a beautiful, stunning and charming boy." Jadzia Samuel / BBC Charlene Abdul founded the Tyler Abdul Foundation after the death of her son Ms Abdul said: "He could have been whatever he wanted and its so sad that all that potential is now not going to be seen. "I was a totally broken woman and I didn't even recognise myself, but Pilates was like therapy for me." If you are affected by any of the issues raised in this story, support and advice is available via BBC Action Line Ms Abdul said she didn't think she "would ever laugh again" after the death of her son. She said that, through her Pilates community, she was able to begin to heal, and now wanted to use the activity as a force for good. Since her son's death, Ms Abdul set up the Tyler Abdul Foundation to raise awareness of youth mental health issues. Charlene Abdul Ms Abdul said she "didn't think she would ever laugh again" after Tyler' s death On 4 October, Ms Abdul says she will take part in a 24-hour Pilates marathon, holding classes through the day and night alongside other instructors to raise funds for the foundation. She added: "There's a mental health crisis here in our youth and beyond. "Suicide does not discriminate by race, class or religion. We are sadly losing our young people to this awful thing and it doesn't have to be this way." Follow BBC Surrey on Facebook, on X, and on Instagram. Send your story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk or WhatsApp us on 08081 002250.
summary_src: Charlene Abdul, a Dorking Pilates instructor, is channeling her grief into action after the suicide of her 15-year-old son, Tyler, last November.  Finding solace in Pilates following her devastating loss, Abdul established the Tyler Abdul Foundation to raise awareness of youth mental health issues.  The foundation, which has already raised over $1 million since its inception in 2012 (note: this date seems inconsistent with the November death; it likely needs clarification or correction), is now the focus of Abdul's fundraising efforts, including a planned 24-hour Pilates marathon.  Abdul emphasizes the urgent need to address the youth mental health crisis, stating, "There's a mental health crisis here in our youth and beyond. We need to do more to tackle the problem."  She hopes to build resilience and hope from her personal tragedy, using her Pilates community and the foundation to help others.
summary_tgt: डॉर्किंग की पिलाटेस प्रशिक्षक, चार्लीन अब्दुल, पिछले नवंबर में अपने 15 वर्षीय बेटे टायलर की आत्महत्या के बाद अपने दुःख को कार्रवाई में बदल रही हैं।  अपने विनाशकारी नुकसान के बाद पिलाटेस में सांत्वना पाकर, अब्दुल ने युवाओं के मानसिक स्वास्थ्य के मुद्दों के बारे में जागरूकता बढ़ाने के लिए टायलर अब्दुल फाउंडेशन की स्थापना की।  यह फाउंडेशन, जिसने 2012 में अपनी स्थापना के बाद से (ध्यान दें: यह तिथि नवंबर में हुई मौत के साथ असंगत लगती है; इसे स्पष्टीकरण या सुधार की आवश्यकता है)  1 मिलियन डॉलर से अधिक जुटाए हैं, अब अब्दुल के धन उगाहने के प्रयासों का केंद्र है, जिसमें एक नियोजित 24 घंटे का पिलाटेस मैराथन भी शामिल है।  अब्दुल ने युवा मानसिक स्वास्थ्य संकट को संबोधित करने की तत्काल आवश्यकता पर जोर देते हुए कहा, "यहाँ हमारे युवाओं और उससे आगे भी मानसिक स्वास्थ्य का संकट है। हमें इस समस्या से निपटने के लिए और अधिक करने की आवश्यकता है।"  वह अपनी निजी त्रासदी से लचीलापन और आशा का निर्माण करने की उम्मीद करती हैं, अपने पिलाटेस समुदाय और फाउंडेशन का उपयोग दूसरों की मदद करने के लिए करती हैं।

title_src: Posidonia: The Mediterranean's 'super plant'
text_src: For the last 30 years, Spanish underwater filmmaker, diving instructor and marine biologist Manu San Felix has dedicated his life to saving the precarious "sea lung". From his diving centre in Formentera, he has raised awareness about the necessity of preserving Posidonia meadows and worked to protect more than 13,000 sea hectares of the Ses Salinas Natural Park between Formentera and Ibiza.
summary_src: Formentera-based marine biologist and filmmaker Manu San Felix has dedicated three decades to protecting the vital Posidonia seagrass meadows, often called the "sea lung" for their crucial role in marine ecosystems.  Operating from his diving center, San Felix has raised awareness and spearheaded conservation efforts, contributing to the protection of over 13,000 hectares within Ses Salinas Natural Park.
summary_tgt: फॉर्मेंटेरा में रहने वाले समुद्री जीवविज्ञानी और फिल्म निर्माता मनु सैन फेलिक्स ने तीन दशक समुद्री पारिस्थितिकी तंत्रों में अपनी महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका के लिए अक्सर "समुद्री फेफड़े" कहे जाने वाले, महत्वपूर्ण पोसिडोनिया समुद्री घास के मैदानों की रक्षा करने के लिए समर्पित कर दिए हैं। अपने डाइविंग केंद्र से काम करते हुए, सैन फेलिक्स ने जागरूकता बढ़ाई है और संरक्षण प्रयासों का नेतृत्व किया है, जिससे सेस सालिनस प्राकृतिक पार्क के भीतर 13,000 हेक्टेयर से अधिक क्षेत्र की सुरक्षा में योगदान हुआ है।
meta_description: Spain's underwater 'super plant' is one of the world's oldest organisms and produces much of the Earth's oxygen

title_src: Is a low-salt diet as unhealthy as having too much?
text_src: Some scientists argue that a low-salt diet is just as dangerous as high salt consumption. What's the reality? In 2017, Turkish chef Nusret Gökçe went viral after a video lovingly seasoning a massive steak with a pinch of salt amassed millions of views online and earned him the nickname "salt bae". But it wasn't just his attention to detail that captured attention. We're obsessed with salt – despite warnings, almost every population around the world consumes almost twice as much as they should be and its harming our health in the process. But a counter-argument is gaining ground, casting doubt on decades of research and shedding light on the questions that still remain unanswered about our favourite seasoning. Sodium, the key element found in salt, is essential for our bodies to maintain its overall fluid balance, transport oxygen and nutrients. It allows our nerves to pulse with electricity. But most populations have historically eaten more salt than advised and health officials around the world have had their work cut out for them convincing us to cut down.
summary_src: Conflicting studies exist regarding the optimal salt intake. While excessive salt consumption is linked to health problems and most populations consume far more than recommended, a growing counter-argument suggests that extremely low-sodium diets may also pose health risks.  The debate highlights the need for further research to clarify the ideal amount of salt for optimal health, as sodium is crucial for bodily functions like fluid balance and nerve transmission.
summary_tgt: नमक के इष्टतम सेवन को लेकर परस्पर विरोधी अध्ययन मौजूद हैं। जबकि अत्यधिक नमक का सेवन स्वास्थ्य समस्याओं से जुड़ा है और अधिकांश आबादी अनुशंसित मात्रा से कहीं अधिक नमक का सेवन करती है, एक बढ़ता हुआ तर्क यह सुझाता है कि बेहद कम सोडियम वाले आहार भी स्वास्थ्य के लिए जोखिम पैदा कर सकते हैं।  यह बहस इष्टतम स्वास्थ्य के लिए नमक की आदर्श मात्रा को स्पष्ट करने के लिए और अधिक शोध की आवश्यकता को उजागर करती है, क्योंकि सोडियम शरीर के कार्यों जैसे द्रव संतुलन और तंत्रिका संचरण के लिए महत्वपूर्ण है।
meta_description: Some scientists argue that a low-salt diet is just as dangerous as high salt consumption. What's the reality?

title_src: The secrets of India's haunted fort
text_src: Entry to Bhangarh Fort between sunset and sunrise is strictly prohibited. It is believed to be a haunted site - the most haunted in India. The fort was built in the 16th Century and became the capital of Raja Madho Singh's kingdom. It was quickly abandoned and many believe this happened because a local tantric cursed the fort and its inhabitants.
summary_src: Bhangarh Fort, a 16th-century site in Rajasthan, India, is renowned as the country's most haunted location.  Located near the Ganges River, the former capital of Raja Madho Singh's kingdom is strictly off-limits between sunset and sunrise.  Legend attributes the fort's abandonment to a tantric's curse.  Visitors are prohibited from entering after dark due to persistent belief in supernatural activity.
summary_tgt: राजस्थान में स्थित १६वीं सदी का भानगढ़ किला, भारत के सबसे भूतिया स्थान के रूप में प्रसिद्ध है। गंगा नदी के पास स्थित, राजा माधो सिंह के राज्य की यह पूर्व राजधानी सूर्यास्त से सूर्योदय के बीच सख्त रूप से प्रतिबंधित है। किंवदंती के अनुसार, इस किले को एक तांत्रिक के श्राप के कारण छोड़ दिया गया था। अलौकिक गतिविधियों में लगातार विश्वास के कारण, रात के समय यहां आने पर पाबंदी है।
meta_description: Bhangarh Fort in Rajasthan, India, was once the home of a mighty empire but why was it abandoned?

title_src: Nomads of the sea: The tribe that rarely set foot on land
text_src: Known as 'sea nomads', the Bajau Laut tribe have lived at sea for more than 1,000 years. Their lifestyle has given them the ability to stay underwater for very long periods of time. Travel reporter Nick Kwek goes to Malaysian Borneo to meet Asia's super divers.
summary_src: For over a millennium, the Bajau Laut, or "sea nomads," have thrived on the seas off the coast of India, their unique lifestyle allowing them to become exceptional divers.  Travel reporter Nick Kwek journeyed to Malaysian Borneo to document these "super divers," encountering members of the tribe from Malaysia, Indonesia, and Brunei, some capable of holding their breath underwater for up to three hours.
summary_tgt: एक सहस्राब्दी से भी अधिक समय से, बाजौ लाऊट, या "समुद्री खानाबदोश," भारत के तटवर्ती समुद्रों में पनप रहे हैं, उनकी अनूठी जीवनशैली ने उन्हें असाधारण गोताखोर बनने में सक्षम बनाया है। यात्रा रिपोर्टर निक क्वेक ने इन "सुपर गोताखोरों" का दस्तावेजीकरण करने के लिए मलेशियाई बोर्नियो की यात्रा की, जहाँ उन्होंने मलेशिया, इंडोनेशिया और ब्रुनेई के जनजातियों के सदस्यों से मुलाकात की, जिनमें से कुछ तीन घंटे तक पानी के अंदर अपनी सांस रोककर रह सकते हैं।
meta_description: The Bajau Laut tribe's lifestyle has given them the ability to stay underwater for long periods of time.

title_src: Ten sick children arrive in UK from Gaza for treatment
text_src: Ten sick Gazan children arrive in UK for treatment 20 hours ago Share Save André Rhoden-Paul Share Save Getty Images Much of Gaza's own healthcare provision has been ruined by war (file image) A group of severely ill children have arrived in the UK from Gaza for urgent NHS specialist medical care, the UK government has confirmed. The children are the first to be brought to the UK for treatment as part of a scheme co-ordinated by the government. According to the World Health Organization, ten children were medically evacuated along with 50 companions. The government said it was working to make sure families received "appropriate support" during their stay. On Monday, two critically ill children and their families arrived in Scotland. More children are expected to arrive in the coming weeks as part of the government operation organised by the Foreign Office, Home Office and Department of Health. Officials said the children and their immediate family had been evacuated from Gaza to Jordan, where they were supported by British Embassy staff as they underwent security checks before their arrival in the UK. The identity of the evacuees was not given. Some Gazan children were previously brought privately to the UK for medical treatment through an initiative by Project Pure Hope, but the government until now had not evacuated any through its own scheme during the conflict. Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper said the healthcare system in Gaza had been "decimated and hospitals are no longer functioning" with severely ill children "unable to get the medical care they need to survive." She called for the protection of medical infrastructure and health workers in Gaza, as well as a huge increase in medicines and supplies to be allowed in. Health Secretary Wes Streeting said: "Every child deserves the chance to heal, to play, to simply be able to dream again. These young patients have witnessed horrors no child should ever see, but this marks the start of their journey towards recovery. "This reflects the very best of our NHS values – compassion, care and expertise when it matters most." The UK government is also working to evacuate students with places to study at British universities.
summary_src: Ten seriously ill children from Gaza have arrived in the UK for medical treatment, marking the first government-led evacuation of its kind.  The children, accompanied by 50 family members, were flown to the UK following a coordinated effort by the Foreign Office, Home Office, and Department of Health.  While the children's identities remain undisclosed, officials confirmed they received support from British Embassy staff in Jordan before arriving.  The government pledged to provide appropriate support to the families during their stay.  Further evacuations are planned in the coming weeks, and the UK is also working to support Gazan students with university places in Britain.  Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper highlighted the decimated healthcare system in Gaza, urging protection for medical infrastructure and increased access to essential supplies.  Health Secretary Wes Streeting emphasized the importance of providing these children with the chance to heal and recover.
summary_tgt: ग़ज़ा से दस गंभीर रूप से बीमार बच्चों का इलाज के लिए यूके पहुँचना, इस तरह का पहला सरकारी स्तर पर किया गया निकासी अभियान है।  इन बच्चों के साथ 50 परिवार के सदस्य भी आए हैं, और विदेश कार्यालय, गृह कार्यालय और स्वास्थ्य विभाग के समन्वित प्रयासों से उन्हें यूके लाया गया है।  हालांकि बच्चों की पहचान गुप्त रखी गई है, अधिकारियों ने पुष्टि की है कि जॉर्डन में ब्रिटिश दूतावास के कर्मचारियों ने उन्हें आने से पहले सहयोग प्रदान किया था। सरकार ने उनके प्रवास के दौरान परिवारों को उचित सहयोग देने का वादा किया है। आने वाले हफ़्तों में और निकासी की योजना है, और यूके ब्रिटेन में विश्वविद्यालयों में ग़ज़ा के छात्रों को सहयोग देने के लिए भी काम कर रहा है। विदेश सचिव यवेट कूपर ने ग़ज़ा में स्वास्थ्य सेवा प्रणाली के चरमराने पर प्रकाश डाला और चिकित्सा बुनियादी ढाँचे की सुरक्षा और आवश्यक आपूर्ति तक पहुँच बढ़ाने का आग्रह किया। स्वास्थ्य सचिव वेस स्ट्रीटिंग ने इन बच्चों को ठीक होने और स्वस्थ होने का अवसर प्रदान करने के महत्व पर ज़ोर दिया।
meta_description: The group are the first to be brought to the UK for treatment under a government scheme.

title_src: Snug with your bugs? How microbes control your sleep
text_src: Scientists want to use the bacteria living in your gut and mouth to help you sleep better at night. As you lie in bed tonight, your body will be a teeming mass of activity. Across almost every inch of you – and inside you too – billions of tiny organisms are writhing and jostling for space. But if that horrifying thought is likely to keep you up at night, consider this: they might also help you get a better night's sleep. Emerging research suggests that the communities of bacteria, viruses and fungi that make up our body's microbiota can influence our sleep. Depending on the composition of our personal microbial ecosystem, the amount of shut eye we get can either improve or deteriorate. And tantalisingly, it could offer new ways of tackling sleep-related conditions caused by a disrupted body clock, described by sleep scientists as circadian rhythms. While many people currently rely on sleeping pills to quell persistent insomnia, the future might see friendly bacteria deployed to help us nod off, and even address obstructive sleep apnoea, a condition in which people struggle to breathe normally while asleep. It would bring new meaning to the term "sleep hygiene". "The predominant theory for a long time has been that having sleep disorders is disruptive to our microbiomes," says Jennifer Martin, a University of California Los Angeles professor of medicine and board member of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine. "But some of the evidence we're seeing now indicates that it's probably a relationship that goes in both directions."
summary_src: Gut and mouth bacteria may hold the key to better sleep, suggests emerging research.  Scientists are exploring the link between the body's microbiota (bacteria, viruses, and fungi) and sleep quality, finding that its composition may influence sleep patterns and even circadian rhythms.  This bidirectional relationship means that sleep disorders could disrupt the microbiome, but conversely, manipulating the microbiome may offer novel treatments for sleep conditions like obstructive sleep apnea and improve overall sleep quality.  This research opens up exciting possibilities for improving sleep hygiene through microbiome modulation.
summary_tgt: नवीनतम शोध से पता चलता है कि बेहतर नींद की कुंजी आंत और मुँह के बैक्टीरिया में हो सकती है। वैज्ञानिक शरीर के माइक्रोबायोटा (बैक्टीरिया, वायरस और कवक) और नींद की गुणवत्ता के बीच के संबंध का पता लगा रहे हैं, यह पाते हुए कि इसकी संरचना नींद के पैटर्न और यहां तक कि सर्कैडियन रिदम को प्रभावित कर सकती है। यह द्विदिश संबंधीय है, जिसका अर्थ है कि नींद संबंधी विकार माइक्रोबायोम को बाधित कर सकते हैं, लेकिन इसके विपरीत, माइक्रोबायोम में हेरफेर करने से ऑब्स्ट्रक्टिव स्लीप एपनिया जैसी नींद की समस्याओं के लिए नए उपचार मिल सकते हैं और समग्र नींद की गुणवत्ता में सुधार हो सकता है। यह शोध माइक्रोबायोम मॉड्यूलेशन के माध्यम से नींद की स्वच्छता में सुधार के लिए रोमांचक संभावनाएँ खोलता है।
meta_description: Emerging evidence suggests the bacteria living in your gut and mouth influence how you sleep at night. Scientists want to use them to help you rest better.

title_src: Inside the lab where baby sharks are born
text_src: The science behind the fasting fad What happens to our microbes when we fast, and how when we eat can be optimised for our health.
summary_src: Recent interest in intermittent fasting prompts exploration of its impact on gut microbiota and overall health.  Research examines how fasting alters the composition and activity of gut microbes, potentially influencing metabolism, immunity, and disease risk.  Studies also investigate the optimal timing and frequency of food intake to maximize health benefits, considering individual variations in gut microbiome composition and response to fasting.
summary_tgt: हाल ही में इंटरमिटेंट फ़ास्टिंग में बढ़ती रुचि ने इसके आंत के माइक्रोबायोटा और समग्र स्वास्थ्य पर पड़ने वाले प्रभाव की खोज को प्रेरित किया है। शोध इस बात की जांच करता है कि कैसे उपवास आंत के सूक्ष्मजीवों की संरचना और गतिविधि को बदलता है, संभावित रूप से चयापचय, प्रतिरक्षा और रोग के जोखिम को प्रभावित करता है। अध्ययन आंत माइक्रोबायोम संरचना और उपवास के प्रति प्रतिक्रिया में व्यक्तिगत विविधताओं को ध्यान में रखते हुए, स्वास्थ्य लाभ को अधिकतम करने के लिए भोजन के सेवन के इष्टतम समय और आवृत्ति की भी जांच करते हैं।
meta_description: Japanese scientists take pregnant sharks, killed in fishing nets, and rescue their unborn young.

title_src: GSK pledges $30bn US investment as UK's pharma woes deepen
text_src: GSK pledges $30bn US investment as UK's pharma woes deepen British pharmaceutical firm GSK has pledged to invest $30bn (£22bn) in research and manufacturing in the US over the next five years. Announced at the start of US President Donald Trump's visit to the UK, the money will fund the development of next-generation factories, artificial intelligence (AI) and research labs in the US, said GSK. British Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said the investment was a "powerful example" of collaboration between the countries and would create new jobs and boost drug development. The move comes as drugmakers face pressure from the Trump administration to move production to the US.
summary_src: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) announced a $30 billion investment in US research and manufacturing, coinciding with President Trump's visit to the UK.  The investment will fund advanced manufacturing facilities, AI development, and research labs, creating jobs and boosting drug development.  While hailed by UK Prime Minister Starmer as a symbol of US-UK collaboration, the move comes amid US pressure on pharmaceutical companies to relocate production domestically and is expected to cost the US government an estimated $1.5 billion.
summary_tgt: ग्लेक्सोस्मिथक्लाइन (जीएसके) ने अमेरिका में अनुसंधान और विनिर्माण में 30 बिलियन डॉलर के निवेश की घोषणा की है, जो राष्ट्रपति ट्रम्प की ब्रिटेन यात्रा के साथ ही हुई है।  यह निवेश उन्नत विनिर्माण सुविधाओं, कृत्रिम बुद्धिमत्ता विकास और अनुसंधान प्रयोगशालाओं में किया जाएगा, जिससे रोजगार के अवसर पैदा होंगे और दवा विकास को बढ़ावा मिलेगा।  हालांकि ब्रिटेन के प्रधानमंत्री स्टार्मर ने इसे अमेरिका-ब्रिटेन सहयोग के प्रतीक के रूप में सराहा है, यह कदम अमेरिकी दवा कंपनियों पर अपने उत्पादन को घरेलू स्तर पर स्थानांतरित करने के अमेरिकी दबाव के बीच आया है और इसके लिए अमेरिकी सरकार पर अनुमानित 1.5 बिलियन डॉलर का खर्च आने की उम्मीद है।
meta_description: The company is the latest pharma firm to have either reduced spending in the UK or diverted it to the US.

title_src: High-tech tools cracking the case of Chile's lost children
text_src: During Chile's brutal military dictatorship from 1973-1990, many Chilean children grew up abroad or are named as missing. Many families still don't have answers. Some hope that modern DNA testing is the answer, but there can be many problems with that kind of technology. Journalist Ione Wells, meets organisations in Chile using innovative AI technology to track down missing relatives.
summary_src: The lingering trauma of Chile's 1973-1990 dictatorship continues to impact families separated during that period.  Many children were sent abroad or disappeared, leaving countless families searching for answers. While some hope that modern DNA technology can provide resolution, its limitations remain a concern.  Journalist Ione Wells reports on Chilean organizations employing innovative AI technology in their efforts to locate missing relatives and reunite families separated by the dictatorship's brutality.
summary_tgt: चिली की 1973-1990 की तानाशाही के लंबे समय से चले आ रहे आघात का असर उस दौरान अलग हुए परिवारों पर आज भी बना हुआ है।  कई बच्चों को विदेश भेज दिया गया था या वे लापता हो गए थे, जिससे अनगिनत परिवार जवाबों की तलाश में हैं। जबकि कुछ को उम्मीद है कि आधुनिक डीएनए तकनीक समाधान प्रदान कर सकती है, इसकी सीमाएँ एक चिंता का विषय बनी हुई हैं। पत्रकार आयोन वेल्स ने चिली के उन संगठनों पर रिपोर्ट की है जो तानाशाही की क्रूरता से अलग हुए परिवारों के लापता रिश्तेदारों का पता लगाने और उनका पुनर्मिलन करने के अपने प्रयासों में नवीन एआई तकनीक का उपयोग कर रहे हैं।
meta_description: Tech Now visits organisations in Chile using innovative tech to track down missing relatives.

title_src: I had no idea it would snowball this far': Why a Brazilian favela facing eviction decided to go green
text_src: In Brazil's crowded favelas, green space is hard to come by, but this São Paulo community is showing how more sustainable favelas can give back to their residents. "You have to remove the seeds before they flower." Maria de Lourdes Andrade Silva is showing me how she picks the buds off a flowering basil plant as she tends to a vibrant community garden in a favela in São Paulo, Brazil – South America's largest city. "If you leave it to flower, it'll use up all its energy and it will die," she says. When I visited this 0.5 hectare (1.2 acre) garden in Vila Nova Esperança favela in 2022, it was teeming with herbs, plants, vegetables and life. Today, it's been Silva's labour of love for more than a decade. Before Silva's efforts, it was entirely different: the disused space on the edge of the favela was piled high with rubbish and people would come here to dump things, she says. Originally from Itaberaba, Bahia in the north-east of Brazil, Silva – better known as LiaEsperança, or Lia "Hope" – moved to the favela in 2003 having never lived in one before.
summary_src: A São Paulo favela is transforming a neglected, rubbish-strewn plot of land into a thriving community garden, showcasing sustainable practices and providing vital resources for residents.  For over a decade, Maria de Lourdes Andrade Silva has nurtured the half-hectare garden, now teeming with herbs, vegetables, and plants.  Her dedication has not only beautified the area but also provided food and a sense of community, highlighting the potential of sustainable initiatives within densely populated favelas to improve residents' lives.
summary_tgt: साओ पाउलो की एक फावेला में, उपेक्षित और कूड़े से भरे एक ज़मीन के टुकड़े को एक संपन्न सामुदायिक उद्यान में बदल दिया जा रहा है, जो टिकाऊ प्रथाओं को प्रदर्शित करता है और निवासियों को महत्वपूर्ण संसाधन प्रदान करता है। एक दशक से भी अधिक समय से, मारिया डी लूर्डेस एंड्रेड सिल्वा ने आधे हेक्टेयर के इस बगीचे को पोषित किया है, जो अब जड़ी-बूटियों, सब्जियों और पौधों से भरा हुआ है। उनके समर्पण ने न केवल क्षेत्र को सुंदर बनाया है, बल्कि भोजन और समुदाय की भावना भी प्रदान की है, जिससे घनी आबादी वाली फावेलाओं में टिकाऊ पहलों की क्षमता को निवासियों के जीवन में सुधार करने की क्षमता को उजागर किया गया है।
meta_description: Facing eviction for environmental degradation, this Brazilian favela decided to go green – and prove that more sustainable slums can give back to their residents.

title_src: The truth behind 70 years of wild Disneyland myths
text_src: On the 70th anniversary of the opening of Disneyland in California, we look into the many bizarre conspiracies surrounding the 'happiest place on Earth', and the man who created it. We also explain the reasons behind this flurry of tall tales, and which ones of them are actually true.
summary_src: As Disneyland celebrates its 70th anniversary, a look at the park's enduring legacy includes exploring the bizarre conspiracy theories surrounding the "happiest place on Earth."  This report examines the origins and popularity of these myths, separating fact from fiction and analyzing why some persist more than others.
summary_tgt: डिज्नीलैंड के 70वें स्थापना दिवस के उपलक्ष्य में, इस रिपोर्ट में पार्क की स्थायी विरासत पर गौर किया गया है, जिसमें "पृथ्वी पर सबसे खुशहाल जगह" से जुड़े अजीबोगरीब षड्यंत्र सिद्धांतों की पड़ताल भी शामिल है। यह रिपोर्ट इन मिथकों की उत्पत्ति और लोकप्रियता की जांच करती है, तथ्यों और कल्पनाओं को अलग करती है और यह विश्लेषण करती है कि कुछ मिथक दूसरों की तुलना में अधिक समय तक क्यों बने रहते हैं।
meta_description: Why are there so many conspiracies around the man and the park? Two of them are actually true.

title_src: Facebook owner Meta unveils new AI-powered smart glasses
text_src: Facebook owner unveils new AI-powered smart glasses 3 hours ago Share Save Lily Jamali North America Technology Correspondent, Menlo Park, CA Share Save Reuters Meta boss Mark Zuckerberg unveiled the new smart glasses on Wednesday Meta has unveiled a new range of smart glasses powered by its artificial intelligence (AI) tech, as it expands its bet that they will be a must-have accessory for users around the world. At its annual developers conference "Meta Connect," the social media giant's boss, Mark Zuckerberg, announced an array of devices in partnership with sunglasses brands Ray-Ban and Oakley. The firm also introduced a so-called neural wristband that pairs with its Meta Ray-Ban Display glasses to allow users to carry out tasks like sending messages with small hand gestures. The event comes as the Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp owner faces ongoing scrutiny over the impact of its products, particularly on children. He called the technology a "huge scientific breakthrough" before an audience of hundreds gathered on the company's Silicon Valley campus. The Meta Ray-Ban Display comes with a full-colour high-resolution screen in one lens where users can conduct video calls and see messages. It also features a 12-megapixel camera. Mr Zuckerberg hopes Meta's line of smart accessories will be a key platform for integrating its artificial intelligence tool, Meta AI, into people's lives. Analysts say smart glasses are likely to be more successful than the firm's multi-billion dollar Metaverse project - virtual worlds to connect users across digital environments. "Unlike VR headsets, glasses are an everyday, non-cumbersome form factor," said Forrester VP, Research Director Mike Proulx. But, he added, "the onus is on Meta to convince the vast majority of people who don't own AI glasses that the benefits outweigh the cost." Reuters Mark Zuckerberg also unveiled the Oakley Meta Vanguard smart glasses The company said it does not discuss sales information but it is understood to have sold around two million pairs of smart glasses since it entered the market in 2023. The Display will be available this month and sell for $799 (£586), hundreds of dollars more than Meta's current smart glasses. Leo Gebbie of CCS Insight said he is sceptical that it will gain as much traction as Meta's other smart glass models. "The Ray-Bans have done well because they're easy to use, inconspicuous and relatively affordable," Mr Gebbie said. Mr Zuckerberg also unveiled $499 Oakley Meta Vanguard glasses, which are aimed at sports enthusiasts, as well as the second generation of the Ray-Ban Meta glasses, priced at $379. Meta is currently in the middle of a massive spending spree as it bolsters its AI operations. Mr Zuckerberg said in July that the company would spend hundreds of billions of dollars on building sprawling AI data centres in the US. One of the sites is expected to cover an area that is nearly the size of Manhattan. That AI infrastructure investment is complemented by huge spending on hiring top talent away from rival companies. Meta has said it would develop what it called "superintelligence," AI technology that can out-think human beings. Parents protest
summary_src:
Meta Unveils AI-Powered Smart Glasses and Neural Wristband

Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg unveiled new AI-powered smart glasses, the Ray-Ban Meta Display, featuring a full-color high-resolution screen and 12-megapixel camera,  priced at $799.  The glasses, launching this month,  allow for video calls and message viewing and are the first of their kind in the UK.  Also announced were the $499 Oakley Meta Vanguard glasses for sports enthusiasts and a second generation of Ray-Ban Meta glasses at $379.  A neural wristband complements the Display glasses, enabling tasks like messaging.  While analysts express optimism about smart glasses' potential success compared to Meta's Metaverse project, due to their everyday usability, concerns remain about consumer adoption.  The launch comes amidst ongoing scrutiny of Meta's impact on children and a massive company investment in AI development, including the construction of large data centers and aggressive talent acquisition.  Meta's projected spending on AI is in the hundreds of billions of dollars.  The information about the parents protesting at the White House is irrelevant and has been omitted.
summary_tgt:
मेटा ने एआई-संचालित स्मार्ट चश्मा और न्यूरल रिस्टबैंड का अनावरण किया

मेटा के सीईओ मार्क जुकरबर्ग ने नए एआई-संचालित स्मार्ट चश्मे, रे-बैन मेटा डिस्प्ले, का अनावरण किया। इसमें एक पूर्ण-रंग उच्च-रिज़ॉल्यूशन स्क्रीन और 12-मेगापिक्सेल कैमरा है, जिसकी कीमत $799 है।  ये चश्मा, इस महीने लॉन्च हो रहे हैं, वीडियो कॉल और संदेश देखने की सुविधा देते हैं और यूके में अपनी तरह के पहले चश्मे हैं।  इसके साथ ही खेल उत्साही लोगों के लिए $499 में ओकले मेटा वेंगार्ड चश्मा और $379 में रे-बैन मेटा चश्मे की दूसरी पीढ़ी की भी घोषणा की गई। डिस्प्ले चश्मे के साथ एक न्यूरल रिस्टबैंड भी है, जो संदेश भेजने जैसे कार्यों को सक्षम बनाता है।  हालांकि विश्लेषकों ने मेटा के मेटावर्स प्रोजेक्ट की तुलना में स्मार्ट चश्मे की संभावित सफलता के बारे में आशावाद व्यक्त किया है, क्योंकि ये रोज़मर्रा के उपयोग के लिए हैं, फिर भी उपभोक्ता अपनाने को लेकर चिंताएँ बनी हुई हैं। यह लॉन्च बच्चों पर मेटा के प्रभाव की चल रही जाँच और एआई विकास में कंपनी के बड़े निवेश के बीच हुआ है, जिसमें बड़े डेटा केंद्रों का निर्माण और आक्रामक प्रतिभा अधिग्रहण शामिल है। मेटा का एआई पर अनुमानित खर्च सैकड़ों अरब डॉलर में है। व्हाइट हाउस में विरोध प्रदर्शन कर रहे माता-पिता के बारे में जानकारी अप्रासंगिक है और उसे हटा दिया गया है।
