title_src: I have no relationship with Trump, Brazil's President Lula tells BBC
text_src: I have no relationship with Trump, Brazil's President Lula tells BBC 10 hours ago Share Save Ione Wells South America correspondent in Brasília and Leandro Prazeres BBC News Brasil Share Save Watch: Brazil's Lula talks Trump, US tariffs and oil in BBC interview Brazil's President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has told the BBC in an exclusive interview that he has "no relationship" with US President Donald Trump. Lula has frequently criticised Trump, but this is the clearest signal yet that he thinks communication between him and his US counterpart is now broken. Even though the US has a trade surplus with Brazil, Donald Trump imposed 50% tariffs on Brazilian goods in July, citing the trial on coup charges of Brazil's right-wing former president Jair Bolsonaro as a trigger. Lula described the tariffs as "eminently political" and said US consumers would be facing higher prices for Brazilian goods as a result. The tariffs imposed by Trump have hit Brazilian exports to the US, like coffee and beef, which Lula said would become more expensive: "The American people will pay for the mistakes President Trump is incurring in his relationship with Brazil." The two leaders have never spoken directly to each other. When pushed on why he had not just tried to pick up the phone or form a relationship, President Lula said: "I never tried that call because he never wanted to have a conversation." Trump has previously said that Lula can "call him anytime." But Lula insisted that members of the Trump Administration "do not want to talk". He told the BBC that he had found out about the US tariffs from Brazilian newspapers. Referring to Trump, he said that the US president "didn't communicate in a civilised manner. He just published them [the tariffs] on his portal - on social media." When asked how he would describe his relationship with his US counterpart he simply said: "There's no relationship." 'He's not emperor of the world!' Lula said that his poor relations with the US leader were the exception, listing how he had built relationships with former US presidents, UK prime ministers, the EU, China, Ukraine, Venezuela and "all the countries in the world". The Brazilian president attended the World War Two anniversary celebrations in Russia this year and has not cut ties with President Putin. Asked who he had a better relationship with - Trump or Putin - he defended his ties to the latter, saying they had formed them when they had both been presidents "in previous times". "I don't have a relationship with Trump because when Trump was elected the first time, I wasn't president. His relationship is with Bolsonaro, not Brazil," Lula responded. He also said that if he passed Trump at next week's United Nations General assembly he would "greet him because I am a civilised citizen", but added that Trump may be "president of the United States, [but] he's not emperor of the world!". When approached for comment on Lula's criticism of Trump, a White House spokesperson referred the BBC to the US president's past public comments on Brazil. Lula said if the 6 January 2021 Capitol riot had happened in Brazil rather than in the US, Trump would have been put on trial Lula also spoke about his predecessor in office, Jair Bolsonaro, who was convicted last week. A 4-1 majority of justices on Brazil's Supreme Court found the ex-president guilty of plotting a coup after losing the election to Lula and sentenced him to 27 years in prison. Lula told the BBC that Bolsonaro and his co-conspirators had "hurt the country, attempted a coup, and plotted my death". Referring to the appeals Bolsonaro's lawyers said they would lodge, Lula said that he hoped that Bolsonaro would continue "to present his defence" but that "for now he is guilty". He also criticised Trump for "inventing untruths" by claiming Bolsonaro was being persecuted and denouncing what the US leader said was a lack of democracy in Brazil. Lula also told the BBC that if the 6 January 2021 Capitol riot had happened in Brazil rather than in the US, Trump would have been put on trial. In the wide-ranging BBC interview, he also advocated for reform of the United Nations. He criticised the fact that five countries - the permanent members of the UN Security Council - have the power to veto decisions and argued that this tilted the balance in favour of those who won World War Two, excluding nations representing billions of people like Brazil, Germany, India, Japan, as well as African countries. The result, he said, was that the UN didn't "have the strength to solve conflicts" and the five permanent members made "unilateral" decisions about going to war. Getty Images Lula travelled to Moscow for World War Two victory celebrations in May He defended his continued alliances with Russia and China – two nations where unfair elections and human rights abuses have been documented – while calling for a more "democratic" UN. Pressed on Brazil's continuing purchases of Russian oil while Russia wages war in Ukraine, he said Brazil was one of the first countries to condemn Russia's occupation of Ukraine and that "Brazil doesn't finance Russia, we buy oil from Russia because we need to buy oil just like China, India, the UK or the US needs to buy oil". He said that if the UN was "functioning" then neither the Ukraine war nor the Gaza war - which he described as "not a war" but a "genocide" - would have happened.
summary_src: Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva told the BBC there is "no relationship" between himself and US President Donald Trump, despite Trump's claims of openness to communication.  Lula criticized Trump's imposition of 50% tariffs on Brazilian goods, calling them "eminently political" and arguing they harm US consumers.  He attributed the lack of communication to Trump's unwillingness to engage, rejecting suggestions he should have initiated contact.  Lula contrasted this with his relationships with other world leaders, noting his continued ties with Russia, while simultaneously condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine and calling for UN reform.  He further commented on the conviction of his predecessor, Jair Bolsonaro, for coup plotting, criticizing Trump's defense of Bolsonaro and suggesting that similar actions in Brazil would have resulted in Trump's trial.  Lula stated that while he would greet Trump at the UN General Assembly, he does not consider him "emperor of the world."
summary_tgt: ब्राज़ील के राष्ट्रपति लुइज़ इनासियो लूला दा सिल्वा ने बीबीसी को बताया कि उनके और अमेरिकी राष्ट्रपति डोनाल्ड ट्रम्प के बीच "कोई संबंध नहीं" है, भले ही ट्रम्प ने संवाद के लिए खुलेपन का दावा किया हो। लूला ने ब्राज़ीलियाई सामानों पर 50% टैरिफ़ लगाने की ट्रम्प की आलोचना करते हुए इसे "पूर्णतः राजनीतिक" बताया और तर्क दिया कि इससे अमेरिकी उपभोक्ताओं को नुकसान होता है। उन्होंने संवाद की कमी का कारण ट्रम्प की संलग्न होने की अनिच्छा बताया और यह सुझाव खारिज कर दिया कि उन्हें संपर्क करना चाहिए था। लूला ने इसे अन्य विश्व नेताओं के साथ अपने संबंधों के विपरीत बताया, रूस के साथ अपने निरंतर संबंधों का उल्लेख करते हुए, साथ ही रूस के यूक्रेन पर आक्रमण की निंदा करते हुए और संयुक्त राष्ट्र सुधार का आह्वान करते हुए। उन्होंने अपने पूर्ववर्ती जायर बोल्सनारो की तख्तापलट की साज़िश के लिए हुई सज़ा पर भी टिप्पणी की, बोल्सनारो के बचाव में ट्रम्प की आलोचना की और सुझाव दिया कि ब्राज़ील में इसी तरह की कार्रवाइयों के परिणामस्वरूप ट्रम्प पर भी मुकदमा चलता। लूला ने कहा कि वह संयुक्त राष्ट्र महासभा में ट्रम्प का स्वागत करेंगे, लेकिन उन्हें "विश्व का सम्राट" नहीं मानते हैं।
meta_description: In an exclusive interview, Brazil's president says Trump is "not emperor of the world".

title_src: Norfolk museum worker denies stealing exhibits to sell at auction
text_src: Museum worker denies theft and fraud charges 13 hours ago Share Save Andrew Turner Share Save Andrew Turner/BBC Mr Harris has denied all charges and will face trial in September 2027 An employee accused of stealing exhibits from Norfolk Museums Service and selling them through auctions has pleaded not guilty to all charges. Stephen Harris, 67, of Hunter Avenue, Mattishall, faces one charge of theft, four counts of fraud and a single charge of converting stolen property. Mr Harris, who worked at the Gressenhall Museum near Dereham, appeared at King's Lynn Crown Court wearing a blue suit and red and white striped shirt. He faces trial in September 2027. Details of the exhibits were not mentioned in court. Recorder Justin Rouse KC said: "I'm sorry its so far into the future, its obviously a worrying matter for you." Andrew Turner/BBC The judge, Recorder Justin Rouse, apologised for the delay in the courts process having listed the trial in two years' time Charges listed in court alleged Mr Harris stole artefacts belonging to Norfolk Museums Service between 10 January and 4 August 2022. The fraud charge related to allegations that between 26 June and 17 July 2020 he made false representation, claiming he was the lawful owner of three exhibits he offered for sale. Three further counts of fraud relate to auction houses listed as Bonhams of London, Keys of Aylsham, near Norwich, and Lockdales in Martlesham near Ipswich. The sixth charge alleged Mr Harris converted criminal property, knowing it to be proceeds of crime. The court set out stages for the case to progress, but the trial, which is expected to last five days, will commence in almost two years time. The judge added: "That's obviously a very unfortunate state of affairs. "You've been on bail and you remain on bail but you must attend your trial. "If you do not turn up you could be fined or imprisoned and the trial could go ahead without you."
summary_src: A 67-year-old Norfolk Museums Service employee, Stephen Harris, pleaded not guilty to theft, fraud, and converting stolen property at King's Lynn Crown Court.  The charges relate to alleged theft of museum artifacts between January and August 2022 and fraudulent sale of exhibits through auction houses including Bonhams and Keys, between 2020 and 2022.  Harris, of Mattishall, faces a potential life sentence if convicted.  His trial, expected to last five days, is scheduled for September 2027, a delay the judge apologized for.  Harris remains on bail, with a warning that failure to attend could result in imprisonment.
summary_tgt: नॉर्फ़ॉक संग्रहालय सेवा के 67 वर्षीय कर्मचारी, स्टीफ़न हैरिस ने किंग्स लिन क्राउन कोर्ट में चोरी, धोखाधड़ी और चोरी की गई संपत्ति के रूपांतरण के आरोपों पर दोषी नहीं होने का पक्ष रखा है।  ये आरोप जनवरी और अगस्त 2022 के बीच संग्रहालय की कलाकृतियों की कथित चोरी और 2020 और 2022 के बीच बोन्हम्स और कीज़ जैसे नीलामी घरों के माध्यम से प्रदर्शनियों की धोखाधड़ीपूर्ण बिक्री से संबंधित हैं।  मैटिशॉल निवासी हैरिस को यदि दोषी पाया जाता है तो आजीवन कारावास की सजा हो सकती है।  उनका मुकदमा, जिसके पाँच दिन चलने की उम्मीद है, सितंबर 2027 के लिए निर्धारित है, जिसके लिए न्यायाधीश ने माफ़ी माँगी है।  हैरिस जमानत पर हैं, साथ ही चेतावनी दी गई है कि उपस्थित न होने पर उन्हें कारावास की सजा हो सकती है।
meta_description: Stephen Harris denies six charges relating to his time working for the Norfolk Museums Service.

title_src: Sky to cut 600 jobs in streaming expansion plans
text_src: Sky to cut 600 jobs in streaming move plans Sky is planning to cut 600 UK jobs as it looks to focus on its streaming services. The media organisation has launched a consultation on proposed changes, which affect 900 roles. However, it expects 600 positions will be axed. About two-thirds of jobs to go are understood to be at sites in Leeds, London and Livingston, West Lothian. Since 2023, Sky has cut almost 3,000 roles including engineers installing satellite dishes and earlier this year it announced the closure of three call centres, slashing 2,000 jobs.
summary_src:
Sky to Cut 600 UK Jobs in Streaming Restructuring

Sky News has announced plans to cut 600 jobs in the UK as part of a major restructuring focused on expanding its streaming services.  The media company initiated consultations on proposed changes affecting 900 roles, with approximately 600 redundancies expected.  The majority of job losses (two-thirds) are anticipated to impact sites in Leeds, London, and Livingston.  This latest round of cuts follows the elimination of nearly 3,000 positions since 2023, including the recent closure of three call centers resulting in 2,000 job losses. While Sky anticipates creating new roles in the coming years, the details of the restructuring are expected to be finalized later this year.
summary_tgt: स्काई न्यूज़ ने अपनी स्ट्रीमिंग सेवाओं के विस्तार पर केंद्रित एक बड़े पुनर्गठन के हिस्से के रूप में, ब्रिटेन में 600 नौकरियों में कटौती की योजना की घोषणा की है। मीडिया कंपनी ने 900 भूमिकाओं को प्रभावित करने वाले प्रस्तावित परिवर्तनों पर विचार-विमर्श शुरू किया है, जिसमें लगभग 600 छंटनी की उम्मीद है।  ज्यादातर नौकरी छूट (दो-तिहाई) लीड्स, लंदन और लिविंगस्टन में स्थित केंद्रों को प्रभावित करने की आशा है।  यह हालिया छंटनी का दौर 2023 से लगभग 3,000 पदों के उन्मूलन के बाद आया है, जिसमें हाल ही में तीन कॉल सेंटरों के बंद होने से 2,000 नौकरियों में कमी आई है। जबकि स्काई को आने वाले वर्षों में नई भूमिकाएँ बनाने की उम्मीद है, पुनर्गठन का विवरण इस वर्ष के अंत में अंतिम रूप से तय होने की उम्मीद है।
meta_description: A consultation has been launched on proposed changes, which affect 900 roles.

title_src: Teachers bid to raise £500,000 to save Penzance School of Art
text_src: Teachers' £500k bid to save 145-year-old art school 3 hours ago Share Save Christine Butler BBC News Cornwall Share Save Sara Ross The Penzance School of Art was built in 1880 and is Grade-II listed according to Historic England An art school affiliated with sculptor Barbara Hepworth, painter Peter Lanyon and potters Bernard and David Leach will be sold unless half a million pounds is raised to buy it. Penwith College has decided to sell Penzance School of Art having relocated its art provision to its main campus. But it has given two of the college's teachers an "off-market" arrangement to come up with £500,000 to buy the building to turn it into a studio and exhibition space. Sculptor Sara Ross and Jeweller Tasha Scannell have set up PZ Arts CIC and are hosting fundraising events to try to complete the purchase. Sara Ross said the former art's school "needed to be brought back to what it was in its heyday" Ross said: "Artists and tutors such as Barbara Hepworth, Bernard Leach, David Leach, Peter Lanyon all taught there or went there. It's got so much heritage and needs to be kept alive and brought back to what it was in its heyday." The Penzance School of Art was built in 1880 and is grade-II listed according to Historic England. Ross said further funding would be needed to refurbish the buildings to host art classes and studio and exhibition spaces. Tasha Scannell said the classes at the arts school "was the one thing in their week" people looked forward to She added: "Many students have come through the doors from 16-year-olds to 85-year-olds, it really does serve every age and everybody in the community. "The space is so important...150 years worth of art has come out of there and you can feel it when you are in the room," said Scannell. "When you are a creator it's so important to be in the right space." Sara Ross A look inside the building which has been serving the community for 150 years Scannell said the funds were needed "straight away" as she feared the building would fall into disrepair if left empty. She said artists who had attended workshops at the college had started small businesses and donated work to be sold at fundraising events. "People have given their all to this place in the past to make sure there is the provision for the community and there is access to art for everyone. "For that to be taken away from the community after people have put their blood, sweat and tears to it, it feels that its not doing them justice." In a statement, Penwith College confirmed the art school was no longer required and the building had "been identified as an asset for disposal". It added: "We are aware of interest from a community interest company seeking to retain the site for creative use, which aligns with our preference for a community-focused outcome, but no timescale has been set. "Until those discussions are complete, the building is not being openly marketed." It added receipts from the sale would be reinvested into supporting student facilities.
summary_src: Two teachers are racing against time to raise £500,000 and save the 145-year-old, Grade-II listed Penzance School of Art in Cornwall.  Penwith College, which relocated the art program to its main campus, plans to sell the historic building to a private buyer within the next few months.  Sculptor Sara Ross and jeweller Tasha Scannell, founders of PZ Arts CIC, launched a fundraising campaign to purchase the building and transform it into a community art studio and exhibition space.  They highlight the school's rich history, citing renowned artists who taught or studied there, and emphasize the vital role it plays in the local community.  While Penwith College supports a community-focused outcome for the building, the teachers urgently need funds to prevent its deterioration and ensure the continuation of art education and creation in Penzance.
summary_tgt: कॉर्नवाल के 145 साल पुराने, ग्रेड-II सूचीबद्ध पेनज़ेंस स्कूल ऑफ़ आर्ट को बचाने के लिए दो शिक्षिकाएँ 500,000 पाउंड जुटाने की समय सीमा के खिलाफ दौड़ रही हैं। पेनविथ कॉलेज, जिसने कला कार्यक्रम को अपने मुख्य परिसर में स्थानांतरित कर दिया है, अगले कुछ महीनों में ऐतिहासिक इमारत को एक निजी खरीदार को बेचने की योजना बना रहा है।  PZ आर्ट्स CIC की संस्थापक, मूर्तिकार सारा रॉस और ज्वैलर ताशा स्कैनेल ने इमारत को खरीदने और इसे एक सामुदायिक कला स्टूडियो और प्रदर्शनी स्थल में बदलने के लिए एक धन उगाहने का अभियान शुरू किया है। वे स्कूल के समृद्ध इतिहास पर प्रकाश डालती हैं, उन प्रसिद्ध कलाकारों का उल्लेख करती हैं जिन्होंने वहाँ पढ़ाया या अध्ययन किया, और स्थानीय समुदाय में इसकी महत्वपूर्ण भूमिका पर ज़ोर देती हैं। जबकि पेनविथ कॉलेज इमारत के लिए समुदाय-केंद्रित परिणाम का समर्थन करता है, शिक्षिकाओं को इमारत की गिरावट को रोकने और पेनज़ेंस में कला शिक्षा और सृजन को जारी रखने के लिए तत्काल धन की आवश्यकता है।
meta_description: The art school is currently owned by Penwith College, which wants to sell it.

title_src: Pablo Picasso: Tate showcases performance in the artist's works
text_src: Tate showcases performance in Picasso's works 1 day ago Share Save Share Save Tate/Larina Fernandes More than 50 works by Pablo Picasso will be on show at Tate Modern The meaning of performance in Pablo Picasso's works is explored in a new exhibition at the Tate Modern. Theatre Picasso marks 100 years since the Spanish artist, often referred to as the godfather of modern art, unveiled his famous painting The Three Dancers. The exhibition brings together more than 50 works by the artist, considered to be one of the most influential figures of the 20th Century, and will feature an accompanying performance programme of dance and flamenco. The Tate said Picasso "was fascinated by performers and their boundless capacity for transformation, and he approached painting as a dramatic act in itself". Tate/ Succession Picasso / DACS 2024 The Three Dancers is one of Picasso's most acclaimed works Picasso, who was born in 1881 in Malaga and died in 1973, is widely acknowledged to be one of the most important artists of all time. He experimented with a wide range of styles and themes in his long career, most notably inspiring Cubism, of which his 1937 work Weeping Woman is a leading example. The Theatre Picasso exhibition is being 'staged' by contemporary artist Wu Tsang and writer and curator Enrique Fuenteblanca. The Tate said: "The Three Dancers sits at the heart of the exhibition, alongside famous paintings such as Weeping Woman 1937 and Nude Woman in a Red Armchair 1932. "The exhibition also showcases prints, drawings, sculptures, textile works and collages, interwoven with key loans from leading Picasso museums in France." Tate/Succession Picasso DACS, London 2025 Weeping Woman (1937) is an example of Cubism Tate/Larina Fernandes The Acrobat (1935) is an example of Picasso's use of circus themes The exhibition will explore Picasso's public persona or brand as an artist, which the Tate calls "a mythologised version of Picasso which portrayed him as both a celebrated creative genius and an outsider". The gallery added: "This figure accompanied Picasso throughout his life and continues to shape how we imagine the role of the artist today." Picasso was known for using drama and theatricality as a theme and also looked towards popular entertainers and those pushed to the margins for inspiration, choosing to depict people working in the circus world, bullfighters and flamenco dancers. Such figures appear throughout the exhibition in works such as Girl in a Chemise, Horse with a Youth in Blue and Bullfight Scene (1960) from the Tate's collection. Theatre Picasso is at Tate Modern on Bankside from 17 September until 12 April. Admission is £15 for non-members. Tate/Succession Picasso DACS, London 2025 Horse with a Youth in Blue (1905-06) is an example of Picasso's early work Listen to the best of BBC Radio London on Sounds and follow BBC London on Facebook, X and Instagram. Send your story ideas to hello.bbclondon@bbc.co.uk
summary_src: Tate Modern's new exhibition, "Theatre Picasso," celebrates the centennial of Picasso's iconic *Three Dancers* and explores the artist's lifelong fascination with performance.  Featuring over 50 works – paintings, sculptures, prints, and more – the exhibition, curated by Wu Tsang and Enrique Fuenteblanca, examines how Picasso approached painting as a dramatic act, drawing inspiration from performers and those on society's margins.  Masterpieces like *Weeping Woman* and *Nude Woman in a Red Armchair* are showcased alongside lesser-known works, highlighting Picasso's multifaceted style and his self-cultivated public persona.  Accompanying the exhibition is a performance program of dance and flamenco.  "Theatre Picasso" runs from September 17th to April 12th at Tate Modern; admission is £15 for non-members.
summary_tgt: टेट मॉडर्न की नई प्रदर्शनी, "थिएटर पिकासो," पिकासो की प्रतिष्ठित कृति *थ्री डांसर्स* की शताब्दी वर्षगांठ का जश्न मनाती है और कलाकार के प्रदर्शन के प्रति आजीवन आकर्षण का पता लगाती है। 50 से अधिक कृतियों – चित्रों, मूर्तियों, प्रिंटों और अन्य – को प्रदर्शित करती यह प्रदर्शनी, वू त्सांग और एनरिक फ्यूएंटेब्लांका द्वारा क्यूरेट की गई है, यह जांच करती है कि कैसे पिकासो ने पेंटिंग को एक नाटकीय कृत्य के रूप में देखा, कलाकारों और समाज के हाशिये पर रहने वालों से प्रेरणा ली।  *वीपिंग वुमन* और *न्यूड वुमन इन ए रेड आर्मचेयर* जैसी उत्कृष्ट कृतियों को कम ज्ञात कार्यों के साथ प्रदर्शित किया गया है, जो पिकासो की बहुआयामी शैली और उनके द्वारा खुद को बनाए गए सार्वजनिक व्यक्तित्व को उजागर करता है। प्रदर्शनी के साथ नृत्य और फ्लेमेंको का एक प्रदर्शन कार्यक्रम भी है। "थिएटर पिकासो" 17 सितंबर से 12 अप्रैल तक टेट मॉडर्न में चलेगा; गैर-सदस्यों के लिए प्रवेश शुल्क £15 है।
meta_description: Theatre Picasso marks 100 years since the Spanish artist unveiled his work The Three Dancers.

title_src: Next generation of cancer drugs could be made in space
text_src: Many companies are racing towards the space economy, a commercial sector projected to reach 1.8 trillion US dollars in the next decade. We're already turning to the stars for holidays with tour operators, farming, and one day soon the atmospheric conditions of space. Tech Now visits a London based startup aiming to improve disease treatment by building a pharmaceutical factory in space.
summary_src: The burgeoning space economy, projected to reach $1.8 trillion in the next decade, is attracting a flurry of commercial activity.  Beyond space tourism and farming,  a London-based startup is leading the charge in applying space to healthcare.  The company plans to construct a pharmaceutical factory in orbit, aiming to both produce existing drugs more efficiently and develop novel medications under unique space-based conditions.
summary_tgt: अगले दशक में 1.8 ट्रिलियन डॉलर तक पहुँचने वाले, तेज़ी से बढ़ते अंतरिक्ष अर्थव्यवस्था में व्यावसायिक गतिविधियों का ताँता लगा हुआ है। अंतरिक्ष पर्यटन और खेती से परे, लंदन की एक स्टार्टअप कंपनी अंतरिक्ष को स्वास्थ्य सेवा में लागू करने में अग्रणी भूमिका निभा रही है। कंपनी की योजना कक्षा में एक फार्मास्युटिकल फैक्ट्री बनाने की है, जिसका उद्देश्य मौजूदा दवाओं का अधिक कुशलतापूर्वक उत्पादन करना और अनोखे अंतरिक्ष-आधारित परिस्थितियों में नई दवाओं का विकास करना है।
meta_description: Tech Now visits a UK startup aiming to build a pharma factory in space to revolutionise cancer treatment.

title_src: Watch kitten try to catch fish for the first time
text_src: Fishing cats are well adapted to water, with wet suit-like fur coats and webbed feet, they are masters of aquatics. This means fish are on the menu, but these kittens might need a bit more practice before fending for themselves.
summary_src: Adorable fishing cat kittens, known for their waterproof fur and webbed feet, are currently under the care of a local family.  While these aquatic specialists will one day hunt fish expertly, the young felines are still developing their hunting skills.
summary_tgt: अपने जलरोधी फर और झिल्लीदार पैरों के लिए जाने जाने वाले, मनमोहक मछली पकड़ने वाली बिल्ली के बच्चे वर्तमान में एक स्थानीय परिवार की देखरेख में हैं।  हालांकि ये जलीय विशेषज्ञ एक दिन मछली का शिकार कुशलता से करेंगे, ये नन्हे बिल्ली के बच्चे अभी भी अपने शिकार कौशल का विकास कर रहे हैं।
meta_description: Fishing cats are well adapted to water, but these kittens might need a bit more practice to feed themselves.

title_src: Mappa Mundi: The greatest map of the medieval world
text_src: On the second floor of the Library of Saint Marks in Venice, a map of the world occupies an entire room – and rightfully so, considering its historical significance and imposing size. The Mappa Mundi, completed by monk Fra Mauro in 1459, is the compendium of all the geographical knowledge of the time and is arguably the greatest medieval map of the world.
summary_src: Venice's Library of Saint Marks houses the Mappa Mundi, a colossal 15th-century world map created by Fra Mauro.  Completed in 1459, this historically significant cartographic masterpiece represents the pinnacle of medieval geographical knowledge and is considered by many to be the greatest medieval world map ever created.
summary_tgt: वेनिस के सेंट मार्क्स के पुस्तकालय में मैपा मंडी स्थित है, जो कि फ्रा माउरो द्वारा बनाया गया एक विशाल 15वीं सदी का विश्व मानचित्र है।  1459 में पूर्ण हुआ यह ऐतिहासिक रूप से महत्वपूर्ण कार्टोग्राफिक उत्कृष्ट कृति मध्ययुगीन भौगोलिक ज्ञान के शिखर का प्रतिनिधित्व करती है और इसे कई लोग अब तक बनाया गया सबसे महान मध्ययुगीन विश्व मानचित्र मानते हैं।
meta_description: From a small island in Venice, a 15th-Century monk designed an astonishingly accurate planisphere of the world.

title_src: Inside one of the world's most remote restaurants
text_src: Wolfgat is a cottage restaurant in the small fishing village of Paternoster along South Africa's rugged west coast, just a two-hour drive from Cape Town. It won the title of the world's 'No. 1 Off-Map Destination' by the World Restaurant Awards in 2019. The restaurant offers a unique dining experience using a selection of hyper-local ingredients specific to the Western Cape and expertly executed by chef Kobus van der Merwe.
summary_src: Paternoster's Wolfgat Restaurant, a two-hour drive from Cape Town, has been named the world's first "Off-Map Destination" by the World Restaurant Awards.  This prestigious accolade recognizes the restaurant's unique dining experience, showcasing hyper-local Western Cape ingredients expertly prepared by Chef Kobus van der Merwe.  While previously garnering attention for its culinary excellence, this award marks a significant milestone for the small, seaside establishment.
summary_tgt: केप टाउन से दो घंटे की दूरी पर स्थित पैटरनोस्टर के वोल्फगैट रेस्टोरेंट को वर्ल्ड रेस्टोरेंट अवार्ड्स ने दुनिया का पहला "ऑफ-मैप डेस्टिनेशन" घोषित किया है। यह प्रतिष्ठित पुरस्कार रेस्टोरेंट के अनोखे भोजन अनुभव को पहचानता है, जिसमें शेफ कोबस वैन डेर मर्वे द्वारा कुशलतापूर्वक तैयार किए गए अति-स्थानीय वेस्टर्न केप के अवयवों को प्रदर्शित किया गया है। जबकि पहले से ही अपनी पाक कला की उत्कृष्टता के लिए ध्यान आकर्षित कर रहा था, यह पुरस्कार इस छोटे से, समुद्र के किनारे स्थित प्रतिष्ठान के लिए एक महत्वपूर्ण मील का पत्थर है।
meta_description: Off-Map Destination' winner Wolfgat offers a menu made from hyper-local and foraged ingredients.

title_src: The last remaining lamplighters of London
text_src: Meet London's last lamplighters, five men whose job it is to maintain London's last remaining Victorian gas lamps, a tradition which dates back to 1812 and one steeped in history. Their unique vocation takes them to some of the capital's most historic districts, areas which give a real sense of what London would have been like over 200 years ago, when these lamps first stood. Every lamp tells a story.
summary_src: London's five remaining lamplighters keep a 200-year-old tradition alive, tending to the city's last Victorian gas lamps.  Working in historic districts, these men offer a glimpse into London's past, maintaining a unique and evocative piece of the capital's heritage.  Each lamp, they say, holds its own story, a testament to a bygone era.
summary_tgt: लंदन के पाँच शेष लैंपलाइटर 200 साल पुरानी परंपरा को जीवित रखते हैं, शहर के अंतिम विक्टोरियन गैस लैंपों की देखभाल करते हुए। ऐतिहासिक इलाकों में काम करते हुए, ये पुरुष लंदन के अतीत की एक झलक पेश करते हैं, राजधानी की विरासत के एक अनोखे और मार्मिक हिस्से को बनाए रखते हैं। वे कहते हैं कि प्रत्येक लैंप अपनी कहानी समेटे हुए है, जो बीते हुए युग की गवाही देता है।
meta_description: More than 25,000 lamplighters used to roam the streets of London, now there are only five.

title_src: Ultimate in cancel culture': Fans outside Jimmy Kimmel studio react to show's axing
text_src: Late-night host Jimmy Kimmel has been pulled off air "indefinitely" by ABC over comments he made about the shooting of right-wing influencer Charlie Kirk. In his Monday night monologue, Kimmel said the "MAGA gang" was trying to score political points off Kirk's killing, and mocked the president's reaction to the shooting. The BBC's Regan Morris spoke to fans outside Jimmy Kimmel Live's LA studio, who called the cancellation "bizarre" and "the ultimate in cancel culture." Read more on this story.
summary_src: ABC has indefinitely suspended late-night host Jimmy Kimmel following controversial remarks he made about the shooting of conservative influencer Charlie Kirk.  Kimmel's comments, which reportedly mocked the president's response and suggested the "MAGA gang" was exploiting the incident for political gain, have sparked outrage.  Fans outside Kimmel's studio expressed bewilderment at the suspension, calling it "bizarre" and an example of "cancel culture."  Further details are available on CNN.com.
summary_tgt: एबीसी ने रूढ़िवादी प्रभावशाली व्यक्ति चार्ली किर्क की शूटिंग पर विवादास्पद टिप्पणियों के बाद देर रात के होस्ट जिमी किमेल को अनिश्चितकाल के लिए निलंबित कर दिया है। किमेल की टिप्पणियों ने, जिनमें कथित तौर पर राष्ट्रपति की प्रतिक्रिया का मज़ाक उड़ाया गया और सुझाव दिया गया कि "MAGA गिरोह" राजनीतिक लाभ के लिए इस घटना का शोषण कर रहा है,  गुस्से को भड़का दिया है। किमेल के स्टूडियो के बाहर प्रशंसकों ने उनके निलंबन पर हैरानी व्यक्त करते हुए इसे "अजीबोगरीब" और "रद्द संस्कृति" का उदाहरण बताया।  अधिक जानकारी CNN.com पर उपलब्ध है।

title_src: New flamingo chicks 'amazing turnaround' for Isle of Man park
text_src: New flamingo chicks 'amazing turnaround' for park 19 hours ago Share Save Ashlea Tracey Isle of Man Share Save Keeper Karin Seven flamingo chicks have been born at Curraghs Wildlife Park in 12 months The successful breeding of seven Chilean flamingo chicks at a Manx wildlife park represents an "amazing turnaround" for the colony, keepers have said. Last September saw the first hatchling of the species at the Curraghs Wildlife Park for 18 years, with a further six hatching since. General manager Kathleen Graham said it meant the Ballaugh conservation facility was now home to "the most flamingo chicks of any collection in the British Isles". The species has been described as "near threatened" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature. Keeper Karin The colony at the wildlife park now has 25 flamingos A spokesman for the park said keepers had built an extended beach area on the island within their enclosure, which the birds "seemed to approve" of and had begun to "build volcano-shaped nests almost straight away". They explained that raising the chicks in the first few weeks was "very much the responsibility of the whole colony" and said it had been "lovely" to see how the adults had gathered round to protect the little ones. With the population at the park reaching 25, staff were hopeful the "current breeding success" would continue as "the larger the group, the more likely they are to breed", he added. When the chicks hatch they have grey-white down and a straight beak. They develop their pink colour over a few years as they eat foods rich in the carotenoid pigments that make some plants, algae and crustaceans red, orange, pink and yellow. Keeper Karin Under human care flamingos can live for about 40 years Ms Graham said the team were unsure as to why there had been an influx of chicks. "Sometimes you're left with more questions than answers as to why now," she added. She explained that it could be one of a number of reasons, such as global warming or changes in diet. "But to suddenly have two chicks was amazing last year and to see five this year is phenomenal," she said. "It has been an amazing turnaround for our Chilean flamingo colony, we're very pleased to see them doing so well." "And it's always nice to have babies, let's be honest." More on this story Rare flamingo chick born at Manx wildlife park
summary_src: Curraghs Wildlife Park in the Isle of Man is celebrating a remarkable breeding season for its Chilean flamingos, a "near threatened" species.  Seven chicks have hatched in the past 12 months, a significant increase following the first hatchling in 18 years last September.  This makes the park home to the largest flamingo chick population in the British Isles.  The park attributes the success to an expanded beach area in the flamingo enclosure, which encouraged nesting.  Keepers highlight the collaborative parenting within the colony, with adults protecting the chicks.  While the reasons for this sudden increase remain unclear – possibly linked to factors like climate change or dietary shifts – the park is hopeful this breeding success will continue with their now 25-strong flock.  The chicks, initially grey-white with black beaks and heads, will gradually develop their characteristic pink plumage over several years.
summary_tgt: आइल ऑफ़ मैन के कुरैग्स वाइल्डलाइफ़ पार्क में चिलीयन फ़्लेमिंगोज़, जो "लगभग संकटग्रस्त" प्रजाति हैं, के प्रजनन काल में उल्लेखनीय सफलता मिली है। पिछले 12 महीनों में सात चूज़े निकले हैं, जो पिछले साल सितंबर में 18 साल बाद पहले चूज़े के निकलने के बाद एक महत्वपूर्ण वृद्धि है। इससे यह पार्क ब्रिटिश द्वीपसमूह में सबसे बड़ी फ़्लेमिंगो चूज़ों की आबादी का घर बन गया है। पार्क इस सफलता का श्रेय फ़्लेमिंगो के बाड़े में विस्तारित समुद्र तट क्षेत्र को देता है, जिसने घोंसला बनाने को प्रोत्साहित किया। रखवालों ने कॉलोनी के भीतर सहयोगी पालन-पोषण पर प्रकाश डाला है, जिसमें वयस्क चूज़ों की रक्षा करते हैं। हालांकि इस अचानक वृद्धि के कारण स्पष्ट नहीं हैं - संभवतः जलवायु परिवर्तन या आहार में बदलाव जैसे कारकों से जुड़े हैं - पार्क को उम्मीद है कि उनकी अब 25 सदस्यों वाली झुंड में यह प्रजनन सफलता जारी रहेगी। चूज़े, जो शुरू में भूरे-सफ़ेद रंग के होते हैं, जिनकी चोंच और सिर काले होते हैं, धीरे-धीरे कई वर्षों में अपना विशिष्ट गुलाबी रंग प्राप्त करेंगे।
meta_description: The Curraghs Wildlife Park has welcomed seven rare Chilean flamingo chicks over the past year.

title_src: Government to appeal against ruling blocking migrant deportation to France
text_src: Government to appeal against ruling blocking migrant deportation to France 25 minutes ago Share Save Sam Francis Political reporter Share Save PA Media The government is going to appeal against a court ruling which blocked a migrant being returned to France under a "one in, one out" migrant deal between the UK and France. Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood vowed to fight "vexatious, last-minute claims" after the deportation of an Eritrean man under the deal was temporarily blocked by the High Court this week. The man, who arrived in the UK by small boat last month, argued he was a victim of modern slavery in an appeal made just hours before his flight was due to take off. The Home Office is also reviewing the Modern Slavery Act to ensure it is not being misused. Mahmood said following the decision that "last minute attempts to frustrate a removal are intolerable". She added: "Migrants suddenly deciding that they are a modern slave on the eve of their removal, having never made such a claim before, make a mockery of our laws and this country's generosity." Home Office lawyers argued that the man could have claimed asylum in France. They added that delaying his departure could encourage others allocated to the return flights this week to make similar claims and would undermine the public interest in deterring deadly small boat crossings. In the first High Court challenge to the "one in, one out" scheme, the Eritrean man's lawyers argued he needed more time to present evidence that he may have been the victim of modern-day slavery - and that the decision to remove him had been rushed. The injunction raises questions about whether other migrants designated for deportation through the scheme could use similar grounds to delay or block their removal. A policy of deporting migrants to Rwanda put forward by the Conservatives under the last government became bogged down in repeated legal challenges before being cancelled by Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer when he came into office. The deal with France was seen by the previous Home Secretary Yvette Cooper as one of her landmark policy achievements. It is now the job of her successor to make it work. Ministers agreed the "one in, one out" pilot deal with France in July to curb record small boat crossings this year. Under the deal, the UK will send asylum seekers who have crossed the Channel back to France, in exchange for those who apply and are approved to come to Britain. France has reportedly said it will only accept a small initial contingent of deportations, while the UK has said it hopes to increase numbers over the course of the scheme. The latest setback follows reports that the first flights to France left empty on Monday and Tuesday. Despite this, the first removals of migrants to France under the pilot scheme are still expected to go ahead this week.
summary_src: The UK government will appeal a High Court ruling that blocked the deportation of an Eritrean migrant to France under a new "one in, one out" deal.  The man, who arrived by small boat, claimed modern slavery just hours before his scheduled flight, prompting the injunction.  Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood condemned the claim as "vexatious" and said it undermined efforts to deter dangerous Channel crossings.  The Home Office is reviewing the Modern Slavery Act to prevent misuse. While the government insists the deal with France will continue, the ruling casts doubt on its effectiveness, following reports of initially empty deportation flights. The deal, intended to curb small boat crossings, involves exchanging returned asylum seekers for those approved to come to the UK.  France's participation appears limited for now.
summary_tgt: यूके सरकार ने उच्च न्यायालय के उस फैसले के खिलाफ अपील की है जिसने एक नए "एक अंदर, एक बाहर" समझौते के तहत एक एरिट्रियाई प्रवासी को फ्रांस भेजने पर रोक लगा दी थी।  छोटी नाव से आए इस व्यक्ति ने अपनी निर्धारित उड़ान के कुछ ही घंटे पहले आधुनिक गुलामी का दावा किया, जिससे अदालत ने रोक लगा दी। गृह सचिव शबाना महमूद ने इस दावे को "उत्पीड़नात्मक" बताते हुए कहा कि इससे खतरनाक चैनल पार करने से रोकने के प्रयासों को कमज़ोर किया गया है। गृह कार्यालय आधुनिक गुलामी अधिनियम के दुरुपयोग को रोकने के लिए इसकी समीक्षा कर रहा है। सरकार का कहना है कि फ्रांस के साथ समझौता जारी रहेगा, लेकिन शुरुआती खाली प्रत्यर्पण उड़ानों की खबरों के बाद इस फैसले से इसकी प्रभावशीलता पर संदेह पैदा हो गया है। छोटी नावों से होने वाले पार करने पर रोक लगाने के उद्देश्य से इस समझौते में लौटाए गए शरणार्थियों के बदले यूके आने के लिए स्वीकृत लोगों का आदान-प्रदान शामिल है। फिलहाल फ्रांस की भागीदारी सीमित प्रतीत होती है।
meta_description: Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood says attempts to block removals "are intolerable" and threaten the government's plans.

title_src: The Treasury of the enigmatic Nabatean civilisation
text_src: Explorer and adventurer Alice Morrison is on the trail of a forgotten ancient civilisation, the Nabateans. In this episode she visits one of the empire's most spectacular sites known as the Treasury or Al Khazneh in Petra in southern Jordan.
summary_src: Archaeologist Alice Morrison explores the remnants of the Nabataean civilization, a little-known ancient empire once flourishing in northern Iraq.  This week, her journey takes her to Petra in southern Jordan, where she examines the Treasury (Al Khazneh), one of the empire's most impressive and iconic structures.
summary_tgt: पुरातत्वविद् एलिस मॉरिसन नाबटी सभ्यता के अवशेषों की खोज कर रही हैं, जो उत्तरी इराक में कभी फल-फूल रही एक अल्पज्ञात प्राचीन साम्राज्य थी। इस सप्ताह, उनकी यात्रा उन्हें दक्षिणी जॉर्डन के पेट्रा ले जाती है, जहाँ वे ख़ज़ने (अल खज़नेह), साम्राज्य के सबसे प्रभावशाली और प्रतिष्ठित ढाँचों में से एक, की जाँच कर रही हैं।

title_src: Commencement speech: The surprising pitfall of your passions
text_src: Students are graduating in the US this week, and the most common advice is 'follow your passions'. According to a Washington University study lead by professor Sapna Cheryan though, this seemingly innocent and uplifting message might be counterproductive, and relegate women to gender conforming jobs - that are not necessarily the best paid ones. In this short video, we look at commencement speeches, from Steve Jobs to Whoopi Goldberg, digging into the psychology of it, its gender and cultural undertones, and ultimately trying to discern what makes a good advice, in this day and age, for a fulfilling career.
summary_src: While "follow your passion" is ubiquitous commencement advice, a new study suggests it may disproportionately steer women toward lower-paying, gender-stereotypical careers.  Professor Sapna Cheryan's research highlights the potentially detrimental impact of this well-intentioned but potentially misleading counsel.  This news piece examines the prevalence of this advice in speeches from figures like Steve Jobs and Whoopi Goldberg, exploring its psychological underpinnings and cultural biases to ultimately question its effectiveness in achieving career fulfillment.
summary_tgt: हालांकि "अपने जुनून का पालन करें" स्नातक समारोहों में आम सी सलाह है, एक नए अध्ययन से पता चलता है कि यह महिलाओं को कम वेतन वाली, लिंग-रूढ़िवादी नौकरियों की ओर अनापत्ति से मोड़ सकता है। प्रोफेसर सपना चेरियन के शोध इस नेकनीयती से दी जाने वाली, लेकिन संभावित रूप से भ्रामक सलाह के हानिकारक प्रभाव को उजागर करते हैं। यह समाचार लेख स्टीव जॉब्स और वूपी गोल्डबर्ग जैसे लोगों के भाषणों में इस सलाह के प्रसार की जांच करता है, इसके मनोवैज्ञानिक आधार और सांस्कृतिक पूर्वाग्रहों की पड़ताल करता है और अंततः करियर की पूर्णता प्राप्त करने में इसकी प्रभावशीलता पर सवाल उठाता है।
meta_description: Students are graduating in the US this week. The commencement speeches might lead them into questionable choices.

text_src: The science behind the fasting fad What happens to our microbes when we fast, and how when we eat can be optimised for our health.
summary_src: Recent interest in intermittent fasting highlights the complex interplay between fasting, gut microbes, and human health.  Scientific research is exploring how fasting impacts the gut microbiome, and how optimizing eating patterns can improve overall well-being.  Studies are examining the effects of fasting on microbial composition and activity, potentially influencing metabolism, immunity, and other health factors.
summary_tgt: हाल ही में इंटरमिटेंट फ़ास्टिंग में बढ़ती रुचि से उपवास, आंत के सूक्ष्मजीवों और मानव स्वास्थ्य के बीच जटिल अंतर्संबंध पर प्रकाश पड़ता है। वैज्ञानिक अनुसंधान इस बात का पता लगा रहे हैं कि उपवास आंत के माइक्रोबायोम को कैसे प्रभावित करता है, और खाने के पैटर्न को अनुकूलित करने से समग्र कल्याण में कैसे सुधार किया जा सकता है। अध्ययन माइक्रोबियल संरचना और गतिविधि पर उपवास के प्रभावों की जांच कर रहे हैं, जो संभावित रूप से चयापचय, प्रतिरक्षा और अन्य स्वास्थ्य कारकों को प्रभावित करते हैं।
meta_description: Passed down through generations in Gokayama, the Japanese tradition of Kokiriko honours the cycle of life.

title_src: Spirit flight warned over proximity to Air Force One
text_src: Pay attention' - Spirit aircraft warned as it gets too close to Air Force One 9 hours ago Share Save Nardine Saad Share Save Listen: Air traffic controllers urge Spirit pilots to avoid Air Force One A Spirit Airlines flight received repeated warnings from air traffic controllers to "pay attention" and "turn away" after it came too close to President Donald Trump's aircraft as he flew to the United Kingdom for a state visit. "Pay attention. Get off the iPad," was the stern message issued to the Spirit pilot as the aircraft flew eight miles (12.8km) parallel to Air Force One, the US president's official plane, over New York on Tuesday. The planes were never within a distance that the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) would classify as unsafe, but it was close enough to alarm officials. "Safety is always our top priority," a Spirit spokesman told CBS, the BBC's US partner.
summary_src: A Spirit Airlines plane flew uncomfortably close to Air Force One carrying President Donald Trump over New York on Tuesday, prompting air traffic controllers to issue repeated warnings to the Spirit pilots.  While the FAA deemed the distance safe, controllers' urgent calls of "Pay attention" highlighted the close parallel flight of the two aircraft for approximately eight miles.  A Spirit spokesperson affirmed that safety is the airline's top priority.
summary_tgt: मंगलवार को न्यूयॉर्क के ऊपर राष्ट्रपति डोनाल्ड ट्रम्प से भरे एयर फ़ोर्स वन के बेहद करीब एक स्पिरिट एयरलाइन्स का विमान उड़ गया, जिससे एयर ट्रैफ़िक कंट्रोलर्स को स्पिरिट के पायलटों को बार-बार चेतावनी जारी करनी पड़ी। हालांकि FAA ने दूरी को सुरक्षित माना, लेकिन कंट्रोलर्स के "ध्यान दो" जैसे तत्काल आह्वान ने लगभग आठ मील तक दोनों विमानों की करीबी समानांतर उड़ान को उजागर किया। स्पिरिट के एक प्रवक्ता ने पुष्टि की कि सुरक्षा एयरलाइन की सर्वोच्च प्राथमिकता है।
meta_description: Air traffic controllers warn Spirit flight after it came too close to President Donald Trump's aircraft as he flew to the United Kingdom for his state visit.

title_src: Liberal Democrat leader blames Trump for AstraZeneca move
text_src: Sir Ed Davey blames Trump for AstraZeneca move 14 hours ago Share Save Andrew Sinclair Political editor, BBC East Share Save BBC Sir Ed Davey says President Trump's drive to encourage companies to invest in the US is a factor in AstraZeneca's decision to scrap expansion plans in Cambridge The Liberal Democrat leader has attributed AstraZeneca's decision to halt further investment in Cambridge to President Donald Trump pressurising companies to move their businesses to the US. Sir Ed Davey said the company's decision to pause plans to invest £200m at the city's biomedical campus was "deeply troubling" and "disastrous", adding "there is an American attack on Britain's pharmaceutical industry". Tom Keith-Roach, the UK president of AstraZeneca, said Britain was "an increasingly challenging place to bring forward innovation" and announced the company would invest more into its US operations. The US Embassy has been contacted for comment. AstraZeneca's expansion would have created about 1,000 new jobs in Cambridge. Sir Ed told BBC East: "The pharmaceutical industry has been one of Britain's leading industries and Cambridge and the East of England has been a key part feeding into that. "This is a disastrous decision. We've seen from President Trump pressure [who] is saying, 'let's build up all the industry in the United States and charge higher prices for your goods elsewhere in the world'. "There is an American attack on Britain's pharmaceutical industry." The government said it was investing heavily in the pharmaceutical sector to make Britain "the destination of choice" . Getty Images AstraZeneca said it would be pausing its previously announced £200m investment in Cambridge's biomedical campus The Liberal Democrat leader said the government should be standing up to Trump and described the US president as "no longer a reliable ally". He called on ministers to make drug pricing part of the US/UK trade deal, which was still being finalised. "The way you negotiate [with Trump] is to build up your own strength by showing you have alternatives. Let's rebuild our trading relationship with Europe, let's build our trading strength by trading with our commonwealth allies," Sir Ed added. Mr Keith-Roach told MPs on the Science, Innovation and Technology select committee on Monday that Britain pays far less than many other companies for its medicines and therefore it was challenging to bring new drugs to the UK market. Science minister Lord Patrick Vallance acknowledged that the NHS will have to pay more for medicines and agreed that the approval and regulatory process for new drugs needs to be sped up. A spokesperson for AstraZeneca said the company was "constantly reassessing" the investment needs of the firm. The government said it has committed up to £520m to the Life Sciences Innovative Manufacturing Fund. A spokesperson added that ministers remained "confident in life sciences as a driver of both economic growth and better health outcomes, and our door remains open to future engagement" with the pharmaceutical industry. AstraZeneca's global headquarters are at its "discovery centre" on Cambridge's biomedical campus Sir Ed was speaking ahead of his party conference in Bournemouth at the weekend, which will see the Lib Dems celebrate their success in this year's local elections. The Liberal Democrats now has a record number of MPs in the East of England, three of them in Cambridgeshire. It also runs a growing number of local councils including Cambridgeshire County Council and South Cambridgeshire District Council. Sir Ed claimed that there were now "two big parties of change in British politics". "There is Nigel Farage and Reform who want to make Britain like Trump's America: very chaotic with people paying for their healthcare [and] the Liberal Democrats who are much truer to patriotic British values, where we want to reform the NHS so we get proper healthcare, reform the energy industry and tackle climate change," Sir Ed said. The Liberal Democrats will discuss a range of issues at their conference and there will be a session on how to counter the threat of Reform UK, the Liberal Democrat leader added.
summary_src: AstraZeneca halts £200 million Cambridge investment, sparking political row.  Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey blames President Trump's pressure on US companies to invest domestically, claiming this contributed to AstraZeneca's decision to pause the expansion, which would have created 1,000 jobs.  AstraZeneca's UK president cited a challenging UK business environment.  The government, while acknowledging the need for faster drug approvals and potentially higher NHS drug prices, maintains its commitment to the life sciences sector.  Davey calls for the government to address drug pricing in the US-UK trade deal and strengthen Britain's trading relationships with Europe and the Commonwealth.  The incident highlights concerns about the UK's competitiveness in the pharmaceutical industry.
summary_tgt: एस्ट्राजेनेका ने 200 मिलियन पाउंड के कैम्ब्रिज निवेश पर रोक लगा दी है, जिससे राजनीतिक विवाद छिड़ गया है। लिबरल डेमोक्रेट नेता सर एड डेवी ने अमेरिकी कंपनियों को घरेलू निवेश करने के लिए राष्ट्रपति ट्रम्प के दबाव को इसके लिए जिम्मेदार ठहराया है, यह दावा करते हुए कि इससे एस्ट्राजेनेका के विस्तार पर रोक लगाने के फैसले में योगदान हुआ, जिससे 1,000 नौकरियां बननी थीं। एस्ट्राजेनेका के यूके अध्यक्ष ने ब्रिटेन के चुनौतीपूर्ण व्यावसायिक माहौल का हवाला दिया। सरकार ने, हालांकि तेज दवा अनुमोदन और संभावित रूप से उच्च NHS दवा कीमतों की आवश्यकता को स्वीकार किया है, लेकिन जीवन विज्ञान क्षेत्र के प्रति अपनी प्रतिबद्धता बरकरार रखी है। डेवी ने सरकार से अमेरिका-यूके व्यापार समझौते में दवा मूल्य निर्धारण को संबोधित करने और यूरोप और राष्ट्रमंडल के साथ ब्रिटेन के व्यापारिक संबंधों को मजबूत करने का आह्वान किया है। यह घटना फार्मास्युटिकल उद्योग में ब्रिटेन की प्रतिस्पर्धात्मकता को लेकर चिंताओं को उजागर करती है।
meta_description: The Liberal Democrat leader says the UK's pharmaceutical industry is under "attack".

title_src: Why wild venison is a climate-friendly swap for beef
text_src: In countries like Scotland where deer populations are culled, eating wild venison can be a low-carbon option. My last meat feast was seven years ago. My parents ­were visiting me in London from Costa Rica and we spent the evening going through the brief but rich menu of a small steak restaurant. For them, it was their final meal before returning home; for me, a farewell to my most carnivorous days. In the years since I've kept a diet of mostly vegetarian dishes, bits of seafood and the occasional exception. As this diet emerged from my work covering climate change, I pick and choose with that in mind: if an animal product is low carbon, like mussels, it will be on my plate regularly. Meat – a high-carbon food – features on my plate for special meals, like my mum's pork leg for Christmas, or on the rare occasion I really crave something like the Costa Rican pork belly-based specialty chifrijo. Each person has their own approach to climate-friendly food; mine is to reduce food-related emissions, not to have a perfect vegetarian scorecard. Since I moved to Scotland a few years ago, a new wrinkle has appeared: venison – the meat from deer. Deer populations are out of hand here: the Scottish Government estimates that the overall population could be around one million, up from half a million in 1990. Deer are thriving, partly because humans eradicated their predators, such as wolves and lynx centuries ago.
summary_src: A shift towards climate-conscious eating is prompting some to reconsider meat consumption.  While a predominantly vegetarian diet is common for the author, who focuses on minimizing food-related emissions, exceptions are made for low-carbon options like mussels and occasional special meals.  In Scotland, where deer populations are high and culled, venison is presented as a low-carbon alternative, adding a new dimension to the author's approach to sustainable eating.  The author's personal journey reflects a growing awareness of the carbon footprint of food and the complexities of balancing personal preferences with environmental responsibility.
summary_tgt: जलवायु के प्रति जागरूक भोजन की ओर एक बदलाव कुछ लोगों को मांस के सेवन पर पुनर्विचार करने के लिए प्रेरित कर रहा है। जबकि लेखक के लिए मुख्य रूप से शाकाहारी आहार आम है, जो भोजन से संबंधित उत्सर्जन को कम करने पर ध्यान केंद्रित करते हैं, मसल्स जैसे कम-कार्बन विकल्पों और कभी-कभी विशेष भोजन के लिए अपवाद बनाए जाते हैं। स्कॉटलैंड में, जहाँ हिरणों की आबादी अधिक है और उन्हें नियंत्रित किया जाता है, वहाँ वेनिसन को कम-कार्बन विकल्प के रूप में प्रस्तुत किया जाता है, जो लेखक के सतत भोजन के दृष्टिकोण में एक नया आयाम जोड़ता है। लेखक की व्यक्तिगत यात्रा भोजन के कार्बन पदचिन्ह और व्यक्तिगत प्राथमिकताओं को पर्यावरणीय जिम्मेदारी के साथ संतुलित करने की जटिलताओं के बारे में बढ़ती जागरूकता को दर्शाती है।
meta_description: In countries like Scotland where deer populations are culled, eating wild venison can be a low-carbon option

title_src: How eating insects became a conspiracy theory
text_src: Insect protein is healthy and sustainable. But now it is also at the centre of a far-reaching conspiracy theory. Throughout human history, insects have been on the menu. One of the earliest known depictions of entomophagy (insect eating) dates as far back as 30,000BC in the ancient cave paintings of Altamira in northern Spain, illustrating the gathering of bees. Today many people in Latin America, Asia and Africa consume insects regularly. In Mexico, for example, boiled and fried grasshoppers, "chapulines", are a popular bar snack and increasingly served in gourmet restaurants. But not everyone's biting. Though insects have long been considered inexpensive, healthy and sustainable sources of protein, they remain largely absent from American and European diets. In recent years, this reluctance has been exacerbated by a web of conspiracy theories claiming that "global elites" are forcing the public to abandon meat in favour of bugs. This disinformation obscures legitimate scientific research into insects as a source of climate-friendly protein and may hinder the shift towards more sustainable food systems, researchers warn. Popping up most commonly in the United States and pockets of Europe, "I will not eat the bugs" is a conspiracy theory that alleges that "global elites" will force the ordinary masses to eat bugs under the guise of environmentalism, says disinformation analyst Sara Aniano.
summary_src: Insect protein, a healthy and sustainable food source with a history dating back millennia, is facing a backlash. While insects have long been a dietary staple in many parts of the world, a growing conspiracy theory alleges that "global elites" are pushing insect consumption on the public under the guise of environmentalism. This misinformation, prevalent in the US and parts of Europe, is overshadowing legitimate scientific research into insect protein as a climate-friendly alternative to traditional meat.  Researchers warn that this disinformation campaign could hinder the transition towards more sustainable food systems.
summary_tgt: कीट प्रोटीन, एक स्वस्थ और टिकाऊ खाद्य स्रोत जिसका इतिहास सदियों पुराना है, का विरोध हो रहा है। जबकि दुनिया के कई हिस्सों में कीड़े लंबे समय से आहार का मुख्य हिस्सा रहे हैं, एक बढ़ता हुआ षड्यंत्र सिद्धांत यह दावा कर रहा है कि "विश्व के कुलीन वर्ग" पर्यावरणवाद के बहाने जनता पर कीटों का सेवन थोप रहे हैं। यह गलत सूचना, जो अमेरिका और यूरोप के कुछ हिस्सों में प्रचलित है, पारंपरिक मांस के जलवायु-अनुकूल विकल्प के रूप में कीट प्रोटीन पर वैज्ञानिक अनुसंधान को कमतर आंक रही है। शोधकर्ता चेतावनी देते हैं कि यह गलत सूचना अभियान अधिक टिकाऊ खाद्य प्रणालियों की ओर संक्रमण में बाधा डाल सकता है।
meta_description: Insect protein is healthy and sustainable. But now it is also at the centre of a far-reaching conspiracy theory.

title_src: It's a way of the sea returning the trash to us': Why plastic-filled 'Neptune balls' are washing up on beaches
text_src: As tiny pieces of plastic clog our oceans, natural meadows of seagrass are bundling up microplastics and spitting them back out onto beaches in the form of "Neptune balls". Neptune balls, or Posidonia oceanica, are round, compact bundles of seagrass mostly found in the Mediterranean Sea. For centuries, Posidonia has been used for packaging, bedding and even insulation for houses. But researchers from the University of Barcelona have found these spongy balls are spontaneously performing another function: mopping up ocean plastic from the seafloor. In the ocean, microplastics – particles under 5mm in size – often originate from items such as plastic bags, bottles and fishing nets. These plastic fragments can harm our health, affecting everything from bone and brain function to hormones (read more about how microplastics affect our health). Although most plastic pollution originates on land, the ocean – including seagrass meadows – acts as a sink.
summary_src: Mediterranean seagrass balls, known as Neptune balls (Posidonia oceanica), are inadvertently cleaning up ocean microplastics, according to University of Barcelona researchers.  These naturally formed, compact bundles of seagrass effectively trap microplastics from the seafloor and then wash ashore, highlighting an unexpected role for this marine plant in mitigating plastic pollution. While the ocean acts as a sink for land-based plastic pollution, the discovery showcases the surprising ability of Posidonia oceanica to help remove microplastics – tiny particles harmful to both marine life and human health.
summary_tgt: बारसिलोना विश्वविद्यालय के शोधकर्ताओं के अनुसार, नेप्च्यून गेंदों (पोसिडोनिया ओशनिका) के रूप में जानी जाने वाली भूमध्यसागरीय समुद्री घास की गेंदें अनजाने में समुद्र के सूक्ष्म प्लास्टिक को साफ कर रही हैं।  ये प्राकृतिक रूप से बनी, संकुचित समुद्री घास के बंडल समुद्र तल से सूक्ष्म प्लास्टिक को प्रभावी ढंग से फँसाते हैं और फिर किनारे पर आ जाते हैं, जिससे इस समुद्री पौधे की प्लास्टिक प्रदूषण को कम करने में अप्रत्याशित भूमिका उजागर होती है। जबकि समुद्र भूमि पर आधारित प्लास्टिक प्रदूषण के लिए एक सिंक के रूप में कार्य करता है, इस खोज से पोसिडोनिया ओशनिका की सूक्ष्म प्लास्टिक - समुद्री जीवन और मानव स्वास्थ्य दोनों के लिए हानिकारक सूक्ष्म कणों को हटाने में आश्चर्यजनक क्षमता का प्रदर्शन होता है।
meta_description: As tiny pieces of plastic clog our oceans, natural meadows of seagrass are bundling up microplastics and spitting them back out onto beaches in the form of "Neptune balls".

summary_tgt: यह पाठ एक समाचार सारांश नहीं है; यह अस्वीकरणों और प्रचारात्मक जानकारी का एक संग्रह है। इसमें कोई समाचार सामग्री नहीं है जिसका सारांश दिया जा सके। इसमें समेरिटन्स (आत्महत्या रोकथाम दान) के संपर्क विवरण, बाहरी वेबसाइटों (सीएनएन और बीबीसी ओलंपिक कवरेज) के लिंक, और सोशल मीडिया खातों और बाहरी लिंक नीतियों के विवरण शामिल हैं।

title_src: Inside the hidden quarters of history's greatest seducer
text_src: The greatest lover of all time, Giacomo Casanova, is also one of the most misunderstood figures of the 18th century. Beyond his legendary romantic escapades, he was an alchemist, a spy (credited with coining the term "secret agent"), a diplomat, a musician, an actor, and above all, a brilliant writer.
summary_src: Giacomo Casanova, renowned as history's greatest lover, was far more than a romantic.  This 18th-century polymath, often considered one of the era's most influential figures, excelled as an alchemist, spy (credited with coining the term "secret agent"), diplomat, musician, actor, and, most notably, a prolific writer.  His legacy extends far beyond his legendary romantic life.
summary_tgt: इतिहास के सबसे महान प्रेमी के रूप में प्रसिद्ध जियाकोमो कैसानोवा केवल एक रोमांटिक से कहीं अधिक थे।  18वीं सदी के इस बहुमुखी प्रतिभाशाली व्यक्ति को, अक्सर उस युग के सबसे प्रभावशाली व्यक्तियों में से एक माना जाता था, उन्होंने एक रसायनज्ञ, जासूस (जिन्हें "गुप्त एजेंट" शब्द गढ़ने का श्रेय दिया जाता है), राजनयिक, संगीतकार, अभिनेता और सबसे उल्लेखनीय रूप से, एक कुशल लेखक के रूप में उत्कृष्ट प्रदर्शन किया। उनका वर्चस्व उनके प्रसिद्ध रोमांटिक जीवन से कहीं आगे तक फैला हुआ है।
meta_description: From an alchemical pharmacy to a shadowy dungeon, uncover the many secrets of Casanova's mysterious world.

title_src: Explore true Icelandic culture in the country's less-travelled north
text_src: This more remote part of Iceland offers visitors a deep dive into its fascinating history and authentic culture. Iceland wasn't always the blockbuster travel destination it is today; in the early 1990s, the country saw just a little more than 130,000 visitors a year. By 2023, however that number had surged to 2.21 million, far outpacing Iceland's tiny population of around 380,000. Experts chalk it up to a mix of savvy marketing, social media virality and sheer natural spectacle. The 2014 #MyStopover campaign turned layovers into week-long adventures, flooding Instagram with images of steaming hot springs, glacier lagoons and volcanic black-sand beaches. Soon, Iceland was no longer just a niche destination for intrepid explorers; it was on every traveller's bucket list. But with soaring popularity came new challenges, pushing the country to grapple with the pressures of overtourism. Most visitors touch down in the capital city of Reykjavik and make a beeline for the Blue Lagoon or the well-trodden Golden Circle. But as Iceland's tourism boom shows no signs of slowing, the country is looking for ways to ease the strain on its most popular spots. The conversation around overtourism has become impossible to ignore, and one solution is clear: encouraging travellers to venture beyond the usual highlights. The country's north, with its dramatic fjords and geothermal hotspots, offers a quieter yet equally spectacular alternative to the capital, with idyllic towns like Akureyri and Húsavík providing a gateway to breathtaking landscapes without the crowds. VIDEO: Click the play button above to watch "The whale watching capital of Europe" Húsavík is the country's oldest settlement as well as its whale capital. The small coastal town was once known for its whaling industry, and indeed Iceland is still one of only three countries that allows commercial whaling. However, many former whale hunting boats are now being converted to whale watching vessels in an effort to attract more visitors. "I've been told there's a 97% chance of seeing a whale on any trip you take here," said BBC Travel Show presenter Roma Wells. "Depending on what time of year you visit, you can see all sorts of different species." That's because a variety of whales, including humpbacks, orcas and minkes, migrate through this area. In addition, many whale-watching vessels use electric rather than diesel engines, creating a quieter, more relaxing experience for both passengers and sealife.
summary_src: Iceland's tourism boom, fueled by savvy marketing and social media, has transformed the nation from a niche destination to a global hotspot, attracting 2.21 million visitors in 2023—far surpassing its population of 380,000.  While this popularity benefits the economy, it has also led to overtourism, particularly in Reykjavik and popular sites like the Blue Lagoon and Golden Circle.  To alleviate this pressure, Iceland is promoting its less-visited regions, such as the north, highlighting towns like Akureyri and Húsavík.  Húsavík, Europe's whale watching capital, offers a sustainable alternative, transitioning from whaling to eco-friendly whale watching tours with a high sighting rate.  This shift aims to distribute tourism more evenly, preserving Iceland's natural beauty while benefiting local communities.
summary_tgt: आइसलैंड में पर्यटन उद्योग में जोरदार वृद्धि हुई है, जिसका कारण चतुर मार्केटिंग और सोशल मीडिया का प्रभाव है।  इससे यह देश एक विशिष्ट पर्यटन स्थल से बदलकर एक वैश्विक पसंदीदा बन गया है, और 2023 में यहाँ 22.1 लाख पर्यटक आए, जो इसकी 3.8 लाख की आबादी से कहीं अधिक है।  हालांकि इस लोकप्रियता से अर्थव्यवस्था को लाभ हुआ है, लेकिन इससे विशेष रूप से रेकजाविक और लोकप्रिय स्थलों जैसे ब्लू लैगून और गोल्डन सर्कल में पर्यटकों की अधिकता की समस्या भी उत्पन्न हुई है।  इस दबाव को कम करने के लिए, आइसलैंड अपने कम देखे जाने वाले क्षेत्रों, जैसे उत्तर, और शहरों जैसे अकुरेरी और हुसाविक का प्रचार कर रहा है। हुसाविक, यूरोप की व्हेल देखने की राजधानी, एक टिकाऊ विकल्प प्रदान करता है, जिसमें व्हेल शिकार से  पर्यावरण के अनुकूल व्हेल देखने के दौरे की ओर बदलाव किया गया है, जहाँ व्हेल देखने की दर बहुत अधिक है।  इस बदलाव का उद्देश्य पर्यटन को समान रूप से वितरित करना, आइसलैंड की प्राकृतिक सुंदरता को बनाए रखना और साथ ही स्थानीय समुदायों को लाभ पहुंचाना है।

title_src: Climate change pushing winemakers to blend different years
text_src: Climate change pushing winemakers to blend wines from different years 24 August 2025 Share Save Will Smale Business reporter, BBC News Share Save Cain Californian winery Cain makes a red wine that is a blend of two consecutive years In the world of wine vintage is king. If you are buying a bottle of red, white or rosé then the specific year of the grape harvest is almost always written on the label. By contrast, non-vintage still wine - that made by blending two or more years - is seen as very downmarket, something cheap and not cheerful. And it is significantly rarer. Yet with climate change hitting vineyards around the world with more extreme weather, a small but growing number of quality-conscious wineries are releasing non-vintage bottles so they can make a more consistent wine. Chris Howell is the winemaker at Cain Vineyard and Winery in California's celebrated Napa Valley region, 50 miles (80km) northeast of San Francisco. He has been in the job since 1991, and he says that summers have got noticeably hotter. "Weather is a complicated thing," he says. "The issue people are focused on most in Napa are dramatic heat spells, heat waves that generally come throughout the summer, particularly in late summer. "They have been around for as long as I have been here, but the peak temperatures of these are higher. The heat can be intense. You can get as high as 50C, something near to that." Meg Smith Winemaker Chris Howell says there is still a stigma attached to non-vintage still wine With the higher temperatures comes the increased risk of wildfires. That was the case back in 2017, when he says "tremendously intense fires" broke out in Napa in the middle of the grape harvest. That year Mr Howell decided to only use grapes from Cain's vineyards that had been harvested before the fires started, approximately half of the total, to prevent the risk of the smell - and taste - of smoke in the air from tainting the subsequent wines. He says he is more "relaxed" than many winemakers would be about such a catastrophe, because he has long made a non-vintage red blend called Cain Cuvée. "So some of the wine we were able to make in 2017 was held over to be blended with that from 2018." Mr Howell adds that "even without fires we are now subjected to more changeable vintages. So the odds are better if you use two different vintages to create the desired style for a particular wine." Getty Images The Napa Valley wine region was hit by wild fires in 2017 While the world's still wines remain mostly vintage, there is one type of wine where non-vintage blends actually dominate – sparkling wine. This is led by France's champagnes, where the vast majority of those produced have always been non-vintage. Historically this was a necessity, as Champagne is the most northern wine region in France, and good summers were rare. So champagne-makers had little choice but to blend wines from different years to create a consistent, quality product. Yet thanks to climate change bringing warmer summers to northern France, there is now more vintage champagne being produced than ever before. Italian winery owner Riccardo Pasqua says it was enjoying the very best non-vintage champagnes that inspired him to make Italy's first multi-year still white wine. Located north of the city of Verona, in the winemaking region of Veneto, his family-run business Pasqua Vigneti e Cantine has been producing the non-vintage wine since 2019, blending it from as many as five different years. He explains that the idea was to produce the best possible wine from a single vineyard, removing the reality of vintage weather variations, both good and bad. "I proposed it to my family and my board, and they told me 'you are crazy man, this is a big risk! You are going against the wine bible, the vintage is the vintage'," he says. "But I decided to stick to the plan, and we went forward. It is about getting the best expression of the vineyard. It is like a book, using more than one vintages gives the wine more chapters." Pasqua's Hey French is made from a blend of wines from five years The resulting wine is called Hey French, You Could Have Made This But You Didn't. The unusual name is a jokey nod to Italy's ongoing wine rivalry with France. With climate change now hitting Italy's winemakers with everything from more droughts to bigger hailstorms, Mr Pasqua says that other wineries are now going down the non-vintage route, or at least considering it. "I have to say in Italy already several wineries follow the idea. In Italy extreme weather events have gone from the extraordinary to the ordinary. "Such as frost in April or early May, or hailstorms become more and more usual. Or heat waves with very high temperatures now year after year."
summary_src: Climate change is forcing winemakers to reconsider traditional practices.  Rising temperatures and increasingly erratic weather, including wildfires and droughts, are impacting harvests globally.  This has led a small but growing number of high-quality wineries to embrace non-vintage wines – blends from multiple years – a practice historically considered low-end.  California's Cain Vineyard & Winery, for example, blends consecutive years to mitigate the effects of extreme heat and wildfires.  Similarly, Italian winemaker Riccardo Pasqua created Italy's first multi-year still white wine, inspired by the consistent quality of non-vintage Champagne.  While non-vintage blends have always been common in Champagne due to the region's historically unpredictable climate, the practice is now gaining traction among quality producers facing the intensified challenges of climate change, offering a way to maintain consistent taste and quality despite increasingly volatile growing seasons.
summary_tgt: जलवायु परिवर्तन के कारण वाइन निर्माताओं को पारंपरिक तरीकों पर पुनर्विचार करने के लिए मजबूर होना पड़ रहा है। बढ़ते तापमान और तेज़ी से अनियमित मौसम, जिसमें जंगल की आग और सूखा शामिल हैं, वैश्विक स्तर पर फसलों को प्रभावित कर रहे हैं।  इससे उच्च गुणवत्ता वाली कुछ वाइनरीज़ ने नॉन-विन्टेज वाइन - कई वर्षों के मिश्रण - को अपनाना शुरू कर दिया है, एक ऐसी प्रक्रिया जिसे ऐतिहासिक रूप से निम्न स्तर का माना जाता था। उदाहरण के लिए, कैलिफ़ोर्निया की कैन वाइनयार्ड एंड वाइनरी, अत्यधिक गर्मी और जंगल की आग के प्रभावों को कम करने के लिए लगातार वर्षों के मिश्रण का उपयोग करती है। इसी तरह, इतालवी वाइन निर्माता रिकार्डो पास्का ने शैंपेन की सुसंगत गुणवत्ता से प्रेरित होकर, इटली की पहली बहु-वर्षीय स्थिर सफ़ेद वाइन बनाई। जबकि शैंपेन क्षेत्र के ऐतिहासिक रूप से अप्रत्याशित जलवायु के कारण नॉन-विन्टेज मिश्रण हमेशा से आम रहे हैं, लेकिन जलवायु परिवर्तन की तीव्र चुनौतियों का सामना कर रहे गुणवत्ता उत्पादकों के बीच यह प्रक्रिया अब लोकप्रिय हो रही है, जो तेजी से अस्थिर बढ़ते मौसमों के बावजूद लगातार स्वाद और गुणवत्ता बनाए रखने का एक तरीका प्रदान करती है।
meta_description: Non-vintage still wine is now increasingly being made in response to more challenging weather.

title_src: The unexpected history of the British cup of tea
text_src: Legend has it that Catherine of Braganza brought tea to England back in the 1600s, giving life to one of the country's most iconic traditions. Today, Portugal is home to the only tea plantation in Europe, a century-old family business located in the heart of the Azores Islands.
summary_src: Portugal's Azores Islands boast Europe's only tea plantation, a century-old family business.  This contrasts sharply with the legend attributing the introduction of tea to England to Catherine of Braganza in the 17th century, highlighting a unique chapter in the history of this iconic beverage.
summary_tgt: पुर्तगाल के अज़ोर्स द्वीप समूह में यूरोप का एकमात्र चाय का बागान है, जो एक सौ साल पुराना पारिवारिक व्यवसाय है। यह 17वीं सदी में कैथरीन ऑफ़ ब्रगान्ज़ा द्वारा इंग्लैंड में चाय के आगमन की कथा के साथ स्पष्ट विपरीतता दर्शाता है, और इस प्रसिद्ध पेय के इतिहास में एक अनोखा अध्याय प्रकाशित करता है।

title_src: Meet WasteShark: The aquatic drone cleaning up waterways
text_src: Hundreds of millions of metric tonnes of plastic pollution are circulating in marine environments. It's a problem in canals, rivers, and oceans all around the world. Tech Now visits a startup in the Netherlands that has come up with a potential solution, an autonomous floating WasteShark.
summary_src: A Dutch startup is tackling the global problem of marine plastic pollution with an autonomous cleaning vessel called the WasteShark.  Millions of tonnes of plastic, a byproduct of paper and other products, clog waterways worldwide.  The WasteShark, currently in prototype phase, is designed to autonomously collect plastic debris from canals, rivers, and oceans, offering a potential solution to a centuries-old environmental crisis.
summary_tgt: एक डच स्टार्टअप, वेस्टशार्क नामक एक स्वायत्त सफाई पोत के साथ समुद्री प्लास्टिक प्रदूषण की वैश्विक समस्या से निपट रहा है।  लाखों टन प्लास्टिक, जो कागज और अन्य उत्पादों का उप-उत्पाद है, दुनिया भर के जलमार्गों को अवरुद्ध कर रहे हैं।  वेस्टशार्क, जो वर्तमान में प्रोटोटाइप चरण में है, को नहरों, नदियों और महासागरों से प्लास्टिक के मलबे को स्वचालित रूप से इकट्ठा करने के लिए डिज़ाइन किया गया है, जो सदियों पुरानी पर्यावरणीय संकट के लिए एक संभावित समाधान प्रदान करता है।
meta_description: Tech Now visits a startup tackling marine pollution with an autonomous robot that gobbles up waste.
